DOC.HEAD: Up With People Opens 25th Anniversary Celebration
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Margriet is cq in last graf
DOC.TEXT: Up With People celebrated its 25th anniversary Thursday with a parade of brightly colored flags and performers, and pledges the wholesome troubadors will continue to sing their upbeat songs for peace. About 5,000 people attended the opening ceremonies at the Colorado Convention Center to commemorate the founding of the group. Former astronaut Eugene Cernan, the last man to walk on the moon and a member of Up With People's board of directors, gave the opening remarks. ``We are here to celebrate not only the dream that has brought us together but you, the dream that has become Up With People,'' Cernan said. ``I haven't been this high since I've been on the moon.'' The event's honorary chairman, President Bush, sent a congratulatory message, as did Canadian Prime Minister Brian Mulroney, West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl and Pope John Paul II. J. Blanton Belk, a former Navy officer, started the multinational musical goodwill troupe in 1965 to promote an upbeat message of brotherhood at a time when much youthful energy in the United States went into civil rights marches and anti-war protests. People from 41 countries and every state are attending the anniversary celebration, which includes concerts and slide shows. More than 12,000 people have participated in yearlong stints singing with the Tucson, Ariz.-based nonprofit group. Belk, 65, told the group's alumni to keep spreading the ideals of the program in their daily lives. ``Give more than you think you can give without any fear, because you are the true spirit of hope,'' he said. Speakers at a forum Friday to discuss global concerns such as the environment and political cooperation will include Belgian Prime Minister Wilfried Martens, Dr. Shoichiro Toyoda, president of the Toyota Motor Company, and Mexico's Oscar-winning filmmaker Manuel Orango. Others attending include Princess Margriet of the Netherlands and Soviet journalist Vladimir Pozner.

DOC.HEAD: Researchers Identify Cause Of One Form Of Epilepsy
DOC.TEXT: A study of the body's energy-producing genes has led a researcher to identify the molecular defect causing a form of epilepsy. ``It's the first epilepsy that's ever been worked out at the molecular level,'' said Douglas Wallace of Emory University in Atlanta. He spoke Thursday at a geneticists' meeting at the Jackson Laboratory in Bar Harbor. In a separate study, Wallace reported that nearly all American Indians are descendants of a single small band of pioneers who walked across the Bering Strait from Asia 15,000 to 30,000 years ago. The form of epilepsy Wallace studied is called myoclonic epilepsy and ragged-red fiber disease. The discovery that it is related to a genetic defect in the body's energy-producing machines, called mitochondria, underscores the importance of these ``little fireplaces in the body,'' Wallace said. He was able to show that this disease, which can produce severe, handicapping muscle spasms, is an inherited illness. Its origin until now has been completely unknown, Wallace said. Although the discovery will not lead immediately to a new treatment, it is an important step toward that goal, he said. Preliminary success has been obtained in treating other mitochondrial diseases, he said. In his study of American Indians, Wallace showed that the descendants of the pioneers who crossed the Bering Strait make up 95 percent of American Indians, including the Mayans, Incas and many others current and former groups across the Americas. The exceptions are the Eskimos and Aleuts of the Arctic rim, the Navajos, Apaches and a few others who arrived later, said Wallace. ``It was clearly a small migration,'' Wallace said. He based his findings on studies of the genes related to the body's energy production, extracted from blood samples from members of three different Indian groups. The research on American Indians showed that the vast majority of American Indians descended from four women in that original migrating group. ``That's a striking finding,'' said Michael Silverstein, an anthropologist at the University of Chicago who studies American Indian languages. If the finding is confirmed, Silverstein said, it significantly extends the conclusions about Indian origins that can be made using language studies. In March, anthropologists met in Boulder, Colo., to debate a suggestion by Joseph Greenberg of Stanford University that most American Indian languages derived from one ancestral language. Other researchers have identified as many as 200 linguistic groups, said Greenberg. That would suggest there had been many separate migrations or that the migrations occurred so long ago that the original language had had time to split into many different forms. Wallace also is one of the leading authorities on mitochondrial genes, which are separate from the body's other genes and are passed on to children only by mothers, not by fathers. Wallace has linked them to several unusual inherited diseases. He has also suggested that the accumulation of defects in these genes during aging could be a cause of the body's normal degeneration, although that hypothesis remains to be examined, he said. ``As we age, our mitochondrial activity is declining,'' he said. Organs that depend heavily on energy _ such as the brain and the heart _ are among the organs that begin to fail in old age, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Maloney Closes Probe of Dinkins on Cable TV Stock Sale To Son
DOC.TEXT: A federal probe of Mayor David Dinkins' sale of stock to his son has ended without any charges being filed, the government announced Thursday. The stock transfer was brought to light last year during Democrat Dinkins' campaign against former Manhattan U.S. Attorney Rudolph Giuliani. Dinkins sold 588 shares of stock in Inner City Cable Broadcasting Co. to his son, David Jr., in October 1985 for $58,000. Three years earlier, he had listed its value at over $1 million on a financial disclosure form. U.S. Attorney Andrew Maloney in Brooklyn investigated the transfer of the stock, apparently to see whether it was authentic and whether the proper amount of taxes was paid on it. Maloney said the investigation ``has been completed without the filing of criminal charges.'' Dinkins said of Maloney's finding: ``His conclusion speaks for itself.'' Maloney said the results of the investigation have been sent to the city Department of Investigations at the department's request. The department is probing whether Dinkins properly filed city financial disclosure forms on the stock transfer. Also being investigated is whether he violated any conflict of interest laws by voting as Manhattan borough president in 1987 in favor of a zoning change for Inner City and in June 1989 concerning a transfer of a cable franchise to a related company. Of the city probe, Dinkins said, ``I look forward to a speedy resolution of the similar inquiry being conducted by the Department of Investigation.'' He added in a written statement, ``Until that time, I will have no further comment.''

DOC.HEAD: Five Bombs Explode In Capital; Caller Links Them To Cuban Anniversary
DOC.TEXT: At least five bombs exploded late Thursday, causing some damage and leaving two people slightly wounded, police and news reports said. A caller said the blasts were to mark the anniversary of Cuba's revolution. Two Citibank branches were among the targets of the bombings, which shattered windows but caused no extensive damage, police said. Other targets included a Chilean communications company and a private home apparently owned by a military officer, said police speaking on condition of anonymity. Government television reported receiving an anonymous phone call by a man claiming the bombings in the capital were intended to mark the 38th anniversary of the Cuban revolution led by Fidel Castro. Police officials were not available for comment on that report.

DOC.HEAD: Board of Inquiry to Investigate Negotiations at Daily News
DOC.TEXT: The state labor commissioner created a board of inquiry Thursday to investigate the tense contract negotiations at the Daily News. The action by Labor Commissioner Thomas F. Hartnett followed the certification by the chairman of the state Board of Mediation, Hezekiah Brown, that a panel was necessary to interpret the situation at the tabloid newspaper. A board of inquiry, under state labor law, has the power to compel both sides in a labor dispute to state their positions. While the state cannot force the settlement of a labor dispute, the board can make recommendations or can be a vehicle for a cooling-off period. ``We strongly feel that this step is an unnecessary intrusion by the government into a private sector matter,'' said John T. Sloan, the News' vice president for human resources. The News is owned by the Tribune Co. of Chicago. This is the first time since the labor commissioner was empowered to create such panels in 1941 that this step has been taken without a strike under way. Hartnett said the board of inquiry may be the only way to head off a strike. The 10 unions at the News, under the umbrella of the Allied Printing Trades Council, requested the board because they said they weren't getting a fair shake in the negotiations over contracts that expired March 30. Central to the offers the News has made have been changes in work rules that management says are necessary to make the paper profitable and enable it to invest in new plants and equipment. The unions have said the News is bent on provoking a strike and wants to shut down the paper or sell it at the expense of the workers, charges the paper denies. Sloan said the News would have to review its options, including a possible court challenge to the board.

DOC.HEAD: Montana Wins Top Fashion Award as Collections Close
LaserPhoto PAR14
DOC.TEXT: Designer Claude Montana of the Lanvin fashion house won the coveted Golden Thimble prize Thursday to wrap up five days of haute couture winter collection shows. Montana won the prize, the French capital's top fashion award, with 24 votes cast by a jury of journalists. Second place went to the Balmain house with nine votes. It made a sweet revenge for Montana, whose first couture show for Lanvin last winter was widely deemed a flop. But this time he was highly praised for a strongly-structured luxury collection. Shows at the opposite end of the spectrum by Hubert de Givenchy and Per Spook preceded the vote. Givenchy showed his talents as a master of opulent sophistication, while Spook took a light-hearted, more casual approach. Givenchy presented a big collection dedicated to the people behind the scenes, especially to his head couture assistant, Gilberte Thomassin. She has been with Givenchy since he left Balenciaga and founded his house about 30 years ago. The craftsmanship of true couture was evident in a collection of beautifully constructed suits, dresses and evening wear. The silhouette was firmly Givenchy, with wide shoulders over slim hips and skirts at wearable length, just above the knee. New details included rounded collars cut away to reveal little, ascot-like ties on superb silk blouses. As usual, Givenchy loved the look of suede, in shades like royal blue and brown. This time, he added fillips of python trim, a favorite with Yves Saint-Laurent as well. Woodchuck trim or white mink sleeves on a dressy black suit added surprisingly elegant touches to handsome day wear. Skirt suits in ``chine'' or flecked tweed were also big, but Givenchy also threw in straight, slim trousers and a few belted day dresses _ in fall shades of autumn-leaf yellow or red, spruce green and brick, plus a dash of powder blue, raspberry or plum. He didn't stint on his evening wear, featuring asymmetrical, shimmering lame cocktail dresses with lowered hems at the back to fabulous ball gowns. Here is where one can see the skill of backroom artisans, not only in seamless sewing, but in dazzling decor: the iridescent failles, endless patterns of pearls, jet beads, sparkling mirror sequins and other embroidery. Norwegian-born Per Spook went back to his roots for inspiration. He laid on a lively winter carnival full of Norwegian jacquard knits, mixed up in duffel coats, minis, leggings and boots, and even topping them with stocking caps right out of Santa's workshop. A few quilted jackets and crepe de chine gowns were amusingly printed with light-hearted Spook fashion sketches. While Spook didn't invest in many elaborate evening clothes, he did show one of the prettiest bridal gowns in town: a charming full-skirted taffeta confection sprigged with pink forget-me-nots worn by his newly-arrived Russian model, Masha Suvorova. Late Wednesday, Valentino put on a show of elaborate ensembles that got to be so pretty they nearly became too much of a good thing, like an overdose of chocolates. Valentino said he was inspired by artisans' work like prismatic crystal or the inlays of a fancy l8th-century cabinetmaker. The results were often stunning tours de force, as in the kaleidoscopic satin short evening gown in shades of sapphire, emerald and peacock blue. He showed a breathtaking long gown with a multicolored mosaic top over a maypole-ribbon basque waist flaring into a luminous cloud of chiffon in deep turquoise, green and siena.

DOC.HEAD: Names in the News
LaserPhoto NY14
DOC.TEXT: It may take a while to know if Bruce Springsteen's new son was ``Born to Run,'' but he certainly was ``Born in the U.S.A.'' Patti Scialfa, the rocker's girlfriend and a backup singer in his E Street Band, delivered the 7-pound, 9-ounce boy at a California hospital, Barry Slott, a lawyer for The Boss, said Thursday. The boy is Springsteen's first child. Slott said the child was born sometime since Tuesday, but he did not know the boy's name or the hospital. Springsteen, 40, and Scialfa, 38, were linked romantically after she joined his E Street Band as a backup singer in 1984. Like Springsteen, Scialfa is a New Jersey native. Springsteen married model-actress Julianne Phillips in 1985. They divorced in 1989.

Hard-hitting reporter Sarah McClendon, who has covered every president since Franklin Roosevelt, says she's not letting up now that she's turned 80. ``I'm not quitting because I have a lot of questions I want to ask George Bush,'' she said. The Tyler, Texas, native got congratulations from President Bush and a host of other Washington figures Thursday at a birthday party. In her nearly 50 years of reporting from Washington, Ms. McClendon has become well known for asking presidents tough questions. She said her favorite president was fellow Texan Lyndon Johnson, even though he once prodded four newspapers to cancel her service.

Director Francis Ford Coppola, working on ``The Godfather, Part III,'' also is apparently working his way out of his money problems. He agreed to settle a debt dispute with a developer and asked a judge to dismiss his personal bankruptcy case and the bankruptcy filing of one of his companies, the Los Angeles Times reported Thursday, citing court papers. As part of the settlement of an $8 million debt, Coppola, who hopes to complete ``The Godfather, Part III'' in time for Christmas release, is to make a payment in August to Canadian real estate magnate Jack Singer and more payments through 1992. Robert Chapman, Singer's lawyer, said aspects of the settlement are still being negotiated. In January, Coppola filed for protection from creditors for himself and his Zoetrope Productions.

For Matthew Broderick, working with Marlon Brando was the highlight of filming ``The Freshman.'' ``He's a role model for everybody in the business,'' Broderick said. ``No matter who they think is their role model, that person probably had Brando as a role model. All roads lead to Brando.'' Broderick, 28, stars in the film as a student who gets hustled out of his possessions as soon as he arrives in New York to attend film school. The chase for the thief leads to a meeting with Brando's character _ a shady guy who bears an uncanny resemblance to a certain Don Corleone of ``The Godfather.'' Broderick's credits include the hit ``Ferris Bueller's Day Off,'' ``WarGames'' and the Oscar-winning ``Glory.''

Entertainer Ben Vereen, who blamed the 1987 death of his daughter in an auto accident for pushing him into using drugs, admits now he had been a drug abuser since the 1960s. ``Sometimes what people really need is a good hug, so they know they are loved. We didn't understand love. Instead, we bought into drugs,'' Vereen said in this week's issue of Parade. Vereen said his drug use became worse after his daughter Naja was killed, but another daughter, Malaika, forced him to see what the drugs were doing to him, and he wound up in a treatment center.

Carlos Santana, the rock singer-guitarist known for the song ``Black Magic Woman,'' says a higher power is pointing him South. ``Lately, I've pretty much been getting a fax message from inside my soul that I should go South. The Lord has put my mind in places South _ South Africa, South America, the southern United States,'' he said. ``That's where people's hearts seem to be the hardest. The Lord wants me to take my message of peace and harmony there. I'm going where things most need to be plowed.'' During his 20-year career, he has recorded 26 albums and has had hit songs such as ``Evil Ways.'' His latest album, ``Spirits Dancing in the Flesh,'' contains references to spirituality and the emotions of love, joy and peace.

DOC.HEAD: Woman Apparently Gets AIDS From Infected Dentist, CDC Says
DOC.TEXT: The American Dental Association charged that a government report of a patient apparently contracting AIDS from her dentist was premature and could cause undue public alarm. The Centers for Disease Control reported Thursday that a young woman who went to have two molars pulled came away infected with the virus, the first time this is known to have happened in dental surgery. The CDC said that while the possibility of another source of infection could not be ruled out, all evidence was consistent with the patient being infected by her dentist. ``We think it is not a totally conclusive case of transmission,'' countered Dr. Enid Neidle, director of scientific affairs for the Chicago-based ADA. ``We are not happy at any report that could raise fears on the part of the public that the dental office is a place of danger and infection.'' The dentist had been diagnosed with AIDS three months earlier and was wearing protective gloves and a mask as recommended, the CDC said. ``We don't know exactly what happened during that procedure,'' said Harold Jaffe, deputy director for science in the CDC's AIDS program. ``We have to assume there was some kind of an accident that exposed the patient to the dentist's blood.'' There was no indication of such an accident, however. The patient didn't remember the dentist being cut, the dentist didn't recall any accidents _ such as sticking himself with the anesthetic needle _ and the procedure ``should have been uncomplicated,'' the CDC said. A long investigation found no risk factors for AIDS in the woman's past, such as intravenous drug abuse or numerous sex partners. She said she had two sex partners prior to her diagnosis; both tested negative for the AIDS virus. Furthermore, molecular tests on the dentist and patient led investigators to believe their viruses were closely related, the CDC said. The case has prompted the government to review its recommendations for AIDS prevention in medical settings. ``We will be looking at the guidelines to see if they need to be modified to decrease the chance this might happen again,'' Jaffe said. Paul Sathrum, program director for the National Association of People With AIDS, said he feared the report would prompt a new round of AIDS hysteria. ``Any little thing like this always brings it back to the surface,'' he said. The report came only two days after the CDC published a study in the Journal of the American Medical Association that said physicians with AIDS were unlikely to spread the disease to patients during surgery. That study, based on a survey of 2,160 patients of a Tennessee doctor with AIDS, found none of the patients whom Dr. Harold Dennison operated on between 1982 and his 1989 death were believed to have contracted the disease during surgery. An accompanying editorial by Dr. Frank Rhame of the University of Minnesota recommended AIDS-infected physicians be allowed to perform all kinds of operations except oral and pelvic surgery. In those types of surgery, doctors often can't see the spot where they are wielding sharp instruments with which they could cut themselves. CDC officials Thursday stressed there is no reason to believe the virus was transmitted just because a dentist with AIDS came close to a patient. ``And we're certainly not suggesting to people they should be afraid to go to their doctors and dentists,'' Jaffe said. The CDC, as is its policy, did not identify the dentist or the patient. It did not say when the infection occurred. Two years after her trip to the dentist, the woman was diagnosed with a rare pneumonia that strikes some AIDS patients. She then tested positive for the AIDS virus. Acquired immune deficiency syndrome damages the body's immune system. It is spread most often through sexual contact, needles or syringes shared by drug abusers, infected blood, and from pregnant women to their offspring.

DOC.HEAD: School Bans Teen-age Mutant Ninja Turtles
DOC.TEXT: A city school has declared Teen-age Mutant Ninja Turtles as mutants non grata, after kids fought on the playground as characters of the popular movie and cartoon series. The Beecroft Public School has banned the green beasts _ be they in the form of turtle toys, cards, or games _ from its premises. Parents have been told that all such items will be confiscated. ``The children have been fighting in the playground and picking up sticks to use,'' deputy principal Suzanne Ziems said Wednesday. ``When you ask them what they are doing, they say they are just doing Ninja Turtles.'' The TV show is popular in Australia and the movie opens in the country next week.

DOC.HEAD: Man Orders Sack of Sandwiches, Gets Cash Instead
DOC.TEXT: Henry Holcomb had a hankering for a ham sandwich, but his take-home meal turned out to be a bag of cash. Holcomb, 62, went to a delicatessen Wednesday night to pick up some ham sandwiches for himself and Mary Ann De Marco, a friend who had helped him move. Ms. De Marco said she was pouring a glass of milk in the kitchen when Holcomb opened the sack. ``He sat down to eat and it wasn't sandwiches at all _ it was full of money,'' she said. The clerk had inadvertently handed him a plastic bag with more than $200 in bills. ``Right away I called K mart. It was closing time. They had notified police the money was stolen,'' she said. ``He kept saying, `Oh, I've got to get that money back.''' The pair was greeted by police and the distressed clerk. Holcomb received a $10 gift certificate for his honesty, Ms. De Marco said _ and the ham sandwiches they had sought to begin with.

DOC.HEAD: Prisoner Gets Stuck in Tunnel, Frustrates Jail Break
DOC.TEXT: For one prisoner, freedom from jail was only inches away. Unfortunately, the inches were around his waist. Police said Jose Ribamar Mesquita de Melo and 18 fellow inmates recently dug a tunnel 10 inches wide under the wall of their jail cell in the 32nd precint station in Itaquera, a district on the outskirts of Sao Paulo. Thirteen prisoners wriggled through and fled. But Melo got stuck ``because his waist was a few inches wider than the hole,'' police inspector Jose Carlos Palacios said by phone. ``We were alerted by his cries for help,'' Palacios said. ``After a few minutes we managed to pull him out and locked him up in another cell.'' Four other prisoners waiting behind Melo never got a chance to escape, he said. After Melo's aborted escape attempt, his fellow inmates promptly nicknamed him ``the cork,'' Palacios said.

DOC.HEAD: Souter Shows Picture of Consistency _ Maybe Too Much
LaserPhoto WX8
DOC.TEXT: Judge David Souter is completing his first week as President Bush's Supreme Court nominee seemingly unawed by the crush of attention and with potential critics still looking for ammunition. Watching Souter court the senators whose votes will decide his confirmation, reporters have found a picture of consistency _ maybe too much consistency. ``If I could ask you a personal question... Someone pointed out that you seem to be wearing the same suit,'' one reporter asked. For that one, the quiet jurist made an exception to his no-comment policy. ``I came down on very short notice ... Frankly I had no expectation of staying for very long, so they're right, somebody's got good eyes. It's the same suit. ``I'll have a different suit soon,'' he promised. Souter is returning home to New Hampshire this weekend where, among other things, he'll renew his wardrobe.

For the most part, Souter has brushed aside both legal and personal questions. Was he troubled, one reporter asked, by suggestions ``that because you're a bachelor and unmarried ... that this calls into question whether you understand the family problems of America?'' ``Well, I think by the time I'm through answering the appropriate Senate questions, any concerns about that I hope will be allayed,'' he responded. Then, asked simply to describe himself, he said, ``modesty forbids.'' Sen. Warren Rudman, R-N.H., Souter's longtime friend, told reporters he objected to anyone trying to insinuate something scandalous into the fact that the judge was 50 years old and never married. ``I think it's offensive,'' said Rudman, whose personality is the opposite of his reserved protege. ``He is a perfectly normal man of the age of 50.''

Souter impressed senator after senator as a scholarly man, and apparently scored points in his closed-door meetings by letting the lawmakers do what they love to do _ talk. Sen. Arlen Specter, R-Pa., a Judiciary Committee member, listed at length and in flowery legal terms the topics covered in his conversations with Souter. ``He made a very good impression on me,'' Specter said. But how did he do that? Did he express his views on the issues of the day, such as abortion and civil rights rulings? ``He did not. I did not press it. He did not volunteer it,'' Specter said. Sen. Patrick Leahy, D-Vt., exchanged good-humored barbs with the judge about their neighboring states before shooing reporters from the room. Leahy said afterward he told the judge he'd be reading all his decisions before the hearings begin in September. ``He said, `Then you'll probably sleep well in the month of August,''' Leahy said. Sen. Orrin Hatch of Utah, a senior member of the committee, said, ``It's very important for senators to like the nominee.'' ``If they do, they have a much greater tendency to support the nominee. And he is very likeable, very unassuming, yet very bright, and he listens very carefully,'' Hatch said. ``I'd be surprised if he has any difficulty'' being confirmed, he said.

Liberals and conservatives have been working overtime to try to define the somewhat enigmatic Souter. One thing he apparently is not, is a news hound. Specter told reporters the judge was unaware on Thursday of news stories that morning on a letter he had written about a New Hampshire bill requiring parental notification for abortions on minors. Specter said he made him a copy. But Souter also is no political naif. When he first entered Specter's office with a crush of television cameras at his heels, Specter remarked that he hadn't had so many since Robert Bork, President Reagan's nominee later defeated, visited a few years ago. ``Can't you find another precedent,'' Souter begged. ``Since Sandra Day O'Connor,'' Specter revised.

DOC.HEAD: Castro: Bush Has `Sick Obsession' with Cuba, Wryly Speaks Of Boatlift
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 5 grafs to ADD Castro quote. Pickup 5th graf `Despite deepening...'
DOC.TEXT: President Fidel Castro told a huge rally Thursday night that President Bush has a ``sick obsession'' with trying to topple his communist government. ``Neither asleep nor awake can Bush forget about Cuba,'' Castro told hundreds of thousands of people massed in Revolutionary Plaza to mark the 37th anniversary of the birth of his movement that took power in 1959. Smiling, he invited Americans to send boats to pick up Cubans wishing to leave the country. His comment came after dozens of Cubans sought asylum in foreign embassies in recent weeks. ``If the Yankees decide that they want to receive these poor, persecuted citizens, let them send the boats and the visas,' he said with sarcastic intonation. It was not clear whether Castro was suggesting a renewal of the Mariel boatlift. Under that operation, 125,000 Cubans went to Florida during a five-month period in 1980. Despite deepening economic problems and growing international isolation, Castro was on the offensive for most of his two-hour, 45-minute speech. Cuban flags adorned buildings and citizens were urged by state media to attend the event, and the anniversary is a national holiday. Castro escalated a dispute with Spain. He renounced a $2.5 million economic cooperation program that Spanish authorities suspended last week in a conflict with Cuba over 18 asylum-seekers at the Spanish Embassy in this capital. The Cuban president invited Spain and the European Community to open an office in Havana to process applications for Cubans who wish to emigrate. Embassies, he said, should not be used as ``travel agencies.'' Spain has refused to expel the Cubans. Cuba says they should not have been given refuge because they are not being sought by Cuban authorities. The incident has produced harsh public exchanges between the two countries. The Cuban president blamed the embassy crisis here on the United States, according to official news agency reports monitored in Mexico City. Dozens of Cubans have sought asylum in various foreign missions recently. Castro said no Cuban who enters an embassy by force will be be granted permission to leave the country, the official Cuban news agency Prensa Latina reported Thursday. In charging Bush with having a ``sick obsession'' about Cuba, Castro cited what he said were a number of ``hostile acts'' by the United States against Cuba. He said the campaign included the initiation of Voice of America television broadcasts to Cuba and threatening military manuevers. Castro also criticized Bush for asserting at the Houston summit this month that the United States would withhold aid to the Soviet Union until Kremlin economic and military aid to Cuba is cut off. Citing the recent testimony of a Cuban dissident, Castro accused the United States of instigating the wave of embassy break-ins by asylum-seekers on July 9. The allegations were first aired a week ago and drew a flat denial from the U.S. diplomatic mission here. An official statement issued Tuesday said, ``No U.S. official has ever encouraged or ever talked about Cubans taking asylum in foreign embassies.'' Late Thursday in Washington, the State Department had no official reaction to Castro's remarks, saying there likely would be a response Friday after the speech is analyzed. Castro said the United States was also to blame for the situation at the embassies because it has not fulfilled a 1984 agreement designed to facilitate Cuban emigration to the United States. U.S. officials here said that 10,000 visa applications from Cubans had been processed since early 1988. It denied Cuban charges that the United States has not fulfilled the agreement. Castro offered a day-by-day account of the asylum issue. Some observers have speculated that hordes of Cubans might seek shelter in embassies, possibly destabilizing the regime, which took power in 1959. But the situation in the embassies appears to have stabilized in recent days. There are 18 Cubans being sheltered in the Spanish Embassy and four at the Italian ambassador's residence. Three Cubans who entered the Swiss embassy last weekend departed voluntarily on Wednesday. Castro normally makes his July 26 address in a provincial capital but decided this year to speak in Havana. The event marks the day in 1953 when Castro led an attack on a military barracks in eastern Cuba. Earlier Thursday, the State Department in Washington issued this statement on the anniversary: ``Tragically, the revolution's promises with Castro's assumption of power in 1959 were betrayed. There is little or no freedom of expression in Cuba. ``The regime has just announced that it will no longer permit the International Committee of the Red Cross to visit Cuban prisoners. Three decades after the revolution, the Cuban people are paying a high price for Castro's devotion to the discredited Marxist model.'' Compared with the anniversary a year ago, the mood in this Caribbean island nation of about 10.5 million people off Florida now is far more uncertain. Collapse of the friendly governments in Eastern Europe has brought an end to the socialist bloc. Grave uncertainty also has arisen about future economic ties with the Soviet Union, Cuba's chief benefactor. Castro has warned his countrymen that harsh austerity measures will have to be imposed if the Soviets stop sending 13 million tons of oil a year to Cuba. Another concern is growing food scarcities. Many Cubans say they can't recall when food supplies have been more meager. For all his problems, Castro's rule still is without serious challenge. He continues to have a strong base of support and representatives of the small dissident community here are either in prison or have been cowed into silence.

DOC.HEAD: Singer's Fear Of Flying Delays Tour Dates
DOC.TEXT: Pop singer Cher says she developed a temporary fear of flying that has caused delays on her current concert tour. It all started when her regularly scheduled USAir plane was forced to return to New Jersey after a faulty indicator showed an overheated engine. The incident prompted her on Thursday to travel by train and bus to Canada's Atlantic region. ``It's just for a day,'' Cher said in a telephone interview from New York. ``I just didn't want to get back on the same exact airplane and the same exact flight.'' She said the aborted flight gave her nightmares. ``I think I feel pretty good, even though I had terrible dreams all night. It was nerve-wracking,'' she said. Her sold-out concert originally scheduled for Wednesday night in Halifax was delayed a day. Thursday's planned show in Moncton, New Brunswick, was moved to Saturday night, and a Saturday concert at Old Orchard Beach, Maine, has been moved to Sunday. Fans who can't make the rescheduled concerts will get their money back.

DOC.HEAD: Justice Department Says Northrop Should be Barred From Building Weapons
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Embargo has been broken; Lead prospects uncertain
DOC.TEXT: The Justice Department is recommending that the Northrop Corp. _ which has pleaded guilty to fraud charges _ be barred by the Air Force from building weapons for the nation's military, agency documents say. In a series of memorandums from March to June of this year, the department sharply criticized the maker of the B-2 bomber and parts for the MX nuclear missile for failing to conduct critical tests on nuclear weapons systems. ``If any case cries out for debarment, this is the case,'' said a March 13 memo from the U.S. attorney's office in Los Angeles to O. Kevin Vincent in the Air Force's general counsel office at the Pentagon. ``If ever the American people deserve to be protected from the type of reckless and potentially life-threatening conduct, this is it,'' the memo said. The House Energy and Commerce subcommittee on oversight and investigations today planned to question Pentagon acquisition czar John Betti, Justice Department witnesses and a former Northrop auditor as part of its broader examination of the company. Northrop pleaded guilty in February to 34 fraud charges and agreed to pay $17 million in fines, the largest criminal fine ever imposed on a defense contractor. In a copy of testimony obtained by The Associated Press on Thursday, a Justice Department official said Northrop pressured the Navy and Air Force to change contract specifications in a way that seriously damaged a fraud investigation of the company. The deputy assistant attorney general in charge of the criminal division, Mark M. Richard, was expected to detail the department's inquiry of Northrop that led to the company's guilty plea. In other documents, the government reacted angrily to the manufacturer's actions following its February plea. In an April 2 memo, U.S. Attorney Robert Brosio and assistant U.S. Attorney William F. Fahey noted ``little, if any, remorse or willingness by Northrop to admit that it has had any serious problems with its management or critical weapons systems.'' On April 26, the government wrote that Northrop ``appears to warrant debarment because it fails to recognize or admit its fault, it is being investigated for the same type of serious misconduct in other production divisions and there is no reason to believe this illegal conduct will not continue in the future.'' The hearing comes one week after the chairman of the House panel, Rep. John Dingell, D-Mich., released portions of a Justice Department memorandum that said the agency was unable to pursue a fraud claim against Northrop because the government had known the company submitted false information. The memo said Northrop, which is located in California, submitted inaccurate cost and scheduling data to the Air Force on the program to build the stealth aircraft. Richard, in his Justice Department testimony, said, ``Successful attempts by Northrop to modify contract requirements during the investigation which Northrop knew were the subject of our investigation were highly damaging to our ability to prosecute.'' ``Northrop's efforts continued after it was indicted,'' Richard said. The inquiry into practices at Northrop began in early 1987 when a test technician working on nuclear, air-launched cruise missiles and the Marine Corps' Harrier AV-8B jet project told the Air Force that Northrop was cheating on critical tests, according to the testimony. After accumulating documents and other evidence, the Air Force brought the case to the U.S. attorney in Los Angeles. The subsequent inquiry by the Justice Department found that ``hundreds of guidance units for the cruise missile had improper testing and that Northrop had generated hundreds of false reports.'' ``Similarly, on the much smaller Harrier jet program, dozens of units had been improperly tested and the results covered up by Northrop employees.'' The U.S. attorney obtained the first indictment in April 1989. Part of the charges against the company centered on evidence that Northrop knew since at least 1983 that it was using the wrong fluid in the cruise missile's gyroscopes. ``Northrop confirmed these conclusions in 1982, 1983 and 1987, but never once disclosed the findings to the Air Force or to Boeing, the prime contractor,'' the Justice Department said in its testimony. In 1988, Northrop sought waivers on an Air Force and Navy requirement that the equipment be able to function at minus-65 degrees Fahrenheit. The company managed to persuade the Navy to change its contract to minus-40 degrees by threatening to hold up delivery on parts for the AV-8B. ``The Navy agreed to this change without demanding any consideration and without notifying our investigators,'' the department said. A Northrop spokesman in Los Angeles, Tony Cantafio, said of the department's temperature accusations, ``They dismissed the charges inside the courtroom, and now they're trying to put us on trial outside the courtroom.''

DOC.HEAD: Hasenfus Recounts Downing of Contra Supply Plane
DOC.TEXT: Attorneys for a retired general and a CIA-linked air company sought to undermine the credibility of a Contra supply plane crewman who has sued them over the 1986 crash that helped unravel the Iran-Contra affair. Eugene Hasenfus, who kicked bales out of planes in the clandestine Contra supply effort, testified Thursday in a federal lawsuit he filed along with the family of co-pilot Wallace Sawyer Jr., who was killed in the Sandinista rocket attack on the Contra supply plane in Nicaragua. Hasenfus alleges that Richard Secord, a retired Air Force major general, and Miami-based Southern Air Transport misled the crew and failed to supply adequate safety equipment. Hasenfus, 49, also claimed he was abandoned after the Oct. 5, 1986 crash, which he survived only to be captured and tried subsequently by Nicaragua's former Sandinista government. Under questioning from Secord's attorney, Thomas Spencer, Hasenfus admitted he had received some money after the crash _ $6,000 in a brown bag given to his wife by a man who said: ``This is from the boys.'' Hasenfus testified he had joined the Contra supply effort out of patriotism, thinking he was working for Southern Air on behalf of the U.S. government fighting Communism in Central America. Hasenfus was sentenced to 30 years in prison by the Sandinistas, but they released him after three months in a humanitarian gesture. Southern Air attorney Robert Beckman emphasized that Hasenfus was an independent contractor, not an employee, and that either he or the company could have terminated the arrangement at any time. ``I stopped the day I was shot down,'' Hasenfus responded. ``I don't believe I terminated myself.'' Beckman forced Hasenfus to show that his pay drafts, tax returns and even unemployment compensation claim all reflected the name of Corporate Air Services, not Southern Air. Hasenfus has called Corporate Air Services a ``front'' for Southern Air. Beckman also sought to show Hasenfus had violated a secrecy agreement he signed by selling his story to CBS for $10,000. Hasenfus said all secrecy ``was already blown by Congress'' when he sold his story, which has not yet been made public. Hasenfus' attorneys say they are still calculating damages, including expenses caused by the crash and lost income, along with emotional distress. On Wednesday they submitted preliminary figures showing actual damages of about $2.4 million for Sawyer's family and about $1 million for Hasenfus. Hasenfus, now a construction worker in Marinette, Wis., and a veteran of CIA-owned Air America flights during the Vietnam War, said he joined the Contra supply operation in July 1986. The shooting down of his C-123 and the revelation the following month of U.S. arms sales to Iran led to the Iran-Contra affair, in which a network of private and public figures were revealed to have transferred cash from the arms sales and other sources to illegally aid the Contras. Secord pleaded guilty Nov. 8, 1989, to lying to congressional investigators when he said he wasn't aware of any money that went to North's benefit from the maze of companies he used in the Iran-Contra affair. Secord was sentenced to two years probation.

DOC.HEAD: `City of Truth' Encampment Shows Break With Past
DOC.TEXT: In the shadow of a mausoleum that until recently housed the body of Communist Bulgaria's founder, pro-democracy protesters have erected a tent city to press for a quicker break with the Stalinist past. While the mausoleum still stands, the embalmed body of Georgi Dimitrov was whisked away one night for cremation and burial in a cemetery. The soldiers who served as honor guards outside the former shrine have been replaced by the mushrooming tent city of anti-government protesters, a gathering unthinkable even a year ago. At least 270 people are living in more than 100 tents. They range from young to old, but most are under 40. For residents of the self-proclaimed ``City of Truth,'' democracy has not made nearly enough inroads in the small Balkan country, now deeply polarized by the victory of the Socialist Party _ the former Communists _ in June's free elections. The elections followed the ouster last November of hard-line leader Todor Zhivkov. While many Bulgarians have fled the sweltering metropolis for the Black Sea coast or the cool mountains, tent city residents seem determined to spend the summer camped out in Sofia. They have pledged to leave only when those they see as perpetrators of communist sins are brought to account. The protesters get water from a faucet in a yard nearby and carry buckets back to the tents. Food is brought by relatives or friends or purchased by the campers in nearby shops. Visitors from rural Bulgaria gaze in wonder at the encampment around the once-hallowed mausoleum and the nearby Socialist Party headquarters. For them, it is hard to believe that icons revered for 45 years could fall _ at least so fast. A symbolic pile of trash is the ultimate insult to the old system: Hundreds of old Communist publications, speeches and rule books are strewn around an old car plastered with defaced portraits of Stalin, Lenin and other former official heroes. Bolstered by their success in securing the resignation of President Petar Mladenov earlier this month, the campers showed little concern on Monday when the government told local authorities to halt ethnic and political unrest. ``What's to fear?'' asked Evgeni Genchev, a 32-year-old Sofia doctor. ``I don't think anything really dangerous can happen to us, but I think something really dangerous can happen to them. You know what happened in Romania. He was referring to Western criticism and a halt in aid after Romania cracked down on anti-government protesters in June. Bulgaria's leaders ``really need Western economic help. We don't want this help to be given to this kind of government; they are lying all the time,'' Genchev said. Discontent with Bulgaria's government _ and with political opposition groups _ is simmering. Sofia residents daily deplore the parliamentary stalemate and procedural haggling that so far have blocked the election of anyone to replace Mladenov as president. He resigned July 6 over a controversy about using force against anti-government protests. A new government cannot be formed until a president is chosen, and Bulgarians and Western diplomats fear lawmakers are courting danger by failing to agree on leaders to fight a worsening economic crisis. Bulgaria has stopped paying capital and interest on its foreign debt of nearly $11 billion. Any exportable item is being sent abroad, resulting in growing food shortages. Prices are expected to rise soon in an attempt to fill state coffers. On Tuesday, hundreds of jeering demonstrators and dozens of honking cars blocked traffic outside the Socialist Party headquarters in support of a trade union threat to stage a general strike if the economic crisis is not tackled soon. Bulgarian nationalists, meanwhile, have shut down services in areas of the country heavily populated by members of the 1 million-member ethnic Turkish minority. The nationalists are angry that ethnic Turks, who suffered a brutal assimilation campaign under former Communist leader Zhivkov, were allowed to win representation in parliament, where their movement is the third-strongest faction. The ``City of Truth'' provides citizens not only with instruction in the relatively new art of peaceful protest, but with comic relief. One day this week, two people donned masks of Zhivkov and current Socialist Party leader Alexander Lilov and clowned around embracing, mocking Lilov's renunciation of Zhivkov's 35-year rule. A sign on a nearby tent taunted British publisher Robert Maxwell, who recently has purchased a soccer team, a large share in a printing house and other concerns in Bulgaria. ``Mr. Maxwell, are you going to buy us?'' the sign said.

DOC.HEAD: Apologetic Frank Says Violation Was `Unintentional'
LaserPhoto WX7
DOC.TEXT: An apologetic Rep. Barney Frank, reprimanded by the House, says his worst ethics offense was unintentional and stemmed from his desire to ``conceal my homosexuality'' during his relationship with a male prostitute. The House voted 408-18 to reprimand Frank on Thursday, rejecting conservative Republican efforts to censure or expel him. But the ethics committee report mentions no link between Frank's then-unknown homosexuality and a misleading memo he wrote in 1986 to help prostitute Stephen L. Gobie, who then was on probation for sex and drug convictions. And Rep. Julian Dixon, D-Calif., chairman of the ethics committee, said that Frank's concern over revealing his sexual preference ``does not, however, justify his making misleading statements.'' Frank paid Gobie $80 for sex in 1985 then hired him as a personal assistant with his own money. Gobie's allegations touched off the ethics investigation last September. The House, after three hours of sometimes heated floor debate, accepted the ethics committee's recommendation that Frank be reprimanded _ the mildest punishment available. The charges centered on the memo and on 33 parking tickets, some of them accumulated by Gobie, that Frank had fixed. By wide margins, the House rejected Republican proposals to censure or expel the five-term liberal Democrat from Massachusetts. Frank, 50, said he hopes he can put the ethics controversy behind him and looks forward to wading back into legislative issues next week. ``This is a part of my life,'' Frank told reporters. ``It's a part of which I am not particularly proud.'' Speaking slowly but with little visible emotion from the well of the House, Frank told his colleagues that he accepted the committee report and took full responsibility for his actions. ``I am here to apologize to my colleagues, to this institution, to those around me,'' Frank said. Frank watched much of the debate flanked by fellow members of the Massachusetts congressional delegation. Many colleagues approached him to shake hands or pat him on the shoulder. But few rose to defend him during the debate. Frank said the April 16, 1986, memo was ``obviously'' the more serious of the two offenses cited by the ethics committee. He said he wrote it for Gobie after the prostitute asked for Frank's help in blocking extension of Gobie's probation on drug and sex convictions. ``I did in that memorandum misrepresent the facts because ... it was necessary to conceal my homosexuality,'' he said. It was a year later, in June 1987, that Frank first stated publicly that he is gay. Under his congressional letterhead, Frank wrote a one-page document saying he met Gobie through mutual friends and asserting that Gobie was obeying the law. The committee said both those statements were false. Frank passed the memo on to a friend identified only as a Virginia attorney. Unknown to Frank, the attorney sent the memo to a prosecutor overseeing Gobie's probation. ``It was just a sloppy thing,'' Frank said at a news conference later Thursday. A reprimand was the appropriate punishment, Frank said, ``because of the unintentional nature of the transgression.'' But Dixon said, ``The fact does remain that the congressman prepared a document with statements that he knew to be misleading. These acknowledged misleading statements could be perceived as an attempt to apply political influence affecting the administration of Mr. Gobie's probation.'' ``Yes, the committee took into consideration Frank's explanation that, in large part, these misleading statements were derived from his desire to maintain confidentiality of his private activities,'' Dixon continued. The session opened with conservative Republican Rep. William Dannemeyer of California proposing that Frank be expelled. Dannemeyer challenged the ethics committee's conclusion that Frank was unaware Gobie was running a prostitution ring out of the congressman's Capitol Hill apartment. But Dixon rose and called Dannemeyer's statements ``garbage,'' and the House voted down the expulsion proposal 390-38. House GOP Whip Newt Gingrich of Georgia then proposed censure, a punishment that would have stripped Frank of a judiciary subcommittee chairmanship. But ethics committee members of both parties said censure was excessive and urged the House not to politicize the debate. The House rejected the censure proposal 287-141.

DOC.HEAD: Texas Tops States in Carbon Dioxide Emissions
With PM-States-Greenhouse List
DOC.TEXT: If Texas were a country, it would rank ahead of such industrial nations as Britain, France and Italy as a source of carbon dioxide emissions, an environmental group says. The Natural Resources Defense Council reported Thursday that several states are among the world's top producers of the gases blamed for the ``greenhouse effect'' said to be warming the entire planet. This means state governments can make a major contribution to fighting global warming, it said. The 10 states with the highest emissions account for half the total carbon dioxide put into the air in the United States, the NRDC study said. Those states together would rank third in the world as a source of carbon dioxide. Texas alone would rank seventh, behind the United States, the Soviet Union, China, Japan, West Germany and India. A buildup of carbon dioxide in the atmosphere is one of the chief reasons scientists expect global temperatures to increase in coming decades with possibly disastrous consequences. The NRDC, a public interest environmental organization, said its study, ``The Statehouse Effect: State Policies to Cool the Greenhouse,'' was timed to influence the annual meeting of the National Governors' Association next week in Mobile, Ala. Ideas for fighting global warming are on the agenda. Daniel A. Lashof, senior project scientist at the council, recalled at a news conference that President Bush promised during his 1988 campaign to counter the greenhouse effect with a ``White House effect.'' ``So far, all we've gotten is the whitewash effect,'' Lashof said. But he said state governments can step in to take the lead. Environmentalists say the Bush administration is blocking international efforts to force cuts in emissions of carbon dioxide and other gases blamed for global warming, while calling for further study. Other industrial countries, such as West Germany, Canada, Britain and France, have pledged to stabilize or reduce carbon dioxide emissions and have pressured the United States to take similar actions. ``The principal finding of our report is that states are big players when it comes to global warming,'' Lashof said. The study recommends that state governments promote energy efficiency with tough building codes and appliance standards, call a moratorium on investing in new coal-fired power plants, encourage utilities to invest in energy efficiency, reduce harvesting of state forests and plant more trees. ``The good news is that states can do a heck of a lot in reducing their carbon dioxide emissions,'' said Robert Watson, an expert on energy efficiency at the NRDC. Energy-saving policies, he said, generally are cheaper than building new power plants and create more jobs within the state. The study, based on 1988 figures, put Texas at the top of the state-by-state list in carbon dioxide emissions with 553 million metric tons, well ahead of California's 310 million metric tons. Texas put out more carbon dioxide than Britain, Italy or Canada, while California ranked ahead of France and Mexico. The rest of the top 10 emitting states were Pennsylvania, Ohio, Indiana, Illinois, Louisiana, New York, Michigan and Florida. Watson said California, New York and Florida, although they rank in the top 10 because of their large populations, were leaders in promoting energy efficiency and scored well on per capita emissions. ``Texas is a hopeless cause,'' Watson said. ``There's something of a frontier mentality. People are very resistant to adopting energy standards because they don't like to be told what to do. They don't want to do it, they're not going to do it, even though it's probably costing their citizens billions of dollars and thousands of jobs.'' Texas was eighth-highest in per capita carbon dioxide emissions, as well as highest in total emissions. Per capita emissions were highest in Wyoming, but Watson said the result could be misleading. ``Wyoming has a very small population and it has a coal production industry and some coal-fired power plants whose electricity is probably consumed out of state. Wyoming is something of an anomaly,'' he said. ``It may also be inefficient, but it's hard to tell.'' For its study, the NRDC analyzed national carbon dioxide data from the Oak Ridge (Tenn.) National Laboratory, and calculated state-by-state figures based on energy consumption data from the U.S. Department of Energy. Emissions from power production for electricity consumed in other states are included in the exporting state's figures, rather than that of the importing state.

DOC.HEAD: Stocks Close Lower
DOC.TEXT: The Nikkei Stock Average closed at 30,863.48, down 506.27 points, or 1.61 percent on the Tokyo Stock Exchange Friday.

DOC.HEAD: Eight Dead in Fiery Accident
DOC.NOTE: Eds: NEW throughout with 8 dead; no pickup
DOC.TEXT: A big-rig truck loaded with a cargo of automobiles crashed into cars driving slowly through an interstate highway construction site Thursday in a fiery wreck that killed eight people, authorities said. The carrier, hauling eight vehicles, came around a curve on Interstate 79 near this central West Virginia town, roared past the road crew flagman, bounced off the side of the bridge and caromed into the cars, police and firefighters said. The driver of the car-carrier and the highway workers escaped injury. Six bodies were found in the wreckage immediately, said state police Sgt. Doug Bryant, the investigating officer, and Braxton County Prosecutor Bill Martin. Two more bodies were found early Friday, said R.S. Faber, a state police spokesman. ``There were five in one car and three in another,'' Faber said. Truck driver Manuel Cruzado Jr., 25, of Buffalo, N.Y., initially was charged with six counts of negligent homicide, Martin said. Braxton County Jail officials said no additional charges had been filed against Cruzado early Friday. One of the cars in which people died was pinned between the carrier and an asphalt truck and burst into flames, said Rob Brady of the Gassaway Volunteer Fire Department. One of the vehicles atop the carrier flew off and landed on another stopped car, which also exploded in flames, Brady said. Fire also destroyed the carrier, the other seven cars on it, the asphalt truck and another highway construction truck.

DOC.BYLINE: CNBC's New President Wants Service to Go Global ^By JAY SHARBUTT
DOC.TEXT: The new head of NBC's Consumer News and Business Channel said he homes to expand the network overseas _ and into Manhattan, where its main competitor has been established for years. But CNBC has no plans become a general-news rival to Ted Turner's 24-hour Cable News Network, said Alfred Barber. On Thursday he was named president of the CNBC cable service that began operations in April last year. ``There's plenty of room in the marketplace for both of us. We're very different services,'' he said. Barber succeeded Michael Eskridge at the Ft. Lee, N.J.-based company. Eskridge is leaving to form a broadcast management company. Barber, 44, has been NBC's executive vice president and chief financial officer since 1987. Before that, he served in various management experience at General Electric Co., which bought NBC in 1986. CNBC, co-owned by Cablevision Systems Corp., says it now is seen in 16.8 million homes and offices. That is about half the number served by its older rival, New York-based Financial News Network. FNN is carried by cable in Manhattan. CNBC isn't, and thus isn't seen by the influential Wall Street and advertising communities. Barber said he'll work hard to get CNBC on cable in New York. Another priority is having it seen around the world, mainly in hotels and financial centers, he said. The company, begun with reported start-up costs of $65 million, still is running in the red. It hopes to turn a profit in its fourth year, when it expects to have 30 million U.S. subscribers.

DOC.HEAD: Bill Would Elevate Religious Freedom
DOC.TEXT: A bill with strong support from groups often in disagreement would negate the impact of a Supreme Court decision that sponsors say undermines religious freedom. The bill would restore a requirement that only a ``compelling state interest'' could be used to deny a religious practice, rather than simply the fact that the practice violates another law. On Thursday, Rep. Stephen J. Solarz, D-N.Y., introduced legislation that would prohibit government from taking any action that impedes religious freedom unless it could be justified for the protection of society. Senate Judiciary Committee Chairman Joseph R. Biden Jr., D-Del., plans to introduce similar legislation next week, said spokesman Ken Drexler. Supporters of the bill say the Supreme Court, in a decision April 17, put the First Amendment's guarantee of religious freedom in last place by saying any general law takes precedence. The justices, voting 6-3, said Oregon officials may deny employment benefits to two drug counselors who were fired for using peyote, a hallucinogenic drug derived from cactus plants, in an American Indian religious ceremony. Writing for the majority, Justice Antonin Scalia said an individual's religious beliefs ``do not excuse him from compliance with an otherwise valid law.'' ``With the stroke of a pen, the Supreme Court virtually removed religious freedom _ our first freedom _ from the Bill of Rights,'' Solarz said in announcing the bill. The House bill has 32 cosponsors who run the political gamut, Solarz said. Joining him in active support of the bill are Reps. Don Edwards, D-Calif., chairman of the Judiciary subcommittee on civil and constitutional rights; F. James Sensenbrenner Jr., R-Wis., the ranking minority member of the subcommittee, and Paul Henry, R-Mich. The four sent a letter to colleagues last month saying the decision could threaten the use of ceremonial wine, the right of public school students to take time off for religious holidays, the exemption of church interiors from landmarking laws, the practice of kosher slaughter, the right to wear yarmulkes or other religious clothing, or the right to refuse to wear clothing such as gym suits that a group might consider indecent. The bill has the support of the ``Coalition for the Free Exercise of Religion,'' comprising 26 religious and civil libertarian groups. The issue unites, among others, the American Civil Liberties Union and Concerned Women of America, an anti-abortion group; the National Association of Evangelicals and the National Council of Churches, and orthodox and reform Jews.

DOC.HEAD: Weak Link Between Atomic Tests and Utah Leukemia Cases, Study Finds
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 6th graf pvs, `Congress last ...' to CORRECT to show that only House has passed measure.
DOC.TEXT: Researchers have been unable to definitively link fallout from atomic explosions in Nevada during the 1950s to the higher than normal leukemia rate in neighboring Utah, although a new study does suggest a link. Weapons tests in Nevada by the old U.S. Atomic Energy Commission may have caused the higher cancer rate in the neighboring state, but the evidence is weak, according to a study conducted by University of Utah researchers to be published in next week's Journal of the American Medical Association. ``The excess of acute leukemias in southwestern Utah is probably not due to chance and may be attributable to fallout radiation. However, the estimated number of cases attributable to fallout in this region is small, and these cases are indistinguishable from other factors,'' the study said. If a direct relationship could have been established between fallout and leukemias ``there would also have been a substantial number of cases attributable to fallout in the rest of the state, because of its much larger population,'' the study said. But no such increased risk was found outside southwest Utah, it said. ``There was an excess of acute leukemia cases, but it was not statistically significant,'' concluded Dr. Joseph L. Lyon, one of the researchers with the University of Utah's Department of Family and Preventative Medicine. The U.S. House last month approved a bill creating a $100 million trust fund to compensate those living downwind from the Nevada test site for alleged radiation injuries. Up to 1,300 alleged fallout victims could collect up to $50,000 each under the legislation, now being considered by the Senate. More than 100 atomic bombs were set off above ground in Nevada between 1951 and 1958, researchers said. Fallout from those blasts spread across southwestern Utah. In one county, the average resident was exposed to nearly 30 times as much radiation as occurred naturally, researchers found. But because leukemia leaves no traces as to its source, it was impossible to determine whether individual deaths were caused by exposure to fallout, Lyon said Thursday. ``You can't say this leukemia was caused by smoking, this one was caused by radiation _ there's nothing in the disease that says what it was caused by. You can't sort out the random cases from those involving fallout,'' Lyon said. Researchers analyzed more than 6,500 deaths in Utah between 1952 and 1981 for the $6.8 million, federally funded study. They confined their analysis to members of the Mormon Church, because church records could be used to determine who had died and moved into or out of the area during the testing period. Earlier studies indicated the state's leukemia rate was 1.45 times higher than that across the country, and 2.45 times higher for children. But those studies didn't directly link that higher rate to radiation fallout, Lyon said. The study did show an apparently significant link between fallout and leukemia among those who were younger than 20 when they were exposed to the radiation. In Washington County, where the highest radiation levels were recorded, there were 17 leukemia deaths. Five were among people younger than 20 when exposed, making them nearly eight times more likely to die from acute leukemia than others their age. But researchers said that study sample was too small to be significant.

DOC.HEAD: Partisan Fight Expected Over Congressional Campaign Issues
DOC.TEXT: The battle over Senate election campaign funding is headed for a showdown next week, with Republicans refusing to guarantee a vote and Democrats threatening to delay the August recess. A last-ditch approach to reach an accord fizzled Thursday as Democrats rejected a Republican proposal to put a ceiling only on large out-of-state contributions that go directly to a campaign. Republicans retained their option to deny majority Democrats a final vote on the bill itself but disavowed any intent to mount a filibuster against it as they did successfully two years ago. ``I think we ought to start the bill first and let's have some amendments,'' said GOP leader Bob Dole of Kansas, telling reporters he was unwilling for now to enter into an agreement with Democrats specifying when a vote on final passage would occur. Democratic leader George Mitchell of Maine threatened to delay the beginning of Senate's scheduled summer recess beyond Aug 3. or Aug. 10 if the campaign finance measure is not disposed of by then. ``Any delays, whatever the intention of the delays, will serve only to delay the onset of the August recess,'' Mitchell said. ``We are simply going to take this bill up and complete action on it.'' In a letter to Mitchell on Wednesday, Dole offered for the first time to accept the concept of a ``flexible'' ceiling on how much a candidate can raise from wealthy out-of-state contributors. The Republican proposal would cut in half _ from $1,000 to $500 _ how much an individual can give each to the primary and general election campaigns of a candidate living in another state and place an unspecified ceiling on how much candidates could raise in contributions of above $250 from out of state. ``It seems to us that we've come quite a distance,'' Dole said, calling the proposal a ``dealmaker'' issue. Democrats, however, said the offer is rife with so many loopholes that campaign spending would continue to skyrocket without an absolute ceiling on the total amount of money a candidate can raise from all sources. ``It exempts any and all money raised in the state and most money raised out of state,'' Mitchell said. ``It is the classic example of the exception swallowing the rule.'' The Democratic bill would limit spending on Senate races to about $2 million for both the primary and general elections in small states to and to $11 million in large states like California and New York. Sen. David Boren, D-Okla., said the GOP proposal would encourage the further development of direct-mail campaigns run by special interest organizations. ``Millions of dollars could be raised this way, especially by incumbents,'' Boren said. ``The proposal won't stop by the money chase but encourage special interest politics. That's the last thing we should be doing.''

DOC.HEAD: Castro: Bush has `Sick Obsession' With Cuba
DOC.TEXT: President Fidel Castro says the United States is stepping up efforts to bring down his communist government as part of a ``sick obsession'' President Bush has about the island nation. ``When Bush goes to eat breakfast, he finds Cuba in his coffee, in his water, in his bread,'' Castro said Thursday night in a speech on the 37th anniversary of the beginning of his revolutionary movement that came to power in 1959. Hundreds of thousands of Cubans massed on Revolutionary Plaza to hear Castro, whose government faces serious economic problems and growing isolation following the fall of communism in Eastern Europe. Cuba's foreign relations have become even more tense in recent weeks because of dozens of asylum-seekers who have sought refuge in foreign embassies in Havana. A smiling Castro invited Americans to send boats to Cuba to pick up those wishing to leave, but it was not clear whether he was suggesting a renewal of the Mariel boatlift. Under that operation, 125,000 Cubans went to Florida during a five-month period in 1980. ``If the Yankees decide and they want to receive these poor, persecuted citizens, let them send the boats and the visas,'' he said sarcastically. Castro was on the offensive during most of his two-hour, 45-minute speech, and he appeared intent on rallying patriotic sentiment against Spain and the United States, the foreign powers that once dominated Cuba. The anniversary of Castro's revolution is a national holiday, and state media urged citizens to attend the rally. Castro accused Spain of collaborating with U.S. ``imperialist'' aims, and he announced the cancellation of a $2.5 million Spanish economic aid program. Spain suspended the program last week after Cuba took a hard line on Cubans who entered the Spanish Embassy seeking political asylum. With the United States now on friendly terms with the Soviet Union, Cuba's chief benefactor, Castro said Bush has become increasingly aggressive toward the Caribbean island nation of about 10.5 million people off Florida. He cited the start of a Voice of America television broadcast to Cuba last March as well as subsequent U.S. military maneuvers near the Cuban coast. In addition, he noted that Bush has linked U.S. aid to the Soviet Union to a suspension of Soviet economic and military aid to Cuba. ``See how the sick obsession of Bush goes?'' Castro asked. ``Neither asleep nor awakes does he forget about Cuba,'' he said. ``It is a shame for the world.'' Cubans have sought refuge in foreign embassies since July 9, and Castro said the United States has encouraged the actions. He cited the testimony of a Cuban dissident who said recently the alleged U.S. activities began last March. The U.S. diplomatic mission has denied the claims. The State Department in Washington had no official reaction to Castro's remarks late Thursday, saying there likely would be a response today after the speech is analyzed. Castro also said the United states was indirectly encouraging disaffected Cubans to seek asylum by refusing to live up to the terms of a 1984 immigration agreement between the countries. U.S. officials also have denied that charge and said that 10,000 visa applications have been processed since early 1988. The Spanish Embassy holds the most asylym-seekers, 18. Spain has said they will not be expelled. There are four Cubans at the Italian ambassador's residence. Three Cubans who entered the Swiss Embassy last weekend departed voluntarily on Wednesday. Castro reiterated Thursday night that his government will never let the asylum-seekers leave the country. He said if a Cuban wants to emigrate, he should go through normal procedures rather than try to use foreign embassies as a ``travel agency.'' Castro invited Spain and the European Community to open offices to allow disgruntled Cubans to apply for emigration visas, and he invited Americans to send boats to pick up Cubans who want to leave. Touching on economic issues, Castro said that oil deliveries from the Soviet Union were 50 percent below what had been contracted for. But he said the Soviet government was doing everything possible to fulfill its obligations. Castro has warned his countrymen that harsh austerity measures will have to be imposed if the Soviets stop sending 13 million tons of oil a year to Cuba. Compared with the anniversary a year ago, the mood today is far more uncertain. Many Cubans say they can't recall when food supplies have been more meager. For all his problems, Castro's rule still is without serious challenge. He continues to have a strong base of support and representatives of the small dissident community are either in prison or silent.

DOC.HEAD: Postal Service Cuts Set Saturday
DOC.TEXT: Some mail that now gets delivered the next day will take a day longer starting this weekend. Postmaster General Anthony Frank announced Thursday he will go ahead with selective cutbacks in overnight delivery service, originally announced last January, despite opposition from the independent Postal Rate Commission. The commission, in an opinion issued Thursday, said it opposed the reductions nationally, although cutbacks in delivery goals might be justified locally in some areas. The commission criticized the postal service for failing to estimate how it might save or customers might lose with the change. It also said the market research on which the service based its decision accurately measured what customers want. A national list of the changes was not issued by the postal service. Officials said information on cutbacks was being made public locally in the areas to be affected. ``We have concluded that (commission opposition) does not warrant delaying our scheduled Saturday implementation of changes in overnight delivery areas,'' Postmaster General Anthony M. Frank said. While the Postal Service is required to seek the opinion of the rate commission when it wants to make such delivery changes, it is not legally bound to abide by that opinion. Frank announced last January that the post office planned to tighten up the areas scheduled for regular overnight delivery to provide what it hopes will be more consistent service nationwide. The program called for concentrating resources in the busier regions. Local mail is not affected by the changes, which officials said will affect areas where there is only a small volume of mail moving between communities but where current standards call for overnight service. Currently 55.5 percent of all first class mail is designated for overnight delivery. Frank said that the new standard will reduce that to 50.7 percent. ``I consider these changes to be minimal in light of the many changes in transportation networks, increases in mail volume and shifts in population that have occurred since the standards were last examined more than a decade ago,'' said Frank. Nonetheless, the plan drew opposition from the beginning, particularly in light of the fact it was first reported at about the same time the post office announced that it would seek to raise rates next year. Implementation of the changes was pushed back from February to June and then to the end of July.

DOC.HEAD: House Committee Advances Bill To Limit Cable TV Rates
DOC.TEXT: Congress is moving toward a vote to limit cable television rates and give a boost to competitors such as satellite broadcasters. The House Energy and Commerce Committee on Thursday approved a cable regulation bill on a voice vote and sent it on to the House. A similar bill is pending in the Senate. The Federal Communications Commission, meanwhile, recommended in a report to Congress against re-regulating cable rates or services _ the industry was deregulated in 1984 _ but said steps should be taken to encourage competition. The bill approved by the House committee would require the FCC to set a price cap on a low-cost ``basic tier'' of channels that would include over-the-air broadcasters and public, educational and government channels. The FCC also would be empowered to go after ``bad actor'' cable systems and roll back their charges to customers for cable-owned services such as MTV, CNN and ESPN if it found the prices to be unreasonable. Pay channels such as Disney, HBO and Showtime would not be affected. Since 1984, the number of cable subscribers has soared, as have complaints about high prices and shoddy service. Lawmakers have said they wanted to assure the health of the cable industry, as well as its competitors, while cracking down on cable ``renegades.'' ``Some cable operators have betrayed the trust placed in them by the Congress in 1984,'' said Rep. Edward Markey, D-Mass., one of the House bill's principal sponsors. This measure would ``rein in these sorts of renegades,'' he said. The congressional watchdog agency, the General Accounting Office, has reported that from 1987 through 1989 rates for the lowest-priced cable service increased by 43 percent, from an average $11.14 to $15.95 per subscriber, while the average number of basic channels increased from 24 to 31. Rep. Billy Tauzin, D-La., noted that the House bill ``does not roll back cable rates ... and does not undo some of the damage done.'' Cable operators still will be allowed to raise rates moderately, he said. He and other committee members said increased competition _ particularly from satellite broadcasters, and perhaps telephone companies _ was the best way to assure that cable operators would not abuse customers. The House bill also would prohibit cable programmers that are owned by cable systems from ``unreasonably refusing to deal'' with competitors. Back-yard dish owners also would get guaranteed access to cable programs. The bill also would: _Allow exclusive contracts between cable programmers and distributors, as long as such agreements do not ``significantly impede competition.'' _Require cable systems to carry public and commercial stations, mainly on their existing channel assignments. _Require the FCC to establish minimum service standards. _Require the FCC to study whether to limit the number of cable systems one company may own or limit cable operator ownership of programming. Quick passage is predicted in both chambers. But administration officials have recommended that President Bush veto such a measure. James Mooney, president of the National Cable Television Association, said the House bill went ``way too far in handing out regulatory benefits to competitors. We don't support it.''

DOC.HEAD: House Subcommittee Approves Cut In Armed Forces
