DOC.TEXT: A House Armed Services subcommittee is proposing a cut in the nation's armed forces of 129,000 troops, with the Army and Air Force taking the deepest reductions in the fiscal 1991 military budget. The panel on military personnel and compensation on Thursday approved a cut in the Army of 68,500 and the Air Force of 37,000. The reductions would slash 50,000 soldiers from the current active duty forces in Europe, a congressional decision based on the lessening Soviet threat. Reductions for the Navy would total 20,000 while the Marine Corps would lose about 4,000 spots. Consistent with the House budget resolution approved on May 1, the Armed Services Committee is drawing up a military budget of $283 billion _ $24 billion less than President Bush had sought in January. The action by the subcommittee was the first of several steps taken by various armed services panels leading up to the full committee's crafting of a 1991 defense bill on Tuesday. The total troop reduction from the nearly 2.1 million troops is slightly higher than the 100,000 approved by the Senate Armed Services Committee in its version of the defense bill and nearly four times the total of 38,000 in the president's proposed budget. In other developments, the subcommittee on military installations agreed to prohibit spending any defense funds on moving the 401st Tactical Wing from Torrejon de Ardoz, Spain, to Crotone, Italy, or any other location overseas, subcommittee chairwoman Patricia Schroeder, D-Colo., said. Defense money could be used, however, to move the 72 F-16 jet fighters from Torrejon de Ardoz to any site in the United States. The panel also agreed to delay closing military bases while requiring Defense Secretary Dick Cheney to come up with an acceptable proposal to Congress, likely a commission, on how installations can be shut down. Democrats had criticized Cheney's proposed list in January as partisan in its selections. The panel on seapower and strategic and critical materials agreed to Bush's request for five DDG-51 Navy destroyers at a cost of $3.6 billion and his proposal of $1.2 billion for the 18th Trident missile-launching submarine. But the panel agreed to only one of the two SSN-21 Seawolf attack submarines President Bush had sought in the fiscal year beginning Oct. 1. The seapower subcommittee was forced to cut $3 billion from the president's original request of $16.1 billion. On the contentious issue of strategic home porting of naval vessels, the subcommittee failed to approve a measure that would have directed Navy Secretary H. Lawrence Garrett III to close the home port in Staten Island, N.Y., and impose a moratorium on construction at five other home ports. The subcommittee expressed concern about acting on the issue before Cheney completes his review of military installations worldwide. Among those facilities are planned home ports in Everett, Wash.; Ingleside, Texas; Pascagoula, Miss.; Mobile, Ala.; and Pensacola, Fla. The panel left a final decision on the home porting issue to the full Armed Services Committee. Behind closed doors, the panel agreed to one of the SSN-21 Seawolf attack submarines. The Navy had planned to buy two of the nuclear boats in the fiscal year beginning Oct. 1 at a total cost of $2.3 billion. The panel's action came two days after the General Accounting Office, the investigative arm of Congress, recommended that Congress slow down the $44 billion submarine program because 15 of the costly vessels will be under contract before critical testing on the lead ship has been completed. The first submarine, designed by the Newport News Shipbuilding Co., of Virginia, and the Electric Boat Division of General Dynamics in Connecticut, is estimated at $1.9 billion. The Navy expects the cost of subsequent submarines to decline, averaging around $1 billion.

DOC.HEAD: Oil Spill Legislation To Create $1 Billion Cleanup Fund
DOC.TEXT: Congress is close to making major changes in the way government and industry deal with oil spills since negotiators agreed on a bill creating a $1 billion federal oil spill cleanup fund. A House and Senate conference committee approved legislation Thursday that would significantly increase oil shippers' liability for spills, create the cleanup fund and require that most tankers have double hulls within 20 years. The package must still go back to the House and Senate, but supporters predicted final approval before the August congressional recess. President Bush is expected to sign the measure. Approval of the compromise bill came 16 months after the Exxon Valdez tanker ran aground in Alaska's Prince William Sound and spilled 11 million gallons of crude oil along the state's coastline. It was the nation's worst oil spill and prompted demands for tougher federal requirements on oil shippers and better preparation for responding to spills. Under the bill, shippers would be liable for up to $1,200 per gross ton of the tanker, instead of the current ceiling of $150 per gross ton. As an example, a tanker the size of the Exxon Valdez under the new requirements would be liable to up to $115 million with unlimited liability if gross negligence is found to be involved. Under current law such a tanker would face only $15 million in legal liability. Exxon already has spent an estimated $2 billion in cleanup efforts as a result of the March 24, 1989 spill. Other major provisions in the compromise legislation include: _ Creation of a $1 billion oil spill response and cleanup fund, with the money coming from a 5-cent-a-barrel fee on both domestic and imported oil. The fee can be used for immediate cleanup requirements as well as compensating for damages beyond what shippers are required to pay under the liability provision. _ A requirement that all new tankers have double hulls and that most of the existing tankers be retrofitted with double hulls or taken out of service over the next 20 years. A small number of tankers will be given until 2015 to have double hulls. The Coast Guard has estimated that if the Exxon Valdez had been double hulled, much of the 11 million gallons of oil that spilled into Prince William Sound might have been contained. _ Formation of regional response teams within the Coast Guard to deal with oil spills and a national response center where computers will hold lists of personnel and equipment that can be called upon after a major spill. The legislation also calls for increased research on oil pollution control and requires the government to check driving records for alcohol-related offenses before issuing licenses to operate an oil tanker. In a stark reminder of the Exxon Valdez catastrophe, Alaska's congressional delegation had included in the bill a provision barring any tanker involved in an oil spill of more than 1 million gallons anywhere in the world from ever entering Prince William Sound. The House and Senate approved separate oil spill bills last November, but progress on reconciling the measures stalled over a number of issues. There were disagreements over whether to require double-hull tankers and whether the bill should be linked to an international treaty limiting oil spill liability. It was decided in June not to make such a link. With the most controversial issues resolved going into Thursday's final meeting of the conference committee, there remained only minor changes to be made in the legislation before it was approved by a voice vote. Injecting some last-minute drama, Rep. Walter Jones, D-N.C., was successful in tacking on a moratorium on offshore oil drilling along the Mid-Atlantic states until further environmental studies can be made. The amendment is aimed at plans by Mobil Corp., and several other oil companies to drill for natural gas on leases off Cape Hatteras, N.C. It prohibits any drilling until after Oct. 1, 1991, so the new environmental studies can be conducted. Rep. Ron Marlenee, R-Mont., who opposed the amendment, said he expects the provision to be challenged when the compromise bill comes up for approval in the House. Congressional sources said, however, they doubt the issue will derail the legislation.

DOC.HEAD: WASHINGTON TODAY: Deputy and Scrambler Telephone Keep Him Advised
An AP News Analysis
LaserPhoto WX9
DOC.TEXT: It took three refueling stops for Secretary of State James A. Baker III to get to Indonesia on his 30-year-old U.S. Air Force jet. But as slowly as he treks through four nations in Asia, he is only an electronic holler away from his command post at home. Baker's plane has parallel telephone and printed message systems, both equipped with scramblers for confidential conversations and sensitive exchanges. They nearly always work. A couple of weeks ago, while stretching his legs at the airport in Shannon, Ireland, while the jet was refueled, Baker was taken aback by reporters whose editors had just told them of the deal West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl had struck in Moscow clearing the way for German unification. The terms reached with Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev surpassed anything Baker expected to see accomplished when he got to Paris for six-nation talks in Germany. ``Terrific, terrific,'' Baker told reporters, recovering quickly. ``The fact of the matter,'' Deputy Secretary of State Lawrence Eagleburger said Wednesday, ``Baker should have had a heads-up. The guy at the airport who had the information missed connections with Baker because Baker was taking a walk.'' Eagleburger, who takes over as acting secretary of state when Baker is abroad or on vacation, is only a telephone call or an electronic message away from the jet or from the headquarters Baker establishes when he reaches his destination. ``It works,'' Eagleburger said in an interview. ``I suppose if they are off at a dinner in Paris and something develops it is going to take longer to get in touch. But it works. The communications on the plane are fantastic.'' Most of the material Washington sends to Baker is dull. Routine reports are transmitted, to be scanned by assistants traveling with him, as well as wire service reports and press clippings. ``He doesn't leave the State Department behind,'' said another U.S. official. ``There is a sort of constant back and forth. And yet there is a tendency not to overburden him.'' One reason Baker can breathe easy is his comfortable relationship with Eagleburger. Their backgrounds are as different as Houston, Baker's hometown, and Stevens Point, Wis., which Eagleburger left for college, the Army and then a career in the foreign service _ with time out for four lucrative years as a Washington consultant. At the start, Eagleburger had Baker's permission to join any meeting he wished _ an offer Eagleburger accepted more often at the beginning. ``On this, Baker has been superb,'' Eagleburger said. ``I think I've got a pretty good sense of where he is going to come out on an issue. If I am in doubt I try to get a hold of him and find out.'' This doesn't happen too often. For a National Security Council meeting Wednesday at the White House, he substituted for Baker without consulting him on the issue at hand. Eagleburger would not disclose the topic President Bush took up that day with his closest advisers. Eagleburger prepared by holding his own sessions first at the State Department. ``This is a case, by and large, you represent the department unless you know the secretary disagrees with what the department's view would be,'' he said. ``In this case I assure you he would not disagree.'' And then there is the crisis situation. Last December, as Bush, Baker and Brent Scowcroft, the president's national security assistant, flew together on Air Force One to Malta for a summit meeting with Gorbachev, army rebels mounted a coup in the Philippines. The future looked bleak for U.S.-backed President Corazon Aquino. She prevailed after two U.S. jet fighter planes from Clark Air Base provided air support for government troops, buzzed rebel positions and otherwise made sure the dissidents knew on which side Washington stood. During the crisis, Eagleburger was in the State Department's Operations Center, the guarded communications hub. Vice President Dan Quayle and Robert Gates, the former CIA official who is Scowcroft's deputy, were at the White House. ``We had a hookup, and then the vice president was on the telephone with Baker. That's an example of where we were able to make decisions based on where the powers were _ namely, on the airplane,'' Eagleburger said. ``We didn't have to wing it from here. The communications were fine.'' Pausing for a moment, Eagleburger continued: ``That was a decision to use American military forces. These are not the kinds of decisions you make on your own, without the president.''
EDITOR'S NOTE: Barry Schweid is The Associated Press' chief diplomatic writer.

DOC.HEAD: House Committee Votes Immunity for Boesky, Milken
DOC.TEXT: Junk bond financier Michael Milken and convicted stock speculator Ivan Boesky will be granted immunity from additional prosecution to get them to testify before Congress. That decision by the House Energy and Commerce Committee on Thursday means that nothing the two most famous figures in the Wall Street scandals of the 1980s tell to Congress could be used against them in court. No date has been set for their appearance before the panel's investigations subcommittee, but the committee agreed to delay Milken's testimony until after he is sentenced for securities fraud, now scheduled for Oct. 1. The committee voted 42-1 to grant immunity. A two-thirds majority was needed. The lone dissent came from Rep. Joe Barton, R-Texas. Spokesman Craig Murphy said the congressman ``does not believe in giving immunity to convicted felons.'' Boesky has agreed to extensive subcommittee staff interviews before his actual testimony. Milken has not agreed to such interviews, said Rep. John Dingell, D-Mich., chairman of both the committee and subcommittee. Milken, former head of Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc.'s high-risk, high-yield bond department, pleaded guilty to six felony charges in April and agreed to pay $600 million to settle the biggest financial fraud case against an individual. He faces up to 28 years in prison at sentencing in New York. Boesky, once a leading speculator in the stocks of companies that were potential takeover targets, pleaded guilty to one count of conspiracy to violate securities laws and was released April 4 after serving about two-thirds of a three-year prison sentence. The committee's vote ended a tug of war between the Justice Department, which does not want Milken to testify before he is sentenced, and Dingell, the powerful committee chairman. Previously, Dingell wanted to hear from Milken before the end of the current congressional session, expected sometime in early October. Justice Department sources who asked not to be identified said prosecutors were concerned Milken could withdraw his guilty plea after being immunized, making it difficult _ if not impossible _ for any prosecution to continue. Dingell said the U.S. attorney's office asked the subcommittee to withhold taking Milken's testimony until after the sentencing, and congressional sources said Dingell agreed to the delay. In a memo to committee members circulated before the vote, Dingell noted that the recent reversal of some of the charges against Iran-Contra figure Oliver North raised concerns about immunized testimony. A federal appeals court in Washington ruled that congressional testimony, like that given by North in the summer of 1987, could unfairly prejudice a defendant's trial. A spokesman for Milken said: ``Of course we will testify when they ask him to testify.'' Milken was linked to a large insider trading network headed by Boesky. Dingell wants to know about some 500 limited partnerships _ set up by Milken and the Drexel junk bond department _ that bought significant stakes in hot junk bond issues underwritten by Drexel before they were made available to the public. Critics say the activity drove up the price of those issues at the expense of Drexel customers, but the transactions' legality has never been resolved. Milken was called to testify before the investigations subcommittee in 1988 but invoked his Fifth Amendment right against possible self-incrimination. A subpoena also was authorized at that time for Boesky but never acted upon pending the outcome of the Milken probe.

DOC.HEAD: With PM-Frank-Ethics, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Following are the 18 House members who voted against a reprimand for Rep. Barney Frank, D-Mass., for using official influence to help a male prostitute. Bob Stump, R-Ariz.; Mervyn M. Dymally, D-Calif.; Nancy Pelosi, D-Calif.; Henry A. Waxman, D-Calif.; William E. Dannemeyer, R-Calif.; Robert K. Dornan, R-Calif.; Wally Herger, R-Calif.; Duncan Hunter, R-Calif.; Newt Gingrich, R-Ga.; Sidney R. Yates, D-Ill.; Dan Burton, R-Ind.; Clyde C. Holloway, R-La.; William Clay, D-Mo.; Melton D. ``Mel'' Hancock, R-Mo.; Robert J. Mrazek, D-N.Y.; Robert S. Walker, R-Pa.; Don Sundquist, R-Tenn.; and Craig A. Washington, D-Texas. Voting present were Ronald V. Dellums, D-Calif.; Gus Savage, D-Ill.; Frank and Donald Lukens, R-Ohio. Not voting were Bill Nelson, D-Fla.; Bart Gordon, D-Tenn.; and Jim Chapman, D-Texas. Four hundred eight members voted for the reprimand. There are two vacancies in the 435-member House.

DOC.HEAD: Perestroika Reaching Ethiopia, Minister Says
DOC.TEXT: Ethiopia no longer proclaims itself communist and is planning a future of perestroika, private enterprise, political competition and reconciliation, its foreign minister says. The onetime staunchest Soviet ally in Africa is also on a road to stronger ties with the United States, Minister Tesfaye Dinka said after meetings the past two days with Deputy Secretary of State Lawrence Eagleburger, other State Department officials and members of Congress. Thursday's talk with Eagleburger was described by Tesfaye as ``an important milestone'' toward improving U.S. relations long mired in disagreement over human rights abuses in Ethiopia. It was perhaps the highest-level U.S.-Ethiopian meeting in a decade. There was no public declaration, however, about normalization, which would include restoring diplomatic representation to the level of ambassador. The minister said he thanked Eagleburger for U.S. relief food shipments sent over the years to his starvation-plagued country and assured him that the governments of Ethiopia and Israel were ``in complete understanding'' about continuing emigration of Ethiopian Jews to Israel. Eagleburger urged that an estimated 15,000 remaining Ethiopian Jews be free to leave and voiced concern about reports that the flow had been interrupted, said a U.S. official who insisted on anonymity. Tesfaye said he and Eagleburger discussed current efforts for settlement of the 29-year Eritrean rebellion and the need for the international community to get insurgents controlling Massawa port in Northern Ethiopia to open it to relief food shipments. ``Political competition I think will be on the agenda'' of peace talks with the Eritrean movement ``and I think it's something that will come about,'' Tesfaye told reporters. Details are uncertain, but the constitution will be revised if necessary, he added. President Mengistu Haile Mariam's Ethiopian government is undertaking economic and political changes that will bring a market-oriented economy with greater incentives and encouragement for domestic and foreign investors, Tesfaye said.

DOC.HEAD: Prominent Honduran Drug Trafficker Convicted in Camarena Case
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Deliberations resume around noon EDT.
DOC.HEAD: Laserphoto LA11 of July 26
DOC.TEXT: The Drug Enforcement Administration's five-year crusade to avenge the murder of agent Enrique Camarena in Mexico attained its first U.S. conviction of a major drug figure in the case. Juan Ramon Matta Ballesteros, a prominent Honduran businessman and convicted drug trafficker, was found guilty Thursday of conspiring to kidnap, torture and murder Camarena in support of a racketeering enterprise. The federal jury also convicted Matta of actually kidnapping Camarena and holding him for interrogation. But he was acquitted of the agent's murder. Matta, 45, shook his head slightly when the verdict was read. Tears streamed down the faces of family members in court. Jurors today were to resume deliberating the fate of three other defendants in the trial, the second U.S. prosecution in the case. In 1988, a former Mexican policeman and two Mexican drug traffickers were convicted of conspiracy charges stemming from the agent's slaying by Guadalajara's powerful drug cartel. Camarena's 1985 torture-slaying in Guadalajara incensed U.S. drug enforcement officials and strained relations between the United States and Mexico. Authorities had described Matta as one of the world's most active cocaine dealers. Last year, Assistant U.S. Attorney Gary Allen Feess placed him ``on the level of the top 10 Colombian drug traffickers.'' Matta's lawyer, Martin Stolar, called the verdicts a ``terrible miscarriage of justice'' and said he will appeal. Matta ``cannot conceive of being convicted for a crime he had nothing to do with,'' Stolar said. ``He questions the ability of U.S. courts to fairly and adequately protect a Honduran citizen accused in this country.'' Matta could receive life in prison at sentencing Sept. 25. He already is serving a life sentence in the United States for running a cocaine syndicate that generated $73 million in just nine months in 1981. He was convicted by a federal jury here in September after his arrest in Honduras. Camarena was a 31-year-old DEA agent working in Mexico when he was kidnapped. Cartel leaders were angered because the agent's undercover work led to the seizure of 10,000 tons of marijuana in 1984, prosecutors said. Testimony at both U.S. trials showed Camarena was tortured and interrogated by drug lords before being slain with his pilot, Alfredo Zavala Avelar. After Camarena's battered body was discovered a month later, Mexican authorities blamed Rafael Caro Quintero, a cartel leader. But DEA agents were skeptical that the reckless, illiterate ``Rafa'' had acted alone. U.S. authorities sought the brains of the cartel, including members of Mexico's power elite and Matta, also known as ``El Negro.'' The DEA has vowed to capture every person involved in his slaying. Twenty-two people have been charged in the United States and more than 20 convicted in Mexico. Among those serving prison terms in Mexico are Caro and another drug kingpin, Ernesto Fonseco Carrillo. Anti-American riots broke out in Honduras in 1988 after U.S. authorities arrested Matta and flew him to the United States. Five people died and the U.S. Embassy annex was torched. Honduras has no extradition treaty with the United States, which added to the anger of citizens who knew Matta as the employer of up to 5,000 people at his cattle ranches, dairy farms and cigar factories. Disputes between Mexico and the United States over the case have erupted several times. Mexico said this month it would seek the extradition of a DEA agent and a Mexican informant who allegedly plotted the kidnapping of a Guadalajara doctor accused in Camarena's murder. Matta's co-defendants are Ruben Zuno Arce, a Guadalajara businessman and brother-in-law of former Mexican President Luis Echeverria; Juan Jose Bernabe Ramirez, a former Mexican homicide officer, and Javier Vasquez Velasco, a bodyguard accused of murdering two U.S. tourists apparently mistaken for U.S. drug agents.

DOC.HEAD: Cosmonauts Fix Balky Hatch
DOC.TEXT: Two cosmonauts have repaired a balky hatch that bedeviled them and dangerously prolonged a previous spacewalk earlier this month, according to Soviet news reports. Anatoly Solovyov and Alexander Balandin also removed and stowed handrails during the three-hour, 31-minute spacewalk Thursday. They had affixed the handrails to the outside of the spacecraft during a July 17 excursion to repair torn thermal insulation on the outside of their Soyuz TM-9 capsule, the Tass news agency said. Tass said ground controllers indicated that human error at the start of the previous spacewalk caused the hatch problem. The cosmonauts had opened the hatch before the airlock was completely depressurized, and it swung outward with such force that a key joint was damaged. Solovyev and Balandin began their spacewalk Thursday by again trying to close the hatch, which was less than an inch ajar, Tass said. They made little progress, however, and ground controllers told them to relax and work on stowing the ladder-like handrails, which were left behind July 17 when Solovyev and Balandin had to rush back inside the spacecraft because their oxygen was running low. The handrails could have posed a problem when the capsule separated from the Mir space station for the cosmonauts' return voyage home. Tass said ground controllers studied a televised picture of the hatch and officials at the Soviet Mission Control Center in Kaliningrad, outside Moscow, recommended how to repair the joint. Tass said the cosmonauts then were able to close the hatch completely. They pressurized the airlock and removed their space suits, Tass said. The evening television newscast ``Vremya'' reported that ground controllers would be monitoring the pressure in the airlock to make sure the outside hatch had sealed properly. The balky hatch was the latest in a series of problems to trouble the cosmonauts' six-month mission. Tass focused on its accomplishments: completing 506 of 520 scientific experiments, photographing 8.4 million square miles of the Earth's surface, and ``growing'' 23 crystals in the weightless environment of space. The report said each crystal was worth $1 million. The cosmonauts, who have been in space since Feb. 11, are scheduled to return home on Aug. 9. A replacement crew is to be launched Aug. 1.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Ready to Initiate Direct Contact with Cambodia
DOC.TEXT: The United States is considering direct contacts with Cambodia's communist government in addition to Vietnam to try to end the war in Cambodia, Secretary of State James A. Baker said today. Baker said the withdrawal last year of Vietnamese troops backing the Cambodian government ``gives us cause to see whether Hanoi is now prepared to support a process of political reconciliation'' that would lead to free elections. ``We are also considering contacts with the Phnom Penh regime,'' he added. The moves would fit in both with efforts to reduce East-West tensions and with continuing U.S. support for the non-Communist Cambodian rebels, Baker said in a speech to the Association of Southeast Asian nations, or ASEAN. He spoke on the first day of a three-day meeting of the group, which comprises Thailand, Singapore, Malaysia, the Philippines, Brunei and Indonesia. The foreign ministers of Australia, Canada, the European Community, Japan, New Zealand are also attending the session. ASEAN foreign ministers criticized Baker's announcement last week that the United States would not recognize the United Nations delegate from the three-part Cambodian resistance because it includes the Communist Khmer Rouge. During Khmer Rouge rule of Cambodia from 1975-78, hundreds of thousands of Cambodians died from starvation or executions while the government enforced a radical program to collectivize agriculture. Vietnam invaded in 1978 and toppled the Khmer Rouge led by Pol Pot, but the rebels have staged a string of recent battlefield victories and are the strongest anti-government force. Baker arrived in Jakarta Thursday on the first leg of a four-nation Asian tour. He assured ASEAN that their goals and those of the United States were not contradictory. ``Our common approach to Cambodia has _ for a decade _ focused on three goals: a verified withdrawal of Vietnamese troops, the prevention of the return to power of the Khmer Rouge, and genuine self-determination for the Cambodian people through free elections,'' he said. The guerrilla resistance was formed under ASEAN sponsorship in 1982 with U.S. support. The Khmer Rouge is by far its most powerful component. ``Continued support for the coalition at the U.N. is only providing the Khmer Rouge diplomatic cover for its military maneuvers,'' Baker said. Baker also noted that Washington is expanding its military ties with Singapore, which offered expanded use of its facilities to U.S. warships and planes last year. Baker is due to visit Singapore on Sunday on the next stop of his trip, which also includes Mongolia and talks with Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze in Siberia. On the issue of refugees arriving from Indochina, Baker said the United States had met its commitments and that its critics were indulging in finger-pointing. ASEAN warned Tuesday that it reserved the right to turn away boat people. The warning was aimed at pressuring Washington to end its opposition to the compulsory return of boat people who are found to be fleeing for economic reasons, rather than because of political persecution. More than 130,000 boat people are held in camps in the region. Refusal by the United States and Vietnam to accept mandatory repatriation led to postponement of an international conference on the problem in Geneva earlier this month.

DOC.HEAD: With PM-Camarena, Bjt
Chronology of Case of Murder of DEA Agent
DOC.TEXT: Here are some key events in the Camarena case: Feb. 7, 1985 _ Drug Enforcement Administration Agent Enrique Camarena is kidnapped outside the U.S. consulate in Guadalajara. March 5, 1985 _ The bodies of Camarena and his pilot, Alfredo Zavala Avelar, are found buried at a remote ranch outside Guadalajara. April 5, 1985 _ Costa Rican police officers acting on information from U.S. officials capture reputed Mexican drug czar Rafael Caro Quintero, a key suspect in the slayings of Camarena and Zavala. Caro is returned to Mexico. Sept. 26, 1988 _ Rene Verdugo Urquidez, Caro's chief lieutenant, is convicted in Los Angeles of five counts of conspiracy, kidnapping, murder and two counts of violent acts in support of racketeering. The two acts were the murders of Camarena and Zavala. Oct. 11, 1988 _ Raul Lopez Alvarez, 29, a former Guadalajara police officer, is sentenced in Los Angeles to 240 years plus life for his part in the torture and killings of Camarena and Zavala. July 27, 1989 _ Juan Jose Bernabe-Ramirez, a police officer from the western Mexico state of Jalisco, is arrested in Los Angeles and charged with the murder of a federal agent. Dec. 12, 1989 _ Caro, 37, and Ernesto Rafael Fonesca Carrillo, 56, are convicted in Mexico and sentenced to 40 years in prison for masterminding the killings. Feb. 1, 1990 _ Miguel Aldana Ibarra, 44, and four others are indicted by a federal grand jury in Los Angeles on charges of participating in the 1985 murders. April 3, 1990 _ Dr. Humberto Alvarez Machain, a Guadalajara gynecologist, is arrested after being abducted and taken to El Paso, Texas, to face charges he drugged Camarena during the agent's kidnapping, torture and murder.

DOC.HEAD: Veteran AP Sportswriter Jerry Liska Dead at 78
DOC.TEXT: Gerald J. ``Jerry'' Liska, an Associated Press sports writer in Chicago for 31 years, died after a long illness. He was 78. Liska died at Methodist Hospital, where he had been treated for a rare blood disease, said his brother, Robert Liska. Liska, a Chicago native, was named a sports writer in the AP's Chicago bureau in 1944 after three years with the news cooperative in Lansing and Ann Arbor, Mich. A past president of the Football Writers Association of America, he retired from the AP in 1975. Liska is survived by his wife, Catherine Ennen Liska, of Alamo; a son, Greg Liska, of Sheridan, Ore., and a daughter, Kathleen Draffkorn, who lives in Florida. Other survivors include his brother and his sister, Margaret Rittiner of Newnan, Ga. A funeral service was scheduled for Saturday.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Up, Nikkei Declines Again
DOC.TEXT: The dollar firmed against the yen in Tokyo today, while share prices on the Tokyo Stock Exchange declined for the sixth straight trading day. The dollar closed the week at 150.75 yen, up 0.64 yen from Thursday's 150.11-yen finish. It opened at 150.40 yen and ranged between 150.32 yen and 150.80 yen. The U.S. currency has kept an upward trend in the last seven trading days, gaining a total of 3.50 yen from the closing of 147.25 yen on July 18. Spot transactions today totaled $9.509 billion, down from Thursday's $10.112 billion. The benchmark Nikkei Stock Average of 225 selected issues fell 506.27 points, or 1.61 percent, to 30,863.48. The index had shed 331.52 points on Thursday. It was the lowest closing since May 2, when the index finished at 30,173.64. The index now has lost a total of 2,192.14 points, or 6.63 percent, in six sessions, compared to the closing of 33,055.62 on July 19. Friday's volume on the first section was estimated at 450 million shares, up from 330 million shares on Thursday. In bond dealings, the widely watched No. 119 10-year Japanese government bond was quoted at 85.30 points as of 4:00 p.m., down from Thursday's close of 85.62 points. The yield was 7.545 percent, up from 7.500 percent. Currency dealers said the weakness of the Tokyo stock market and the Japanese government bond's slip were the main factors for the dollar's gain this week. ``Besides, the dollar usually is bought here as a safe haven in times of international tension,'' said Toshiyuki Nishiguchi, an analyst with Daiwa Securities. He referred to the dollar's gain and decline in share prices in Tokyo in the wake of tension in the Middle East between Iraq and Kuwait. ``Uncertain prospects for interest rates and the weakness of the Japanese government bonds were other factors,'' Nishiguchi said. Akihiko Kagawa of Bank of Tokyo said, ``The exchange market today is more concerned about the declining share prices than any other factors.'' Share prices plunged to a 2{-month low in response to higher interest rates on the bond market, Kagawa said. The benchmark government bond has lost 0.84 points from 86.14 last Friday, when the yield stood at 7.385 percent. Japan's discount rate and long term prime rate are one of the lowest among industrialized countries, and the country has been under pressure from its trading partners to raise the rates. Higher interest rates tend to make a country's stock market less attractive to investors.

DOC.HEAD: Buddhists Poised to Become Political Force in Mongolia
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Gandan for name of monastery and Gaandan for name of former chief monk are cq.
DOC.TEXT: A new group that is not even taking part in Sunday's legislative elections _ a Buddhist association _ is rapidly becoming a potent force in Mongolia. As of early July, the Union of True Believers had registered 79,000 members, making it second in size only to the ruling Communist Party, which claims 98,000. New members are joining hourly, said the union's chairman, Bayantsagaan, who like most Mongolians uses only one name. ``It's like a river after a heavy rain,'' he said in an interview this week at the union's headquarters in a traditional nomad's tent, or ger, outside Gandan Temple in Ulan Bator. When the Communists took power in Mongolia in 1921, they ended the Buddhist monasteries' centuries-old role in politics. In the 1930s, the Communists shut down more than 700 monasteries and forced the monks to find secular work. Religious worship was banned and later tightly restricted. Gandan was reopened in 1944, and until April it was the country's sole place of Buddhist worship. But Bayantsagaan and others say most Mongolians continued to pray in private. When the democratic revolution sweeping Eastern Europe inspired Mongolians to demonstrate last winter and spring for an end to authoritarianism, Buddhist monks and lay believers tentatively ventured into the fray. They held a protest of their own to demand monasteries be reopened and sent a letter to the legislature calling for an end to government control of religion. They formed the Union of True Believers in March, and it established a political wing, the Mongolian Buddhist Party. The party has yet to register with the government and so is ineligible to put candidates forward in Mongolia's first multi-party legislative elections, being held Sunday. But when the next elections are held, the Buddhists could win, said Bayarsuren, the party chairman, claiming strength in the ``somons,'' the lowest administrative units in rural Mongolia. ``In some somons, the entire population has joined the movement,'' he said. Somons usually have about 2,000 residents. There are no figures for the percentage of Mongolia's 2 million people who still adhere to Buddhism, but both men maintained that it is a majority. They said young people are as interested in religion as their elders. Should the party win a future election, Bayarsuren said, it would restore complete freedom of worship and re-establish traditional links between Buddhism and government. ``Religion, government and people will be one,'' he said. Even without joining in this year's election, the Buddhists have made a more rapid comeback than was anticipated in March, when the Communists pledged to allow political and religious freedoms. At that time, the chief monk of Gandan Temple, Gaandan, said two more temples would be reopened shortly but other restorations would proceed slowly and there would be no effort by the Buddhists to take political power. Since then, however, Bayarsuren said, about 30 temples have been reopened, using public donations.

DOC.HEAD: Leaders of Political Party Convicted In Trial
DOC.TEXT: A British colonial court today convicted five pro-democracy activists of using a megaphone and collecting money without a permit in a case that has been called a show trial to suppress political activism. Critics said the verdict was another example of Britain kowtowing to Communist China, which takes control of the colony in 1997 when Britain's 99-year lease runs out. Magistrate Betty Kwan told a packed courtroom that using megaphones during political demonstrations was ``not necessary or justified'' and fined the five the equivalent of about $20 each. The defendants, four men and one woman, said they would appeal. If they lose, they said, they would refuse the fine and risk prison. ``We are fully prepared for the consequences,'' said Yeung Sum, a professor at Hong Kong University and one of the defendants. He accused the British colonial government of trying ``to silence those who express their political opinions in a peaceful and orderly manner.'' Yeung, lawyer Albert Ho, labor union leader Lau Chin-shek, teacher Lee Wing-tat, and Christian worker Wong Pik-wan, the woman in the group, are central committee members of the United Democrats of Hong Kong, a political party that was formed in April to promote democracy in Hong Kong. They, along with political activist Tsang Kim-shing, were prosecuted under a 1933 law forbidding the use of bullhorns. The law is rarely invoked and widely ignored by teachers and tour guides who use bullhorns daily. Tsang, who is not a leader of the United Democrats party, was acquitted. The group held a peaceful sit-in at the Star Ferry terminal in February and called for greater protection of human rights in Hong Kong. They collected donations and gave speeches through a megaphone. Police charged the group in late May, two weeks before the anniversary of the bloody crackdown on a movement for democracy in China on June 4. About 100,000 people took to the streets in Hong Kong that day to commemorate the crackdown. Several U.S. congressmen and Petra Kelly, leader of West Germany's Green Party, have expressed concern about the case. Amnesty International, the London-based human rights organization, said it would adopt the defendants as prisoners of conscience if they are imprisoned. Friday's case marks the third time in the last 10 months that the Hong Kong government has prosecuted political activists. Many people in Hong Kong worry that once China takes control of the territory it will break its promise to maintain Hong Kong's freewheeling economic and social system for 50 years. Many also have begun to doubt Britain's commitment to supporting Hong Kong up to 1997. Over the past few months, the colonial government has barred prominent Chinese dissidents from entering Hong Kong, censored films critical of China and turned away the Goddess of Democracy radio ship, which wanted to beam pro-democracy messages to mainland China. Hong Kong government officials have publicly denied that the government is trying to suppress political activism. But in a confidential letter written to Chinese authorities late last year, British colonial official William Ehrman stressed that Britain would not allow Hong Kong to be used as ``a base for subversive activities.''

DOC.HEAD: Many of Frank's Constituents Support Him Despite Sex Scandal
DOC.TEXT: The Capitol Hill sex scandal that prompted congressional colleagues to reprimand Rep. Barney Frank isn't likely to hurt him at home, constituents said. Frank, who faces no serious Republican challenge in his re-election bid, drew the reprimand Thursday in a 408-108 vote that imposed the lightest punishment possible for his dealings with a homosexual prostitute. ``I'm pleased he was just reprimanded even though I have some concerns about the whole thing,'' said Kathi Sadow of Brookline. ``He's an extremely good congressman who showed extremely bad judgment and we'll vote for him again.'' But George Fattell of Brighton said House representatives were ``too lenient.'' ``I think he should have been censured,'' Fattell said. The House rejected Republican proposals to censure or expel the five-term liberal Democrat, who apologized for the indiscretions he said arose because he wanted to conceal his homosexuality. Frank was accused of using his influence on behalf of male prostitute Stephen L. Gobie, whom he paid $80 for sex in 1985 and then hired as a personal assistant. Gobie, whose allegations sparked the scandal, allegedly operated a prostitution service from the home he shared with Frank. Some of Frank's constituents said they had mixed feelings about him. ``I'm torn,'' said Nicole Tufo, 21. ``I think what he did was wrong but I guess I feel bad for him.'' Newton City Clerk Edward G. English said he still supports Frank, citing a letter the congressman wrote him in 1981 congratulating him for a decade of public service. ``At a time when so many negative things are being said about people in public life, it is important to remind people, especially young people, that public service can be a noble cause,'' the letter read. ``I think he still believes in those principles,'' English said. ``I'm sad for Barney,'' said Newton Mayor Thomas Mann. ``I'm sad for everybody that's gone through so much. I wonder how well others would have taken this.'' Hilda Dorgin of Brookline echoed the sentiments of many people interviewed: ``I think he's tremendous.'' ``I don't agree with what he did but I think he's an excellent politician,'' Dorgin said. Ina Gibson of Roxbury said Frank's sexual preference should not cloud evaluations of his achievements. ``Barney Frank has been a very good politician,'' she said. ``I think he's done a good job. His personal life is his own business as far as I'm concerned.''

DOC.HEAD: Earthquake-Ravaged City Attempts to Rise From Ruins
DOC.TEXT: Every day since an earthquake ravaged this mountain resort July 16, photographer Washington Canilao goes to Burnham Park hoping someone will ask him for souvernir pictures. Few do. ``Business is slow,'' said Canilao, 39, a park photographer since 1966. ``The only people asking us for photographs are people who want pictures of their damaged homes. We are hoping some tourists would start promenading the park again.'' But officials fear it may take years for the city's tourism industry to recover. The devastating earthquake killed nearly 400 people in this city, where thousands of Filipinos spend their summers to escape the country's torrid tropical heat. Nationwide, more than 1,600 people died and about 1,000 others are missing. More than 90,000 people are homeless. For Baguio's 300,000 residents, the return to normalcy has been slow. There have been scattered incidents of looting and muggings of pedestrians at night along Baguio's Session Road, the main thoroughfare. Grocery and department stores are open only for a few hours a day. The main market is closed but vendors are scattered along many sidestreets. Thousands have left the city to live with relatives in the lowlands until aftershocks cease and conditions improve. Many residents also have remained outdoors, staying in tents or their cars for fear of the potential danger of aftershocks. Baguio, nearly a mile above sea level, is a city designed for fun and relaxation. After seizing the islands in 1898, the Americans searched for a mountain refuge from the sweltering tropical heat. They chose a site 130 miles north of Manila where the cool nights and sweet pine air reminded then of America's Catskills and Poconos. Daniel Hudson Burnham, who pioneered development of the skyscraper in Chicago and New York, designed the city, whose major park bears his name. The American presence remains. U.S. officials estimate about 1,500 American civilians live in Baguio. The city includes the U.S. Air Force's Camp John Hay, a rest and recreation area for the 40,000 American service members, Defense Department civilians and military dependents stationed in the Philippines. But the quake heavily damaged eight hotels, including the luxury Hyatt Terraces. ``The job of restoring Baguio is difficult,'' said city engineer Valentin Julian. ``It will take 10 to 15 years to rebuild Baguio and that depends on the availability of funds.'' Julian said about half the buildings and homes in the city reported major damage and another 40 percent suffered cracks and minor damage. About 15 percent of the buildings reporting major damage will have to be condemned. Johnvic Trinos, a Baguio resident, said the main problem facing the city is the lack of electricity. ``Restore electricity and business will follow suit,'' Trinos said. Power has been restored in areas near the city hall, hospitals and water stations but the rest of the city remained without electricity. Mayor Jaime Bugnosen said he is optimistic that the city will recover in a few years. ``I would not accept (Baguio) is dead or dying,'' Bugnosen said. ``We are all still alive here.''

DOC.HEAD: State, Rebels Accused of Human Rights Violations
DOC.TEXT: A human rights group has accused rebels and government troops of gross human rights violations in northeastern Uganda. The Uganda Human Rights Activists, in a report covering January to March, accused the warring parties of murder, rape, robbery and abductions. The Kampala-based group also accused the government of President Yoweri Museveni of making ``unlawful arrests and detention in unauthorized places.'' ``In a few cases that have been brought to court, the prosecution has not followed the due procedures,'' said the report, obtained Wednesday. The report, however, noted some progress, especially in the reduction of arrests by the military. ``Throughout the period under review, the civil police affected a greater proportion of arrests than in the past and as a result many people were charged before courts of law,'' the report said. The report accused the rebel Uganda People's Army of brutally killing at least 75 civilians in its largely northeastern Ugandan insurgency. The report urged the government to use unspecified but non-military solutions to solve problems in the East African nation. ``As it has been demonstrated elsewhere, civil strife can rarely be permanently subdued through violent means,'' the report said.

DOC.HEAD: Science Minister Says Israel Has Chemical Weapons
DOC.NOTE: Eds: AP style is to call Iraqi president Saddam on second reference, although in quoted material he is referred to as Hussein.
DOC.TEXT: Science Minister Yuval Neeman said today that Israel has chemical weapons and would use them if attacked by Iraq. The remarks were the most far-reaching by an Israeli leader on the issue. In the past, Israeli officials have always refused comment on whether Israel has chemical weapons, though the country was widely believed to have the arms. Neeman's statement intensified the war of words that was started when Iraqi President Saddam Hussein said he would destroy half of Israel with chemical weapons if attacked. ``In my opinion, we have an excellent response, and that is to threaten Hussein with the same merchandise,'' said Neeman, who also is head of Israel's space program. Neeman, a member of the ultra-rightist Tehiya Party, said any advanced nation has the capability to prepare chemical weapons. ``And if there is an enemy like this, it is possible to prepare a suitable response,'' he said on Israel radio. ``I have no doubt that also today we can respond to a threat like this.'' Defense Ministry spokesman Dan Weinreich refused comment. The 65-year-old Neeman has a long involvement with Israel's military and scientific establishments. He has served both as deputy director of army intelligence and scientific director of Israel's atomic energy program. Eliyahu Ben Elissar, head of Parliament's Defense and Foreign Affairs Committee, said Israel would retaliate harshly if attacked by Iraq. ``Iraq, after the first use of a missile, won't be the same Iraq any more. Hussein will lose control in a split second,'' the radio quoted Ben Elissar as saying in a speech Thursday night in Tel Aviv. The report did not elaborate. Neeman and Ben Elissar came under sharp criticism from Elazar Granot, head of the socialist Mapam Party, who said their words were as irresponsible as those of radical Arab leaders. ``The two have joined the crazy club of (Libyan leader) Moammar Ghadafi and Saddam Hussein. The time has come that the prime minister call them to order so that it becomes clear that not all government leaders have lost their minds,'' Granot was quoted as saying by the radio. Israel has been accusing the Iraqi leader of heightening tensions in the Middle East since April when he first issued the threat to use chemical weapons against Israel if it attacked his own country with atomic bombs. At the same time, Israeli officials have been threatening Iraq with harsh retaliation. Last week, Maj. Gen. Avihu Bin-Nun, commander of Israel's air force, said Israel would inflict severe damage on Iraq if it attacked the Jewish state.

DOC.HEAD: Scattered Rain for Some of Nation, Sunny Skies and Heat Seen for West
By The Associated Press
DOC.TEXT: Thunderstorms broke out today southern Iowa after flooding caused by eight inches of rain in the past two days and rain also fell in Boston and New York. Dry hot weather was forecast for the West, while scattered showers were expected over much of the nation. No major flooding damage was reported in Iowa, where more rain was expected today. Rising waters on the the Nishnabotna River in southwest Iowa were likely to crest today at about 28 feet, a level 12 feet above flood stage and approaching the record of 28.14 feet set on May 27, 1987. Heat and humidity brought by high pressure to the north was expected to prevail on the East Coast. Scattered showers were expected from North Carolina to southern New England. Heavy rain and hail were predicted for Minnesota and Wisconsin. Wet weather also was extending from South Dakota across Nebraska and Kansas. Thunderstorms also threatened Illinois, while showers were possible in Montana and Wyoming. High pressure pushing marine air offshore created a warming trend along the West Coast, with temperatures likely to reach the 90s and 100s in some areas. The high temperature for the nation Thursday was 110 degrees at Borrego Springs, Calif. DOC.HEAD: State Official Stops U.S.-Funded Program To Study Tigers
DOC.TEXT: A U.S.-funded project to study tigers in the wild has been canceled by a state official in southern India. Experts say the move threatens India's attempts to save its share of the world's biggest cat. The minister of forests for Karnataka also is trying to transfer an internationally recognized forest service officer involved in the research. Minister Basappa Basavalingappa said he wants ``a friend'' to replace Forest Service Officer K.M. Chinnappa, who was awarded a medal for wildlife conservation in 1989 by the New York Zoological Society. Observers in Bangalore, the state capital, say political motives were behind the minister's decision. Basavalingappa said he stopped the Indo-U.S. Tiger Project, funded by a $90,000 grant from the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, because it ``interferes with nature.'' ``If nature wants tigers to die out, who are we to save them?'' he said in an interview. ``Have you ever heard a tiger complain?'' An increasing number of rural Indians oppose the country's system of national parks. They accuse the government of depriving them of grazing land. A growing number of deaths from encounters with lions, tigers and elephants has fueled this anger. Last year at least 150 people were killed by wild animals. Ironically, the goal of the canceled project was to alleviate this tension. The project sought to answer such questions as how much land tigers need, how much prey they eat and how they mate, according to its director, K.U. Karanth, who heads the Indian Center for Wildlife Studies in Mysore, also in Karnataka. Armed with this knowledge, forest officers could better manage tigers, moving the cats from an over-populated reserve to a less crowded one or, in extreme cases, culling tigers, he said. Karanth said he had hoped his research could be used by India's Project Tiger, a string of 18 tiger reserves established in 1973. Although they have gotten high marks for protecting tigers, the reserves have been criticized for their failure to adequately manage the tiger population. Karanth said he would fight the minister's order in court but was not optimistic about winning. Melvin Sunquist, a tiger expert and professor of wildlife ecology at the University of Florida, said the minister's actions could set India's efforts to save its Royal Bengal tiger back decades. ``It's sad what politicians can do to wildlife,'' Sunquist said in a telephone interview from Florida. ``This was a key project.'' Sunquist, who spent a decade studying tigers in southern Nepal, helped start the Indian project. Royal Bengals account for more than half the world's estimated 5,000 tigers. Only the massive Siberian tiger, which can weigh 800 pounds and stretch for 10 feet, is bigger. The government claims there are 4,200 tigers in the country, but wildlife experts say this figure is at least 25 percent too high. Tiger census takers in India count paw prints, not considered a reliable technique. Basavalingappa canceled the project at Nagarahole National Forest, a stunning mixture of teak forests, bamboo groves, swamps and gorges, on July 12. The minister also ordered Forest Officer Chinnappa, known for protecting the park from poachers, transferred to a desk job. Chinnappa, who has run Nagarahole for the past 20 years, said he will fight the transfer in court. Basavalingappa began attacking the research project in May following the deaths of five tigers within three months in the park. At the time researchers in the park had just begun capturing tigers and putting radio collars around their necks to monitor their movements. Basavalingappa blamed the collars for the deaths. But reports by the state Ministry of Forests and the central government's Ministry of Environment and Forests concluded the deaths were unrelated to the project. Indeed, only one of the five tigers had been collared.

DOC.HEAD: Grateful Dead Keyboard Player Brent Mydland Found Dead in Home
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Mydland pronounced MID-lend
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto NY22 of July 26
DOC.TEXT: Brent Mydland, keyboard player, singer and songwriter since 1979 for the psychedelic rock band the Grateful Dead, was found dead in his home. He was 37. Friends discovered Mydland's body Thursday in the bedroom of his home in Lafayette, a suburb 25 miles east of San Francisco, said Sgt. Richard Terry of the Contra Costa County Coroner's office. It was not clear when or how Mydland died, but there was no sign of foul play, Terry said. An autopsy was scheduled for today. Mydland had returned Tuesday from a three week national tour with the band, Terry said. ``We lost a brother, and we are very devastated,'' Grateful Dead spokesman Dennis McNally said. Surviving band members met Thursday night ``to talk, to grieve and to figure out what to do next,'' McNally said. Tickets already have been sold for Grateful Dead shows in August and September in California, Ohio, Pennsylvania and New York City and in October in Sweden, West Germany, France and England. The Grateful Dead formed in 1965 and were at the forefront of the psychedelic counterculture movement in San Francisco. Among their better known songs are ``Truckin','' ``Casey Jones'' and ``Touch of Grey.'' Known for their diverse live sets and spontaneous ``jams,'' the Grateful Dead today retain a strong following of fans known as ``Deadheads.'' Many fans follow the band from show to show and trade tapes of concerts, which the band lets them record. Mydland joined the band in April 1979, replacing keyboardist Keith Godchaux, who died a year later in an auto accident. Godchaux had replaced keyboardist Ron ``Pig Pen'' McKernan, who died of cirrhosis of the liver at age 27 in 1973. Mydland was born in Germany to American parents stationed there with the military and grew up in the San Francisco area. As a teen-ager, he played with small local rock 'n' roll bands. He worked with the group Batdorf and Rodney in the early 1970s, then joined the Los Angeles-based rock band Silver. He joined the Grateful Dead after a stint with rhythm guitarist and vocalist Bob Weir's side band Bobby and the Midnites. At first Mydland had played in the shadow of the other more famous band members, including lead guitarist and vocalist Jerry Garcia. But he developed a greater presence in recent years, writing more songs and helping the band's harmonies with what McNally called his ``rough, bluesy textured voice.'' John Barlow, who had collaborated with Mydland on most of his songs, said, ``Brent could pick his way through anything immediately, which meant he had the special requirement it was going to take to walk into the Dead overnight. ``He was musically central to the band, but he was so good at what he did that he was able to become fundamental to everything that the band was doing musically without it being immediately apparent to the audience,'' Barlow said. Tunes Mydland wrote include ``Far From Me'' and the environmental ballad ``We Can Run (But We Can't Hide),'' used recently in an Audubon Society video. Most recently, Mydland frequently performed his ``I Will Take You Home,'' a lullaby written for his two young daughters. He is survived by his wife, Lisa, his daughters and his parents, who live in the Sacramento area.

DOC.HEAD: Police To Begin Digging for Buried Bodies in Drug Cult Slayings
DOC.TEXT: Police said they will try to dig up the bodies of as many as 41 victims of a drug cult that practiced human sacrifice in a remote mountain region of northern Mexico for five years. Juan Granados Martinez, the federal judicial police chief in Nayarit state, said Thursday his force and police in Durango state planned to begin digging today in a border area. Police on Tuesday arrested 14 members of the alleged cult. The nine men and five youths were charged with homicide, arms possession, criminal association and drug-related offenses. Nayarit district attorney's investigator Jose Fernando Armas Hernandez said Thursday authorities learned that at least 41 men, women and children may have been slain by group members in macabre rituals practiced since 1983. Police said cult members believed human sacrifice would protect their illegal drug-related activities. Armas said police found a leather quiver with 41 arrows, apparently dipped in blood, that alleged cult member Esteban Mendoza Cervantes claimed represented the spirits of each of the sacrificed humans. Cervantes, 19, was allegedly the chief aide of Olayo Soto Soto, accused of being the ``head sorcerer'' of the devil-worshipping cult. Soto denied the accusations Thursday in an interview at police headquarters in Tepic, the capital of Nayarit. ``Those are rumors and lies of the authorities,'' Soto told The Associated Press. The group was arrested while cultivating marijuana plantations in the Horse Hill region on the border of Nayarit and Durango states, about 450 miles northwest of Mexico City, police said. Cult members sacrificed their victims before an altar consisting of a 16-inch-high clay monkey in offerings to a deity called ``El Amigo'' _ ``The Friend'' _ police said. Granados said the group claimed to be practicing a version of Palo Mayombe, a religion that originated in the Congo and sometimes uses human skulls in its rituals. He said the occult rites were practiced in caves on remote hillsides where police discovered apparent cult material, including a statuette of the Virgin Mary with her face replaced by a skull. Police said they also found a foot-long dagger, a .32-caliber hunting rifle and .38-caliber pistol. The dagger may have been used by Soto, who allegedly stabbed the victims in the back of the neck to kill them, Armas said. In addition to Soto and Cervantes police idendified those in custody as Jorge Mendoza Cumplido, Geronimo Rodriguez Flores, Arturo Mendoza Medina, Prudencio Cervantes Soto, Maclovio Soto Mendoza, Cirilo Rodriguez Cervantes, Eliseo Rodriguez Soto, Mariano Soto Flores, Samuel Soto Flores, Jose Rodriguez Soto and Epifanio Soto Gurrola. In an earlier drug-cult case police in April 1989 found 15 bodies buried on a ranch near the city of Matamoros across the U.S.-Mexico border from Brownsville, Texas. Four members of that group are on trial in Mexico City and Matamoros. Alleged group leader Adolfo de Jesus Constanzo and his bodyguard died of gunshot wounds as police closed in on them in a Mexico City apartment in May last year.

DOC.HEAD: Last Year's Economic Growth Slowest Since 1982
With PM-GNP
DOC.TEXT: Economic activity last year was significantly weaker than previously thought because the government badly overestimated the strength in personal incomes, the Commerce Department said today. The department said the broadest measure of economic health _ the gross national product _ grew just 2.5 percent in 1989, instead of the 3 percent previously estimated. That put economic growth at its slowest pace since a drop of 2.5 percent in the recession year of 1982. The government also put out new estimates for growth in 1988 and 1987. It said the GNP grew 4.5 percent in 1988, just slightly above the 4.4 percent previously estimated. It put growth in 1987 at 3.4 percent, down from a 3.7 percent previous estimate. But it was the 1989 change that was likely to raise eyebrows. The government blamed its mistake on overestimating by $57.9 billion the amount Americans earned in wages and salaries. The initial estimate is based on a partial sample of businesses while the revision takes into account more complete data gathered from the country's roughly 6 million businesses. The more complete data is used when the government makes its once-a-year revisions to GNP data every July. While the full details of the Commerce Department revisions were made public only today, the information was made available earlier to economists at the Office and Management and Budget. The big drop in incomes, which also would affect taxes, was a major factor behind the administration's dramatic increase in the budget deficit. It boosted the 1991 deficit to $169 billion, up from an estimate of $100.5 billion made last January.

DOC.HEAD: Two Die as Air Force Jets Crash In Death Valley
DOC.TEXT: Two fighter-bombers carrying U.S. and West German officers collided over the salt flats of central Death Valley, killing two pilots, officials said. Two other pilots, including a West German, ejected safely after the Thursday morning collision, said Inyo County sheriff's Lt. Bill Lutze. The Phantom F-4E fighter-bombers were on a basic fighting-maneuvers training mission when the collision occurred, said Capt. James Tynan. The cause of the crash has not been determined. Both planes were stationed at George Air Force Base, about 70 miles northeast of Los Angeles. The names of the dead fliers were being withheld early today. Sgt. Rick Corral identified the survivors as Capt. Wade J. Lujan, a pilot assigned to the 20th Tactical Fighter Training Squadron at George AFB, and Capt. Roland Molter, a West German flier undergoing training at George. Lujan and Molter, who managed to eject from their F-4E, were treated for cuts and bruises and returned to George, said Capt. James Tynan. The bodies of the dead pilots were found a short distance from wreckage strewn on the valley floor. Tynan said he didn't know if they had ejected from their plane before the crash. Thursday's crash was the second fatal incident this year involving the Vietnam War-era Phantoms based at George AFB. In June, an F-4E crashed into a remote area of California's San Bernardino County, about 60 miles west of Las Vegas. Two California National Guardsmen died in the crash.

DOC.HEAD: A Chronology of Recent Red Army Faction Attacks
DOC.TEXT: Here is a list of recent attacks blamed on the leftist Red Army Faction terrorist group: June 27, 1990: Hans Neusel, a state secretary in the Interior Ministry escapes with slight injuries when a bomb explodes on a road near Bonn as he drives to work. Nov. 30, 1989: Deutsche Bank chief Alfred Herrhausen is killed when his car is blown up by a roadside bomb in Bad Homburg, near Frankfurt, as he drives to work. Sept. 20, 1988: Shots are fired in Bonn at Hans Tietmeyer, state secretary in the Finance Minister. He is unhurt in what authorities say is a bungled kidnapping attempt. Oct. 10, 1986: Diplomat Gerold von Braunmuehl, a top aide of Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher, is assasinated on a Bonn street. July 9, 1986: A bomb attack kills Siemens manager Kalr Heinz Beckurts and his driver near Munich. Aug. 8, 1985: A bomb attack at the U.S. Rhein-Main Air Base near Frankfurt kills two Air Force personnel. A U.S. soldier is murdered several hours earlier near Wiesbaden. Feb. 1, 1985: Ernst Zimmermann, chairman of the Motoren und Turbinen-Union industrial concern is fatally injured by assassins at his home near Munich. Sept. 15, 1981: U.S. General Frederik Kroesen narrowly escapes a rocket attack in Heidelberg. Aug. 31, 1981: 18 people are injured in a bomb attack at the U.S. Air Force headquarters in Ramstein. Oct. 18, 1977: West German commandoes storm a Lufthansa airliner hijacked by Palestinian terrorists to force the release of West German terrorist Andreas Baader. Shortly afterward, Baader and two inmates, Gudrun Ensslin and Jan-Carl Raspe, commit suicide in prison. Oct. 18, 1977: Hanns Martin Schleyer, head of the employers association, is killed by his kidnappers. He had been seized on Sept. 5, 1977. July 30, 1977: Three terrorists assassinate Dresdner Bank spokesman Juergen Ponto near Frankfurt. Apirl 7, 1977: Federal Prosecutor Siegfried Buback and two bodyguards are shot and killed in Karlsruhe. April 24, 1975: Terrorists break into West German embassy in Stockholm and set off explosives. Two diplomats and two terrorists die of injuries. Nov. 10, 1974: West Berlin judge Guenter von Drenkmann, the top judge in the city, is killed in his apartment.

DOC.HEAD: Diplomats, Witnesses Say Government Soldiers Kill Civilians
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 7 grafs to UPDATE with report on number of refugees from fighting, offer of EC aid. Pickup 6th, `The suspects...'
DOC.TEXT: EDITORS NOTE: The following is based on a pool report from journalists in Monrovia, including Associated Press correspondent Michael Goldsmith.

Government troops have killed civilians and dumped their bodies in the sea as rebels advanced on the city center, where President Samuel Doe remained barricaded in his mansion, witnesses and diplomats said. The rebels could be seen Thursday trying to battle their way over a bridge into the heart of Monrovia, the capital of this West African nation. The rebels, who began their offensive in December, accuse the government of corruption and human rights abuses. But their insurgency has become a tribal war between supporters of Doe and backers of the rebels. At least 375,000 Liberians have fled the fighting into neighboring Guinea, Ivory Coast and Sierra Leone, the office of the U.N. High Commissioner for Refugees said today in Geneva. The European Community today gave more than $330,000 for medical aid to help about 30,000 of the refugees in the Ivory Coast. In Monrovia, soldiers of Doe's Krahn tribe killed at least two dozen civilians who were taken from their houses, from a hospital ward and from lodgings near the beleaguered city's one remaining airstrip, said witnesses and diplomats, who spoke on condition of anonymity. The suspects, some of whom were shot while tied back to back with their hands bound behind them, were Gio or Mano tribesmen suspected of supporting the rebels, they said. Some victims were taken overnight to a beach near the city's exclusive Mamba Point district where they were summarily shot or slashed to death with machetes, the witnesses said. Their bodies and the rotting remains of previous victims were dumped into the sea nearby. The bodies could be seen bobbing in the surf. The ambassadors of the five European Economic Community nations represented in Liberia _ France, Britain, Italy, Germany and Spain _ expressed ``horror and disgust at the tribal killings of innocent civilians being carried out by both sides in the present conflict.'' Their statement said there was ``ample evidence that government soldiers are continuing to murder Gios and Manos, more than 100 of whom were yesterday taken from centers in Monrovia, while the National Patriotic Front are murdering Krahn and Mandingos.'' ``If Liberia as a nation is to retain the respect of the rest of the world these killings must cease forthwith,'' the statement said. In Washington, State Department spokesman Richard Boucher said Doe still had not asked the United States for help in leaving his country. The spokesman said insurgent troops, believed to be those of rebel leader Charles Taylor, moved into the city Thursday morning after heavy fighting northeast of the capital on Wednesday night. Other rebel forces, presumably those of rival rebel leader Prince Johnson, moved into the city Thursday morning amid small-arms fire, Boucher said. Johnson is believed to have split with Taylor sometime in the past three months, and some diplomats say his army is now stronger than Taylor's National Patriotic Front. Despite his first name, Johnson is not known to have any aristocratic background. Discipline among the estimated 1,500 remaining troops loyal to Doe has broken down, and a Western diplomat said many were drugged. But some diplomats had also dismissed Doe's troops more than a month ago, predicting they would flee as soon as rebels got anywhere near the city. Some government units have continued to fight, blocking Taylor's main rebel force in the city's eastern suburbs. Earlier this week, a rival faction led by Johnson surprised government troops and fought its way into the downtown area briefly before being turned back. More than 8,000 refugees were camped without food or water in a U.S. compound near the American Embassy, and many reacted with terror when security guards passed word that soldiers intended to enter to check identities and search for rebels. A group of about two dozen soldiers blocked the path of three foreign reporters covering the conflict and seized their car without explanation. Some ordered the reporters to leave the city center. ``It is not safe. There is nobody in control here,'' one soldier said.

DOC.HEAD: One Officer Killed, One Seriously Hurt By Drug Suspects in Jacksonville, Fla.
DOC.TEXT: One undercover policeman was killed and another seriously injured as they pursued two drug suspects into an apartment and were shot at near point-blank range, authorities said. The two gunmen escaped and were still on the loose today despite a manhunt by dozens of officers and police dogs that continued throughout the night, said Jacksonville Sheriff's spokesman Asa Higgs. The shootout occured late Thursday as undercover officers Warren C. Sanders and Kirk P. Clark investigated a series of robberies and shootings in an apartment complex near Jacksonville University, police said. Sanders and Clark saw the two suspects engage in a drug transaction and called for backup units before getting out of their unmarked car and chasing after the gunmen, Higgs said. The suspects kicked open an apartment door and rushed inside in hopes of eluding the officers. Residents of the apartment went out the back and were gone by the time the officers arrived. ``When our officers went inside is when the gun battle started,'' Higgs said. ``We know Clark returned fire. I don't know if the suspects were hit.'' Sanders, 33, was shot in the chest and was pronounced dead later Thursday at Baptist Medical Center, said Sgt. Steve Weintraub. The bullet apparently pierced his bullet-proof vest. Officer Kirk P. Clark, 30, survived at least four gunshots to his arms and legs and remained in serious but stable condition today at University Medical Center, authorities said. No bystanders were hurt, police said.

DOC.HEAD: Social Democrats Withdraw Threat to Leave Government
DOC.TEXT: East Germany's second-biggest political party withdrew its threat to resign from the government today, averting a political crisis over the process of German unification. The left-leaning Social Democrats threatened Tuesday to leave the coalition government of Prime Minister Lothar de Maiziere today unless a dispute over united German elections was reached. The Liberal Party resigned Tuesday over the dispute. With compromise now in sight on the political feud, the Liberals planned to meet to reconsider their decision. Meanwhile, Social Democrat party chief Wolfgang Thierse said his party would remain in de Maiziere's government, even though a key difference remained over how German elections should be held. The Social Democrats and the conservative Christian Demcrats of de Maiziere, the biggest party in East Germany, agree that the two German nations will vote as a single electorate for a united Parliament on Dec. 2. Under that plan, East Germany would dissolve itself Dec. 1. The Christian Democrats and several smaller political parties had demanded that East Germany remain a nation at the time of balloting so that two elections could be held. That would give smaller parties a better chance of winning seats in Parliament. De Maiziere and the Christian Democrats backed down from that demand in recent days. However, disagreement still exists over what percentage of the vote a party must get to be represented in Parliament. Under West German law, parties need 5 percent of the vote to be represented in Parliament. No minimum is required in East Germany. The Social Democrats want the 5 percent limit, while the Christian Democrats and several smaller parties sought to lower it. De Maiziere has said special accomodations should be made to ensure that smaller East German parties have a chance to be represented in a big new all-German Parliament. The Social Democrats in both East and West Germany believe the lower limit would hurt them by allowing smaller leftist groups to get in Parliament and splinter the left-leaning vote. Under one proposed compromise, smaller parties could run on the ballots of larger parties. That would allow allied parties to share ballot space. That could hurt the East German Communists, who country's No. 3 party, because they have no allies. Under another idea, the 5 percent limit would be mandated for each nation, rather than Germany as a whole. That means an East German party would only have to win 5 percent of the vote in what is now East Germany, rather than 5 percent of the total vote. Another idea would allow any party with 5 percent of the vote in each of the 11 individual states in West Germany and five in East Germany to win representation. The complicated argument that centered essentially on whether East Germany should dissolve one day before or immediately after elections was basically political manuevering by parties seeking the most favorable election conditions. There was much speculation that West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl, who longs to be leader of a unified Germany, was prodding de Maiziere into insisting on separate elections to boost the West German leader's chances.

DOC.HEAD: Asthma Fatality Rate Increasing; Infections, Air Quality Cited
With PM-CDC-AIDS -Dentist, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Nearly 10 million Americans now suffer from asthma, and the death rate from it has increased more than 30 percent in seven years, according to a new report from federal health researchers. The national Centers for Disease Control reported Thursday that between 1980 and 1987, the death rate from asthma in the United States rose from 1.3 per 100,000 population to 1.7. The number of actual asthma deaths rose from 2,891 in 1980 to 4,360 in 1987, the latest year for which statistical analysis is available. The increase in asthma fatalities comes as more and more Americans suffer from the chronic disease, characterized by difficulty in breathing. An estimated 9.6 million people in the United States were affected by asthma in 1987, or about 4 percent of the population, compared with 6.8 million in 1980, the CDC said in its weekly report. The death rate for asthma was ``consistently higher'' for blacks than for whites, the CDC said. For blacks, the asthma fatality rate increased 44 percent from 1980 to 1987 _ from 2.5 per 100,000 to 3.6 _ while the white fatality rate increased 36 percent, from 1.1 to 1.5. Death rates were higher for older people, with the highest rate of asthma death _ 7.9 per 100,000 in 1987 _ for people 65 and older. A number of factors may contribute to the increases in asthma deaths and cases, the CDC said. They include exposure to infections and other ``triggers'' for bronchial constriction, health-care factors and air quality. The agency called on health care workers to promote ``timely and aggressive medical treatment'' for asthma.

DOC.HEAD: Senior Official Injured By Red Army Faction Bomb
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 16 grafs to UPDATE with more background on roundup of Red Army Faction suspects in East Germany, most recent previous attack on government official. Pickup 14th graf pvs, `Neusel later..'
DOC.TEXT: A roadside bomb blast triggered by a beam of light injured a senior West German official today, and the Red Army Faction terrorist group claimed responsibility. Hans Neusel, the state secretary of the Interior Ministry, escaped with only minor injuries, though his car was wrecked. Neusel, whose ministry is in charge of law enforcement, was taken to the hospital but released a short time later and returned to the scene of the bombing, a highway on the outskirts of Bonn. He later told reporters he was happy to be alive. Today's bombing was the first Red Army Faction attack since eight long-sought fugitives _ reputed to be top members of the group _ were captured in East Germany in recent weeks.
