The Red Army Faction has been responsible for a series of killings and bomb attacks in West Germany in the last two decades. The eight reputed members of the group captured in East Germany had been living there under assumed names, some for as long as 10 years. Some say they had been granted sanctuary by East Germany's former Communist government. West German officials had believed the roundup had put a serious dent in the group's ability to carry out attacks. Today's explosion demolished Neusel's silver BMW sedan, shattering the windows, ripping apart the interior, smashing its doors and tearing open the hood and the trunk lid. The blast blew a large hole in the highway and damaged the guardrail. Officials said Neusel probably escaped serious injury because he was driving, and the bomb went off on the car's passenger side. He suffered only minor cuts. The Interior Ministry said the 62-year-old official had no security detail, and his automobile was not equipped with any protective equipment such as armor plating or bulletproof glass. West German television said Neusel's driver was on vacation. Police said a letter claiming responsibility in the name of the Red Army Faction was found near the site of the attack and that it appeared to be genuine. Hans-Juergen Foerster, spokesman for the federal prosecutor's office, said the letter carried the Red Army Faction symbol, a red star superimposed by a machine gun. It said the attack was carried out by the ``Jose Manuel Sevillano commando.'' Foerster said Sevillano was a convicted member of the Spanish terrorist group GRAPO who died in May after a six-month hunger strike. Foerster said the bomb was triggered by the car crossing a light beam. He said the devise used today was the same as the one used in a bomb attack that killed Siemens manager Karl Heinz Beckurts in July 1986 near Munich. The attack also resembled the November killing of Deutsche Bank chief Alfred Herrhausen, whose car was blown up by a bomb planted by the Red Army Faction near Frankfurt, he said. The most recent previous terrorist attack on a government official came in September 1988, when shots were fired at Hans Tietmeyer, a state secretary in the Finance Ministry. Authorities said Tietmeyer apparently had been the target of a kidnapping attempt. Neusel later spoke with reporters about the attack, telling them: ``You can understand that I am especially happy to be able to be with you today.'' Speaking in a calm, unemotional voice, described the impact of the bomb blast, saying, ``Naturally the sensation of shock was there.'' He said he believed the bombers must have had an observation post near the site of the attack, but told authorities earlier he saw no attackers. Neusel called on the Red Army Faction to cease its long campaign of terror. ``I appeal emphatically for you to give this up,'' he said. ``Even if you were successful, how would that have changed the fact that we are a free democracy?'' The federal prosecutor's office in Karlsruhe, which is in charge of investigating terrorist attacks, took over the investigation. Neusel, the No. 2 official at the Interior Ministry, is in charge of domestic security and police affairs.

DOC.HEAD: Storm Arthur Passes Haiti, Heads Toward Jamaica
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 4 grafs to UPDATE with storm downgraded to depression. Picks up 5th graf pvs: `Storm watches ...'
DOC.TEXT: Tropical Storm Arthur dropped heavy rains on the southern coast of Haiti but weakened to a depression today as it swirled toward Jamaica with top winds of 35 mph, forecasters said. A tropical storm warning was discontinued for Haiti after the brunt of Arthur all but bypassed the island, according to the National Hurricane Center in suburban Coral Gables. At 8:30 a.m. EDT, the depression was centered near latitude 16.5 north and longitude 76 west, about 100 miles east-southeast of Kingston, Jamaica. The storm was moving west at about 20-25 mph. Arthur's top sustained winds dropped from a high of 70 mph to 35 mph Thursday before building to 40 mph late Thursday night, but satellite pictures this morning indicated a second spate of weakening. To be defined as a tropical storm, a weather disturbance must have sustained winds of at least 39 mph. Storm watches for the southern coasts of Puerto Rico and the island of Hispaniola, shared by Haiti and the Dominican Republic, were lifted by Thursday afternoon. Strong winds and heavy rains battered Puerto Rico but cuased no serious damage and no injuries, civil defense officials said. Arthur, the 1990 Atlantic hurricane season's first named storm, grew from the season's second depression, which formed Sunday in the open Atlantic. It crossed the southern Windward Islands and entered the southeastern Caribbean early Wednesday. Top winds of 55 mph were reported on Grenada. The hurricane season runs from June 1 to Nov. 30.

DOC.HEAD: Mandela Denies Existance of Anti-Government Plot By ANC Members
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs grafs 5-13 pvs, `There is...' with 8 grafs to UPDATE with ANC spokesman saying de Klerk asked that Communist chief be removed from ANC delegation. Pickup 14th pvs, `The leader...'
DOC.TEXT: Nelson Mandela today denied government claims that ANC members had plotted to overthrow President F.W. de Klerk but said he would meet again with de Klerk to discuss the allegations. South Africa's police chief said today he expected more arrests of ANC and Communist activists for stockpiling weapons if talks fail on power-sharing. De Klerk met for more than two hours with Mandela on Thursday night, apparently seeking to persuade him that Communists within the African National Congress have been plotting a coup. News reports said de Klerk presented police evidence of a such a conspiracy to Mandela but that the ANC deputy president wasn't convinced by it. ``There is no plot as far as we're concerned,'' Mandela said during an appearance today at a nursery school in the township of Soweto. He said he would meet with de Klerk again Wednesday to discuss the government accusations. ANC spokesman Pallo Jordan told a news conference that during the meeting with Mandela, de Klerk had ``expressed the government's preference for the exclusion'' of Communist Party leader Joe Slovo from Aug. 6 negotiations between the ANC and the government's Cabinet. Jordan said the ANC's national executive committee would discuss de Klerk's request at its meetings Saturday through Monday. He said Mandela had no power to remove someone from the ANC's delegation, but ``he can make suggestions.'' The ANC is allied to the South African Communist Party, with many senior Communists, including Slovo, holding top ANC posts. The newspaper Business Day today reported that police had seized records of a Communist meeting at which Slovo allegedly said the party would not be bound by any cease-fire between the ANC and the government. Another senior ANC official, Mac Maharaj, is among 40 ANC members who have been detained in recent weeks by police under the Internal Security Act. The act allows police to hold detainees indefinitely in solitary confinement, without access to lawyers, and to interrogate suspects until they provide ``satisfactory answers.'' The country's police chief, Gen. Johan van der Merwe, said the detentions had yielded considerable evidence of a conspirarcy. In an interview with the state-run South African Broadcasting Corp., van der Merwe said more arrests ``were likely'' but gave no details. A police statement said the militants had been arrested recently because of ``information about an alleged conspiracy by the (Communist Party) and the ANC's military wing to overthrow the government by force if negotiations with the government failed.'' The leader of the opposition pro-apartheid Conservative Party, Andries Treurnicht, demanded the government end talks with the ANC. In a statement today, Treurnicht said the ANC had no interest in a political settlement, but was determined to seize power. The talks Aug. 6 are aimed at removing barriers to full-scale negotiations on ending white-minority rule. The ANC is insisting the government release all political prisoners and other conditions, while the government wants the ANC to agree to a cease-fire. Mandela says the ANC would accept a cease-fire when its conditions for talks are met. The ANC's guerrilla campaign is virtually at a standstill, but the ANC sees a cease-fire as a bargaining chip to force concessions. Communist Party spokesman Jeremy Cronin told reporters Thursday that the arrests were part of a government effort to derail a rally Sunday marking the party's emergence as a legal political group after years being banned.

DOC.HEAD: Rangel: Armed Services Committee Probing 1989 Panama Invasion
DOC.NOTE: Eds: subs last graf of first item The PDF, to CORRECT description of Dignity Battalions.
DOC.TEXT: The House Armed Services Committee is investigating how many Panamanians were killed during the 1989 invasion to oust Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega, according to a letter released by Rep. Charles Rangel, D-N.Y. The letter, dated July 13 and released Thursday, asked the Center for Constitutional Rights in New York for information on the extent of Panama's military and civilian casualties. It was signed by Rep. Les Aspin, D-Wis., chairman of the Armed Services Committee. ``I would appreciate your providing to the committee any figures in your possession on Panamanian casualties and all supporting documentation that would substantiate those figures,'' Aspin wrote. He also asked for the names, addresses and-or telephone numbers of any Panamanian nationals or U.S. military personnel who may have aided in the group's rsearch. ``This committee is fully prepared to protect their confidentiality and will abide by any reasonable restrictions,'' Aspin added. The committee is trying to differentiate between Panamanian Defense Force dead, Dignity Battalion dead and civilian deaths, according to the letter. The PDF was Noriega's militia; Dignity Battalions were paramilitary forces that supported Noriega.
DOC.HEAD: Fans Recalled After Blades Found to Separate From Motor
DOC.TEXT: A ceiling fan distributor says it is recalling 10,000 of the fans because of a defect that can cause the blades to separate from the motor. ``Builders Square said these ceiling fans are equipped with metal fan blade bracket holders which may break, allowing the blade to separate from the motor while the fan is in use,'' the Consumer Product Safety Commission said Thursday. The company has received seven customer complaints, one reporting a minor injury, involving its fans, the agency said. The voluntary recall involves eight models of 52-inch ``Bay Breeze'' ceiling fans distributed by Builders Square, Inc. of San Antonio. The fans, sold with and without lights, were distributed nationwide from October 1989 until two months ago. Consumers should stop using the fans and return them to any Builders Square store for a refund or call the company at 1-800-634-5949.
DOC.HEAD: Consumer Groups Push For Recall Of Some All-Terrain Vehicles
DOC.TEXT: Two consumer groups want the government to ban use of all-terrain vehicles by children and say people who bought them for anyone under 16 should get their money back. The groups said Thursday an agreement between the Consumer Product Safety Commission and ATV manufacturers has failed ``to adequately reduce the risk to consumers.'' ``Since the core problems is that children lack the developmental skills and maturity needed to operate any ATV safely, children must be kept off these vehicles,'' said the Consumer Federation of America and the U.S. Public Interest Research Group in a petition to be submitted to the commission. In 1988, five ATV manufacturers _ Honda, Kawasaki, Suzuki, Yamaha and Polaris _ agreed to ban sales of three-wheel ATVs in the United States for 10 years. The consumer groups want a permanent ban on three-wheelers. The manufacturers also agreed to restrict sales of adult-size four-wheelers with engines 90 cubic centimeters or greater for use by people over 16. ``Our nationwide survey of ATV dealers and a separate CPSC survey both found that ATV dealers are willing to sell adult-size ATVs to children,'' added Lucinda Sikes, an attorney with public interest research group. Surveys last year by that group and the commission found that more than half of ATV dealers were ignoring the sales restrictions and adult-sized vehicles could be obtained for young children. However, the agency said earlier this month that three of the manufacturers had further agreed to conduct routine dealer inspections and discipline dealers, including termination of franchises, to ensure compliance with the earlier decree.

DOC.HEAD: Planned Korean Border Crossing Scrapped Again in Dispute
DOC.TEXT: North and South Korea failed to agree today on conditions to permit five North Koreans to cross the border, and the event was canceled for the second time in two days. South Korean authorities said the five had left the border village of Panmunjom and they did not expect them to return. The dispute increased the hostility between the nations, just as they were planning an unprecedented meeting of prime ministers to ease tensions. Today was the 37th anniversary of the truce that ended fighting in the 1950-53 Korean War, which started when Communist North Korea invaded the South. U.S. troops have been stationed in South Korea to deter further Communist aggression, and many radicals consider their presence an obstacle to reunifying the peninsula. It was divided in 1945. Outside the main U.S. military installation near central Seoul, 13 radical students yelling ``Withdraw U.S. troops!'' were arrested today after they staged a protest. In another rally at a city park, 200 radical students and dissidents chanted ``Yankee go home!'' They demanded the withdrawal of the 43,000 American soldiers in South Korea and nuclear weapons they claim are kept in Korea. South Korean officials said it was probably a coincidence the five North Koreans tried to cross the border again on the armistice anniversary. The five were invited to Seoul to participate in a two-day meeting aimed at planning a joint North-South unification rally. It would have been the first civilian crossing approved by both nations since 1985. Both governments must approve such crossings because the border is heavily guarded and inaccessible to average citizens. The dispute involved the northerners' accomodations during their planned visit. South Korea's government demanded they stay in a Seoul hotel, citing security. The civilians wanted to stay with South Korean dissidents. North Korea charged the South with trying to block plans for the joint rally. The South charged the North with purposely creating a controversy over the arrangements. The crossing originally was planned Thursday and was expected to coincide with the signing of a historic agreement to have the prime ministers of North and South Korea meet for the first time in an effort to improve relations. Those talks are scheduled Sept. 4-7 in Seoul, but comments by the North indicated they could be canceled because of the border controversy. North Korea's chief delegate at the signing, Paik Nam Jun, warned Thursday that if the two nations experienced ``difficulty'' in setting up the joint unification rally, ``relations of the South and North would further deteriorate.'' He said, ``It would have an irreparably bad impact on the holding of the high-level talks.'' North Korea said today: ``Your insincere attitude has set a bad precedent in relations of the North and South and will create regrettable consequences.''

DOC.HEAD: Burma Delays Transfer of Power to Pro-Democracy Forces
DOC.TEXT: Burma's military rulers today announced more delays in turning over power to the pro-democracy party that won elections two months ago, and a diplomat said troops were deployed in the capital. The government warned it would ``take action against any attempt to adopt any interim constitution and government.'' A Western diplomat said large numbers of soldiers were patrolling Rangoon, the capital, in what he said was ``obviously an attempt to prevent any reaction'' to the government's announcement. The diplomat, reached by telephone from Thailand, called today's moves the clearest indication yet that the army intends to keep its grip on power despite its election loss to the opposition National League for Democracy. ``In effect it is an attempt to negate or destroy or deprive the election of all meaning,'' said the diplomat, who spoke on condition of anonymity. The May 27 parliamentary elections were Burma's first free vote in 30 years, and the opposition won overwhelmingly. But the miltitary rulers have refused to set a timetable for turning over power, and have refused to free the National League for Democracy's top leader from house arrest. Earlier, the military authorities had said that the only barrier to transferring power was the drafting of the constitution by the Parliament. Today, though, the government said it would convene a national conference to set up guidelines for the newly elected Parliament to draft the new constitution, then hold a national vote on the draft constitution. ``Only when the people approve the constitution by the referendum, the (military government) will adopt the same as the national constitution,'' said government spokesman Kyaw Sann. He did not say how long these steps were expected to take. In the past two weeks, there have been small anti-government demonstrations in Rangoon and the central city of Mandalay, the Western diplomat said. A demonstration in the capital on Monday _ one of the largest such rallies in recent months _ drew about 150 youths, he said. Some protesters were reported to have been arrested. The government's announcement came one day before the opening of a conference at which the League was to consider the drafting of a new constitution and the transition to democratic rule. The party seeks an early transfer of power and the release of its leader, Aung San Suu Kyi, who has been under house arrest for more than a year. Authorities accused her of subversion, but have not filed formal charges. The diplomat said the government announcement appeared deliberately timed to preempt the National League's conference. ``Certainly this is going to increase the pressure on the (League) to respond in some fashion,'' he said. The current military government came to power in 1988, when soldiers killed thousands of people demonstrating for democracy.

DOC.HEAD: Truck Driver Charged in Accident That Killed Eight
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throughout with further details of accident, including identities of some victims, status of charges, and truck driver's explanation.
DOC.TEXT: A truck driver was charged with negligent homicide after his rig plowed into cars driving slowly through a highway construction site, sparking a fiery wreck that killed eight people, police said today. Manuel Cruzado Jr., 25, of Buffalo, N.Y., escaped serious injury and was being held on $60,000 bond early today at the Braxton County Jail, State Police Sgt. Doug Bryant said. Cruzado's big-rig truck carrying a load of eight automobiles came around a curve on Interstate 79 near this central West Virginia town, roared past the road crew flagman, bounced off the side of a bridge and caromed into two cars early Thursday evening, police and firefighters said. He told police his brakes failed. Eight people in two cars, including two children, were killed. Six bodies initially were found in the wreckage, and Cruzado was charged and arraigned on six counts late Thursday night. Two more bodies were found early today. Braxton County Prosecutor William Martin said he does not plan to file any more charges against Cruzado until all of the victims are identified. The state medical examiner's office expects to have all the bodies identified by later today. Cruzado's carrier slammed into the back of two cars at the bottom of a mile-long incline where the Department of Highways was resurfacing a bridge, state police Sgt. J.K. Riffle said. ``He just came down through there and knocked them out of his way,'' he said. The car in which five people died was crushed between the carrier and an asphalt truck and burst into flames, Riffle said. Those five victims weren't immediately identified. One of the vehicles atop the carrier flew off and landed on another stopped car, which also exploded in flames. The victims in that car were identified as James F. Sullivan III, 35, Stephen W. McKinney, 37, and James F. Clayton, 9. Fire also destroyed the carrier, the other seven cars on it, the asphalt truck and another highway construction truck. Cruzado received only minor burns, authorities said. ``He walked away from it,'' said Brady.

DOC.HEAD: Farm Loans Shouldn't Be Higher Than Loans to Soviets, Senate Says
DOC.NOTE: EDs: LEADS with 5 grafs to UPDATE with Senate action; picks up 2nd graf pvs, bgng, The last...
DOC.TEXT: The Senate voted today to prevent banks from loaning money to the Soviet Union at a lower rate than to farmers, unless the funds are used to buy U.S. agricultural products. The amendment to the 1990 farm bill was approved 64-32 as the first item of business as the Senate began its seventh day of debate on the bill that will set agriculture policy for the next five years. The provision, offered by Sen. Jesse Helms, R-N.C., pertains to banks, savings associations, credit unions or any entity that has deposits insured by the federal government. Helms, during debate Thursday on the amendment, said lending institutions should not be loaning money to the Soviets at lower rates than to U.S. farmers. Senate leaders say they are moving right along towards final passage of the bill, despite dozens of unresolved issues. The last time Congress rewrote the nation's basic farm law, in 1985, the Senate spent a month trying to arrive at final passage, Republican Leader Bob Dole of Kansas said. ``We've only had 45 hours of debate, and we're not even up to 100 amendments yet,'' he said early today. Senate Majority Leader George Mitchell of Maine called off debate Thursday when it became clear at midnight that the senators were still far from a vote on whether strict economic sanctions should be placed against Iraq. He read off a long list of amendments on issues ranging from paperwork reduction to loans to the Soviet Union that still had not been resolved. Senators then began mentioning others they planned to offer. Sen. Howell Heflin, D-Ala., said he had an amendment. ``To what does it pertain?'' asked Mitchell. ``Farming,'' Heflin said, causing titters through the chamber. ``We're all in a good mood now,'' Mitchell said, smiling himself. But then he began to scold. ``The Senate's lengthy hours are a consequence of action by senators, but sometimes you wouldn't know it by what's happening here,'' said the majority leader. ``The likelihood of another late night tomorrow and Saturday is increasing with each amendment.'' Earlier in the evening when a debate over cargo preference had droned on for more than two hours, Agriculture Committee Chairman Patrick Leahy, D-Vt., bemoaned the snag. ``I would like to spend some of the non-sleeping hours someplace besides this wonderful chamber,'' said Leahy who has been managing debate on the bill for the Democrats. ``I have counted the stars on the ceiling, the panels, the lights, and the number of members of the press.'' Thursday was the third consecutive day in which debate lasted late into the night. An amendment to the bill offered by Sen. Thomas Daschle, D-S.D., was passed earlier in the day that would preserve the crop insurance program. The amendment provides for the program to be funded through the Commodity Credit Corp. if money earmarked specifically for crop insurance is phased out as directed by a vote of the House. The Bush administration, which wants the insurance program abolished, estimated that it would cost $601 million in 1991 if continued at its present level. The administration eliminated it from its budget request. Daschle said his crop-insurance provision ``respons to the troubling situation that has developed over in the House.'' The House stripped funds from the program last week over the objections of its agriculture committee, which has been studying ways to improve the program and increase participation. Common complaints by farmers about crop insurance include that premiums are too expensive and that payments can be inadequate when disaster strikes. Only about 40 percent of the eligible farmers participate in the program. ``What's killed the crop-insurance program has been total mismanagement of the program,'' said Sen. Thomas Harkin, D-Iowa, ``I've never seen a program so mismanaged from Washington, D.C., in my life.'' Sen. Christopher Bond, R-Mo., tried unsuccessfully to phase out the crop insurance over three years, though several changes he suggested for the program were adopted along with the Daschle proposal. The farm bill, estimated to cost $54 billion over five years, establishes price-support programs for commodities and sets policy for nutrition programs, agricultural exports, soil and water conservation, agricultural research and extension work, food inspection and other responsibilities of the Agriculture Department. In other action, the Senate: _Increased the payment limit to wool and mohair producers from the $50,000 in the original bill to $250,000. The House, on a voice vote Wednesday, approved an amendment that sets payments per producer at $200,000 in 1991; $167,000 in 1992; $133,000 in the 1993 and $100,000 in 1994. _Approved an amendment to give special attention to improving conditions for minority farmers who through the years have become a smaller and smaller part of the agriculture industry.

DOC.HEAD: American Rabbi Claims Police Brutality
DOC.TEXT: An American rabbi today accused police of trying to suffocate him and of punching an associate after their arrest in a protest against President Kurt Waldheim. Rabbi Avi Weiss and the associate, Jacob Davidson, shouted ``Shame for meeting Nazi Waldheim!'' as visiting presidents Richard von Weizsaecker of West Germany and Vaclav Havel of Czechoslovakia shook hands with Waldheim Wednesday. Although private, the visits were interpreted by some as a gesture of support for Waldheim, who has been boycotted by most heads of state for covering up his past as an intelligence officer in the German army during World War II. After their shouts, Weiss and Davidson were quickly subdued by security agents and dragged into a small room. A third American Jewish activist involved in the protest was not arrested. ``They forced me to lie prostrate, face down. Then they took the jacket and pulled it over my face so I could hardly breathe for many seconds,'' Weiss said in a telephone interview. He said he yelled and then was allowed to get up again. He said the situation was all the more precarious for him because he had previously undergone heart bypass surgery. Davidson was also forced to lie on the floor and punched in his chest, Weiss said. ``This is unseemly, absolutely outrageous,'' he said. The police did not immediately respond to the rabbi's claims.

DOC.HEAD: Education Secretary Cavazos to Head Delegation to Lima
DOC.NOTE: EDs: SUBS lead to CORRECT first name of Cavazos
DOC.TEXT: Secretary of Education Lauro Cavazos will head the U.S. delegation to the inauguration of Peruvian President-elect Alberto Fujimori in Lima Saturday, the White House announced today. Cavazos will be accompanied by his wife, Peggy. Other members of the delegation will be Chase Untermeyer, director of presidential personnel, and Anthony Quainton, ambassador to Peru.

DOC.HEAD: Couple Arrested 15 Minutes After Marriage
DOC.TEXT: A couple having their wedding dinner shared a second important event. They were arrested together after a customer at the restaurant recognized the man. Jerry Conner and Sheila Maria Boyd told police they had been married 15 minutes before their arrest on robbery charges Thursday. Boyd, 23, and Conner, 27, are accused of robbing 13 patients and five employees in a doctor's office last month, said Sgt. Edward Burns, a police spokesman. The victims lost $890 in cash and $7,000 in jewelry, he said. One of the vitcims went to Cobblestone's Restaurant with a friend on Thursday and thought she recognized Conner as the man who had held a gun up to her head during the robbery. She called police, who arrested the couple. They were charged with 18 counts of robbery and criminal possession of a weapon, Burns said.

DOC.HEAD: Iraq Renews Browbeating Kuwait
With PM-Opec, Bjt
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 8 grafs to UPDATE with U.S. Senate vote on economic sanctions. Pick up 6th graf pvs, `On Thursday...'
DOC.TEXT: One day after halting its verbal attacks on Kuwait over oil production and disputed border lines, the Iraqi government renewed its demands today, calling on Kuwait to recognize Baghdad's ``legitimate rights.'' The official Iraqi News Agency carried a statement from an unidentified spokesman saying Kuwait must send representatives to Baghdad to resolve the issues that divide them. There was no immediate response from Kuwait. INA said a meeting scheduled in Saudi Arabia in the next few days between Izzat Ibrahim, vice chairman of the Iraqi Revolutionary Command Council, and Sheik Saad al-Abdullah al-Sabah of Kuwait is only a preliminary step. The news agency said it will be a ``protocol meeting and will be followed by a meeting between them in Baghdad to resume the negotiations.'' ``It is necessary that the prime minister of Kuwait know that whoever comes to the meeting with us should be prepared to remove the harm and aggression suffered by Iraq and respond to Iraq's legitimate rights,'' the spokesman said. In Washington today, the Senate voted today to impose harsh economic sanctions on Iraq, including an end to the $1.2 billion in loan guarantees Baghdad now receives to buy U.S. farm and commercial products. The vote, on an amendment to the 1990 farm bill, was the latest sign of congressional worry over Iraq's increasingly threatening stance in the volatile Middle East. Before the 80-16 vote, lawmakers cited concern about Iraqi human rights violations. But farm-state interests indicated they might try to water down the sanctions before the bill's final passage. On Thursday, Iraq scaled back a weeklong intimidation campaign against Kuwait after gaining concessions at an OPEC meeting to end violations of production quotas set by the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries. The threats started just before the OPEC meeting that began Thursday in Geneva to set prices and production levels for the rest of the year. The OPEC ministers met today to complete the details of a new accord designed to restrain oil production and lift crude prices above $20 a barrel. The current target price is $18 but slipped $4 to $5 due to a world oil glut. It was not immediately clear if the renewed Iraqi pressure on Kuwait was linked to the OPEC bargaining. Diplomatic sources based in the Persian Gulf said Iraq had agreed to pull some of the estimated 30,000 troops it reportedly deployed back from the countries' disputed border starting at dawn Thursday. Travelers returning from the border area said there were fewer weapons on display, and that convoys of troops were headed north. Kuwait had insisted that Iraq withdraw forces massed at the 100-mile border and stop the propaganda campaign before Kuwait would sit down for negotiations this weekend, the diplomatic sources said. Iraqi newspaper officials said they received instructions from the Ministry of Information on Wednesday night to halt attacks on Kuwait as part of an agreement to defuse the crisis. Although the spokesman quoted today did not say what he meant by Iraq's ``legitimate rights,'' the nation's demands are well known. President Hussein Saddam claims Kuwait and the United Arab Emirates deprived his nation of $14 billion in revenue by depressing the international price of crude oil. He also wants Kuwait to compensate Iraq for $2.4 billion worth of oil he claims was stolen since 1980 from an oil field along the countries' disputed border. The disputed Rumaila oil field extends two miles into Kuwait, but Iraq claims it owns the entire field. With an estimated $70 billion in debts from the Iran-Iraq war, Saddam faces increasing grumbling at home over economic conditions. Iraq is dependent on oil revenues to pay its debuts and fund reconstruction.

DOC.HEAD: Mother Collapses While Testifying in Defense of Son
DOC.TEXT: A mother collapsed on the witness stand and had to be carried from the courtroom today after testifying in defense of her son, who is charged with fatally plunging a toddler headfirst into a toilet. Mary Coe's collapse came after she had completed direct questioning in Thomas Coe's first-degree murder and aggravated child abuse trial in the death of his 2-year-old stepson, Bradley McGee. But as cross-examination was to begin, she asked for paramedics to be standing by because she was not feeling well. She soon collapsed and the proceedings were stopped. Paramedics treated her at the Lee County Justice Center before she was carried out on a stretcher. Her condition was not immediately known. At the time, the judge was listening to her testimony with the jurors out of the room. Coe, 23, is charged with murder and aggravated child abuse in the death of Bradley one year ago this week. Prosecutors are seeking the death penalty. Coe has admitted dunking the boy headfirst into the toilet, saying it was punishment for soiling his pants. The toddler died the next day of head injures. Defense attorneys argue that he should be convicted of a lesser crime because it was a one-time form of punishment and there was never any intent to harm the child. Bradley's death came two months after social workers recommended to a judge that he be returned from foster care to his mother, Sheryl Coe, and stepfather. The death lead to a change in state policy toward foster care and charges against several child welfare workers, most of whom were acquitted. Mrs. Coe, 21, pleaded no contest to second-degree murder and aggravated child abuse and is serving a 30-year term.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
France Frees Convicted Pro-Iranian Terrorist
DOC.TEXT: Anis Naccache, convicted of killing two people during a botched assassination attempt ordered by Iran, was freed by the French government today after spending 10 years in prison. The Justice Ministry said Naccache and four accomplices left France for Iran this afternoon after their release was ordered by President Francois Mitterrand. Naccache, whose release had been sought by several hard-line Arab leaders, went on a 19-week hunger strike ending in January in a bid to obtain his release. There were unconfirmed news reports that he ended the fast after obtaining assurances he would be freed sometime this year. He and three members of his group were sentenced to life imprisonment for an attempt in 1980 to kill Shahpour Bakhtiar, Iran's prime minister before the 1979 Islamic revolution. A fifth member of the team received a 20-year sentence. Bakhtiar escaped injury and still lives in Paris, but a policeman and a bystander were killed. Both defense and prosecution said at the trial that Naccache and his team were acting on orders from senior Iranian officials. Those freed along with Naccache were Mehdi Nejad Tabrizzi, an Iranian; Fauozi Mohamed el Satari, a Palestinian; Mohamed Jawat Jeneb, an Iranian; and Salaheddine el Kaara, a Lebanese.

DOC.HEAD: Agents Arrest Noriega Co-Defendant Named in 1988 Indictment
DOC.TEXT: The arrest of a pilot named in a drug-trafficking indictment with deposed Panamanian leader Manuel Noriega brings to eight the number of defendants in custody, federal officials said. Roberto Steiner, arrested by Drug Enforcement Administration agents Thursday, was scheduled to appear before a U.S. magistrate today. Steiner and Noriega were among 16 people named in the February 1988 federal indictment. Noriega was taken into custody in January following the U.S. invasion of Panama and is being held in Miami awaiting trial. DEA agents arrested Steiner following a raid on a home in Key Biscayne, an island off Miami. The agency did not provide further details of the arrest. Steiner is accused of three counts of conspiracy to distribute cocaine and one count of flying cocaine into the United States.

DOC.HEAD: Bush to Nominate Quayle Aide to Court of Claims
DOC.TEXT: President Bush plans to nominate Diane Weinstein, an aide to Vice President Dan Quayle, as a judge of the U.S. Court of Claims, the White House announced today. Ms. Weinstein has been counsellor to the vice president since 1989. She would succeed Randall R. Rader on the Court of Claims. Her term would run for 15 years.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
Survivors Pulled From Quake Rubble After 11 Days
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Leads with 13 grafs to ADD quotes from survivor. Pickup ADDS quotes from survivor. Pickup 7th pvs, `Last week...
DOC.TEXT: Rescuers alerted by cries of ``Help us!'' today pulled two survivors from the rubble of a hotel 11 days after it collapsed in an earthquake that killed more than 1,600 people. Rescuers and spectators cheered as Luisa Mallorca was pulled from the wreckage of the Hyatt Hotel at about 9:50 p.m. (8:50 a.m. EDT). Arnel Calabia was recovered about an hour later. Foreign rescue teams gave up the search for survivors last week, but Filipino miners and other volunteers had vowed to search until all the missing were accounted for. Doctors said Calabia, a hotel security guard, and Ms. Mallorca, a cleaning woman, were in surprisingly good condition. In a radio interview, Calabia said he, Ms. Mallorca and another man dived under tables when the quake struck, ``and then the ceiling fell in.'' ``We recovered consciousness later and we called out to each other,'' Calabia said. He said the third person died about four days ago. ``I was okay where I was, but I realized just a while ago that there was a concrete slab above my forehead,'' he said. ``Just a few more inches and I would have been dead too.'' The two were being treated at Baguia General Hospital. Doctors said they suffered cuts and bruises and severe dehydration. Calabia said his hand was injured and that a nurse warned that three of his fingers may have to be amputated. Ms. Mallorca complained of chest pains. Both are employees of the state-run Philippine Amusement and Gaming Corp., which operated a casino in the luxury hotel. They were found in rubble of the second floor of the 12-story building. Workers returned to the site to search for others who might still be alive. Miners said they heard cries of ``Help us! Help us!'' late today. After boring for five hours, rescuers said they reached the hotel elevator shaft and found Ms. Mallorca pinned beneath a beam. Calabia was found in the same general area, lying next to four bodies. Last week, foreign rescue teams abandoned the search for survivors of the massive quake, which struck July 16 and measured 7.7 on the Richter scale. Baguio, about 130 miles north of Manila, was one of the cities hit hardest. Officials believe there are more than 20 people still unaccounted for in the Hyatt, one of eight hotels that collapsed during the quake. In October, a California longshoreman was pulled from beneath tons of wreckage of an Oakland freeway that had collapsed four days earlier in an earthquake. Buck Helm had suffered injuries to virtually every organ in his body when his compact car was crushed under Interstate 880. He died 28 days after his rescue, which came after workers had given up hope of finding any more survivors. According to the latest figures, the Philippines earthquake left at least 1,653 people dead, 1,000 missing and presumed dead, 3,000 seriously injured and 110,000 homeless. It was the strongest to strike the Philippines in 14 years. Nearly 400 people were killed in Baguio. The air force chief today ordered gunships and rocket-firing planes to escort helicopters carrying relief supplies to villages stricken by the quake. The order follows guerrilla attacks on two helicopters. The military said the guerrilla fire Wednesday over the town of Kayapa represented a violation of the rebels' unilateral cease-fire in areas hit by the July 16 earthquake. ``We will go on with our mission despite gunfire from the NPA,'' Maj. Gen. Gerardo Protacio said, referring to the Communist New People's Army guerrillas. An air force spokesman, Col. Avelino Abiol, said he was aboard one of the two helicopters ferrying relief goods Wednesday to Kayapa, a remote mountain town cut off from the rest of Luzon island by landslides. The rebels fired with M-16 and M-14 rifles but missed the helicopters, he said. The town, about 120 miles north of Manila, is considered a rebel stronghold.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Slides ON GNP Figures
With PM-GNP, Bjt
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 8 grafs to UPDATE with dollar slumping on GNP report. Picks up 17th graf, `Gold dealers...'
DOC.TEXT: The dollar slumped against other major currencies in European trading today on news of weaker-than-expected growth in the U.S. economy. Gold prices were mostly lower. The dollar fell after the Commerce Department reported in Washington that the gross national product grew at a sluggish annual rate of 1.2 percent during the second quarter. Traders had predicted the GNP would expand by 1.8 percent. Slow economic growth improves prospects for lower U.S. interest rates, which undermine the dollar because it cannot compete against currencies backed by higher rates. In London, the British pound, which is supported by high interest rates, was quoted at $1.8335, up sharply from $1.8133 late Thursday. Other afternoon dollar rates, compared with late Thursday's prices, included: 1.6150 West German marks, down from 1.6220; 1.3655 Swiss francs, down from 1.3780; 5.4125 French francs, down from 5.4355; 1.8205 Dutch guilders, down from 1.8290; 1,184.60 Italian lire, down from 1,187.50; and 1.1532 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1513. The dollar was quoted at 150.20 Japanese yen in London after the GNP report. In earlier Tokyo trading, the dollar rose 0.64 yen to a closing 150.75 yen. Gold dealers in London fixed a recommended price of $368.50 a troy ounce in morning trading, down from $368.65 bid late Thursday. In Zurich, the bid was $368.50 an ounce, unchanged from late Thursday. Gold in Hong Kong fell 98 cents to close at a $368.96 an ounce. Silver was unchanged in London at a bid price of $4.85 a troy ounce.

DOC.HEAD: Senate Votes to Slap Harsh Economic Sanctions on Iraq
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs 3rd graf pvs, But farm-state, with 2 grafs, Senate action to preserve sanctions, House moves to consideration of similar amendment
DOC.TEXT: The Senate voted today to slap harsh economic sanctions on Iraq, including an end to the $1.2 billion in loan guarantees Baghdad now receives to buy U.S. farm and commercial products. The 80-16 vote came on an amendment to the 1990 farm bill offered by Sen. Alfonse D'Amato, R-N.Y. It was the latest sign of congressional worry over Iraq's increasingly threatening stance in the volatile Middle East. Senators underscored the action a short time later by killing, 57-38, an attempt by farm-state colleagues to water down the sanctions and avoid the loss of a $1 billion market for wheat, rice and other commodities. In the House, which was considering its own version of the farm bill, action was expected today on a similar amendment to eliminate U.S. agricultural credit guarantees to Iraq. At the same time, government sources said the Bush administration was seriously considering a range of options for action against Iraq which could signal U.S. displeasure without totally alienating President Saddam Hussein. Options under consideration included putting Iraq back on the U.S. list of terrorist nations, which would end commodity loan guarantees and Export-Import Bank credits for purchase of American industrial goods, and more limited tightening of restrictions on U.S. exports. ``This is a freight train coming down the track'' from Congress, said one senior administration official, speaking only on condition of anonymity. ``There is plenty of impetus. The question becomes, do we want to be active, or let (Capitol) Hill do it to us?'' The House Foreign Affairs Committee scheduled action for next week on a bill drafted by Rep. Howard Berman, D-Calif., that would impose a similar list of sanctions on Iraq. Still other sanctions were contained in an Export Administration Act pending on the Senate calendar. The State Department has described Iraq's human rights record as ``abysmal.'' Concerns also have mounted over the country's development of chemical and nuclear weapons and missiles to deliver them. Hussein also has made direct threats against Israel in recent months, and early this week massed troops on the border with Kuwait. D'Amato had offered his sanctions legislation as an amendment to another bill in May, but had withdrawn it in order to hold hearings on the proposal. The administration testified against the bill at hearings on June 15, but D'Amato picked up support from colleagues, including Sen. Nancy Kassebaum, R-Kan., who backed it even though it might hurt sales of Kansas wheat. The amendment would revoke credit guarantees of up to $1 billion a year that Iraq now uses to buy rice, wheat, timber, cattle, and a $200 million line of credit for commercial goods through the Export-Import Bank. It also would bar sales of weapons, high-technology goods and items that could have a military use. ``It is time we stop talking and take action against Iraq,'' D'Amato said. ``We should not give to the Iraqis the kind of treatment you reserve for friends, for allies.'' Sen. Richard Lugar, R-Ind., a senior member of the Foreign Relations Committee, said the sanctions would ``badly undercut any possibility we have of influencing Iraqi behavior. They will more likely respond angrily and defiantly.'' And he said it would cut into important farm exports. But Kassebaum said serious human rights violations by Iraq make those considerations less important. ``I can't believe any farmer in this nation would want to send his products, under subsidized sales, to a country that has used chemical weapons and a country that has tortured and executed its children in order to force their families into compliance with the government,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: Defense Concludes In Barry Case Without Mayor's Testimony
DOC.NOTE: EDs: Combines pvs; edits to tighten; no pickup
DOC.TEXT: The defense rested its case today in Marion Barry's cocaine and perjury trial after the mayor decided not to take the witness stand. ``I have advised Mr. Barry that no matter how we restrict his testimony ... he would still be subject to cross-examination,'' R. Kenneth Mundy, one of Barry's lawyers, told the court. ``This is a matter we have considered extensively ... and it is his informed decision that he will not take the stand,'' said Mundy. The trial on 14 criminal charges is in its sixth week of testimony and the prosecution plans to conclude today or Monday by calling several rebuttal witnesses. Final arguments and instructions to the jury will follow Tuesday or Wednesday. Barry is charged with 10 counts of cocaine possession, three counts of perjury and one count of conspiracy. Mundy ended his case by grilling the FBI agent whose sting operation videotaped the mayor smoking crack cocaine. Agent Ronald Stern should have stopped the Jan. 18 sting against Barry before he smoked the crack, said Mundy. ``What would you suggest I say to Rasheeda?'' Stern retorted. ``The sting's off _ throw away the drugs?'' Stern was referring to ex-model Rasheeda Moore, a former Barry girlfriend who persuaded Barry to come to her hotel room. An undercover agent posing as Moore's friend supplied the crack while Stern monitored the sting from the next room. Stern repeatedly insisted that it was Barry, not Moore, who brought up the subject of drugs and asked for them. On Thursday, Mundy said the FBI had targeted Andrew Young, Julian Bond and other black leaders for undercover sting operations. ``Stern in effect moves around the country as the head of an ... assault force of FBI agents,'' Mundy said out of the presence of the jury. ``There is absolutely no truth to the allegation,'' responded assistant U.S. attorney Judith Retchin. Stern is ``not part of a roving band,'' Retchin told the judge in the Barry trial before the jury was called into the courtroom this morning. Mundy had asserted that, ``Prior to coming here to organize and orchestrate the sting against Mr. Barry, Mr. Stern had been in Atlanta trying to set up a sting of Julian Bond, Andrew Young and two other black politicians and public figures in Atlanta.'' ``We stand on the representations we made,'' Mundy told the court today after Retchin's comments. He said the information is based on ``five different sources.'' Mundy said they include two attorneys for witnesses in the Barry case, one of whom provided an affidavit on the matter. Another is a person to whom Stern in an ``unguarded moment mentioned his activities,'' said Mundy. In addition, Mundy said today, ``we received a letter making certain representations.'' On Thursday, Mundy said some of the information also came from a former FBI informant, from a congressional office and from a figure convicted in the HUD scandal. Barry's lawyers were prohibited from questioning Stern in front of the jury about the allegation. U.S. District Court Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson ruled that the defense would be prohibited from presenting evidence that Barry was a target of selective prosecution. Mundy said he wanted to put the information on the record in case ``the court of appeals would inquire as to what other things we would have gone into had we been permitted.'' Retchin said she also wanted to make the record clear in case of a possible appeal.

DOC.HEAD: Panamanian Lawsuit Specifies Civil Charges to be Filed Against Noriega
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 8 grafs to UPDATE with Washington visit over, Cruz in Miami. Pick up 9th graf pvs, `Noriega, who...'
DOC.TEXT: Panama's attorney general visited Washington this week to talk to his government's private lawyers about filing a $6 billion lawsuit against former Gen. Manuel Noriega. The government's 40-page civil suit, to be filed in Miami, contains 11 charges against the toppled dictator for alleged misconduct during his 28-year military and political career. The Panamanian attorney general, Rogelio Cruz, was in Miami today, where he traveled from Washington. Noriega's forays have cost Panama ``enormous material losses,'' lawyers John Kester, Gregory Craig and Kevin Hasson contend in the complaint obtained Thursday by The Associated Press. Noriega is in prison on drug trafficking charges in a criminal lawsuit in Miami, after surrendering to U.S. troops in a December invasion of Panama. Panama's lawsuit outlines cases of Noriega's alleged participation in assassination, torture, drug trafficking, money laundering, embezzlement, detouring of funds, illegal sale of visas and passports, abuse of authority and abuse of duty while he was head of the defunct Panama Defense Forces. The complaint demands that Noriega and his associates repay three times over a sum of $500 million they allegedly owe Panama, plus $5 billion in punitive damages. Craig, an attorney in the Panamanian government's Washington law firm Williams and Connolly, told the U.S. judge in the Miami suit last month that his client plans to file charges to assure that ``no irreparable damage be done to those funds that rightfully belong to the Panamanian people.'' Noriega, who surrendered to U.S. troops Jan. 4, is being held in the Metropolitan Correctional Center outside of Miami on a February 1988 indictment accusing him of taking $4.6 million in bribes from Colombia's Medellin drug cartel to turn Panama into a way station for cocaine trafficking. Miami U.S. District Judge William Hoeveler took note of the civil lawsuit, but said he wouldn't allow it to interfere with the criminal proceeding against Noriega. Panama's complaint is based on allegations of illicit appropriations, fraud, noncompliance, illicit enrichment, racketeering and other alleged offenses against the Panamanian people. It claims Noriega had earnings of $700,000 during his 28 years as a military officer, but now has assets valued at $300 million. The suit names co-defendants Marcos Justines, Noriega's chief of staff, in jail in Panama City; Carlos Duque, the 1989 presidential candidate of Noriega's Revolutionary Democratic party; Michael Harari, a former Israeli military officer, three former ambassadors, Noriega's wife Felicidad, his mistress Vicki Amado and others.

DOC.HEAD: Cabinet Members Favor Releasing Gilbert From Prison
DOC.TEXT: State officials are considering granting clemency to an 81-year-old man convicted of murdering his ailing wife in what he said was a mercy killing. Three Cabinet members have said they are ready to consider freeing Roswell Gilbert, who has served 5{ years of a 25-year sentence for the shooting death of his 73-year-old wife, Emily. ``I don't think justice would be served by keeping him in prison any longer,'' Comptroller Gerald Lewis said Thursday. ``The chances of him committing a violent crime again are nil. It's time to let him go and make room for more violent criminals.'' Attorney General Bob Butterworth and Insurance Commissioner Thomas Gallagher also said they will consider clemency when Gilbert's case is heard Sept. 12. Gilbert said he killed his wife to end her suffering from Alzheimer's disease and osteoporosis. Clemency in Florida is granted to prisoners when the governor and three of the six Cabinet members support it. Gov. Bob Martinez, who has opposed clemency for Gilbert, would not comment on it, spokesman Jon Peck said.

DOC.HEAD: Murder Conviction Overturned in High Court Retrial
DOC.TEXT: A court has overturned the murder conviction of a 44-year-old man, 18 years after he was first found guilty and sent to prison to be executed. He was immediately freed. The Nagoya High Court, in a ruling announced Friday, found Norio Shimogami guilty of the less serious charge of attempted armed robbery resulting in injuries, and sentenced him to eight years in prison. But since Shimogami had already served 18 years on the murder charge, he was released after his recent retrial, said court officials in Nagoya, in central Japan. Shimogami was arrested in June 1972 on charges of murdering a taxi driver. Courts had previously found him guilty and sentenced him to die on a murder charge based on a confession made by his alleged accomplice, who has served an eight-year prison term. But a three-judge panel in the retrial said the confession by the alleged accomplice was insufficient proof of Shimogami's guilt. Prosecutors said they would decide in two weeks whether to ask for yet another retrial. The Supreme Court ordered the retrial by the high court in June last year.

DOC.HEAD: German World War I Cemetery Vandalized
DOC.TEXT: Vandals broke metal crosses off 38 graves of German soldiers at a World War I military cemetery in northern France, police said Friday. An employee discovered the damage at the Meurchin cemetery near Lens, 124 miles north of Paris. Empty beer and wine bottles were found at the scene, and police said they believed the culprits were youths who made a drunken foray into the cemetery last weekend after a village festival. No graffiti was found at the cemetery, where 828 German soldiers were buried.

DOC.HEAD: No Injuries in Fire at Hilton Hotel near Regent's Park
DOC.TEXT: A small fire damaged part of an upper floor of the Hilton International Hotel near Regent's Park in north London on Friday, the London Fire Brigade said. There were no injuries and nobody was trapped or rescued, said a brigade spokeswoman, who by custom was not identified. But 15 percent of the 12th floor was damaged in the fire, the spokeswoman said. The hotel, one of nine operated by Hilton in the London area, was evacuated and firemen using breathing equipment put out the blaze. Automatic fire alarms went off on three floors of the 13-story building. The cause of the blaze was under investigation, the spokeswoman said.

DOC.HEAD: Louisiana Gov. Roemer Vetoes Abortion Bill
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Rewrites throughout to DELETE incorrect reference in penultimate graf pvs that two-thirds majorities needed to call override session _ only a simple majority of each house is required; and to UPDATE with abortion opponent saying he will press for special session; add comment from pro-choice group, further comment from Roemer. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Gov. Buddy Roemer announced today that he has vetoed what would have been the nation's toughest state abortion law, a measure thrown together in the final days of a tumultuous session of the Louisiana Legislature. ``I vetoed this bill because it does not meet even the minimum standards set forth by me long ago,'' Roemer said, reading from a statement. Roemer has long insisted that any anti-abortion bill must contain exceptions for rape and incest. The rape exception in the bill he vetoed wasn't strong enough, he said. A leading abortion opponent immediately said he would seek a special session to override the governor. Roemer said he had supported much of the bill but that rape ``is treated unevenly and unsatisfactorily.'' The bill would have had doctors who perform abortions face sentences of up to 10 years at hard labor and fines of up to $100,000. It was designed pave the way for a court case to challenge the 1973 Supreme Court decision that legalized abortion. Nancy Myers, spokeswoman for National Right to Life Committee, said Roemer ``betrayed the pro-life majority that elected him. Gov. Roemer has abandoned thousand of unborn children.'' She accused him of using ``phony excuses to hide the fact that he doesn't care at all for unborn children.'' But Joy Gilmore, president of the state chapter of the National Organization for Women, called Roemer's decision ``rational and reasonable'' and said it ``sends a clear and distinctive message that the power of the pro-choice majority cannot be denied.'' Lawmakers put the bill together July 8, the day before the session ended, by amending anti-abortion language onto an unrelated anti-flag-burning bill. They did so after failing by three votes to override Roemer's veto of an even tougher anti-abortion bill passed earlier in the session. Roemer said he had vetoed the first bill because it lacked exceptions for rape or incest. Even before announcing his veto of the second bill today, Roemer had complained that the new measure would require rape victims, in order to gain permission for an abortion, to report the crime and seek medical treatment to prevent conception within seven days of the rape. The bill's opponents also noted it doesn't allow abortions of pregnancies resulting from ``simple rape,'' defined in Louisiana law as sexual intercourse when a woman is incapable of resisting; for instance, if she is intoxicated. Roemer repeated today that he considers himself an abortion opponent, adding, ``abortion on demand and as a substitute for birth control must be, in the name of the unborn, sharply controlled.'' But, he said, most citizens he talked to around the state agreed with him that ``some common-sense, decent exceptions should be made.'' Shortly after the veto was announced, Rep. Woody Jenkins, D-Baton Rouge, a key abortion opponent, said he would ask the Legislature to come back into session next month and would first seek once again to override the original bill. Jenkins noted that under Louisiana's constitution, if the lawmakers approve a veto session, all bills vetoed by the governor are automatically eligible for consideration. Under the law, a veto session is held 40 days after the end of the regular session if a majority of both houses agrees. For a veto to be nullified, more than two-thirds of each house must approve the override. The measure that was vetoed today, unlike the measure that Roemer vetoed earlier, was passed in both legislative chambers with more than the two-thirds majorities. Nevertheless, override opponents have history on their side in one respect: No Louisiana governor's veto has been overridden this century.

DOC.HEAD: Former Vice President Calls for Kenyan Leaders to Quit
DOC.TEXT: A former vice president today claimed Kenya's government is corrupt and he demanded the resignation of its leaders, the dissolution of Parliament and multiparty elections. The scathing criticism of President Daniel arap Moi comes as the government is cracking down on opposition activists in the wake of a series of anti-government protests. In an open letter, 81-year-old Ajuma Oginga Odinga denounced Moi's government as unpopular, authoritarian and ``bent on acts of suppression and arrogant insensitivity to public opinion and demands.'' He called Parliament ``a creature of rigged elections'' that is ``no better than an orchestra of blind and deaf cheerleaders.'' Odinga's letter, which was made available to news organizations, follows six months of increasingly heated debate over political pluralism in this East Africa nation. Kenya has been a one-party state by law since 1982, but in reality has had only one party since 1969 when the last opposition party _ led by Odinga _ was banned. Riots in early July left at least 28 dead and at least six of the government's most prominent critics have been detained, including Odinga's son. Raila Odinga, a businessman twice before detained for a total of six years, was picked up along with five others days before a banned pro-multiparty rally on July 7. When authorities acted to prevent the rally, riots occurred in Nairobi and four other major towns and rural areas. Among the six detained without charge were three lawyers who were released Wednesday after being held for 20 days. But one of them _ the editor of a law review _ was immediately arrested again and charged with sedition. Still being held without charge are former Cabinet ministers Charles Rubia and Kenneth Matiba, plus Raila Odinga. Matiba and Rubia had proposed the July 7 rally. In his letter, Odinga condemned ``the detention without trial of many Kenyan citizens and the spate of harassment and killing of innocent Kenyans in the wake of their legitimate demands for democracy, justice and equality. ``If detention without trial is not right in South Africa, it cannot have a basis in a free and supposedly democratic republic like Kenya,'' Odinga wrote. Odinga, as have other critics, accused Moi's government of amending the constitution to eliminate the independence of the judiciary, the attorney general and the office of the auditor-general, which is supposed to serve as a watchdog against corruption. The former vice president also suggested the government may be trying to suppress a Scotland Yard report of an investigation of the killing last February of Foreign Minister Robert Ouko. The mysterious death also touched off an outbreak of violence in Nairobi and elsewhere, with some accusing the government of involvement in the slaying. Moi, other Kenyan leaders and their supporters argue that more than one political party could lead to conflict among the nation's approximately 40 tribes. Odinga, who is in frail health, was vice president under Kenya's first and only other president, Jomo Kenyatta. He broke with Kenyatta in 1966 and formed an opposition party. In 1969, Kenyatta was heckled and, authorities later claimed, stoned at a political rally in western Kenya, the homeland of Odinga's Luo tribe. The president's bodyguards opened fire and 12 people were killed. The next day, Kenyatta had Odinga arrested and his party banned. The former vice president served two years in detention before being freed in 1971.

DOC.HEAD: Sister City Trip Leads to Altar
DOC.TEXT: Richmond's Sister City program to foster good will between the United States and the Soviet Union has resulted in more than simple friendship. It led to marriage. Carol Kimbrough and Igor Kuzminich were married last week in the Rose Garden at Glen Miller Park, culminating a courtship that began last August when Kimbrough went to the Soviet Union on an exchange trip. On Aug. 28, her second day there, Kimbrough met Kuzminich, a Russian, while getting on a bus to take a canoe trip with her group. As they got to know each other, the pair found they had much in common, Kimbrough said. ``He spoke no English when we met,'' she said. ``He has taught himself incredibly well, though.'' A translator helped them communicate as they floated on the canoe. After Kimbrough left the Soviet Union, she and Kuzminich continued to write. She returned to the Soviet Union in March to visit Kuzminich's home in Pushchino and meet his mother. It was during this visit that she and Kuzminich decided to marry. Kimbrough said her vows in Russian and Kuzminich said his in English during the ceremony.

DOC.HEAD: Peru's President-Elect to Inherit Nation on Edge of Chaos
LaserPhoto planned
DOC.TEXT: President-elect Alberto Fujimori takes office Saturday inheriting a nation that is bankrupt, blacked-out and ravaged by drought and war. How he will cope remains a mystery. Fujimori's team of advisers has been wracked by dissension and defections. Only days before the inauguration, Fujimori was scrambling to put together both a government and a plan with which to govern. Fujimori's ``good intention of selecting the best from each party may end in disaster, because the best may not want to join a government without well-defined aims,'' the magazine Caretas said. Fujimori's government will face immense problems. Inflation tops 3,000 percent a year. Four of five people lack steady work. The Central Bank has no dollars and has sold almost all its gold. Bread is rationed. Provincial gas stations are dry. Guerrilla violence is at an all-time high. Maoist Shining Path rebels control much of Peru's Andean mountains and Amazonian jungle. The pro-Cuban Tupac Amaru Revolutionary Movement recently staged a spectacular breakout from Lima's maximum-security prison. The worst drought to hit Peru this century has devastated crops and drastically cut Lima's water supply. Hydroelectric plants run at half capacity. The daily blackouts have paralyzed industry. A U.S.-backed plan to fight the trade in coca leaves, the raw material of cocaine, threatens to deprive Peru of its top export. The country earns $1 billion a year from the coca trade, which directly employs about 200,000 people in this country of 2 million. To reverse this economic collapse, Fujimori has proposed drastic measures. He says they will include a major devaluation of Peru's inti, the end of price subsidies, privatization of many state companies, and emergency taxes on the rich. Soon after his June 10 landslide victory over novelist Mario Vargas Llosa, Fujimori traveled to the United States and Japan seeking economic aid. In New York, he met with the heads of the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank. Outgoing President Alan Garcia cut ties with these organizations four years ago. Fujimori hopes to receive loans in return for implementing an IMF-approved austerity plan. But Fujimori's plan has met with strong domestic opposition. This is due largely to Fujimori's own condemnation of such a ``shock'' program during his campaign against Vargas Llosa. Within Fujimori's Change 90 party, one camp favors a drastic economic ``shock'' and another favors a more gradual approach. Many believe this conflict has resulted in chaos. The party's ``organizational structure has disintegrated,'' economist Daniel Schydlowsky said. A professor at Boston University, Schydlowsky resigned last week along with two other top Fujimori advisers. ``There's no time to put together a program and no team to do so,'' Schydlowsky told the Lima daily La Republica. When Fujimori finally named 11 of his 14 ministers last week, none belonged to Change 90. Most were independents, with a sprinkling of people from Peru's strong left- and right-wing parties. ``What awaits us is an intermediate, zig-zagging path,'' said Manuel D'Ornellas, a political commentator, after Fujimori named his Cabinet. ``It will be neither shock nor gradualism.'' An unprecedented three ministries _ Defense, Interior and Fisheries _ went to military officers. Most analysts view this as a sign of Fujimori's weakness. Fujimori's opponents showed little inclination to help the president-elect form what he had wanted to be a ``concensus'' Cabinet. The center-right Popular Action party forced Juan Carlos Hurtado Miller to resign his membership when he became Fujimori's prime minister and economy minister. The Marxist United Left coalition attacked member Gloria Helfer for becoming education minister. With the support of neither the left nor right, Fujimori will have a hard time imposing his plan. Change 90 holds fewer congressional seats than either Vargas Llosa's Democratic Front coalition or Garcia's Aprista Party. Peru has a strong presidency, and Fujimori will be able to govern partly by decree. But many of his plans will require congressional support, which means he will have to form some sort of alliance. But Fernando Belaunde Terry, twice Peru's president and de facto leader of the center-right congressional faction, says his group was elected to the opposition. And on the left, Garcia has made clear he will stick to his populist positions rather than help a Fujimori government impose austerity measures. ``One may have grave problems managing the economy, but this doesn't mean one should yield to the right or to imperialism. What is important is to stand firm with the poor,'' Garcia said. ``I am sure these adjustments will not take place.''

DOC.HEAD: Woman Who Dated Nominee Calls Him Fair-Minded
With AM-Souter, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: A woman who once dated Supreme Court nominee David Souter describes him as fair-minded, willing to listen and aware of the impact of abortion on women's lives. Ellanor Stengel Fink, now chairman of the board of elections in suburban Somerset, Md., married and the mother of three children, went out with Souter for several years in the 1960s, The Washington Post said Friday. Post columnist Judy Mann reported an interview with Fink, 45, who met Souter just after his return from Rhodes scholarship studies at Oxford University in England. She was then a student at Wheaton College. ``He's not an ideological person,'' she said. ``What's characteristic of him is he's tremendously fair-minded. He wants to know and to listen to everybody and to reach a fair position based upon the law. The one thing you can say is he will be fair and he will listen to all sides and he will tell you how it is.'' Souter, who lives alone in New Hampshire, has never married. ``I know everyone is wondering does he have the empathy to understand women's issues, and I think he would,'' Fink said. ``It's not as though he's lived in a cave for the last 25 years. He has many friends and I'm sure many women friends and I'm sure he's very aware of the impact of abortion on women's lives and men's lives as well.''

DOC.HEAD: Businessman Buys British Title on Vacation
DOC.TEXT: With two Rolls-Royces and a net worth put at $370 million, Joseph Hardy Sr. has some trappings of nobility. But it wasn't until Thursday that the western Pennsylvania businessman could say he was a lord of the manor. That's when Hardy and his wife purchased a title at a London auction for $187,000. Now Hardy is lord of the manor of Henley-in-Arden in Warwickshire. The title doesn't qualify the founder of 84 Lumber Co. to a seat in the House of Lords but that doesn't bother his wife, Dottie. ``It's an interesting path to go down that we hadn't traveled,'' she told the Pittsburgh Post-Gazette by telephone from London. ``We thought we might want to try learning a new way of life ... a little bit about the history of England.'' Hardy, who also owns a resort, gains certain rights with his lordship, including the authority to preside at Henley Court Leet, an annual gathering each November with the mace-bearer, ale-taster and butter-weigher. The title, which dates to the 11th century, allows Hardy to use the manor's coat of arms on his letterhead. ``I think it's very weird to tell you the truth,'' Mrs. Hardy said. ``We came over for a holiday. We just happened to be here when they held the auction.''

DOC.HEAD: Couple to Celebrate Anniversary Atop Grain Elevator
DOC.TEXT: Jim and Kelly West will celebrate their seventh wedding anniversary by getting about as high as they can in this central Illinois town: dining atop a grain elevator. Some 130 feet up, they will enjoy an evening of dinner and tap dancing, performed by her daughters, Megan, 10, and Ginnie, 7. The Wests, both 29, bought their dinner with a $125 bid at an auction April 21 benefiting 40-year-old Faye Jackson, a La Place leukemia patient needing a bone marrow transplant. ``It was for a good cause and it sounded interesting,'' said West, who works for a trucking company in La Place. Dinner for four will be served Saturday by employees of Bement Grain Co., which owns the grain elevator. The Wests and the other couple they invited will ride to the elevator top on a lift that holds two at a time. A card table and folding chairs will be hoisted the same way. ``We're looking forward to a high time!'' said Pam Jarboe, assistant manager at Bement. Manager Dick Thomas will cook the steaks on a table-top grill on top of the grain elevator. The rest of the meal will be prepared in the kitchen of Vanessa Stinson, another manager. ``It's going to be kind of scary to be up that high,'' said Mrs. West. ``I hope it's not too windy.''

DOC.HEAD: Problems Force Destruction of Rocket Bearing Star Wars Components
DOC.TEXT: A Aries rocket carrying an electronics payload to be tested for the Star Wars program went off course and was destroyed 31 seconds after it lifted off, authorities said today. ``This will not set back the (Star Wars) program,'' said Maj. Bill O'Connell of the Strategic Defense Initiative Organization in Washington, D.C. He estimated the loss at about $20 million. Debbie Bingham, a spokeswoman at White Sands Missile Range, said the single-state rocket was launched about 11:50 p.m. Wednesday from White Sands, but a problem quickly developed that forced the flight to be aborted. ``It was veering off course,'' she said. ``Everything stayed within the boundaries of the range.'' Investigators will try to determine the cause of the problem, Bingham said. The payload, sponsored by the Defense Nuclear Agency and the SDIO, consisted of electronic components that were to undergo testing in space, officials said. The components had undergone testing on the ground, O'Connell said. The rocket had been scheduled to lift off a week ago, but O'Connell said weather and other problems delayed the suborbital flight until Wednesday. The Star Wars program, known formally as the Strategic Defense Initiative, is a research effort to develop lasers and other exotic weapons that could automatically shoot down nuclear missiles fired at the United States.

DOC.HEAD: Flying Nuclear Command Post Flights Scaled Back
DOC.TEXT: The United States' flying nuclear arms command post is no longer in the air 24 hours a day, the Strategic Air Command said today. In a budget-cutting move that recognizes thawing superpower relations, SAC scaled back flights for the operation known as ``Looking Glass'' this week of the mission that had flown continuously since 1961, officials said. SAC said it modified the Looking Glass mission by putting the airplanes on ground alert and flying them randomly a few times each week. The last of the 24-hour-a-day flights ended at 2:28 p.m. CDT Tuesday, said Lt. Col. George Peck, a SAC spokesman. ``In this time of budget crunch, it was the right thing to do,'' Peck said. ``It makes good sense to put it on an alert status (instead of constantly in the air) where the world situation is such that keeping continuously airborne is perhaps not as critical as in the past,'' he said. Looking Glass had flown continuously since Feb. 2, 1961. SAC expects the change to save about $18 million in the 1991 fiscal year that begins Oct. 1, Peck said. About $23 million should be saved the following year, he said. Most of the savings will come from reduced fuel and maintenance costs, he said. The mission is dubbed ``Looking Glass'' because it mirrors the capability of SAC's underground command center. It would perform the command and control functions if something happened to the SAC headquarters at Offutt Air Force Base near Omaha. ``The roles and responsibilities of the Looking Glass have not changed, only the alert posture,'' a SAC statement said. ``SAC maintains the capability to launch the Looking Glass into a continuous airborne alert posture within minutes should strategic or tactical warning warrant.'' Looking Glass flights include a crew of 31 _ three who operate the plane and 28 who work in the airborne command center, including an Air Force general, Peck said. Now, the crew will in a building nearby when the Looking Glass flight is not in the air, he said. Recent changes in Eastern Europe were not directly responsible for the decision to modify the round-the-clock flights but ``world events'' contributed to the decision, Peck said. Improved U.S. intelligence capabilities and the resulting increased warning time of any attack also were factors in the decision to change Looking Glass, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Rafsanjani: Cooperation With Iraq Has Raised Oil Prices
With AM-OPEC, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Iranian President Hashemi Rafsanjani said Friday that Iran's cooperation with its wartime enemy Iraq had helped boost oil prices, Tehran radio reported. In Geneva, the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries, including Iran and Iraq, agreed Friday to increase the benchmark price of crude oil from $18 to $21 per barrel. Tehran Radio, monitored in Nicosia, quoted Rafsanjani as joining Iraq in criticizing fellow Persian Gulf states for violating OPEC production quotas. ``Two or three countries in the Persian Gulf have committed a great treason due to their dependence on the West,'' Rafsanjani said. Speaking at prayers in Tehran, Rafsanjani did not name the countries, but added: ``They have inflicted an atrocity on the Arab world.'' His remarks supported a vehement attack by Iraqi President Saddam Hussein last week on Kuwait and the United Arab Emirates. Saddam blasted the two gulf states for violating OPEC production quotas. He claimed the violations had cost Iraq $14 billion in lost revenues this year, when overproduction by the two fellow Arab countries helped push oil prices below $14 per barrel. Since the August 1988 cease-fire in their eight-year war, Iran and Iraq have been trying to rebuild their countries, inflicting heavy strains on their economies. They have been strong advocates of an oil price hike. Indicating a future improvement in his country's ``no war, no peace'' situation with Baghdad, Rafsanjani said ``recently we and the Iraqis have started talking to each other, writing letters to one another, and moving in the same direction, and look at what great change has occurred.'' The price of oil has already risen from a low of $14 a barrel and in the future will increase even more, he added.
