DOC.HEAD: Castro Searches For Political Advantage in Fleeing Cubans
An AP News Analysis
DOC.TEXT: To Fidel Castro, the spectacle of Cubans fleeing his revolution is less a problem than an opportunity to score points against capitalist foes. As is his custom, Castro went on the offensive Thursday night, daring the United States, Spain and other proponents of ``human rights'' to take in all Cubans who are fed up with his revolution. The only Cubans exempted from this offer, he said, are the 40 or so who have barged into foreign embassies over the past 18 days to ask for political asylum. It is inconsistent for Western governments, he said, to offer refuge to unhappy Cubans at their embassies on the one hand, while not welcoming Cubans who wish to emigrate through more conventional procedures. In Washington, the Bush administration sharply rejected Castro's sarcastic call for U.S. ships to come and pick up Cubans unhappy with his rule. One of the darkest moments of Castro's 31-year rule occurred 10 years ago when 125,000 Cubans fled to Florida aboard ships with little more than the shirts on their backs. The exodus began when Cubans by the thousands began seeking asylum at the Peruvian Embassy. There was a sense of deja vu this month when Cubans eager to leave began arriving at the Czech embassy. Others sought refuge at embassies elsewhere in the capital. Could this be Castro's Waterloo? After all, the Communist regime in East Germany began to unravel last year after Hungary allowed East Germans to escape to the West through its country. Within months, democratic movements were sweeping Communist governments from power throughout Eastern Europe. Castro easily survived the exodus a decade ago, but now he is faced with political and ideological isolation and an economy worse off in many ways than it was in 1980. When encountering difficulty, Castro is not one to pout. He demonstrated that trait Thursday night when he spoke to hundreds of thousands of his countrymen on the 37th anniversary of the start of his revolutionary movement. He was especially tough on Spain, whose embassy has sheltered 18 uninvited asylum-seekers over the past week. Four others are at the Italian ambassador's residence. His voice rising in indignation, Castro chastized Spain for sheltering Cubans who were not targets of law enforcement authorities. The Spaniards, he said, are even giving refuge to a Cuban who fought his way in with a machete. He expressed outrage with Spain's decision last week to suspend a $2.5 million aid program for Cuba. He said the move puts Spain in the same league as Cuba's No. 1 enemy, the United States. ``For arrogance, for pride, who knows why, they (the Spaniards) have made themselves accomplices ... in the imperialist aggression against Cuba,'' he said. Castro did not spare President Bush either, suggesting that Bush is obsessed with bringing down Communism in Cuba. He cited the recent testimony of a Cuban dissident, who said that as far back as March the U.S. diplomatic mission had been encouraging Cubans to seek asylum at foreign embassies. Beyond that, he said the United States has not fulfilled the 1984 bilateral agreement on immigration, thus indirectly forcing Cubans who want to escape to utilize drastic means. He also said Bush was lobbying the Soviet Union to suspend aid to Cuba and had threatened the island with military exercises in nearby waters. ``When Bush goes to eat breakfast, he finds Cuba in his coffee, in the water, in the bread,'' Castro said. ``Neither asleep nor awake does he forget about Cuba. It is a sick obsession and a shame for the world.'' The U.S. diplomatic mission here says the United States has lived up to the 1984 immigration agreement and never incited Cubans to seek refuge at foreign embassies. The Spanish government said Friday it had no interest in further conflict with Cuba and did not encourage aslyum-seekers. ``Accusatory or high-flown phrases don't help very much to produce the dialogue'' needed to resolve the problem, said the Foreign Ministry undersecretary, Inocencio Arias.
DOC.NOTE: EDITOR'S NOTE
DOC.TEXT: George Gedda has covered foreign affairs for The Associated Press since 1968.

DOC.HEAD: Panel Urges Removing Social Security Surplus From Deficit
DOC.TEXT: A Department of Health and Human Services advisory panel Friday recommended removing Social Security from the calculation of deficit reduction targets to focus public attention on the ballooning deficit. The Advisory Council on Social Security also recommended continuing the payroll tax rate at the current level to build reserves as a cushion for the retirement of 75 million baby boomers, which will begin around 2010. The council said in its interim report that maintaining a strong Social Security system depends on having a healthy, growing economy and that large deficits in the federal budget weaken the economy. ``The Council believes that the growing Social Security reserves should not routinely be used simply to offset large operating deficits in the rest of the federal budget,'' the panel said. The panel's report said the financial soundness of the Social Security trust funds is not affected by whether the trust funds are included or excluded in calculating deficit reduction targets. But ``taking Social Security out of the Gramm-Rudman-Hollings calculations will help federal policy-makers and the American people focus on the fundamental importance of reducing the deficit and moving toward a surplus in the overall federal budget,'' the council said. The council also opposed changing the Social Security program's financing to a ``pay-as-you-go'' system, in which payroll taxes would be set at a rate sufficient to raise enough revenues to cover current expenses and maintain a contingency reserve. Under the current system, Social Security taxes raise more than is needed for current payments to build up reserves for use in future years. These trillions of dollars in baby boomer's future retirement benefits stirred heated debate earlier this year when Sen. Daniel Patrick Moynihan, D-N.Y., proposed cutting the Social Security payroll tax. Under Moynihan's plan, the tax would begin going up again in the year 2015. He said that would give the country 25 years of lower taxes to help the economy grow and allow it to afford the higher taxes later. The White House opposed the idea and the plan is stalled in Congress. The council also recommended continuing the current policy of investing Social Security trust fund reserves in interest-bearing Treasury securities guaranteed by the government. About 39 million Americans receive Social Security benefits, most of them retired workers. The payroll tax rate paid by workers and employers is 6.2 percent each on earnings up to $51,300. Self-employed workers pay both the employer and employee share of the tax.

DOC.HEAD: Israel: Will Use Chemical Weapons Against Iraq if Attacked
DOC.TEXT: Israel could respond with its own chemical weapons if Iraq attacked it with such arms, Science Minister Yuval Neeman said Friday in an escalation of Middle East war rhetoric. Defense Ministry spokesman Danny Naveh refused to comment on Neeman's remarks, the most far-reaching by an Israeli leader on the subject. Israel is widely believed to have chemical weapons, but officials have never admitted it. Neeman's warning was the latest volley in a war of words started by Iraqi President Saddam Hussein, who in April threatened to burn half of Israel if Israel attacked Iraq. In June 1981, Israel bombed an Iraqi nuclear reactor near Baghdad, claiming it was being used to develop nuclear weapons. Iraq denied this. Last week, Saddam threatened hostilities with neighboring Kuwait and the United Arab Emirates if they did not cut oil production. In the past week, Israeli officials have sharpened their rhetoric in response to Saddam, with Defense Minister Moshe Arens saying Iraq's threats have increased the likelihood of war. Some Israeli newspaper editorials and analysts said Arens and others apparently were trying to rally U.S. support at a time when the U.S. Congress is debating wide-ranging cuts in military spending that could affect Israel. Neeman, a member of the ultra-rightist Tehiya Party, said in an interview with Israel radio Friday that Israel was ready to counter Iraqi threats. ``In my opinion, we have an excellent response, and that is to threaten (Saddam) Hussein with the same merchandise,'' said Neeman, who also is head of Israel's space program. Neeman said any advanced nation has the capability to manufacture chemical weapons. ``And if there is an enemy like this, it is possible to prepare a suitable response,'' he said. Reached by telephone after the radio broadcast, Neeman did not deny he meant Israel had chemical weapons. When asked directly if the country possessed such arms, he replied: ``That'a a question for the minister of defense.'' Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir apparently was displeased by Neeman's remarks. A source in Shamir's office said the prime minister would meet with Neeman to discuss the radio interview. Neeman, 65, has served in the past both as deputy director of army intelligence and scientific director of Israel's atomic energy program. Another threat against Iraq came from Eliyahu Ben Elissar, head of Parliament's Defense and Foreign Affairs Committee, who said in a speech Thursday night that Israel would retaliate harshly if attacked by Iraq. Editorials in two left-leaning papers, Al-Hamishmar and Davar, said Arens' remarks on Iraq increasing the likelihood of war were mostly aimed at gaining more money for Israel's defense. Military analyst Aharon Levran said that talk of war was exaggerated and aimed, in part, at securing continued U.S. funding for the Arrow anti-missile system that Israel is developing. Levran, a retired brigidier general, argued that with Egypt and Syria unlikely to attack Israel, Iraq would have a hard time waging war because it doesn't share a border with the Jewish state. At worst, ``there might be an exchange of air blows, but I don't see a continued and intensive war erupting because of the distance.''

DOC.HEAD: Cars Pulled Out of Popular Swimming Hole in Apparent `Car-dunking' Scam
DOC.TEXT: More than a dozen vehicles, some nearly new, have been pulled from a popular swimming hole, which police also found to be a popular repository for ``car-dunking.'' Most of the cars were dumped by owners who then falsely reported the vehicles stolen to collect insurance money, officers said Thursday. Others, primarily the very new ones, were dumped when people got behind in payments and wanted to collect on the insurance, police said. ``Car-dunking,'' a form of insurance fraud is to blame for most of the cars being submerged in the cool, green pond that is surrounded by sunflowers and tall grass, authorities said. All of the vehicles had been reported stolen in Plano, Arlington, Dallas and Sherman. But none showed evidence of auto theft when wreckers dragged them from the pond, according to Plano Detective Gregg Gibbs. Anna is located between Dallas and Sherman in north Texas. ``We were finding that they were unstripped with keys in the ignition and boards and bricks holding the accelerators down,'' Gibbs said. ``It is estimated that 46 percent of all auto thefts reported in the United States are actually insurance fraud,'' he said. Collin County sheriff's investigator Jim Broyles said officers became suspicious when swimmers reported seeing oil slicks on the water. Broyles and other divers then went into the water and discovered the underwater parking lot. Many of the cars were piled on top of other cars, Broyles said. ``It was like swimming through a wrecking yard,'' Broyles said. Charley Evans, division manager of the National Auto Theft Bureau in Dallas, said car-dunking scams are common nationwide. Many ponds across the country are probably filled with cars, he said. But Evans said he has never heard of so many cars being found in one place before.

DOC.HEAD: Hijacker Extradited to Soviet Union
DOC.TEXT: A Soviet hijacker who forced an Aeroflot passenger jet to land in Helsinki last month was extradited to the Soviet Union Friday. The 20-year-old hijacker, Oleg Kozlov, had applied for political asylum, but was turned down. He was handed over to Soviet authorities at the Finnish border post of Vaalimaa. News reports quoted Kozlov as saying he was too upset to comment to the press before his departure. Kozlov's hijacking of a flight from Riga, Latvia, on June 19 was one of five such incidents in June and early July. During that time, three Soviet flights were commandeered to Sweden and two to Finland. Soviet authorities have requested that all the hijackers be extradited. One hijacker remains in custody in Finland. Sweden extradited one hijacker and still holds two others. Swedish lawyers, Ukrainian deputies and others have appealed to the Swedish authorities to sentence the youths in Sweden. They say Soviet courts still lack standards of fairness and the hijackers could face up to 15 years in prison under atrocious conditions. But Sweden's Supreme Court ruled earlier this week there were no legal obstacles to the extraditions.

DOC.HEAD: Berlin Authorities Arrest Suspect in 1986 Bombing of Disco
DOC.TEXT: Authorities have arrested a suspect in the 1986 bombing of a West Berlin discotheque frequented by U.S. soldiers that led to an American air raid on Libya, officials said Friday. A man, described only as being of an Arab nationality, was arrested Wednesday, said Werner Thronicker, a spokesman for the West Berlin Interior Ministry. Authorities searched six apartments and a jail cell and also seized written materials they said could help the investigation, Thronicker said. He refused to identify the man or release any other details. The April 5, 1986, bombing of the La Belle discotheque, a popular spot for U.S. military personnel, killed two American soldiers and a Turkish woman. More than 200 people were injured. U.S. officials blamed Libya for the attack. Ten days later, U.S. jets bombed the Libyan cities of Benghazi and Tripoli. Several recent West German newspaper reports have said East Germany's secret police were aware that the disco bombing was being planned and allowed it to be carried out. West Germany's Stern magazine reported July 10 that one of the suspects was already jailed on another criminal matter. It said the suspect was being used as a prosecution witness. There have been reports that information on the case has come from former East German secret police files, which are believed to contain a treasure trove of information about terrorist activity.

DOC.HEAD: News of Rare Case Reverberates; CDC Says Report in `Public Interest'
DOC.TEXT: Federal AIDS experts said Friday they likely will never know for sure whether a dentist transmitted AIDS to a patient, but were obligated to warn the public about the possibility. A report Thursday from the U.S. Centers for Disease Control that a young woman apparently was infected by her dentist while having two molars pulled made headlines across the country and drew criticism from the American Dental Association. Dental association officials said the agency may have jumped to conclusions. Dr. Harold Jaffe, deputy director for science at the CDC's HIV-AIDS program, said Friday there's no way researchers will ever prove that the woman was infected during the dental procedure, although all available evidence points to that conclusion. ``We don't really expect we will get more information,'' Jaffe said. The CDC's weekly report, which carried details of the case, routinely informs physicians and public health officials about noteworthy developments in infectious disease. It is not unusual for the report to note _ as this week's report did _ that the source of a specific illness cannot be proven with 100 percent certainty. But Dr. Enid Neidle, director of scientific affairs for the Chicago-based ADA, said the association thought it was not a conclusive case of transmission. ``We are not happy at any report that could raise fears on the part of the public that the dental office is a place of danger and infection,'' Neidle said. Responding to the ADA's criticism, Jaffe said, ``I don't think we'd be serving the public interest to not publish this case.'' The agency said a lengthy investigation of the woman's case found no other risk factors for AIDS, such as intravenous drug abuse or numerous sexual encounters. Two men she had dated each tested negative for HIV, the AIDS virus, and DNA-virus testing showed a likely match between her strain of HIV and the dentist's. But researchers are not exactly sure how the woman actually became infected. Jaffe said not much more will ever be known about the case. The woman's trip to the dentist occurred more than two years ago, records in the case are somewhat sketchy and there's a limited amount to be gleaned from questioning the doctor, he said. ``Everyone's frustration here revolves around the lack of information about the specific exposure,'' he said. The dentist was wearing a mask and gloves while pulling the woman's teeth, as recommended. The case has prompted the CDC to review its guidelines for transmission of AIDS in medical settings. The guidelines say that to prevent the spread of diseases such as AIDS and hepatitis, bodily fluids from any patient must be considered potentially infectious. Health care workers are urged to wear appropriate protection whenever skin or mucous-membrane exposure to bodily fluids is likely, including gloves, face masks, protective goggles and surgical gowns. Federal experts will meet Aug. 13 with representatives from the dentral association, other medical societies, workers groups and other interested parties to discuss the case. ``We have no doubt that if the CDC decides that some aspects of the (precautionary) procedures should be changed, and there is a consensus, the ADA will obviously take under very serious consideration the recommendations that emerge,'' Neidle said. ``But it's difficult to imagine how one could get more elaborate than the current precautions are.'' Since the CDC report was made public, many dentists have called the dental association for more information about the federal report, said Phil Weintraub, the organization's manager of media relations. ``They're very concerned about how the public is going to take this information,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Forty-two Convicted Coup Plotters Executed
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 2 grafs to upgrade attribution, ADD color from prison. Pickup 3rd pvs, `They were...;' SUB grafs 8-9, `More than... the government' with 2 to add report of acquittals. Pickup 10th pvs, `No casualty...
DOC.TEXT: Forty-two men convicted in a bloody coup attempt were executed by firing squad Friday night immediately after appeals of their death sentences were rejected, the government announced. The echoes of rifle fire were heard outside Kirikiri Prison, where the condemned men were held. Many prominent Nigerians and international organizations, including Amnesty International, had urged President Gen. Ibrahim Babangida to spare their lives. They were charged with attacking Dodon Barracks, the military headquarters and residence of Babangida, on April 22 in an attempt to overthrow him. Babangida barely escaped with his life, and his house was badly damaged. The coup leaders, who took over national radio headquarters for several hours, said they wanted to end the domination of the country by Moslem northerners. The men were convicted following a military tribunal this month that was closed to the public, and they were sentenced to death. The Armed Forces Ruling Council rejected appeals of the death sentences, and the executions were carried out, the radio reported. The council ordered retrials for 31 other people convicted by a military tribunal. The council met Thursday and Friday, making its ruling late Friday afternoon. There was little doubt the coup ringleaders, including Maj. Gideon Orkar, would be shot. Wooden stakes had been set up at the prison where the men were held. Hundreds of people, including some civilians, were arrested after the coup attempt. The government said the civilian financer of the coup, millionaire businessman Chief Great Ovedje Ogboru, and some officers believed involved in it, had escaped. Adm. Augustus Aikhomu, the No. 2 man in the military government, read a statement on television and radio Friday evening saying 764 people had been acquitted of all charges. No casualty figures were ever released from the attempted overthrow, but army spokesman Col. Fred Chijuka said it was ``the bloodiest'' attempt ever against the government. Dozens of people died in coups in 1966, which triggered ethnic violence that ultimately sparked the Biafran War. The 1967-1970 war was an effort by easterners to secede from the federation. The easterners, mostly Christian or followers of traditional African religions, alleged Moslem northerners dominated the nation. The rebels, after capturing the national radio station in April, made a similar claim. They also said Babangida's execution of Lt. Gen. Mamman Vatsa in 1986, for allegedly plotting a coup, was a reason for seeking his overthrow. Ethnic tensions were fanned in January when Babangida removed Lt. Gen. Domkat Bali from his post as defense minister, effectively demoting the most important non-northerner in the government. Though Bali said he remained loyal to the president, there were widespread protests of his reassignment, and the general retired. The government sought to portray the coup attempt as a bid by greedy soldiers to gain wealth. It said coup backers offered $1,428 to enlisted men and $7,142 for officers. Fighting began at 2 a.m. with an attack on Dodan Barracks. Babangida fled and directed a counterattack. Fighting continued for 10 hours and was only quelled after senior commanders in other regions of the country went on the radio to announce their support for Babangida.

DOC.HEAD: Man Convicted of Trying to Extort Anchorwoman Over Imaginary Nude Photos
DOC.TEXT: A man was convicted of demanding $30,000 from a local anchorwoman to block publication of naked pictures that did not exist. A Superior Court jury Thursday convicted Gilbert Cabot, 44, of attempted extortion and conspiracy in connection with a 1988 plot against KTLA anchorwoman Jann Carl. Cabot, who is to be sentenced Sept. 11, faces up to five years in prison. Prosecutors described the Los Angeles man as a veteran con artist. They said Cabot called Carl and told her a woman planned to sell nude photos of the anchorwoman to a national magazine. Cabot said the photos were taken from a sexually explicit videotape, and that he could block their publication by paying the woman $30,000, prosecutors said. Carl, knowing the tape did not exist, helped police with a sting operation that resulted in Cabot's June 1988 arrest.

DOC.HEAD: Congress Told Kids Still Dying on ATVs
DOC.TEXT: A 2-year-old agreement regulating all-terrain vehicles fails to protect children from death and serious injury, said congressmen, state legislators and consumer advocates on Friday. ``ATVs are kid-killers, plain and simple,'' said Charles J. Chvala, a Wisconsin state senator, urging further federal action to ban ATV use by children under 16. Even adult riders face risks due to the lack of adequate safety standards for the stability of the off-road vehicles, witnesses told the Senate Governmental Affairs Committee. ``Your age doesn't mean you're going to be safe,'' said Rep. Bill Sarpalius, describing how he suffered a broken back when an ATV he was riding rolled over. The Texas Democrat called for an outright ban on sales of ATVs in the United States. Government figures show about 300 people are killed annually in ATV-related incidents and 50,000 people are injured. The government estimates there will be 200 such deaths and 39,000 injuries in 1992. But industry representatives argued that a 1988 consent decree signed with the Consumer Product Safety Commission provides for an unprecedented $8 million consumer information program and has resulted in a reduction of injuries. The agreement between the CPSC and five manufacturers of ATVs in the United States _ Honda, Yamaha, Suzuki, Polaris and Kawasaki _ banned sales of new three-wheel ATVs, restricted marketing of larger four-wheelers to adults and required age restriction labeling on vehicles and notices in dealerships. ``It is virtually impossible for a consumer to visit an ATV dealership and not be made aware of appropriate age recommendations and safe use information,'' said Howard P. Willens, an attorney representing ATV makers. CPSC Chairwoman Jacqueline Jones-Smith defended the accord, saying it struck ``a balance between allowing consumers the freedom to purchase adult-sized ATVs ... while at the same time, providing consumers with protection against the risks associated with ATVs.'' However, recent government and consumer studies have shown dealers routinely violate the agreement. ``I do not mean to belittle the efforts of the CPSC,'' said Sen. Joseph Lieberman, D-Conn., a member of governmental affairs panel. ``Nevertheless, the number of deaths and injuries from ATVs remains unacceptably high, and children under 16 still account for nearly 40 percent of those hurt or killed.'' Anne Graham, a commissioner who has opposed most CPSC decisions regarding ATVs, said the government must do more to get children off adult-sized ATVs, including considering a ban. ``These machines are not bought by children,'' said Willens, arguing that federal or state action to ban the ATVs would be improper. Willens insisted that a subsequent letter of agreement with the CPSC regarding monitoring and dealer discipline would ensure greater compliance. Two consumer groups, the Consumer Federation of America and U.S. Public Interest Research Group said it had submitted a petition to the CPSC that would close gaps in the current accord. The organizations recommended the agency institute a permanent ban on three-wheel ATVs, a ban on ATV sales to children, a mandatory requirement for ATV lateral stability and a refund program to consumers for ATVs purchased for children. Willens said manufacturers would resist any refund program.

DOC.HEAD: Mandela Denies Plot Within ANC to Overthrow Government
DOC.TEXT: Nelson Mandela insisted Friday there was no Communist plot within the African National Congress to seize power, but the national police chief said arrests of ANC guerrillas probably would continue. Police Gen. Johan van der Merwe said the detention of a number of senior ANC and South African Communist Party militants in recent days had turned up considerable evidence of a conspiracy. In an interview with the state-run South African Broadcasting Corp., van der Merwe said more arrests ``were likely,'' but gave no details. President F.W. de Klerk met with Mandela for more than two hours Thursday night. News reports said de Klerk showed him police evidence of an alleged plan by Communist members of the ANC to stage a revolt if negotiations with the government break down. ``There is no plot as far as we're concerned,'' Mandela said Friday morning. The ANC's National Executive Committee, which includes several leaders of the South African Communist Party, is to meet over the next three days to discuss the government allegations, and Mandela said he and de Klerk would meet again Aug. 1. ANC spokesman Pallo Jordan said de Klerk told Mandela the government would prefer that Communist Party leader Joe Slovo not be part of the ANC delegation in talks with the government on Aug. 6. The talks are aimed at removing barriers to full-scale negotiations on ending white-minority rule. The ANC is insisting among other things that the government release all political prisoners and lift the remaining state of emergency. The government wants the ANC to agree to a cease-fire. The ANC has been allied with the South African Communist Party for more than four decades. Slovo is a member of the ANC's executive committee and a former chief of the ANC military wing. De Klerk's office said the president had invited Mandela to the meeting in Pretoria because ``it appears ... the ANC does not appreciate the seriousness of the facts which were brought to light by the South African police investigations of the past few days.'' A police statement said about 40 militants had been arrested recently because of ``information about an alleged conspiracy by the (Communist Party) and the ANC's military wing to overthrow the government by force if negotiations with the government failed.'' Several newspapers reported that de Klerk had shown Mandela a police dossier allegedly based on seized records of a Communist Party meeting. The police reportedly said Slovo announced that the party would not be bound by any cease-fire between the ANC and the government. The reports said Slovo made the remark two weeks after signing an agreement in May with the government and the ANC to work to end violence. South African newspapers, quoting unidentified government sources, have said the ANC's top leadership and the commanders of the ANC military wing did not know about the alleged plot.

DOC.HEAD: Third Child in Week Dies by Stray Gunfire in New York City
LaserPhotos NY12, NY13
DOC.TEXT: Ed McKay scanned the bullet-riddled room in the Brooklyn apartment where his 3-year-old nephew was killed while sleeping on a pullout couch. ``Maybe where you live, children are not being shot, but this violence is a cancer and creeping, and it won't be long before it is in your neighborhood, too,'' he warned. The boy, Ben Williams, was hit by one of 18 bullets sprayed through the metal front door of his grandmother's four-bedroom apartment in the Walt Whitman housing project about 4 a.m. Thursday. He was the city's third child in a week to die from stray gunfire. ``When a child can't sleep in his own bed comfortably, the city's got to wake up,'' McKay said Thursday. The shooting in the Fort Greene section devastated the boy's grandmother, Susie O'Garro, who often cared for others' children, said McKay. Family members said they did not know why anyone would fire on the apartment. Police investigators working on the case Friday had no immediate explanation. Earlier this week, 1-year-old Yaritimi Fruto and 9-year-old Veronica Corales were killed by stray gunfire in the East New York section of Brooklyn. Fruto was shot in the head by a gunman who killed her father. Corales was struck in the head as she slept in her family's car after returning from a New Jersey amusement park. Housing Police Chief Vincent Pizzo said three weapons were used to fire 18 shots through the first floor apartment where young Ben Williams was killed and his 15-year-old sister was grazed. Thirteen other shots were fired through a second-floor apartment door where no one was hurt. ``I think there's too many illegal guns in this city and too many people not afraid to use them,'' Pizzo said. There have been several drug-related shootings at the complex, he said. Timothy O'Garro, 26, another uncle of the dead boy, said an older brother of the victim was recently released from prison. ``My mother told him, `Don't come here at all,''' Garro recalled. However, Chief of Detectives Joseph Borrelli said authorities were not sure the brother was the intended target. He was not in the apartment during the shooting, police said. ``These are the rumors that are flying around. We're not satisfied that that's the reason,'' said Borrelli. In the apartment, a tiny white teddy bear rested upside down against a wall. Several strollers were neatly stacked nearby. Bullets also struck the stereo and television and a kitchen towel was taped over the large bullet holes in the front door. Family members pointed out 22 pictures, many including the victim, displayed in the room where the boy was shot. Neighbor Paula Perry said she was ``going to miss the little boy. He was smart. He asked me for cookies. If somebody told him `no' he would go ask somebody else.'' The tragedy overwhelmed neighbor Lilly Ramos, who has spent all of her 21 years at the housing complex. ``They shot a 3-year-old over there last year,'' she said, pointing to an area where children played. ``He lived. ``Why? Why this little boy?'' she asked. ``I hate this neighborhood. I want out of here.''

DOC.HEAD: Utility Reports Shutdown, Gas Release at Pennsylvania Nuclear Plant
DOC.TEXT: Radioactive gas was released from a nuclear reactor early Friday shortly after the unit at a power plant was shut down, Philadelphia Electric Co. announced. The 10-minute release from Unit 3 was well below limits for the plant, and didn't endanger the public or workers at the Peach Bottom plant near the Pennsylvania-Maryland line about 40 miles west of Philadelphia, officials said. Philadelphia Electric declared an unusual event at the plant, the lowest of four classifications of nuclear power plant emergencies. Unit 3 had been working at full power when it was shut down at 4:03 a.m. because of low suction in the unit's steam condenser, Philadelphia Electric said. During the shutdown, the operators declared an unusual event at 5:38 a.m. because of a momentary increase in radiation levels in an internal gas filtering system. The unusual event ended at 6 a.m., the utility said. No radiation was released up to then. The gas release happened after the shutdown, as plant operators were trying to restore suction in the steam condenser, Philadelphia Electric said. The release consisted primarily of inert gases such as xenon and krypton, which don't react with other chemicals, said Nuclear Regulatory Commission spokesman Karl Abraham. Such gases are normally dispersed in the atmosphere, Abraham said. ``The radioactivity from such a release is usually too low to measure,'' he said. Unit 3 will remain shut down while workers do maintenance, said utility spokesman Neil McDermott. ``They've been waiting for an opportunity to work on some systems and this is it,'' McDermott said. ``None of the work is safety-related.'' While the 1,055-megawatt reactor is shut down, its twin, Unit 2, is expected to continue working at 100 percent output, McDermott said. The middle of summer is a time of peak demand for electricity in the Philadelphia area. McDermott said the loss of Unit 3 would ``obviously make conditions a little tighter, depending on the weather.'' Abraham said NRC resident inspectors at the plant would pursue a routine follow-up on the shutdown and gas release while Philadelphia Electric carries out its own investigation. In addition to the NRC, the utility said it reported the release to Pennsylvania, Maryland and York County officials.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Finds Navy Lieutenant Guilty of Raping Woman Officer
DOC.NOTE: Eds: note contents
DOC.TEXT: A military judge on Friday convicted a U.S. Navy lieutenant of raping a woman officer in her stateroom aboard an ammunitions ship. Naval officials in Spain said they could not recall a previous instance of a Navy officer being tried or convicted for raping a female officer on board ship. Lt. j.g. Robin E. Brown of Rawlins, Wyo., remained expressionless as military judge U.S. Navy Capt. Thomas A. Lawrence announced the verdict. Lawrence scheduled sentencing for Saturday in the court at the U.S.-Spanish naval station in Rota, in southernmost Spain. The case stemmed from an incident April 4 on the USS Suribachi while in port in Cartagena, Spain. In his closing argument Friday, prosecutor Marine Capt. Walter G. Sharp said the evidence showed Brown had entered the woman officer's stateroom, gotten into her bed and began having intercourse with her while she was asleep. When the woman awakened, she pushed Brown away and told him to leave the room. Under the law, Sharp said, a sleeping woman cannot give consent to sexual intercourse. He pointed to the results of a medical exam of the woman just after the incident, which showed the presence of semen. The case has drawn attention because as the number of women in the Navy has increased in recent years, so have complaints of sexual harassment and discrimination. The U.S. military adopted an all-volunteer force in 1972, and since then the number of women in the Navy has grown from 9,000 to 64,000. The Navy said shipboard rapes are extremely rare. The 350-member crew of the Suribachi includes 34 women, five of whom are officers. There are about 25 male officers serving on the ship, according to Navy spokesman Lt. Paul Weishaupt. The defense attorney, Marine Capt. J.H. Drescher, suggested the woman had mistaken Brown for another officer aboard the ship for whom she acknowledged romantic feelings. He stressed the woman referred to Brown by the other man's name as soon as she woke up.

DOC.HEAD: Cattle Count Unchanged From Year-Ago Level
DOC.TEXT: A mid-year cattle inventory showed 108.9 million head on the nation's farms and ranches as of July 1, virtually unchanged from the levels of one and two years ago, the Agriculture Department said Friday. The figure compared to last year's 108.6 million and the 108.5 million level of 1988. Officials said the 1990 calf crop is expected to be 40 million head, down fractionally from last year and 1 percent below 1988. The July 1 inventory of 108.9 million head _ which includes calves and dairy cattle as well as beef stock _ included these categories, compared with the last two years, respectively: _Beef cows, 34.3 million, up slightly from July 1, 1989 and 1 percent above July 1988. _Milk cows, 10.1 million, unchanged from last year and 1 percent below two years ago. _All heifers 500 pounds and over, 16.8 million, up 1 percent from last year and up 2 percent from two years ago. _Beef replacement heifers, 5.2 million, up 4 percent from 1989 and 8 percent from 1988. _Milk replacement heifers, 4.3 million, down 4 percent from last year and down 2 percent from two years ago. _Other heifers, 7.3 million, up 1 percent from a year ago and unchanged from two years ago. _Steers weighing 500 pounds and over, 14.7 million, up 1 percent from both years. _Bulls weighing 500 pounds and over, 2.2 million, unchanged from both years. _Calves under 500 pounds, 30.8 million, down fractionally from last year and down 1 percent from two years ago.

DOC.HEAD: Roemer Vetoes Abortion Bill
LaserPhoto NU1
DOC.TEXT: Gov. Buddy Roemer on Friday vetoed what would have been the nation's toughest state abortion law. He said the male-dominated Legislature that fashioned it was insensitive to the rights of rape victims. The decision by Roemer, who describes himself as ``pro-life,'' drew outrage from abortion opponents. ``He's betrayed the pro-life majority that elected him,'' said Nancy Myers, spokeswoman for the National Right to Life Committee in Washington. Rep. Woody Jenkins, the bill's sponsor, said he would ask the Legislature to return for a special August session to hand the governor an override. If that happened, it would be the first override this century in Louisiana. The bill had been thrown together in the tumultous final days of the session, which ended July 9. During the session, Roemer vetoed an even tougher bill that would have made an exception only to save the life of the mother. An override of that veto failed by only three votes. In March, Idaho Gov. Cecil Andrus vetoed a similar bill, which would have banned abortion except when the mother's life was threatened, in most cases of rape, or in cases of incest when the victim was under 18 years old. The bill vetoed Friday was passed in both legislative chambers with more than the two-thirds majorities necessary for an override. Because the session is over, however, lawmakers would have to call themselves back for a special session by mail. The bill would have prohibited abortions except to save the life of the mother and in cases of aggravated rape and incest reported to police and a physician no more than a week after they occurred. Had the bill become law, doctors who perform abortions could be sentenced to 10 years in prison and $100,000 fines. The bill was designed to challenge the U.S. Supreme Court's 1973 Roe vs. Wade decision that legalized abortion. ``I consider myself pro-life ... abortion on demand and as a substitute for birth control must be, in the name of the unborn, sharply controlled,'' Roemer told reporters. But ``rape is treated unevenly and unfairly'' in the bill, and its seven-day reporting period ``is totally unworkable and uncaring and unrealistic,'' he said. The bill allowed abortions in cases of aggravated rape, in which the victim had been threatened with death or injury from a weapon. It did not protect victims of simple rape, defined as sexual intercourse when a woman is incapable of resisting, such as when she is drunk, unconscious, or afraid of the rapist. ``One of the things that I've tried to become sensitive to is the voice of women on this issue,'' Roemer said. ``It might serve us well, legislators and governors, who tend to be predominantly male, to take time to listen to the viewpoint of women.'' Only three of the 144 state legislators are women. ``One of the most burdensome things about the bill that I vetoed today is that it did not listen at all,'' Roemer said. ``It's like simple rape was non-existent. It was like if a woman was mentally retarded she had no right and was fair game. How insensitive can you be?'' Abortion rights advocates said they were heartened. ``Roemer's response to this challenge restores the nation's confidence in our state's leadership and sends a clear and distinctive message that the power of the pro-choice majority cannot be denied,'' said Joy Gilmore, president of the state chapter of the National Organization for Women. But abortion foe Myers said: ``Governor Roemer has abandoned thousands of unborn children. ... He's using phony excuses to hide the fact that he doesn't care at all for unborn children.''

DOC.HEAD: Canada Buys Land in Bid to End Mohawk Dispute
DOC.TEXT: Canada said Friday that its Indian Affairs Department bought a parcel of land from a French businessman in the hopes of ending a 17-day-old armed confrontation between Quebec police and Mohawks. The standoff in Oka, 18 miles west of Montreal, began after police rushed a barricade set up by the Mohawks to stop the expansion of the local golf course on land they claim is ancestral. An officer was killed in the gun battle that followed. No announcement has been made fixing responsibility in the death. Indian Affairs Minister Tom Siddon said in a statement that the Ottawa government will buy 60 residential lots _ about 30 acres _ just outside Oka for nearly $1.2 million (U.S.) from Maxime Rousseau of Poitiers, France. He said the government also hopes to buy the rest of the disputed parcel of land, a total of 54 acres. ``We're negotiating to complete the purchase of the balance from the village of Oka,'' Siddon said. Josee Beliveau, a spokeswoman for Oka, said the town could still be left with enough land to expand the golf course. Mohawk negotiator Mavis Etienne shrugged off the purchase announced Friday as ``a drop in the bucket,'' adding: ``No one has any business negotiating for our land, acting like they are buying it when they don't even own it.'' At the Kahnawake reserve south of Montreal, Mohawks have blocked Mercier Bridge to Montreal in sympathy with the Oka Mohawks, forcing commuters to make long detours.

DOC.HEAD: FCC Head Says Cities Should Allow Cable Competition
DOC.NOTE: EDS: SUBS 9th graf pvs, bgng: Most cable, to CORRECT to `systems in the country' sted in the company. INSERTS 2 grafs after 11th graf pvs, The pro-competitive, to UPDATE with Sen. Lieberman comment. Picks up 12th graf pvs, Sikes, who ... ^By JAY ARNOLD
DOC.TEXT: Municipal officials too often slam the door on companies that could provide head-to-head competition for cable TV operators, a federal regulator said Friday. Federal Communications Commission Chairman Alfred Sikes rejected the notion that, like utility monopolies, communities are best served by exclusive cable TV franchises. Competition, he said, will drive down both costs and prices. But he said a new FCC study of the cable TV marketplace shows that cable operators face head-to-head competition in only a handful of communities. The result, Sikes told a news conference, is high prices and poor service. ``Head-to-head competition places an exceptionally high premium on cutting costs and putting the customer first,'' Sikes said. ``Competitive markets and competitive markets alone will in the final analysis forces prices toward true costs.'' Rather than reregulate cable prices, which Congress is preparing to do after lifting most local rate regulation in 1984, Sikes said laws are needed to ease the way for multiple-cable franchises and more competition from technologies such as satellite broadcasters and microwave cable systems. On Thursday, Sikes and his fellow commissioners voted 5-0 to forward a report to Congress urging legislation that ``limits municipal authority to erect barriers or sustain entry barriers and which prohibits an unreasonable refusal to grant a second (cable) franchise.'' Most cable systems in the country are de facto monopolies. Local franchising authorities generally prefer to deal with one cable company, while cable operators say it is too risky financially to put two cables into neighborhoods. Sikes said side-by-side cable systems could be economically feasible. He said about 87 percent of the nation's TV viewers could subscribe to cable, but only about 60 percent do. That, Sikes said, shows there are ``many new profit centers potentially available to multichannel video providers. Millions of people in America are waiting for the right package of service at the right price.'' The pro-competitive, rather than regulatory, tone of the FCC report is in line with recent statements that Bush administration officials have made regarding cable legislation pending in Congress. Sen. Joseph Lieberman, D-Conn., said Friday that ``by failing to endorse regulation of cable television rates, the FCC does nothing to protect consumers now from cable monopolists.'' Lieberman, along with Rep. Christopher Shays, R-Conn., has introduced a bill to return rate regulation of most cable programming to state and local authorities. Lieberman said it will be ``years before a truly competitive'' cable market emerges. Sikes, who has been quoted as saying his job is to regulate, denied that he had been told by Congress or the White House to ``back off'' on cable. The House and Senate bills would require the FCC to regulate basic cable prices _ or delegate such authority to municipal officials.

DOC.HEAD: Senate Panel Would Ban Radar Detectors on Trucks
DOC.TEXT: The Senate Appropriations Committee on Friday approved a $29 billion transportation spending bill that would ban radar detectors for trucks and require state courts to suspend the driver's licenses of drug offenders. The bill also includes $125 million to speed passenger rail service between New York and Boston by electrifying rail lines between Boston and New Haven, Conn. Except for increased Amtrak funding and the radar-detector provision, the bill allocates funds in roughly the same manner as the House-passed appropriations bill. The House bill also includes an amendment to require states to suspend the licenses of drug offenders or suffer cuts in federal transportation dollars. The bill covers transportation spending for the fiscal year beginning Oct. 1. The Senate bill sets aside $13.85 billion for highway construction, maintenance and repairs; $8 billion for aviation, including operations at the Federal Aviation Administration; $785 million for Amtrak; and $3.3 billion for mass transit. Committee Chairman Frank R. Lautenberg, D-N.J., said electrifying the New England line will encourage more rail travel between New York and Boston, decreasing the burden on airports.

DOC.HEAD: Give Little Kids a Stimulating Place to Explore
DOC.TEXT: The best way to teach the nation's preschoolers is simple, according to a group of school principals: let them do what interests them and give them a stimulating classroom to explore. Formal academic environments for 3- and 4-year-olds can stunt children's interest in education, the National Association of Elementary School Principals said Friday. Instead, association officials say teachers should let kids learn by playing, freely explore the classroom and do hands-on activities. The association's report, ``Early Childhood Education and the Elementary School Principal,'' has recommendations and a checklist of 28 standards that teachers, schools and parents can apply to change the structured, teacher-directed learning process to a flexible, stimulating one. A daily classroom routine should provide a balance of teacher-directed and child-initiated activities; active and quiet activities; independent and guided activities; and large group, small group and individual group activities, the report says. Among the association's recommendations are that school programs should give children ``a strong sense of self-esteem, social and communication skills and a curiosity for learning.'' ``Children should be assessed and measured by observation, not tested for success or failure. No letter grades should be used,'' the book recommends. The report, which echoes a number of other studies, was released one day before the National Governors Association was to offer its strategies for states to reach six national education goals that make improvements in early childhood education a priority. ``These kids are not just younger versions of our first graders,'' said Samuel Sava, executive director of the principals' association. ``They do not learn in the same ways that older children learn, and their education programs should not be patterned after traditional elementary grade programs.'' The number of 3- and 4-year-old children attending some kind of preschool program has increased by 29 percent since 1965, according to the U.S. Department of Education. The reason, association official said, is that the American family has changed. In most homes, both parents work or the family is headed by a single working parent. These families rely on preschool programs to care for their children. Another reason for the rise in the younger school population is the pressure for achievement, association officials said. Parents think that if children start school earlier, the youngsters will be better prepared for later academic success. Association officials said traditional academic learning should begin no earlier than the third grade. The National Association of Elementary School Principals, established in 1921, is a professional organization serving more than 26,000 elementary and middle school principals in the United States, Canada and overseas.

Also, INSERTS 2 grafs to describe investigation progress after 15th graf pvs bng, ``A NASA committee.'' Picks up 16th graf pvs bng ``Meanwhile, a Perkin-Elmer;'' trims last 6 grafs pvs to shorten.
DOC.HEAD: Losing Bid Offered Independent Check Of Mirrors, Documents Show
DOC.TEXT: An unsuccessful Eastman Kodak bid to make the Hubble Space Telescope mirrors called for a second company to double check the grinding and polishing, a provision not offered by low bidder Perkin-Elmer, the firm that produced the flawed Hubble mirror. The Kodak bid submitted to NASA for manufacture of the Hubble mirrors called for Kodak to make one primary mirror within its plant and for Itek Optical Systems to make an identical primary mirror at another plant. NASA made the bid proposal documents available in response to a Freedom of Information petition. In its proposal, Kodak said that the two mirrors and the different testing systems of the two companies could be used to verify the prescription. One of the two primary mirrors would then be used in the Hubble Space Telescope. NASA officials, however, awarded the contract to Perkin-Elmer. The Danbury, Conn. firm, now known as Hughes Danbury Optical Systems, did its own mirror grinding and polishing and used its own personnel and equipment to check the mirror prescriptions. Perkin-Elmer's winning bid was $64.28 million. Kodak's proposal was for $99.79 million. Through overruns, the Perkin-Elmer contract climbed to an eventual total of $451 million. The Hubble Space Telescope, which was launched in April, has been found to have a focusing flaw in either the primary or secondary mirror. This error, NASA officials have said, means the $1.5 billion telescope is now able to capture images that are only about half as clear as those planned. Dick Wollensak, a vice president of Itek, which is now a subsidiary of Litton Industries, said that the losing Kodak-Itek bid called for a so-called ``end-to-end'' test that would have detected any flaw in the mirrors before the telescope was launched. ``We weren't going to build those things and then not test them after they were assembled,'' he said in a telephone interview. ``Between Kodak and Itek, there were facilities to test the assembled optical system without a major modification.'' NASA officials have said that the Perkin-Elmer optical assembly was not tested after it was put together because it would have required a test facility that may have cost more than $100 million. As a result, the telescope was launched into space without ever being optically tested as an assembled unit. The focusing error was not discovered until the telescope was in orbit. Wollensak said that the Perkin-Elmer design did not allow for the primary mirror to be tested after it was placed into the assembled telescope. He said that the instrument was designed to work in zero gravity and that the gravity of Earth caused the glass to sag slightly, which would have changed the focus. Kodak and Itek, however, said Wollensak, had developed a way to prevent the sag and thus test the mirrors as an assembled unit. Wollensak said he believes cost was a major factor in NASA selecting Perkin-Elmer to make the Hubble optics. ``NASA had developed their own version of what it should cost and that was lower than the Itek-Kodak bid,'' said Wollensak. ``They felt that the Perkin-Elmer bid was low, but they thought that the difference between the NASA expectation and the Perkin-Elmer bid would cover the overrun.'' As it turned out, the final cost was seven times more than the Perkin-Elmer bid. Wollensak said that the Kodak-Itek bid would have avoided many of the problems that led to the Perkin-Elmer overruns. A NASA committee investigating the flawed Hubble telescope plans to return to Perkin-Elmer's plant in Danbury on Aug. 15 for two more days of testimony and a review of documents and equipment related to the flawed optics. The committee met for two days this week in Danbury and an engineer who was there said it may take weeks to find the precise mistake that caused the flawed focus. The engineer, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said the investigation ``is like looking for a bookkeeping error. It will go on and on.'' NASA hopes to be able to have an optical prescription for the error before the exact cause is found, however. Once it can be described mathematically, engineers can make lenses for a replacement Hubble camera that will correct the fuzzy focus for that camera. NASA plans to send a space shuttle to the orbiting telescope in June, 1993, and spacewalking astronauts will replace the old camera with one that has the corrective lenses. Other instruments will be replaced in later years.

DOC.HEAD: Don't Expect to See Roseanne at the White House
With AM-People-Barr
DOC.TEXT: President Bush said Friday that comedienne Roseanne Barr's screeching rendition of the national anthem was ``disgraceful. ``That's the way I feel about it and I think a lot of San Diego fans said the same thing.'' Ms. Barr was loudly booed and has been roundly criticized since she sang the national anthem in an off-key, screaming voice between games of a baseball doubleheader Wednesday at San Diego's Jack Murphy Stadium. Bush, asked if he meant that she won't be invited to sing at the White House, Bush told reporters on Air Force One, ``There's no change of plans on that.''

DOC.HEAD: Senate Gives Final Parliament Approval to State Industry Sell-Off
DOC.TEXT: The Senate has given final parliamentary approval to legislation allowing the transfer of government-owned industries to private investors. That accounts for 80 percent of Polish industries. The Senate voted 60-7 with two abstentions Thursday to approve the law as passed by the Sejm, or lower house of parliament, on July 13. The Senate offered no amendments to the legislation. It adopted a resolution calling for quick work by the Solidarity-led government to prepare regulations for implementing it. Although privatization is considered crucial to the effort to create a capitalist system from the centralized socialist economy, controversy over how the heavily monopolized and often outmoded state-owned industries should be put into private hands delayed passage of the legislation for months. None of the 7,600 state-owned industries will be considered off-limits to privatization. It is expected that only about a dozen of the major factories will be privatized the first year, although the sale or lease of small state-owned shops, restaurants and services are progressing more quickly. All citizens are to be given bonds that can be exchanged for company stocks, allowing even the estimated 65 percent of Polish families with no savings to participate. There is widespread concern that economically depressed Poland will be ``bought out'' by Westerners seeking less expensive properties in central Europe. This is directed most strongly at neighboring Germany. In a reflection of this concern, the Sejm voted Friday to bar the sale of government-owned real estate to non-Poles. The vote was 224-136 with seven abstentions. The law does not apply to privately owned land, which currently can be sold to foreigners with the permission of the Interior Ministry. The threat to Poland that could result from wholesale land purchases by foreigners has stirred concern. Private land now sells for $15 per square yard in the Warsaw area. The envisioned economic might of a united Germany has coupled with vivid memories of its 1939 military invasion to focus distrust on Germans. ``It wouldn't be a problem if they (the foreign property purchasers) were Americans,'' said one parliament member Friday, speaking on condition of anonymity. Sejm Deputy Anna Dynowska told the official PAP news agency that the law still does not solve the problem because privately owned land can be purchased by foreigners. ``So we may face the situation where foreigners will be buying land from Poles who bought it earlier from the state,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: Record Labeling, Abortion Make For a Big Week For Buddy Roemer
DOC.TEXT: For months Louisiana's Legislature had been grabbing the headlines on abortion and record labeling, but this week it was Gov. Buddy Roemer's turn. Roemer made headlines of his own Wednesday and again Friday by undoing what the Legislature did regarding record labeling and abortion. On Wednesday, he vetoed a bill that would have required the recording industry to put warning labels on records deemed to promote deviant sex, drug abuse, violence, suicide or ritualism. It also would have sent retailers to jail if they sold the labeled recordings to minors. Roemer said that, as a parent, he really wanted to sign the bill after reading lyrics of ``some of the trashy music.'' But he vetoed the measure because he believed it threatened First Amendment rights. On Friday, he vetoed an abortion bill that was hastily thrown together on July 8. The measure would have sent doctors who perform abortions to jail for up to 10 years. Although it contained rape and incest exceptions that Roemer said he wanted, the governor said Friday that the rape exception was too narrowly drawn to truly protect a rape victim's right to abortion. The dust won't settle for some time. A move is afoot among some conservative lawmakers to call a rare ``veto session'' in mid-August and attempt to override the Roemer vetos. Susan Howell, a pollster and political science professor at the University of New Orleans, said such a session is unlikely because lawmakers won't want to go through the politically divisive debates again. ``But,'' Howell added, ``You don't make much money betting on the Louisiana Legislature.''

DOC.HEAD: TV Marti Reaching Small Audience, Report Says
DOC.TEXT: TV Marti, the government-sponsored television station making test broadcasts to Cuba, is reaching a small audience outside Havana despite jamming by the Castro government, President Bush told Congress Friday. A feasibility study conducted by the Voice of America and submitted to congressional leaders by the president reached no conclusions as to the future of the operation. The president is expected to make a determination this summer as to whether TV Marti should be made permanent. The VOA said a clear signal of ``excellent quality'' reaches Havana from the transmitter at Cudjoe Key, Fla., and does so without interference to foreign or domestic channels. The report said there is ``widespread interest among Cubans'' in seeing the broadcasts despite the jamming and the fact that they are carried during early morning hours to avoid interfering with Cuban daytime broadcasting on the same channel. TV Marti provides news and entertainment programs. ``Although there is no effective way to overcome Cuban jamming, there are areas where jamming does not interfere with the TV Marti signal,'' the VOA said. The report estimated that possibly 50,000 to 70,000 individuals could occasionally view TV Marti. The population of Cuba is 10.24 million. A survey commissioned by the U.S. Information Agency of Cuban immigrants and visitors arriving in Miami found that 28 percent of households in the primary target area for TV Marti should be able to receive the broadcasts at least occasionally. This would be about 273,000 households. President Fidel Castro of Cuba has called TV Marti a ``gross instrument of subversion'' and jammed it signal from the day programming began.

DOC.HEAD: Jean Fourastie, Economist, Dead at 83
DOC.TEXT: Jean Fourastie, an economist who helped oversee the reconstruction of postwar France, has died. He was 83. A statement from the Academy of Moral and Political Sciences, once headed by Fourastie, said the economist died Wednesday in the Lot region of south-central France. It gave no details. Born April 15, 1907, Fourastie worked alongside such figures as Jean Monnet and Pierre Masse in planning economic and industrial policies after World War II. He was a longtime commentator for the newspaper Le Figaro and the news magazine l'Express. He also wrote numerous books, including ``The Great Hope of the 20th Century'' and ``40,000 Hours.'' In addition to economics, his works dealt with such diverse topics as travel, religion and higher education. He married in 1935 and had four children, one of them now dead. No funeral arrangements were announced.

DOC.HEAD: Terrorist Bomb Explodes in Car of Senior West German Official
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 6 grafs to UPDATE with red Mazda sought, reward offered. Picks up 5th graf `His injuries' with minor editing to trim
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos BON5,6, LaserColor BON106
DOC.TEXT: A roadside bomb activated by a beam of light blasted the luxury sedan of a senior government terrorism-fighter Friday, but he escaped serious injury. A leftist terrorist group claimed responsibility. The attack on Hans Neusel, No. 2 at the Interior Ministry, in charge of counterterrorism, marked a comeback by the Red Army Faction after last month's roundup in East Germany of eight suspected members of the terrorist gang. The government Friday evening offered a $30,000 reward for information leading to apprehension of the attackers. Federal investigators said a red Mazda 323 may have been used in the attack, with terrorists perhaps posing as construction workers or landscapers to plant the bomb. The explosion smashed in the right side of Neusel's BMW, blew out windows, ripped apart upholstery, and sprung open its trunk and hood. It blew a crater in the road, near an autobahn exit in Bonn, and twisted an iron guardrail. Neusel, 62, walked away with a few cuts on his right hand and arm. He pushed the car off the highway to keep it from blocking traffic. His injuries could have been far worse had he been a passenger rather than driving, officials said. West German television said Neusel's chauffeur was on vacation, and he was alone in the car. The Red Army Faction claimed responsibility in a note left near the scene. Also discovered at the site was a sophisticated light-beam device similar to one used in the gang's killing in November of Deutsche Bank chief Alfred Herrhausen, whose car was blown up near Frankfurt. The terrorist gang has been responsible for killings and bomb attacks in West Germany in the last two decades. About three hours after the morning attack, Neusel strode into a news conference and said he was happy to be alive. Speaking in a calm voice, Neusel described the impact of the bomb blast, saying, ``Naturally the sensation of shock was there.'' Neusel also said the note claiming responsibility indicated a connection between the Red Army Faction and a Spanish terror group called GRAPO. The letter carried the Red Army Faction symbol, a red star superimposed by a machine gun. The letter said the attack was carried out by the ``Jose Manuel Sevillano commando.'' According to the federal prosecutor's office, Sevillano was a convicted member of GRAPO who died in May after a six-month hunger strike. The Interior Ministry said Neusel had no security detail, and his automobile was not equipped with armor plating or bulletproof glass. Friday's bombing was the first Red Army Faction attack since eight long-sought fugitives were captured in East Germany in recent weeks. The eight had been living there under assumed names. Some say they had been granted sanctuary by East Germany's former Communist government. Also Friday, law officials announced that one of the eight has been released for lack of evidence. Ekkehard von Seckendorff-Gudent, a 50-year-old doctor, was picked up June 14 as a suspect in a 1984 bank robbery in the West German city of Wuerzburg. The West German prosecutor's office said he was released by East German authorities after witnesses were unable to identify him as a participant in the robbery. The prosecutor's office said it did not immediately appear the attack on Neusel was in reprisal for the roundup since the assassination attempt was likely mapped out before the suspects were nabbed. Neusel called on the Red Army Faction to cease its campaign of violence. ``I appeal emphatically for you to give this up,'' he said. ``Even if you were successful, how would that have changed the fact that we are a free democracy?''

DOC.HEAD: Barr Defends Screeching Version of National Anthem
DOC.NOTE: Eds: RECASTS lead. SUBS 4th graf, `Barr said ...,' to CORRECT that she performed between games of doubleheader, sted before. SUBS 11th graf, `The news ...,' to restore dropped words ``as her television show.' INSERTS 1 graf after 18th graf, `Barr said ...,' to ADD that she plans to sue National Enquirer next week.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto LA9
DOC.TEXT: Comedian Roseanne Barr admitted Friday that it was a mistake for her to screech the national anthem to an audience of booing baseball fans, but she refused to apologize and denied being rude. The star of the top-rated ABC-TV comedy ``Roseanne'' said she nearly left the field in mid-song Wednesday as San Diego baseball fans at Jack Murphy Stadium bombarded her with boos. ``I'm sorry I didn't sing so good. What else do I have to say?'' she said. ``I figured everybody knew I wasn't the world's greatest singer.'' Barr said she realized how horrible the reaction was within three or four notes of beginning ``The Star-Spangled Banner'' between games of a doubleheader. ``Then everybody started booing me and I went into this panic thing,'' she told a raucous news conference at the Beverly Hilton Hotel which included the police ejection of a photographer. ``It took all the guts I've got in my life to finish singing.'' More than 2,000 phone calls about her unmelodious performance had come into the Padres switchboard by midday Friday, and President Bush joined the chorus of boos. Barr said she had the best of intentions. Although she refused to apologize, she used the word ``sorry'' several times. ``I'm not going to apologize for doing it,'' she said. ``Because I feel like it was the wrong choice for all of us to make. But not anybody anticipated that it would be this negative.'' She capped her solo by grabbing her crotch and spitting _ actions she described as a parody of a baseball player, not a response to the boos. ``I probably should have waited a while before I scratched myself and spit,'' she said. ``But I wanted to get out of there.'' The news conference became as chaotic as her television show when her husband ordered police to eject a tabloid photographer. ``I want the cameras off right now!'' bellowed Barr's husband, Tom Arnold, as three policemen arrived. Photographer Kip Rano of American Photo Syndicate was led from the meeting room of the Beverly Hilton Hotel after police warned him he would be handcuffed and arrested if he refused to leave. The incident, carried live by local television stations and CNN, delayed the news conference for more than 20 minutes. In a Hollywood twist, Rano was escorted out by police Officer Paul Kramer _ the same motorcycle patrolman who arrested and was slapped by Zsa Zsa Gabor last year. Barr said she had Rano expelled because ``I'm not going to talk to the tabloids. I'm suing them.'' She said she planned to file a libel lawsuit against the National Enquirer next week. Rano said his firm sells photos to ``everyone,'' including tabloid newspapers. He called the expulsion a publicity stunt by Arnold and Barr. Barr, the Padres and Tom Werner, ``Roseanne's'' executive producer and the owner of the Padres, ``thought it was going to be fun,'' to have the portly comic sing the national anthem on a night at the stadium honoring working women. About 30,000 fans attended. ``I did it for free on my day off,'' she said. ``I took my kids down there. Why would I have taken my kids down there if I didn't think it would be fun?'' Bush joined the ringing chorus of boos Friday for Barr's rendition of the anthem. It was ``disgraceful,'' Bush said. ``That's the way I feel about it and I think a lot of San Diego fans said the same thing,'' Bush said while flying to Kennebunkport, Maine, for the weekend. Told of Bush's comment, Barr replied: ``I'm sorry I didn't sing so good. I'd like to hear him sing it.'' Barr said she never would have performed if there had been any objections. ``If there had been even 50 calls that came in that said, `Don't do it,' I wouldn't have, but there wasn't even one.'' ``None of us meant it viciously _ Tom Werner, the Padres and me,'' she said. ``We all made a mistake.''

DOC.HEAD: Barry Defense Rests Without Calling Him to Stand
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS new 2nd graf with prosecution attacking testimony of four defense witnesses; SUBS 5th graf: ``Prosecutors said,'' to add that Mundy wants to recall two witnesses; INSERTS grafs 6-7: ``Bary said,'' quotes from mayor; INSERTS grafs 16-21: ``The defense,'' with further detail; DELETES last six grafs to tighten
DOC.TEXT: The defense rested in Marion Barry's drug and perjury trial Friday, keeping Barry off the stand rather than give prosecutors a chance to question him before the jury. Prosecutors immediately began their rebuttal case, attacking the accuracy of the testimony of four witnesses who had appeared at the trial on Barry's behalf. ``I have advised Mr. Barry that no matter how we restrict his testimony ... he would still be subject to cross-examination,'' R. Kenneth Mundy, one of Barry's attorneys, told the judge. Mundy said he had told Barry he could have expected to face ``all the questions'' prosecutors wanted to ask about the numerous allegations of drug use. Prosecutors said they expected to complete their rebuttal case on Monday. Mundy said he wants to recall two witnesses following the government's rebuttal. U.S. District Court Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson said closing arguments would be next Tuesday or Wednesday. Barry told reporters later he wanted to avoid the theatrics his tesimony would have produced. ``It would have been good Perry Mason drama, L.A. Law drama, but I'm not about Perry Mason drama,'' he said. ``My spirits are high; my defense is on course.'' The prosecution tried to strike back quickly Friday, introducing a city form indicating a defense witness had been absent from work at a time he has testified he had accepted a document figuring prominently in one of the charges against Barry. Cliff Roberson, an assistant to longtime Barry aide Anita Bonds, has testified he took a job application from admitted cocaine dealer Lydia Reid Pearson shortly after 10 a.m. on Sept. 7, 1988. Pearson has testified she handed the application _ and crack cocaine _ to Barry that morning. The form indicates that Roberson was absent for two hours that day. The typewritten original portion says he was missing from 4:30 p.m. until 6:30 p.m., but that time is scratched out and the hours 8:30 a.m. to 10:30 a.m. are handwritten above it. The form, signed by Bonds, included a handwritten note indicating that Roberson had been ``laying a gravestone for my father's grave'' that morning. Former Bonds assistant Darcelle Walker testified that she typed the form and also said she recognized Bonds' signature. She identified the handwriting in the margin as Roberson's but said under cross-examination she didn't know who had written in the changes on the form. The charge involved is the most specific of the drug possession charges, with regard to date and time, of the 10 the mayor faces. He is also charged with conspiracy and with three felony counts of perjury. As Assistant U.S. Attorney Judith Retchin introduced the form on Friday, Barry huddled briefly with Bonds at the defense table and then turned away with a scowl on his face. Bonds, who had been managing Barry's re-election campaign, volunteered her services to the mayor's legal defense after he dropped his plans for a fourth term. The defense plans to bring Roberson back to the witness stand next week, if the judge will allow it, said Mundy. After the trial, the mayor said he believed Roberson had been at work when Pearson left the application, adding, ``I know I didn't take it.'' As part of its rebuttal case, the prosecution also called: _Delois Mise, who testified that she saw Barry bodyguard, police officer James Stays, snort cocaine at a 1985 party. Stays had testified for the defense that he never saw Barry use drugs on a March 1988 trip to the Virgin Islands. Stays denied that he himself had used drugs at the 1985 party. Mundy said he wants to recall Stays next week. Police sources, speaking on condition of anonymity, said the department planned an internal investigation of Stays as soon as the trial is over. _Terry Lee Brenay, the skipper of a sailboat in the Virgin Islands. He contradicted the testimony of a Virgin Islands couple who said they didn't have any indication of drug use during a June 1986 boat ride with Barry. Brenay said he and the couple smelled marijuana smoke aboard the vessel. The couple, Albert and Carmen Benjamin, ``expressed alarm'' over the smell, said Brenay. Mundy concluded his seven-day defense of the mayor by closely questioning the FBI agent in charge of the sting operation in which Barry was arrested after being videotaped smoking crack cocaine. Agent Ronald Stern should have stopped the Jan. 18 operation before Barry actually smoked the drug, Mundy argued. ``What would you suggest I say to Rasheeda?'' Stern retorted. ``The sting's off _ throw away the drugs?''' Stern was referring to ex-model Rasheeda Moore, a former Barry girlfriend who had persuaded the mayor to come to her hotel room. An undercover agent posing as Moore's friend supplied the crack while Stern monitored the operation from an adjoining room. Stern repeatedly said that it was Barry, not Moore, who brought up the subject of drugs and asked for them. Before Stern took the stand for additional questioning _ and before the jury was called into the courtroom _ prosecutor Retchin heatedly denied an assertion by Mundy that Stern had been part of an ``assault force'' targeting black elected officials for drug arrests.

DOC.HEAD: Demonstrations in Bulgaria; Interior Minister Resigns
DOC.TEXT: Thousands of Bulgarians demonstrated outside Parliament on Friday demanding a live television broadcast when ousted Communist leader Todor Zhivkov addresses Parliament. Stormy scenes took place inside as well, as Parliament debated Zhivkov's appearance. At one point, Interior Minister Atanas Semerdjiev rushed to the rostrum and announced he was resigning, the state BTA news agency reported. According to BTA, Semerdjiev _ apparently exasperated over the debate and charges hurled between the governing Socialist Party and the opposition _ said during his announcement, ``I am sorry the guards didn't give me a pistol.'' BTA said the minister quit the chamber after an opposition deputy alluded to alleged strongarm tactics by police against demonstrators _ an apparent reference to a government warning to local authorities to halt spreading ethnic and political unrest. The deputy suggested members of Parliament speak to the demonstrators outside after it emerged that the opposition was split over whether Zhivkov's speech should be broadcast live. No date has been set for Zhivkov's appearance. Zhivkov, 78, was ousted last Nov. 10 in a Politburo coup. None of the old guard Communist leaders in Eastern Europe has as yet spoken out publicly about the past. Possible revelations about Zhivkov's harsh, 35-year rule have helped to make his expected speech a highly emotional and controversial issue here. Zhivkov has been under house arrest and in custody in a military hospital. He is under investigation for alleged abuses of power and misappropriation of state property. He has also been accused of fomenting ethnic unrest with his assimilation campaign against the ethnic Turkish minority. Zhivkov asked to be allowed to speak before Parliament to ``tell the Bulgarian people the truth'' about his rule. Parliament debated on Friday the conditions for allowing such an address. A parliamentary commission proposed that Zhivkov's speech should be taped before being broadcast to allow possible deletion of state secrets, BTA said. It said that minutes after this proposal was broadcast on radio, thousands of angry Bulgarians converged on the Parliament building shouting, ``Zhivkov before the people!'' The crowd later dwindled to hundreds, BTA reported. The deputies agreed to postpone further debate until Monday. Observers say leaders of the Socialist Party, formerly the Communist Party, are concerned that Zhivkov could say something that would hurt them politically by implicating them in unpopular decisions of the previous hard-line government. The Socialists won 211 of the 400 seats in Parliament in last month's free elections. The main opposition alliance, Union of Democratic Forces, won 144. Hundreds of people have camped outside Socialist Party headquarters demanding that Zhivkov and others be brought to account.
