Protesters and striking students last month forced Petar Mladenov to resign as president over a call he made last December for tanks to be used against anti-government demonstrators. Parliament has failed in four rounds of voting to elect a new president. The new government cannot be formed until the president has been elected. BTA meanwhile reported Friday that rationing of sugar, soap and some other basics was introduced in several Bulgarian cities because of acute shortages.

DOC.HEAD: Mexican Police Search for Victims of Ritual Killings
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS two grafs after 8th `Soto Soto...' to UPDATE with quote from other suspect; pickup graf 9 pvs, `The accused...'
DOC.TEXT: Members of a drug-growing cult suspected of making human sacrifices testified Friday that police had beaten them and forced them to sign false admissions of murder. Authorities have descended on a rural western town to search for up to 41 bodies of cult victims, but they were delayed by bad weather Friday. Police have quoted cult members as saying they made sacrifices to the devil, whom they believed was embodied in a 16-inch earthenware statue of a monkey. They reportedly called the statue ``El Amigo,'' or ``The Friend.'' However, District Judge Cuevas Zavala played down the cult charge Friday. ``There is nothing to it,'' said the judge hearing the case in Tepic, the Nayarit state capital, about 450 miles northwest of Mexico City. He did not elaborate. Some of the 14 suspects arrested in the case testified at their arraignment Friday that police had beaten them into signing accusations of murder against Olayo Soto Soto, the 65-year-old alleged leader of the cult. Other suspects, handcuffed in pairs, made the same claims in interviews with reporters outside the courthouse. The purported cult leader pointed to a dark spot under his eye and to other parts of his body and said he was beaten into confessing to killing three alleged victims. Soto Soto, who was wearing traditional white garb of an Indian medicine man, said he was a ``good Catholic.'' Another suspect, Epifanio Soto, said he grew only apples, peaches and prickly pears. ``We are peaceful peasant workers,'' he said. He said the group had a temple in a cave. ``There we had saints _ the Saint Jesus Christ and the Virgin of Guadelupe,'' Mexico's patron saint, he said. Of the monkey idol, he said, ``the authorities must have mistaken the Virgin of Guadelupe for it.'' The accused appeared Friday on the drug charges, which District Judge Jose Cuevas Zavala said could take 10 months to prosecute. Confessions made without an attorney present are admissible in Mexico, although the accused are permitted to recant them in court later. They almost invariably do so. Because there is no bail under Mexican law for people accused of crimes that carry a sentence of five years or more, the suspects likely will remain in jail the whole time their case is prosecuted. Authorities say the victims were killed and buried by the marijuana-growers in a remote area along the line separating Nayarit and Durango states over a seven-year period. The human sacrifices were made in the belief they would protect the drug crop from police, authorities said. Nine men and five youths have been held by police in Tepic since Tuesday. They are charged with homicide, arms possession, criminal association and drug offenses. Alejandro Maldonado Loyo, who represents the federal prosecutor in Tepic, said Friday all 14 had confessed to marijuana charges. He said the homicide charges would be handled by state officials in Durango because the bodies reportedly were buried on that side of the line. He said the marijuana patches were small. ``Their sacrifices didn't bring them many results, did they?'' he said. The Nayarit district attorney's investigator, Jose Fernand Armas Hernandez, said Thursday tht police found a leather quiver with 41 arrows, apparently dipped in blood. One suspect claimed the arrows represented the spirits of each of the sacrificed humans, the investigator said. Authorities said the occult rites were practiced in caves on remote hillsides where police discovered apparent cult material, including a statuette of the Virgin Mary with her face replaced by a skull. Federal police said the group claimed to be practicing a version f Palo Mayombe, a religion that originated in the Congo and sometimes uses human skulls. The group is reminiscent of another drug cult broken in April 1989, when police found 15 bodies buried on a ranch near the city of Matamoros across the U.S.-Mexico border from Brownsville, Texas. Four members of that group are on trial in Mexico City and Matamoros. Alleged group leader Adolfo de Jesus Constanzo and his bodyguard died of gunshot wounds as police closed in on them in a Mexico City apartment in May 1989.

DOC.HEAD: Colombia's Cocaine Traffickers Offer Truce in Drug War
DOC.TEXT: Drug traffickers declared an end Friday to their campaign of bombings and assassinations, according to a communique bearing the letterhead The Extraditables, as the Medellin cocaine cartel calls itself. The cartel said its offer follows recent movements toward peace in Colombia and the end of President Virgilio Barco's administration. ``We decree a unilateral, indefinite cease-fire and we suspend attacks against police, bombings in all Colombian cities and the executions of politicians, journalists, judges and other functionaries,'' the statement said. The communique was faxed to news outlets throughout Colombia. Its authenticity could not be confirmed. Barco leaves office Aug. 7. His successor, Cesar Gaviria, has vowed to continue Barco's hard-line anti-drug policies. Gaviria has said he will keep extraditing drug trafficking suspects wanted in the United States, the fate cocaine smugglers fear most. Friday's statement said official claims that the government is winning the drug war are false. It said police desertions and the killing of police by drug dealers indicate the government is not victorious. It listed as victories by drug traffickers: ``215 policemen dead and 256 wounded, more than 400 desertions by policemen, 10 police headquarters bombed and 20 police posts destroyed.'' Authorities say drug traffickers began a campaign this year to assassinate policemen in Medellin, the cartel's headquarters. Judicial police say the cartel has been paying $4,300 to each young assassin who kills a law officer. Since August 1989, when Barco began his drug crackdown, traffickers have been blamed for killing more than 450 Colombians in terrorist attacks. The Extraditables suspended their attacks last January, but resumed them shortly after, saying the government rejected their peace overtures. The statement Friday reiterated cocaine traffickers' claims that the government was torturing and murdering drug suspects. It also accused the government of killing leftist political leaders and placing bombs in public buildings. It said its cease-fire comes because ``almost all of the people want peace.'' This year, peace negotiations have been initiated between the government and several leftist guerrilla groups. Talks are also under way between authorities and right-wing paramilitary groups. Feuding emerald miners have signed a peace accord. But so far this year, 10,956 people have been murdered in Colombia, according to a judicial police report published in a Bogota newspaper Thursday.

DOC.HEAD: Pentagon Would Use Northrop Despite Justice Department's Recommendation
DOC.NOTE: EDs: New thruout with testimony from former Northrop employee; additional background on subpoena. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: The Pentagon's chief procurement official said Friday he would not prohibit Northrop Corp. from building weapons for the military despite the Justice Department's belief that the company should be barred. ``I'm not anticipating any debarment procedure,'' John Betti, undersecretary of defense for acquisitions, told reporters during a break in a six-hour hearing by a House Energy and Commerce panel on charges of fraud and mismanagement at Northrop. Justice Department officials described how Northrop falsified reports on the air-launched cruise missile and conducted improper tests on the Harrier AV-8B jet. The company's action led to its guilty plea in February on 34 charges of fraud and a fine of $17 million, the largest criminal fine ever imposed on a defense contractor. The last witness before the panel, a former Northrop employee who has filed a false claims lawsuit against the company, charged that the Air Force adjusted the budget targets on the B-2 bomber when it realized the program was financially out of control. ``We paid Northrop $26 billion to build a new type of paper airplane that carried this nation's debts to new heights,'' Jean-Francois Truong, who worked as one of eight financial comptrollers for the 14,000-man B-2 work force in Pico Rivera, Calif., and blew the whistle on Northrop, told the panel. Northrop is still the target of federal grand jury criminal investigations, and Justice Department officials were reticent about discussing specifics. Pressed, however, about whether the Justice Department stood by the contention, spelled out in a series of memoranda from March to June, that Northrop should be barred from weapons contracts, agency officials did not retreat. ``Are they still your beliefs today?'' the department officials were asked. ``They haven't changed,'' said William F. Fahey, assistant U.S. attorney for the central district of California. Another Justice Department official, Mark M. Richard, deputy assistant attorney general for the criminal division, detailed for the subcommittee on oversight and investigations how Northrop pressured the Navy and Air Force to change contract specifications, seriously damaging a fraud inquiry. Under questioning, Richard said there are civil proceedings under way in connection with evidence of false testing by Northrop on parts for the MX nuclear missile. The legal action involving the B-2 stealth bomber, the costliest weapon the military is building at nearly $860 million a copy, relates to problems with Northrop's cost system. Asked to name a single Northrop weapons program in which the government has no evidence of criminal activity, Richard said he was unable to answer that question and would have to check the department's records. Pressed, however, as to whether the Justice Department would contract with a company like Northrop, Richard said, ``I would hope not.'' Lawmakers reacted angrily to the details provided to the committee about Northrop's operation, especially in light of the fact that the company has received more than $35 billion in Pentagon contracts. ``Northrop appears to have been engaged in a continuing criminal enterprise for a long time,'' said Rep. John Dingell, D-Mich. and the subcommittee's chairman. Truong accused Northrop of maintaining two separate financial books with actual charges included in an operating set and another set prepared by the financial department for the Air Force. The former employee, who said he resigned because of fraud and abuse, recommended that the government bar or prosecute the company ``to stop Northrop from cheating the taxpayers of this country.'' In addition to manufacturing the B-2 bomber, Northrop is bidding for the right to build the Air Force's Advanced Tactical Fighter. Dingell also expressed frustration at the refusal of Thomas V. Jones, chairman of the board of Northrop, to testify before the panel even though the subcommittee had issued a subpoena. ``Mr. Jones was invited to testify today but refused on the grounds that one of his several attorneys is in Africa,'' Dingell said. The subpoena has been in existence since last year, but the committee decided not to enforce it this time because it expected Jones to refuse to answer on the grounds he was testifying without his counsel. Dingell told his staff shortly after the hearing he wants to enforce the subpoena against Jones at another hearing in September. Otherwise, the panel would vote on whether to hold the Northrop official for contempt of Congress. But much of the anger among lawmakers was directed at Betti, who said that Defense Department officials overseeing management at Northrop ``have assured me that all monitoring systems necessary to protect the interests of the taxpayers and national security are currently in place and working well at Northrop.'' ``I have serious doubts about whether you're the man for the job that you hold,'' said Rep. John Bryant, D-Texas, as he questioned why the Pentagon still does business with Northrop when the chairman of the board, Jones, has been convicted of felonious offenses.

DOC.HEAD: Venezuelan President Keeps Key Ministers, Despite Complaints
DOC.TEXT: President Carlos Andres Perez on Friday returned to the Cabinet the major players in his free-market program, despite growing criticism of the radical measures. The appointments followed the mass resignations Thursday of all 20 of Perez' ministers. They stepped down to let him reshape the new 22-member Cabinet. However, the new body will include such major figures in the previous Cabinet as Miguel Rodriguez, who returns as planning minister. He is the architect of Venezuela's program to dismantle the state-run economic system in this nation of 19 million people. Rodriguez acknowledged a few days ago that Venezuela would not be able to meet initial optimistic projections for this year. Inflation and public deficit will be considerably higher than expected, while economic growth will probably be less than half the original forecast of 4 percent. Central Bank President Pedro Tinoco, who has clashed publicly with Rodriguez, also remains in the Cabinet. Also returning are Cabinet are Finance Minister Roberto Pocaterra, Foreign Minister Reinaldo Figueredo, Development Minister Moises Naim and Energy Minister Celestino Armas. This will be the third Cabinet for the 17-month-old Perez government. The president first rearranged his Cabinet in August 1989, six months after taking office. He later fired his finance minister. A week ago, the transportation and communications minister, Augusto Faria Viso, resigned over accusations that he solicited a $3.5 million kickback from a French company in exchange for awarding it a $100 million radar equipment contract. Only eight members of the Cabinet are new. They were inducted at a swearing-in ceremony Friday. They are: Armando Duran, presidential secretary; Roberto Smith, transport and communiciations; Jesus Moreno Guacaran, justice; Jonathan Coles, agriculture; Vladimir Gessen, tourism; Gerver Torres, Venezuelan Investment Fund; Regulo Villegas, drug control; and Jesus Carmona, executive-congress relations.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Predicts Confirmation With `Flying Colors'
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS grafs 17-21: ``In Boston,'' Thornburgh remarks; DELETES last two grafs to tighten
DOC.TEXT: President Bush gave David Souter a ride back to New England on Air Force One Friday, saying he was pleased with the nation's reaction to the little-known Supreme Court nominee and predicting Senate confirmation ``with flying colors.'' Addressing the closest thing to a controversy so far, Bush denied that he had agreed before meeting Souter last Monday not to ask him delicate questions about his views on controversial issues such as abortion. Two senators have quoted Souter as saying he had requested that such questions not be asked, and Bush has said he didn't ask them. But Bush, when asked whether he had made such a deal in advance of interviewing his prospective high court choice, said, ``No, nothing on my side on that.'' Meanwhile, Sen. Joseph R. Biden Jr., D-Del., chairman of the Senate Judiciary Committee, announced the panel will open hearings on Souter's nomination on Sept. 13. Souter, after a hectic week in Washington readying for the confirmation hearings, flew with Bush aboard the presidential aircraft to Pease Air Force Base in New Hampshire, then went his own way while Bush and his wife Barbara flew to Kennebunkport by helicopter to their oceanside summer home. The laconic Souter briefly appeared in the press cabin aboard Air Force One, but quickly retreated after quipping, ``I don't want to ruin my reputation. I have two words to say. 'Hi' and 'Goodbye.''' On the ground, when reporters asked the 50-year-old federal appeals judge how it felt to be back in New Hampshire, he replied, ``It feels damn good.'' He then drove off with a friend, Tom Rath, and Rath's twin children, to visit his mother at a retirement community in Concord. Rath said Souter hopes to visit friends, do his laundry, get some rest and ``try to disappear'' while digging into a pile of reading in preparation for his confirmation hearings. Earlier Friday in Washington, Souter continued his get-acquainted meetings with senators, fending off reporters' questions on specific issues _ primarily abortion rights. ``I think, with respect, that that is certainly a question that I'm going to be asked when the time for the confirmation hearing comes, and I think that would be the appropriate place for me to respond,'' he said. Souter also met with Vice President Dan Quayle, who later said the Senate should ``avoid rancorous partisanship'' and resist arguments of special interest groups that might oppose the nominee. Quayle said some groups have taken the position that ``if we don't know in advance that Judge Souter is for us on our single issue, we oppose him.'' He named no groups. Bush, answering questions during the flight north, declined to retort to sharp criticisms leveled at him and Souter by Supreme Court Justice Thurgood Marshall in a television interview on ABC-TV Thursday. Marshall said he had never heard of Souter and said White House Chief of Staff John Sununu appeared to be ``calling the shots'' on the selection. Of Bush, Marshall said, ``It's said that if you can't say something good about a dead person, don't say it. Well, I consider him dead.'' Bush said, ``My response is that I have great respect for the Supreme Court and I have no comment on it, none. ... I have a very high regard for separation of powers and for the Supreme Court.'' In Boston, Attorney General Dick Thornburgh told a news confernece he was saddened by Marhsall's remarks. ``I believe it is the first time any sitting Supreme Court justice has ever in our history criticized an appointment and indeed criticized the president who made the appointment,'' Thornburgh said. ``I don't believe that is a constructive attitude to have on the eve of consideration by the Senate of the nomination of a man possessed by extraordinary qualitites of intellect, integrity and character.'' Thornburgh denied that Bush sought a nominee with unknown views of abortion, like Souter's. ``The question of aqny nominee's views on abortion was not considered,'' he said. Back in Washington, Senate Republican Leader Bob Dole of Kansas was less reticent, calling Marshall ``a very partisan liberal Democrat'' and suggesting political views ``will also be reflected in his judicial opinions.'' Bush, who nominated Souter Monday just three days after the retirement of the court's foremost liberal, William J. Brennan Jr., called reaction to Souter ``very favorable so far.'' ``It's hard to tell about the Senate because a lot have not expressed their views. But nationally, I'm very pleased,'' said Bush. ``There seems to be well-deserved support for Judge Souter.'' Bush acknowledged Souter is ``not the most well known figure in the country, but that's not why I selected him.'' ``He'll be plenty well known when he gets testifying and gets through this process, which I think he'll do with flying colors,'' said the president. Some critics have suggested Bush did choose Souter in part because he has not written widely on controversial issues. As for Souter's job interview, Bush has said he purposely avoided asking questions on sensitive issues because he thought that was appropriate. Sen. Warren Rudman, R-N.H., considered a main Souter sponsor in the selection process, also flew to New Hampshire on the plane. He said the judge had not set pre-conditions for the White House interview but had expressed concern about questions he would be asked. Rudman quoted Souter as telling him last weekend, ``I'm aware there are a lot of issues of great concern to many people in public life. You know I'm a sitting judge on the 1st Circuit and I just would be very embarrassed to be asked questions because I could not answer them. I would not want to put the president or anybody else in (that) position.'' Rudman said he relayed Souter's concerns to White House Sununu who assured him it was ``not our policy'' to grill jurists on how they would rule on specific issues.

DOC.HEAD: Heavy Thunderstorms Continue to Pelt Soggy Iowa
DOC.TEXT: Roads flooded and rivers jumped their banks Friday as slow-moving storms dumped rain on central and northeast Iowa. Showers and thunderstorms fell elsewhere in the Midwest, as well as sections of the East and the West. The Iowa River left its banks at Marshalltown, the Cedar River threatened Waterloo and Cedar Rapids, and the Nishnabotna River in southwest Iowa was still high as it tried to carry away rain that fell Thursday. High water in creeks and streams continued to drain into the Cedar, Iowa and Skunk rivers, and produced significant flooding. Heavy rainfall Thursday night caused flooding of many streets and underpasses in Des Moines. Iowa rainfall between midnight and 11 a.m. EDT included more than 3.66 inches in Mason City, 1.43 inches in Waterloo and 1.28 inches in Des Moines. Scattered showers and thunderstorms fell from northwest and south-central Texas to southeast Louisiana, northwest Oklahoma, southeast and northwest Kansas, Nebraska and South Dakota, eastern Colorado and parts of Montana, as well as New England. Showers and thunderstorms also extended over parts of Florida, the South Carolina coast, Virginia, Delaware and Maryland. Ely, Nev., cooled to 40 degrees Friday morning, breaking the low-temperature record for the date of 41 degrees. Greenville-Spartanburg, S.C., tied its 65-degree low-temperature mark. The low temperature for the Lower 48 states was 36 degrees in Jackson, Wyo. Temperatures around the nation at 3 p.m. EDT ranged from 60 degrees in Oak Harbor-Whidbey Island, Wash., to 104 in Palm Springs, Calif.

DOC.HEAD: House Subcommittee Approves Military Support Cuts
DOC.TEXT: A House Armed Services subcommittee pared more than $5 billion from the Pentagon's budget on Friday by continuing a hiring freeze for civilians and slashing maintenance funds for overseas bases, congressional sources said Friday. The panel on readiness cut force structure support costs by $5.9 billion from President Bush's original proposal of $79.3 billion to meet levels set under a House budget resolution approved on May 1. The action came in advance of Tuesday's session of the full House Armed Services Committee, which is expected to craft a 1991 military budget of $283 billion _ $24 billion less than President Bush sought in January. The lawmakers approved a $1.09 billion reduction in pay for the Pentagon's civilian work force, which currently numbers around 1 million people. They also approved continuing the hiring freeze that was introduced earlier this year by Defense Secretary Dick Cheney ``as a means of reducing the civilian work force,'' said the congressional source, who spoke on condition of not being identified by name. This would mean 60,000 to 65,000 fewer jobs for the civilians who work for the military during the next fiscal year, which begins Oct. 1, the source said. The panel also slashed $914 million in funding from accounts for maintaining property overseas, a move made in line with anticipated base closures abroad due to the lessening Soviet threat, the source said. Anticipating a smaller work force of foreign nationals overseas in line with base closures, the panel also approved a $324 million reduction in their pay and benefits. Among other things, the lawmakers made $920 million in across-the-board cuts in the military's operation and maintenance budgets, and slashed $800 million in support costs for active duty personnel, the source said.

DOC.HEAD: Tanker Involved In Spill Begins Journey to Scrap Heap
DOC.TEXT: The wrecked supertanker Mega Borg on Friday began a two-month trip to Pakistan, where it will be broken into scrap. A tugboat towed the vessel from the Gulf of Mexico early in the afternoon, the Coast Guard said. The Mega Borg rested about 57 miles offshore since it was rocked by an explosion June 8. Four crew members were killed and a fire raged for several days aboard the ship, which spilled 3.9 million gallons of light crude oil into the gulf. Maritime insurance adjusters declared the supertanker a total loss. Its Norweigan owner sold the vessel for scrap to Ailesford Ltd. of Gibraltar for $2.4 million.

DOC.HEAD: Plane Lands Safely Despite Damaged Wheel
DOC.TEXT: An American Airlines jet with 134 people aboard made an emergency landing Friday at O'Hare International Airport after the pilot reported the plane's front tire was damaged. American Airlines Flight 186, bound for Chicago from Denver with 127 passengers and seven crew members on board, landed safely despite a ``missing chunk'' from the front left tire, aviation officials said. ``The air did not deflate from the tire, and they landed without incident,'' said airline spokesman Tom Stack. The pilot noticed vibrations in the wheel when the jet took off in Denver, and alerted officials at O'Hare, Stack said. The plane's engine blades were damaged by debris during take-off and the plane will remain out of service awaiting repair, he said. Federal Aviation Administration officials planned to investigate the incident.

DOC.HEAD: McMartin Case Concluded, Finally, After Second Mistrial
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Leads with 13 grafs to INSERT comment from prosecutor and defense lawyer, Buckey still awaiting judge's final decision; picks up 8th graf, `Even one ...; edits throughout to tighten; no pickup
DOC.TEXT: A mistrial was declared Friday in Raymond Buckey's second trial on charges he molested children at the McMartin Pre-School, and prosecutors said they wouldn't try him a third time. The prosecutors' decision following a jury deadlock on eight sex counts ended the longest, costliest criminal case in U.S. history. ``It is clear to me that the jury will not reach a verdict in this case on any of the counts,'' Superior Court Judge Stanley Weisberg said in declaring the mistrial. Votes on seven of the eight counts leaned toward acquittal, and deputy District Attorney Joseph Martinez said Buckey would not be tried again. ``The community has had enough. We gave it our best shot,'' Martinez said. ``These kids cannot be McMartin kids for the rest of their lives. It's been a horrible experience.'' Buckey said he would not be happy until Weisberg makes a final ruling at a hearing Wednesday on whether to abide by the prosecution motion to dismiss. ``No one has won in the McMartin case, one or two,'' Buckey said. ``I was innocent coming in and I'm still innocent because I wasn't found guilty.'' The lack of resolution was another bizarre development in the McMartin case, which has consumed seven years of court time and cost Los Angeles County more than $13.5 million. During a news conference, District Attorney Ira Reiner conceded there were ``fundamental problems with the evidence in this case that go back six or seven years.'' But he said he did not regret going through with the second trial. ``The parents felt it was important there would be a resolution,'' he said. ``I think it's clear now there cannot be.'' Defense attorney Danny Davis said the ordeal would never be over for the parents. ``It's a horrible predicament to ... consider it didn't happen and they bought into a circus,'' he said. Even one of the most outspoken parents, who had demanded the retrial, said she had tired of the battle. ``I really wasn't surprised,'' Jackie McGauley said of the mistrial. ``People are real divided on this issue. ... I feel such relief that it's over. I'd like to get on with the work of seeing that the justice system is changed to accommodate children.'' Asked what he would do with the rest of his life, Buckey said, ``I'm just going to go on. I've learned to endure a lot of things in seven years. ... I would like to be just left alone.'' ``I'll have to get a job now,'' he added with a smile. Buckey's father, Charles, said he was disappointed his son was not acquitted. ``I've lost faith in the district attorney's office,'' he said. ``Every one of these people has lied and been very deceitful.'' Divided on all counts, the jurors were unanimous on one thing: That the case should not be tried again. ``There are too many questions, too many gaping holes and it's too much time to spend,'' said juror Michael Carapella, a 25-year-old musician. Jury Foreman Richard Dunham told the judge that an extra week of deliberation, which came after the panel reported earlier deadlocks, only resulted in splitting jurors further. Early Friday, they retracted two unanimous verdicts they submitted in sealed envelopes, reporting they were deadlocked on those counts as well. Dunham said the panelists had divided their votes differently on the eight counts, with the splits ranging from 6-6 to 11-1. The jurors took the same route an earlier jury took last January, choosing not to decide because they could not agree whether Buckey was guilty or innocent of molesting three young girls as long as 10 years ago at his family's Manhattan Beach preschool. A number of jurors said they felt the crucial pieces of evidence dividing them were the videotapes made by Childrens Institute International, in which therapists interviewed toddlers about whether they were molested. ``The CII tapes were in my mind very bad,'' said Dunham. ``We did not put a lot of credibility in them. Most of us felt the techniques of the interviews were very leading.'' Another juror complained there was insufficient corroborating evidence from witnesses other than the parents to back up the children's stories. ``All the evidence I saw in the process, to me he's not guilty,'' said juror Sylvia Scrigna, 30, a bank employee. The second, abbreviated Buckey trial had the feeling of a postscript, following the first so closely. Before the first trial, an 18-month preliminary hearing for seven original defendants strained the court system and spurred calls for reform. Charges against five defendants, all teachers, were dismissed. The first trial was a dramatic tableau of passionate advocacy by prosecution and defense attorneys determined to prove their points. It drew capacity audiences of former McMartin parents as well as supporters of the defendants. A parade of 124 witnesses testified at the first trial. In the second trial, which lasted just three months, 46 witnesses testified. A new duo of prosecutors seemed only mildly familiar with the facts of the case and less obsessed with winning conviction at all costs. There were reports they had tried to plea bargain with Buckey to avoid the second trial, a claim they denied. The witnesses were older and fewer. In the first trial of Buckey and his 63-year-old mother, Peggy McMartin Buckey, nine children testified. The second time, three adolescent girls took the stand to tell of the time when they were toddlers. Often, they answered lawyers' questions, ``I don't remember.'' Buckey, who spent five years in jail awaiting resolution of his case before he was released on bail, denied at both trials he ever molested any child. The McMartin saga began in August 1983 when a mother called Manhattan Beach police to complain that her child had been molested at the school. Police responded by sending letters to parents suggesting they check their children for signs of molestation. Hysteria followed, and the case ignited a national wave of concern over molestation. Buckey, his mother, grandmother, sister and three other teachers were arrested. Children gave investigators accounts of ``naked games,'' satanic rites and animals tortured to frighten the youngsters into silence. The first jury spent nine weeks deliberating on the 65 molestation and conspiracy charges against the Buckeys, who were accused of molesting 11 children during a five-year period at their family-owned preschool. On Jan. 18, the panel acquitted Mrs. Buckey of 12 charges, absolved her son on 40 counts but deadlocked on another 13 charges against him. Parents who had championed the prosecution went on national TV shows and submitted petitions pressuring the county to retry Buckey. Reiner, running for state attorney general, decided to reprosecute eight counts involving three children. The McMartin case, which had become a symbol of prosecutorial excess, was widely blamed for his defeat in the Democratic primary.

DOC.HEAD: OPEC Agrees on New Accord to Raise Crude Prices
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout, UPDATING with Iraqi quotes, REVISING current production figures, ADDING LaserPhoto numbers. No pickup
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos GEV4,7
DOC.TEXT: OPEC ministers agreed Friday to halt overproduction in hopes of pushing up the price of crude oil, and New York experts said U.S. motorists may wind up paying five to 10 cents more a gallon at the pumps this fall. All 13 ministers of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries signed an accord to notch up their target price immediately from $18 a barrel to $21. OPEC President Sadek Boussena, who is Algeria's oil minister, said the agreement allows no cheating on production quotas ``for any reason whatsoever.'' The cartel set a new production ceiling of 22.5 million barrels a day for the rest of the year. OPEC is producing about 23 million to 23.2 million barrels of oil a day, well over the ceiling of 22.1 million in effect in the first half of the year. Friday's agreement was struck a little more than a week after President Saddam Hussein of Iraq threatened military action against overproducers. Chronic oil-cheaters Kuwait and the United Arab Emirates _ targets of Saddam's anger _ agreed to slash their output by hundreds of thousands of barrels a day under the new agreement. Iraq's oil minister, Issam Abdul Raheem al-Chalabi, said in an interview his country had to ``put an end'' to the excess production in OPEC, which depressed oil prices in the spring. ``We just cannot let anybody do whatever they like. ... They were harming the others,'' he said. If excess production is indeed curbed, crude prices could climb several dollars higher by year's end, when demand for oil increases with colder weather in the United States and other consuming nations, analysts said. They said higher gasoline prices could follow. Paul Mlotok, head of energy research at the Morgan Stanley investment firm in New York, predicted that with OPEC restraint, crude prices ``could go up a couple of dollars a barrel'' in the October-December period. ``This could add about five cents to a gallon of gasoline at the pump by the end of the year,'' he said. Nauman Barakat, first vice president in the energy department at Shearson Lehman Hutton in New York, said gasoline prices could go up even higher _ by about a dime a gallon. ``Gasoline prices are going to remain strong in the summer,'' he said. ``They will get even stronger going into the winter period because of the agreement.'' Every dollar decline or rise in the price of a barrel of oil amounts to a 2-cent to 5-cent change in gasoline prices. Crude prices were expected to hold steady in August and September because of the glut of oil on the market, which sent prices tumbling in the spring. The average price of a basket of crudes monitored by OPEC surged to $20.46 a barrel in early January, but skidded to $13.64 last month. It has since rebounded to about $17.50, not far off the $18 target, which has been in effect since December 1986. Saudi Arabia's influential oil minister, Hisham Nazer, predicted crude prices would ``go beyond'' the $21 reference price by December. Nazer said the accord was designed to ``prevent deterioration of prices. ... This agreement emanated from a very bad situation.'' In raising its supply ceiling, the cartel lifted the output quota of the United Arab Emirates by 400,000 barrels a day to 1.5 million barrels. Howevr, the Persian Gulf producer has been pumping up to 2 million barrels a day. The other dozen nations, including Kuwait, will keep the same quotas. Kuwait's cap is 1.5 million barrels a day, but it too had been producing well over that. Kuwait's oil minister, Rasheed Salem al-Ameeri, called the deal ``excellent.'' And the U.A.E.'s Mana Saeed Oteiba promised to toe the line. ``It is a good agreement,'' said Ecuador's Diego Tamariz. ``It's about the best agreement we could get, considering.'' Saddam claimed excess OPEC production cost financially strapped Iraq about $14 billion in lost oil revenues in the last year. While the ministers made no mention publicly of the Iraqi threats, analysts said Saddam clearly influenced the outcome of the meeting. ``They did accomplish a credible agreement,'' said Barakat. ``I certainly think he (Saddam) was the catalyst.'' OPEC chief Boussena said the accord was endorsed by the ``highest level'' of the members' governments. But he acknowledged OPEC has no penalties to enforce discipline. Instead, the ministers intend to apply peer pressure by splitting into two panels to monitor each other's production. The U.A.E., for example, will be grouped with Iraq and Saudi Arabia. OPEC members are: Algeria, Ecuador, Gabon, Indonesia, Iran, Iraq, Kuwait, Libya, Nigeria, Qatar, Saudi Arabia, the U.A.E. and Venezuela.

DOC.HEAD: `Run Bambi Run' _ Escapee's Supporters Urge New Investigation, Trial
DOC.TEXT: More than 200 supporters, many wearing ``Run Bambi Run'' T-shirts, rallied Friday to wish a convicted killer luck in evading capture. Lawrencia Bembenek, 31, a former model and policewoman convicted of murdering her then-husband's ex-wife in 1981, is believed to have fled with her fiance after scaling a fence July 15 at a women's prison in east-central Wisconsin. Ms. Bembenek, who was nicknamed ``Bambi,'' was serving a life term, but would have been eligible for parole in 1993. Her efforts to win a new trial have been rejected by state appeals courts three times and the Wisconsin Supreme Court once. Supporters at the rally, held at a municipal park next to the Milwaukee Police Department and courthouse where Ms. Bembenek worked, wore paper masks of her likeness and told passers-by, ``Confuse the enemy.'' Many maintained that Ms. Bembenek received an unfair trial and was the victim of a police setup. Some carried posters that read ``It's not too late to investigate'' and ``Justice for Bembenek.'' Donations were accepted for a Bembenek legal defense fund. Although no members of Ms. Bembenek's family attended, the parents and sisters of Dominic Gugliatto, her 34-year-old fiance, sat by an information table. Gugliatto, a Milwaukee factory worker and father of three, divorced his wife in January. He met Ms. Bembenek at Taycheedah Correctional Institution while visiting a sister and has not been seen since the day of Ms. Bembenek's escape. Florence Gugliatto, Dominic Gugliatto's mother, said the family believed the two were together, although they haven't heard from the couple. ``Each day's harder when we don't hear from them. Everything's assumption,'' she said. ``... I feel very strongly she received an unfair trial.'' Ms. Bembenek, a one-time Playboy waitress, became a police officer in Milwaukee. She was fired from the department in 1980 for lying and the next year was arrested in the shooting death of Christine Schultz. Mrs. Schultz was the ex-wife of Ms. Bembenek's then-husband, police detective Elfred Schultz. She was found by her two young sons in her bed. She had been bound, gagged and shot in the back. A jury convicted Ms. Bembenek of first-degree murder despite testimony from one of the victim's sons that the person seen in the house the night of the killing was not Ms. Bembenek. Prosecutors have conceded their case was based on circumstantial evidence. A television movie later recreated the killing and trial. Ms. Bembenek's escape has touched off a circuslike atmosphere in Milwaukee. Radio and television newscasts have sponsored special shows detailing her life, and entrepreneurs have capitalized on renewed interest in the case by selling ``Bambi'' T-shirts, bumper stickers and cardboard cutouts. Many at the rally wished Ms. Bembenek well as a fugitive. Others criticized prosecutors for refusing to reopen the case. Ira Robins, a private investigator who has spent years investigating the case, blasted the police investigation during an impassioned speech at the rally. ```They turned around and buried the evidence,'' he said. Schultz, who left the police force and now lives in Naples, Fla., vigorously defended Ms. Bembenek at her trial. He later divorced her, and recently said he believed Ms. Bembenek was the killer.

DOC.HEAD: Russia, Baltics Ready to Circumvent Soviet Authority
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 14 grafs, UPDATING with Russia, Baltics agree to negotiate accord bypassing central authorities; pickup graf 5, Tass, reporting... with minor editing to TRIM
DOC.TEXT: Boris N. Yeltsin, the reformist president of the Russian Federation, agreed Friday to negotiate treaties with the three Baltic republics bypassing the Soviet government's central authority, Baltic officials said. In Byelorussia, bordering Lithuania, Parliament declared its laws take precedence over Soviet law and that Byelorussia has the right to its own armed forces, Tass news agency said. The developments came as setbacks to Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's plans to glue together the country's 15 republics in a new confederation. Byelorussia is considered to be among the least reform-minded republics, but it followed Russia, the Ukraine and the Baltic republics in declaring its sovereignty. While the Byelorussian Supreme Soviet was approving its declaration of sovereignty, the presidents of Lithuania, Latvia and Estonia met in Jurmala, Latvia, with Yeltsin, a spokesman said. ``Negotiations between the three Baltic states and Russia must start immediately,'' the Estonian News Service said in a report on a statement issued by the presidents. ``After the talks, treaties will be signed between each Baltic state and Russia on political, legal, economic, scientific and technical, and cultural aspects of mutual relations, on relations between nationalities and citizenship.'' The treaties should be ready in six to eight weeks, it said. Latvian sources, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said recognition of the Baltic republics' independence by the Russian republic likely would be contained in the treaties, but would not be made before the agreements are completed. Signing of formal agreements between Russia and the independence-minded Baltic republics would be a stiff blow by reformers to Gorbachev's efforts to draft a new agreement binding the Soviet republics together. The Baltic republics do not want to participate in negotiations on the new agreement because they have declared their intention to be independent countries. A Russian-Baltic accord would signal a serious challenge by Yeltsin to Gorbachev's leadership. It could lead to other direct agreements among republics that would exclude the Soviet government and circumvent central authority. Latvia's Supreme Council parliament quoted Yeltsin as saying in a meeting with Latvian officials on Thursday that ``Latvian independence definitely must be recognized in the first, political section of our treaty.'' A Latvian delegation was expected to go to Moscow on Monday to begin talks with Yeltsin's Russian government. Presidents Anatoly Gorbunov of Latvia, Vytautas Landsbergis of Lithuania and Arnold Ruutel of Estonia also met Friday to discuss their approach to the negotiations on the new agreement binding the Soviet republics. But no statement emerged. Tass, reporting on the declaration approved in the Byelorussian capital, Minsk, said: ``It was decided that the republic has the right to its own military forces, its interior forces, its organs of state and public security, under the control of the republic's Supreme Soviet. ``Byelorussia establishes the superiority of the constitution and laws of the republic on its territory and its independence in external relations.'' Interfax, an unofficial news service affiliated with Radio Moscow, said a group of deputies of the Byelorussian People's Front reform group walked out of the parliamentary session because they wanted to debate a declaration of full independence for the republic of 10 million people. The news reports said the declaration was nearly unanimous, but did not give figures. In claiming a right to its own armed forces, Byelorussia appeared to be following its southern neighbor, the Ukraine, which declared its sovereignty on July 16. Supporters of Ukrainian sovereignty said their declaration was much stronger than the declaration passed in June by Russia, largest of the Soviet republics and which includes Moscow, the seat of federal power. But all those declarations are milder than the Baltic republics' efforts to become independent. Lithuania declared independence on March 11, and Latvia and Estonia both declared their intent to follow at the end of unspecified transition periods. After Moscow imposed an economic blockade, Lithuania agreed to suspend its declaration of independence for 100 days once talks on the matter begin with Soviet officials. Moscow then lifted the blockade. In another republic on the Soviet Union's western frontier, the parliament of Moldavia on Thursday codified its June declaration of sovereignty. On Friday, according to Tass, the lawmakers approved a decree stating that all power in the republic belongs to its people. Uzbekistan has also passed a decree seeking more independence from central authority, and Soviet Georgia last month established a commission to work toward independence.

DOC.HEAD: Six Sets of MIA Remains From Cambodia Arrrive In U.S.
DOC.TEXT: Six sets of remains believed to be those of American soldiers missing in Cambodia arrived Friday in the first peacetime repatriation by the communist government. Military pallbearers at Hickam Air Force Base carried the metal coffins off an Air Force plane and past an honor guard. The remains were taken to the Army's Central Identification Laboratory for analysis. The remains were turned over to U.S. officials in Phnom Penh on Thursday following a two-day visit by a team of American experts. It was the first time since the Vietnam War ended in April 1975 that Cambodia's communist government turned over remains believed to be those of American servicemen. Of the 2,300 Americans still missing or unaccounted for in Indochina, 83 are in Cambodia, according to a statement from the U.S. Pacific Command.

DOC.HEAD: Some Facts About Byelorussia
With AM-Soviet-Republics
DOC.TEXT: Here are some facts about the Soviet republic of Byelorussia, which declared Friday that its laws take precedence over Soviet law: HISTORY _ The Byelorussian Soviet Socialist Republic was set up Jan. 1, 1919. It is one of the 15 republics of the Soviet Union. PEOPLE _ The population is 10,141,000. The largest ethnic group is Byelorussian, accounting for nearly 80 percent of the population. About 12 percent are Russian, and 4 percent are Polish. GEOGRAPHY _ The area is 80,134 square miles. Leading farm products are flax, fodder, potatoes and hemp. The republic raises pigs and sheep, as well as cattle for meat and dairy products.

DOC.HEAD: Cambodian Prime Minister Welcomes U.S. Overture
DOC.TEXT: Cambodian Prime Minister Hun Sen said Friday he is willing to negotiate with the United States about holding elections in his country. He spoke as Secretary of State James Baker told the Association of Southeast Asian Nations that the United States is considering direct contacts with the Cambodian government. Baker spoke to the organization known as ASEAN on Friday in Jakarta, Indonesia. Hun Sen, in an interview from Asia with National Public Radio, also said he welcomes the U.S. decision to hold direct talks with Vietnam on resolving the civil war in his country, but he warned against intervention in Cambodia's affairs. The United States, shifting long-standing policy, announced last week that it would hold talks next month with the communist government of Vietnam, the patron of the Hun Sen government. The United States also decided to withhold diplomatic recognition at the United Nations from the three-party coalition fighting to topple the Cambodian government. ``I welcome the negotiations between the USA and Vietnam over Cambodia,'' Hun Sen said. ``But I think they have to admit the fact that the issue of the domestic problem of Cambodia must be resolved only by the people of Cambodia,'' he added. Hun Sen has opposed a proposal for U.N. forces to oversee the installation of a temporary Cambodian government and to make sure that free elections are held. But in the interview he said he was ``personally prepared to discuss with the United States government and others to negotiate about these issues of general elections in Cambodia.'' Hun Sen rejected any role for the Khmer Rouge in an interim government, saying it would only open the door for the murderous faction to gain a foothold in a permanent government. The Khmer Rouge is estimated to have killed over one million Cambodians when it ruled the country in the 1970s before being ousted by a Vietnamese invasion in 1979. Any temporary role for the Khmer Rouge ``would be a chaos, and that would also destroy the result of the final political solution,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Zsa Zsa Gabor Begins Three-Day Sentence For Cop-Slapping Conviction
DOC.TEXT: Zsa Zsa Gabor checked into the city jail Friday to begin serving a three-day sentence for slapping a Beverly Hills motorcycle police officer. The 72-year-old celebrity, dressed in slacks and a sweatshirt and clutching a ``good-luck frog,'' appeared in good spirits when she checked in at 1 p.m., said Fern Ruiz, a police department records clerk. ``She seemed to be a very pleasant lady,'' said Ruiz. After a three-week, highly publicized trial, Miss Gabor was convicted of three misdemeanors Sept. 29 arising from her June 14, 1989, run-in with Officer Paul Kramer. Kramer, who stopped Miss Gabor's Rolls-Royce because its license plates had expired, testified that Miss Gabor drove away from him. When he pulled her over again, she swore and slapped his face. The actress, who unsuccessfully appealed the 72-hour jail sentence, is to be released Monday afternoon. Ruiz said Miss Gabor was the only prisoner at the 17-person jail in this Los Angeles suburb when she checked in, but that others were expected Friday. The one-time Hungarian beauty queen will stay in an 8-foot by 10-foot, one-person cell, furnished with a metal-frame bed, a toilet and a sink, Ruiz said. ``Normally those who come in for these weekend stays just sit in their cells and if they want to work we usually have them do something like wash cars,'' Ruiz said. ``In her case, we didn't think that would be appropriate,'' Ruiz said. ``So we'll have her doing the clerical work. That's something she has expressed an interest in.'' Miss Gabor will dine on TV dinners and be allowed to wear her own clothing, like other jail prisoners, Ruiz said. Miss Gabor is paying $85 a day to stay in the city jail of her choice. Otherwise, she would have been assigned as a general population prisoner. Beverly Hills Municipal Judge Charles Rubin also ordered Miss Gabor to pay nearly $13,000 in fines and restitution and to serve 120 hours of community service at a Venice shelter for homeless women. In May, Rubin found Miss Gabor in violation of probation for failure to complete the community service. As for Officer Kramer, he was busy across town Friday in Beverly Hills. He was sent in response to a call by Roseanne Barr and husband Tom Arnold to remove a photographer from a news conference the couple held at the Beverly Hilton Hotel. Barr held the news conference to explain her screeching rendition of the national anthem Wednesday before a baseball game in San Diego.

DOC.HEAD: Some Examples of Miracle Survivors of Earthquakes
With AM-Philippines-Quake
DOC.TEXT: In the Philippine city of Baguio, rescuers Friday pulled two survivors from the rubble of a hotel 11 days after it collapsed in an earthquake that killed more than 1,600 people. Here are some other miraculous cases of earthquake survival: MEXICO CITY, September 1985 _ The most celebrated survivors of the Mexico City earthquake were the ``miracle babies'' found in the rubble of two maternity hospitals. The newborns survived periods of entombment ranging from eight hours to almost nine days. EL SALVADOR, Oct. 10, 1986 _ Rescue workers heard a woman's voice from within the wreckage of a downtown office building toppled by a devastating earthquake six days earlier. The woman was found by the Swiss team and other foreign and domestic crews tunneling through the maze of twisted steel and broken concrete. SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 21, 1989 _ Buck Helm, the Oakland longshoreman who survived without food or water for 89 { hours, was rescued after his car was crushed in the rubble of the flattened Oakland Freeway. He died 28 days after his rescue.

DOC.HEAD: Problems Force Destruction of Rocket Bearing Star Wars Components
DOC.TEXT: An Aries rocket carrying a $20 million Star Wars experiment was destroyed shortly after liftoff because the rocket's guidance system failed, authorities said Friday. ``This will not significantly affect the program,'' said Lt. Col. Alan R. Freitag of the Strategic Defense Initiative Organization in Washington. ``It's a very unfortunate loss, certainly, but not an insurmountable calamity.'' The SPEAR 2 experiment cost $20 million and the launch itself cost $1 million, he said, but the payload was designed to be recoverable, so it will be difficult to calculate the loss. The single-stage rocket was launched from White Sands Missile Range at 11:51 p.m. Wednesday, he said. ``Approximately 35 seconds into the mission, flight safety determined that the missile was off course,'' Freitag said, and the range missile flight safety officer decided to abort the launch by cutting off the rocket's boost. ``All pieces of the booster and the SPEAR 2 experiment package fell within the boundaries of White Sands Missile Range,'' he said. The payload was to have flown in a suborbital, 13-minute flight, reaching an altitude of 124 miles, Freitag said. Maj. Bill O'Connell of the Star Wars office in Washington said the rocket had been scheduled to lift off a week ago, but weather and other problems delayed the flight until Wednesday. SPEAR 2, which stands for Space Power Experiment Aboard Rocket, was designed to provide scientific measurements of high-voltage conductors exposed to a space environment, he said. The experiment had undergone testing at the National Aeronautics and Space Administration's Plum Brook Space Power Facility at Sandusky, Ohio, he said. The ground tests simulated experimental conditions in space, Freitag said. ``But you can only have a certain degree of confidence that you've created the space environment'' on the ground, he said. ``The launch would have validated information already obtained at Plum Brook.'' Officials are considering the necessity of repeating the experiment in light of costs and the scientific data already obtained through ground testing, he said. The Senate last month trimmed $1 billion from President Bush's $4.7 billion budget request for SDI, a research effort to develop lasers and other exotic weapons that could shoot down nuclear missiles fired at the United States.

DOC.HEAD: FDA Says Don't Use Cal-Ban 3000
DOC.TEXT: The Food and Drug Administration said Friday it wants Cal-Ban 3000 diet tablets and capsules taken off the market because they can cause throat obstructions and their weight-loss claims are unproven. The agency advised consumers to stop using Cal-Ban, whose main ingredient is guar gum, a complex sugar that swells with water and creates a sense of fullness when eaten. The FDA sent a letter to Cal-Ban's distributor, Health Care Products Inc. of Lutz, Fla., saying the agency would take legal action against the company if it does not stop distribution of the product. The agency called Cal-Ban ``a health hazard'' based on reports of 17 cases in which people experienced throat obstruction after eating Cal-Ban 3000. Ten were hospitalized and one died as an indirect result of the obstruction when a blood clot reached the lungs during surgery, the FDA said. Last week, Florida stopped state sales of the product because it had reports of 50 cases involving injuries. The FDA said it has asked to review those cases. Company officials could not be reached for comment. The telephone number for the company, which also does business as Anderson Pharmacals of Tampa, Fla., reached a recording that said the line had been disconnected. Cal-Ban is distributed nationally, the FDA said. The FDA said guar gum has not been demonstrated to be an effective weight-loss ingredient. The agency has been moving to ban the substance for this use. Use of guar gum is permitted in small amounts in foods such as cheese, salad dressings and ice creams. The FDA said it poses no health problem when used that way. Health Care Products is currently under a temporary restraining order issued by a federal court in Tampa that prohibits the company from selling Cal-Ban 3000 by telephone or mail, said Jeff Drucker, an attorney in the consumer protection division of the Postal Service. He said the order stems from a Postal Service action several years ago in which the agency alleged the company falsely advertised that Cal-Ban was an effective weight-loss product.

DOC.HEAD: Bush OK's Nippon Sanso Acquisition of Semi-Gas Systems
DOC.TEXT: President Bush has decided against intervening in the planned acquisition by a Japanese corporation of an American firm, Semi-Gas Systems, Inc., that makes equipment used in manufacturing semiconductors, the White House announced Friday. The decision follows an administration investigation of whether the sale of company to Nippon Sanso K.K. posed a threat to U.S. security interests, and drew an immediate angry response from executives of Sematech, the federally financed research consortium that links several important U.S. semiconductor companies. The parent company of Semi-Gas, Hercules Inc. of Wilmington, Del., in April announced its intention to sell the subidiary to Nippon Sanso for $23 million. Semi-Gas designs, assembles and installs gas systems used in making computer chips, which must be manufactured in super-clean environments. ``We've worked with a leading American firm to develop leading technology and then to have that technology fall into the hands of a foreign competitor doesn't sit very well with us,'' said Miller Bonner, a spokesman for Sematech in Austin, Texas. Bonner said Sematech also feared the sale would give the Japanese company confidential information held by the 14 American computer company partners that make up the consortium. White House deputy press secretary Alixe Glen said Bush ``based his decision on the results of an investigation by the Committee on Foreign Investment in the United States,'' chaired by Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady. That panel investigated national security concerns relating to the possible acquisition, Ms. Glen said. The investigation was carried out under the Exon-Florio provision of the Defense Production Act, which allows the president to prohibit or suspend foreign acquisitions of U.S. businesses that threaten national security. If the deal goes through, Sematech will not allow Semi-Gas employees on the premises and the consortium will use every legal means ``to protect our intellectual property.'' ``We sort of feel like we're in an economic war right now,'' he said. Bonner said Sematech tried to block the proposed sale, saying it would breach national security or run afoul of antitrust laws. ``Why would we want to develop leading world class technology only to sell it to a foreign competitor. It's very ironic that we get half of our funding from the Department of Defense and then we get a ruling like this,'' he said. The company receives about $100 million a year from the Defense Department.

DOC.HEAD: Leukemia Patient Undergoes Tests for Transplant from Mother
DOC.NOTE: Eds: `Allison' is cq.
DOC.TEXT: Leukemia patient Allison Atlas, whose unsuccessful quest for a perfectly matched bone-marrow donor drew 50,000 would-be contributors, underwent tests Friday for a possible transplant from her mother. Miss Atlas, 20, was admitted to the transplant floor of the Fred Hutchinson Cancer Research Center on Thursday, center spokeswoman Susan Edmonds said Friday. The first step in such a transplant _ a week of chemotherapy and radiation to destroy the diseased marrow _ will not begin until a date has been set, which might happen later Friday, Edmonds said. ``There have been no procedures done, just some testing'' to determine Miss Atlas' condition, Edmonds said. Simon Atlas, a cousin of Miss Atlas' father, said Friday in New York that the chemotherapy and radiation could begin Monday, with the transplant performed early the following week. Relatives are uneasy, he said, but Miss Atlas ``seems to be pretty cool.'' ``I spoke to her the night before. She's anxious to get it done. She wants to get on with her life,'' Atlas said. ``She really feels confident it's going to work. It's just remarkable how positive her attitude is.'' The Bethesda, Md., woman was a student at New York University until she became ill last year. She said last week she had decided to undergo a transplant of her mother's marrow while she is strong enough for the procedure. Arline Atlas's marrow matches four out of six antigens, or cell identifiers, in her daughter's marrow. With Miss Atlas's type of leukemia, doctors say there is a 60 percent survival rate with a transplant if there's a six-antigen match. The survival rate is even lower without a perfect match. But without a transplant, the disease is 100 percent fatal. Miss Atlas is in an extremely sterile environment, said Edmonds, as is the case with all bone marrow patients. Well-wishers can send ``cards, balloons and little animals,'' but she cannot receive flowers or plants, said Simon Atlas. Her room is divided by a clear plastic curtain, so she and her family are separated but can see each other and talk, he said. Blood-producing marrow is a key element in the body's immune system, and transplant recipients are extremely vulnerable to infection immediately after the procedure, before the new marrow begins functioning. A campaign launched last fall by Miss Atlas' family and a support group, Friends of Allison, prompted 50,000 people in the United States and Israel to take blood tests to determine if they were perfect donors. It also raised $3 million for processing the samples. Ten patients found perfectly matched donors as a result of the flood of new listings with the National Marrow Donor Program, but Miss Atlas was not among them. Mrs. Atlas had been ``a fallback all along,'' Simon Atlas said earlier this week. ``She's not a perfect match, obviously, or we would have used her'' at the outset. If a perfect match is found ``up to the moment of transplant, we would use it,'' he said. Marrow from Mrs. Atlas will be given to her daughter in a transfusion, a procedure that takes two to three hours. Two to three weeks after the transplant, doctors watch for an increase in white blood cells, a sign that the transplant has taken. In leukemia, a form of cancer, white blood cells multiply uncontrollably. Bone marrow produces blood, and doctors can combat the cancer by replacing the diseased marrow with healthy tissue.

DOC.HEAD: Intelligence Analysts Discharged After Mysterious Florida Trip
DOC.TEXT: The Army on Friday discharged six soldiers who left their intelligence unit in Europe and went to a Florida beach town known for frequent sightings of UFOs. The soldiers were reported missing July 9 from their post in Augsburg, West Germany, and were arrested less than a week later in Gulf Breeze, Fla. An investigation found no evidence the soldiers from the 701st Military Intelligence Brigade had been involved in espionage during the time they were AWOL, said Maj. Ron Mazzia, a spokesman for Fort Knox, where the soldiers were detained. Stan Johnson of Bybee, Tenn., a friend of one of the soldiers, Spec. Kenneth G. Beason, 26, said Beason told him they had been ``chosen by ... divine intervention to help prepare for the end of the world, which was supposed to occur in about eight years from now.'' Johnson added that, ``when the second coming of Christ occurred, Jesus Christ was going to arrive in a spaceship.'' Gulf Breeze, a beach town near Pensacola where Beason and others in the group received training, has been the site of many reported UFO sightings. A symposium of the Mutual UFO Network concluded there July 8, police said. Besides Beason, the others who received general discharges were identified as Pfc. Michael Hueckstaedt, 19, of Farson, Wyo.; Pfc. Kris Perlock, 20, of Osceola, Wis.; Pfc. William Setterberg, 20, of Pittsburgh; Spec. Vance Davis, 25, of Valley Center, Kan.; and Sgt. Annette Eccleston, 22, of Hartford, Conn. Capt. Kenneth Hicks of the Gulf Breeze police said that when he questioned Hueckstaedt and Eccleston, they said the group planned to travel to Texas or New Mexico ``and they were just going to kind of live out in the woods.'' Mazzia said the soldiers were fined half a month's pay and were reduced in rank: Eccleston to specialist and the others to private. They were absent without leave for varying amounts of time, but the longest was seven days, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Sunny Forecast Clouds Firefighters' Hopes
DOC.TEXT: Scattered rain has checked some of the more than 120 fires that have consumed nearly 3,000 square miles of Alaskan forest and tundra this month, but a fair-weather forecast had firefighters worried Friday. ``The battle's not over yet by any means,'' Trish Hogervorst-Rukke, a spokeswoman at the Fire Information Center in Fairbanks, noting the forecaset for clear, sunny skies over the next several days. The rain over the past few days has reduced much of the smoke that hampered air and ground travel and obscured many of the blazes. ``It's clear as a bell in Fairbanks today,'' said Hogervorst-Rukke. ``This is the first time I've seen blue sky since I got here over a week ago.'' The most intense firefighting Friday was in the McGrath area in western Alaska, where a complex of four wind-driven fires near Nikolai had claimed 249,530 acres and was within two miles of villages and cabins. About 2,700 firefighters and 11 air tankers were working 12 of the 122 fires statewide, including one new blaze. The largest single fire in the state Friday was a 210,000-acre blaze in the Kanuti Wildlife Refuge, 140 miles northwest of Fairbanks. Federal firefighting costs in Alaska this season are estimated at $10.5 million so far, and state costs at $22.4 million. The state will be reimbursed by the federal government, however, for costs incurred on federal land. Two weeks ago, the fires' cost was estimated at $15 million, and the state has long since scrapped its initial firefighting budget of about $3 million. State forester Bob Dick has said he doesn't know where the extra funding will come from.

DOC.HEAD: Feeling Is Believing With New Football Cards
LaserPhoto NY19
DOC.TEXT: Three years after his retirement, Jim Plunkett is back, on the first football card you can feel _ the Braille card. Plunkett, whose parents are visually impaired, on Friday unveiled his card, the first in what will be a set of 280 National Football League cards featuring raised pictures of the players with Braille information on the back. The cards hold particular significance for Plunkett, who retired from the Los Angeles Raiders in 1987. ``It's one heck of an idea. They contacted me a few months ago with the idea because of my family background,'' he said. Money from sales of Plunkett's card will be donated to The Peninsula Society for the Blind, and Family Service of Mid-Peninsula. The Plunketts are active in both agencies. The manufacturer, Hi-Pro Marketing, plans a full 280-card set of current players, to be sold for $120, and packs of six cards for $2.49, said Laurie Pearlstein, a publicist for the collection. Pearlstein said there was no determination on exactly how many of the Plunkett cards will be manufactured, but they will be ``very limited, quite the collector's item.'' Some of the cards will be distributed to visually impaired children, she said. John Bosworth, vice president of Hi-Pro Marketing, said his company decided to try the Braille cards after discovering the process it used to emboss the pictures could be used for Braille type. ``We jumped at the chance to make sports cards more accessible to the blind,'' said Bosworth. ``We are very excited at the prospect of expanding production into an entire series of Braille cards.''

DOC.BYLINE: NBC Union Rejects Contract for Second Time ^By JAY SHARBUTT
DOC.TEXT: The union that struck NBC for 17 weeks in 1987 has rejected the company's four-year contract offer for the second time since April, the union said Friday. No walkout is imminent, however. No strike vote has been taken yet and ``we're trying to arrange further bargaining talks,'' said John Krieger, a spokesman for the National Association of Broadcast Employees and Technicians. NABET members at NBC, voting in a mail ballot last month and this month on the network's latest contract offer, rejected it 1,290 to 516, he said. NBC said in a statement that it would not further revise its offer, which was changed slightly in April after the union rejected it 1,601 to 353. The union's previous contract expired March 30, but its 2,373 members kept working. The network, noting that contract talks have lasted seven months, said it would review ways to conclude the negotiations. NBC spokesman Joseph Rutledge declined to elaborate on the network's strategy, or to say whether NBC would implement its last contract offer. When the company did that in 1987, the union began its long strike. NBC's offer provides for a 3 percent pay hike upon ratification, and would not be retroactive. Salaries would rise another 3 percent in the contract's second year. Union members would get a lump-sum payment equal to 5 percent of their base salary in the third year and a 4 percent raise in the contract's last year. Krieger said money was not a major issue. The main issues include jurisdiction, daily hires and ``four-walling'' proposals, he said. Under the last, outside producers renting NBC facilities would not be required to use NABET crews employed by the network. That condition would apply only to new shows, however. The union claims 2,373 members at NBC, network-owned operations in New York and Burbank, Calif., Washington, Chicago, and Cleveland, and NBC news bureaus throughout the country. The majority _ 1,300 _ are engineers and technicians. Other members include local and national news writers, couriers and building maintenance workers. Engineers at NBC now average $895 a week in base pay, and their supervisors get $1,110 a week. Newswriters average $674 a week, plus fees for working on different programs, the union said.

DOC.HEAD: Avianca Offers $75,000 Immediate Payment to Crash Victims
DOC.TEXT: Avianca Airlines announced Friday it was willing to pay $75,000 each to survivors or relatives of victims of the crash of Flight 52 without requiring them to relinquish their rights to further claims. Seventy-three people died and 85 were injured in the Jan. 25 crash of the Boeing 707 on Long Island during an approach to Kennedy Airport after a flight from Colombia. Attorneys for the victims hailed the offer as unprecedented and generous. ``They were smart and did what was morally correct,'' said Marc S. Moller, who represents 45 of the crash victims. ``This is a great humanitarian gesture,'' said lawyer Robert A. Solomon, who filed a $100 million lawsuit against Avianca on behalf of a man and his young son. The proposal was made by an attorney for Avianca, George Tompkins, during a hearing before U.S. District Judge Thomas C. Platt on civil lawsuits filed against the airline in the tragedy. So far, about 100 civil lawsuits have been filed against Avianca in the crash, so the offer would cost the airline at least $7.5 million. Under the terms of the Warsaw Convention governing international aviation, air-crash victims' awards are generally limited to $75,000 unless willful misconduct by the airline is proven. Moller said that in the past airlines had paid out settlement money only after they had been ordered to do so by a court following the resolutions of often lengthy lawsuits. Moller said he would proceed with the civil lawsuits against the airline. Under the Avianca proposal, the airline also would continue to pay survivors' medical expenses at least until the end of the year. Subtracted from the lump sum would be payments already made to the families _ $2,500 to each survivor plus a $1,500 monthly living-expense allotment paid for the last several months. Generally, Solomon said, payments are offered only as settlements in which the plaintiff agrees to drop any future legal action. ``My client will be very pleased with this offer because they need the money,'' said Kenneth P. Nolan, whose firm represents about two dozen families of crash victims. He called the Avianca offer ``generous'' and ``fair,'' but said he believed many of his clients would eventually receive much more compensation. ``It's a good first step,'' he said. In addition to the action against Avianca, at least 12 passengers injured in the crash have sued the Federal Aviation Administration, maintaining that air traffic controllers failed to insure a safe flight for the jetliner. The plane crashed on a wooded hillside near Cove Neck, N.Y., about 20 miles east of New York City after running out of fuel. Under the terms of the Avianca offer, the U.S. government would have to acknowledge that in making the payments the airline does not abandon its right to sue the federal government to recoup the payments.

DOC.SECOND: Former CIA Agent: Planes Used `Fuzz Busters'
DOC.TEXT: A former CIA agent who helped coordinate the Contra supply effort in Central America testified Friday that planes were so ill-equipped they used ordinary ``fuzz busters'' to detect enemy radar. Felix Rodriguez' testimony came in the trial of a federal damage lawsuit by the family of William Sawyer Jr. and Eugene Hasenfus, the sole survivor of the October 1986 crash in Nicaragua that helped unravel the Iran-Contra affair. Hasenfus and the family of Sawyer, who died when Sandinistas shot down the C-123 carrying supplies to the Nicaraguan rebels, claim retired Air Force Gen. Richard Secord and Miami-based Southern Air Transport were their true employers, misrepresented the mission and skimped on safety equipment. Rodriguez testified that when he left the operation in June 1986 he brought then-White House aide Oliver North a letter from crewmen complaining their navigational equipment was inadequate. ``They hit a tree in Costa Rica because they were off course,'' Rodriguez said. ``They had quite a lot of maintenance problems in the beginning.'' Over the strong objections of Southern Air attorneys, Rodriguez was allowed to testify about the primitive nature of the equipment. He said the only radar detection devices aboard were Radio Shack ``fuzz busters,'' designed to help drivers spot police cars on the highway. Under cross-examination, Rodriguez said that by September 1986, before the crash, he was told the equipment had improved. Rodriguez said he began helping the Contra supply operation at North's request, but left because his top priority was helping the El Salvador air force fight leftist guerrillas. The former agent, who left the CIA in 1976, is credited with capturing Cuban leader Fidel Castro's close ally Ernesto ``Che'' Guevara in Bolivia and was a veteran of the Bay of Pigs invasion in 1961. Hasenfus' attorneys also presented a deposition by Richard Gadd, who helped set up the supply operation, in which Gadd said Secord directed the funds and made policy decisions in the enterprise. Corporate Air Services was used as a front to hide the involvement of Southern Air, which was once owned by the CIA and continued to do contract work for the U.S. government, Gadd said. He and Southern Air President William Langton decided the effort ``should be treated as a clandestine or covert activity (so the) media could not attempt to trace it back to the owners and the United States government,'' the deposition said. Secord denies the connection and says he never met Hasenfus or Sawyer. Southern Air has denied involvement with the Hasenfus flight and claims Hasenfus and Sawyer worked for Corporate Air Services, a separate company. After the crash, the Reagan administration acknowledged that money from Iran arms sales was diverted to the Contras, despite a congressional ban on U.S. military aid to the rebels. Attorneys for Hasenfus, of Marinette, Wis., and Sawyer's family, of Magnolia, Ark., have submitted a preliminary estimate of of $3.4 million in damages, including expenses caused by the crash and lost income. Secord pleaded guilty Nov. 8, 1989, to lying to congressional investigators when he said he wasn't aware of any money that went to North's benefit from the maze of companies he used in the Iran-Contra affair. He was sentenced to two years probation.
