DOC.HEAD: Prosecutor Who Filed McMartin Charges Blames D.A. for Outcome
With AM-Preschool Molest
DOC.TEXT: The former prosecutor who first filed molestation charges in the McMartin Pre-School case blamed District Attorney Ira Reiner for Friday's mistrial. But Reiner said the case was in trouble long before he took over. ``There was nothing wrong with that case when it was filed,'' said Robert Philibosian, who lost his post to Reiner in a hard-fought 1984 contest. ``(Reiner) has to answer for that case.'' Philibosian called the outcome a ``political disaster'' for Reiner, whose future was already clouded by his recent primary election loss for state attorney general. Superior Court Judge Stanley Weisberg declared a mistrial in Raymond Buckey's molestation retrial after a jury said it was hopelessly deadlocked on eight sex counts involving children at the preschool. The McMartin case consumed seven years of court time and cost Los Angeles County more than $13.5 million, making it the longest, most expensive criminal court case in U.S. history. Reiner decided to put an end to the case following the mistrial. ``We are not going to retry this case for a third time,'' Reiner said. ``Nothing would be served by putting the children, the parents and the public through this for a third time.'' But Reiner said he did not regret going through with the second trial. ``It was important to see if this case was tried with dispatch if there would be another result,'' he said. ``The parents felt it was important there would be a resolution. I think it's clear now there cannot be.'' Reiner conceded, however, there were ``fundamental problems with the evidence in this case,'' but contended those problems predated his tenure as district attorney. He singled out the use of private therapists rather than police officers to interview the children who claimed they were molested. ``These people were acting in good faith,'' he said. But he added they were not trained in criminal law and did not know that ``it's necessary when you question children not to say anything that was leading or suggestive to the child.'' The case originally featured seven defendants, but Reiner dropped charges against five defendants in 1986 for lack of evidence. Reiner and others criticized Philibosian, contending he pursued the McMartin case as vigorously as he did to help himself politically. Philibosian has denied the allegation.

DOC.HEAD: Stepfather Who Killed Boy With Dunking Says It Wasn't Intentional
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Note contents.
DOC.TEXT: The stepfather charged with fatally plunging a 2-year-old headfirst into a toilet testified Friday that he never meant to kill the child and only dangled him in the toilet to teach him a lesson. ``Murder is the wrong word to use because it wasn't intentional,'' said Thomas Coe, 23. ``His death was not planned. ... It was an instantaneous thought.'' Coe's testimony in his first-degree murder and aggravated child abuse trial came a year from the day he dunked stepson Bradley McGee into the commode as punishment for soiling his pants. ``I turned him upside down, put his head in the commode and lifted him back out,'' Coe said. ``I grabbed both feet with my right hand and flushed the commode holding him above the water.'' Bradley died of massive head injuries the next day. Earlier Friday, Coe's mother collapsed on the witness stand and was taken out in a stretcher after testifying that her son's wife, Sheryl McGee Coe, hated Bradley and was to blame for the child's misfortune. Mary Rae Coe Anders testified that on one occasion, she had to rush over to the couple's trailer when her son called to say Mrs. Coe had violently shaken the boy. When Mrs. Anders arrived, she said, she found Coe cuddling Bradley and his wife screaming, ``I didn't mean to do it, I didn't mean to do it.'' After Mrs. Anders' collapse, she was treated for chest pains at a hospital and released. The jury was not present during Mrs. Anders' testimony, and prosecutors and defense attorneys agreed to have it read to the jury without mention of the frantic courtroom scene. Coe has confessed to the dunking, but his attorneys contend he should be convicted of a lesser offense because it was merely an isolated punishment in potty training and there was no malicious intent. Prosecutors are seeking the death penalty, arguing Bradley's death was the culmination of weeks of Coe's torturous abuse. Bradley's death came only two weeks after he was ordered returned from foster care to his mother and stepfather. Mrs. Coe, 21, has testified that during those two months her husband often forced the child to pick up feces with his mouth and that Coe ground his fist and cayenne pepper into the boy's genitals. She admitted to sometimes aiding in abuse and beating the toddler with pillows just before he died. She pleaded no contest to second-degree murder and aggravated child abuse and is serving a 30-year sentence. Medical experts have testified that Bradley's body was found to be covered with more than 50 bruises, many inflicted up to two weeks before his death. ``You've seen the pictures of your son since the day he was killed,'' prosecutor John Aguero shouted, pointing to hospital photos of Bradley. ``How hard did you have to hit him to cause those bruises?'' ``I don't know the amount of force it took,'' Coe answered. ``You hit him hard, didn't you Mr. Coe?'' the prosecutor said. ``I don't know,'' Coe replied. Final arguments were scheduled for Monday. The case was moved from Polk County, where the death occurred, to Fort Myers because of intense publicity.

DOC.HEAD: Two Found Alive After 11 Days in Philippine Quake Rubble
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 22 grafs to UPDATE with rains delaying evacuation; ADDS details of rescue, ages of two survivors, reports they drank rainwater and urine to stay alive; pickup 18th graf, Local miners . ..
DOC.TEXT: Miners who heard cries of ``Help us!'' rescued two people Friday from the rubble of a luxury hotel that collapsed 11 days ago in an earthquake that killed more than 1,600 people. Doctors said the man and woman were in surprisingly good condition. The man said a beam missed his head by inches. He was found lying near the bodies of four people. Rescuers said the woman was in good spirits. They said when they called out ``Mrs., are you all right?'' she shouted back: ``I'm still a miss!'' Manila radio reporters, broadcasting from the scene, said the two survived by drinking rainwater and their own urine. Rescuers and spectators cheered as Luisa Mallorca, a 20-year-old cleaning woman, was pulled from the wreckage of the Hyatt Hotel at about 9:50 p.m. Arnel Calabia, a 26-year-old security guard, was recovered about an hour later. As dawn broke Saturday, miners combed the hotel for other possible survivors. They pulled two male bodies from the debris. At least 18 people who were in the Hyatt during the July 16 quake are still missing. Foreign rescue teams gave up searching last week, convinced no survivors would be found. It was a major quake, measuring 7.7 on the Richter scale. Calabia said he, Ms. Mallorca and a male employee were on the third floor when the quake struck. All three dived under tables ``and then the ceiling fell in,'' he said in a radio interview. ``We recovered consciousness later and we called out to each other.'' The three lay in the dark, talked to each other and prayed, Calabia and Ms. Mallorca said. The other man was badly hurt and died about four days ago. Ms. Mallorca said the man complained of thirst in his final days and became delirious. ``He said: `I'm very very thirsty. I want a cold Coke. Go to my wife and ask for money and buy us a Coke,''' she said on the radio. ``The following day he was still asking for a Coke. I told him, `Don't think about it, just pray.''' The man finally fell silent. ``I convinced myself he was not yet dead,'' Calabia said. ``I told him I would cover his face because rain was dripping down.'' ``I was OK where I was, but I realized just a while ago that there was a concrete slab above my forehead. Just a few more inches and I would have been dead too.'' Calabia and Ms. Mallorca are employees of the state-run Philippine Amusement and Gaming Corp., which operated a casino in the 12-story hotel. They were being treated at Baguio General Hospital. Doctors said both suffered cuts, bruises and severe dehydration. Calabia told reporters his right hand was injured and nurses told him three fingers might have to be amputated. Ms. Mallorca complained of chest pains, rescuers said. Officials planned to fly the survivors to Manila, but monsoon rains closed Baguio airport Saturday. The rains interrupted flights of relief supplies. Attempts to look for other survivors had been slowed by a fire touched off Thursday night by acetylene torches used to cut through the wreckage. The ruins still smoldered early Saturday. Local miners and other volunteers vowed to keep looking until all the missing were accounted for. Jacinto Benayan, one of the miners, said they stepped up the search Thursday after hearing cries of ``Help us! Help us!'' After boring for five hours, they reached the hotel elevator shaft and found Ms. Mallorca pinned beneath a beam. Calabia was found nearby. In October, a California longshoreman was pulled from beneath tons of wreckage of an Oakland freeway that had collapsed four days earlier in an earthquake. Buck Helm had suffered injuries to virtually every organ in his body when his compact car was crushed under Interstate 880. He died 28 days after his rescue, which came after workers had given up hope of finding more survivors. The Hyatt was one of eight hotels that collapsed during the July 16 earthquake, the strongest to hit the Philippines in 14 years. Baguio, a mountain resort 130 miles north of Manila, was one of the cities hardest hit. Nearly 400 people died in the town. According to the latest figures, the Philippines earthquake left at least 1,653 people dead, 1,000 missing and presumed dead, 3,000 seriously injured and 110,000 homeless. Also Friday, air force chief Maj. Gen. Gerardo Protacio ordered gunships and rocket-firing planes to escort helicopters carrying relief supplies to villages stricken by the quake. The order follows guerrilla attacks on two helicopters. The military said the guerrilla fire Wednesday over the town of Kayapa represented a violation of the rebels' unilateral cease-fire in areas hit by the earthquake.

DOC.HEAD: Charges Dropped Against Alleged 911 Network Hacker
By MICHAEL GOUGIS
Associated Press Writer
DOC.TEXT: Prosecutors on Friday dropped all charges against a student accused of publishing a computer program stolen from a nine-state 911 emergency network in an underground electronic newsletter, attorneys said. Craig Neidorf of Chesterfield, Mo., a member of a computer hacker network known as the Legion of Doom, was assigned to a three-year pretrial diversion program similar to probation, said Assistant U.S. Attorney William Cook. Neidorf faced 10 counts of wire fraud, receiving stolen goods and interstate transportation of stolen goods, Cook said. Had he been convicted, he could have faced up to 31 years in prison and $122,000 in fines. The 20-year-old pre-law student at the University of Missouri was indicted in February in the theft a year before of the Atlanta-based BellSouth Corp. computer program that controlled 911 emergency calls to police, fire, ambulance and emergency services. The program handled 911 calls in Alabama, Mississippi, Georgia, Tennessee, Kentucky, Louisiana, North and South Carolina and Florida. Much of the computer program that prosecutors originally believed was stolen was actually public property, which prompted prosecutors to drop the charges, Cook said. The case was heard in U.S. District Court in Chicago because the newsletter was published on a computer bulletin board in Lockport, Ill., prosecutors said. Prosecutors said Legion of Doom members used their computers to tap into the 911 system and copy the program. They then published the information in PHRACK, an underground electronic newsletter Neidorf had published since he was 16 for ``computer freaks and hackers,'' he said. Emergency telephone service was not interrupted during or because of the break-in, although the hackers threatened the network's operation when they breached its security codes, Cook said. ``He was just doing this to put it into his newsletter _ to say, `See what I got,''' Cook said. ``It was just for ego gratification _ an ego trip.'' Neidorf's attorney, Sheldon Zenner, said he's happy prosecutors dropped the case. ``We are just grateful that the U.S. attorney's office took the evidence into consideration,'' Zenner said. When the indictments were handed down, acting U.S. Attorney Ira Raphaelson called the break-in intentional and threatening. ``These were not teen-agers playing games,'' Raphaelson said. ``They are thieves, they're reckless and they're dangerous.'' An estimated $3 billion to $5 billion is lost each year to computer fraud, Raphaelson said. Another man indicted in the February, 1989 break-in, Robert Riggs, 20, of Decatur, Ga., pleaded guilty to charges of wire fraud and transferring stolen goods across interstate lines, Cook said. The Neidorf decision will not have any effect on Riggs' case, he said. Riggs is to be sentenced in U.S. District Court in Georgia on Sept. 14. He faces up to 15 years in prison and $500,000 in fines, Cook said.

DOC.HEAD: Grateful Dead Keyboard Player Found Dead in Home at 38
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 10th graf pvs, `He replaced...,' to CORRECT spelling to Godchaux sted Godschaux and add background on previous deaths of band members. Mydland is pronounced MID-land.
DOC.TEXT: Brent Mydland, keyboard player for the rock band Grateful Dead, was found dead in his home Thursday. He was 38. It was unclear when and how he died, said Sgt. Richard Terry of the Contra Costa County Coroner's office. ``We lost a brother and we are very devastated,'' said Grateful Dead spokesman Dennis McNally. The 1960s counterculture band, known for such hits as ``Casey Jones,'' and ``Truckin','' retains a loyal cult following today. Fans _ known as ``Deadheads'' and including people who weren't born when the band first came to prominence _ follow the group from performance to performace. An autopsy on Mydland was scheduled for Friday morning. Friends apparently went to his home in Lafayette, a suburb 25 miles east of San Francisco, after being unable to contact Mydland, Terry said. He had returned Tuesday from New York City, where the band completed a three-week national tour, Terry said. Mydland wrote the well-known Grateful Dead tune ``Far From Me,'' and more recently co-wrote the environmental ballad ``We Can Run (But We Can't Hide),'' which was used in an Audubon Society video. He was also known among fans for his ``I Will Take You Home,'' a lullaby written for his two daughters. Mydland was born in Germany to American parents stationed there with the military and grew up in the San Francisco Bay area, McNally said. As a teen-ager, Mydland played with small local rock 'n' roll bands. He eventually made his name as the keyboard player with the 1970s rock band Silver. Mydland joined the Grateful Dead in April 1979 after a stint with lead guitarist and vocalist Bob Weir's side band Bobby and the Midnights. He replaced keyboardist Keith Godchaux, who died a year after leaving the band. The band's second keyboard player, Ron ``Pig Pen'' McKernan, died in the early 1970s at the age of 27. Mydland is survived by his wife, Lisa, and his daughters.

DOC.HEAD: Knapp Charged Again In 1973 Deaths
DOC.TEXT: John Henry Knapp, freed three years ago after spending 12 years on death row for allegedly setting fire to his trailer with his two young daughters inside, was charged again Thursday in their deaths. The charges came in a bare-bones, two-page complaint, and the state Attorney General's office refused to say what new evidence it might have. Prosecutors claim that Knapp, now 44, set the Nov. 16, 1973 fire that killed Linda Louise and Iona Marie Knapp, ages 2 and 3, while they slept in the family house trailer in suburban Mesa. Knapp's attorneys claim the fire was started either by Knapp's then-wife, Linda, or by the children themselves. Knapp was sentenced to death in January 1975 but was freed in 1987 by Maricopa County Superior Court Judge Stephen Gerst, who ruled that new defense evidence left it unclear what or who started the fire. The new charges come weeks before an election for attorney general, and Knapp's attorney Mark Wallace said the timing seemed curious. ``The facts speak themselves,'' he said. ``I think you should draw your own conclusions.'' A spokesman for the prosecutors' office, Cathy Czagany, said prosecutors would not discuss their evidence for fear of violating court-imposed rules on what lawyers may say before trial. Knapp has been living with relatives in Texas and Pennsylvania since being released. He was arrested on the new charges Wednesday night in Carnegie, Pa., and is being held without bond pending extradition. Knapp, then a taxi driver, admitted his guilt shortly after the fire but retracted his statement. He has since maintained that he gave the statement because of pain from recurring migraine headaches. The state's expert had claimed the fire was so fast and fierce that it must have been fed by flammable material. But Knapp's lawyers said their expert believed the trailer's carpet could have been set alight by children playing with matches and still produced the same burn pattern that the state's expert claimed was proof of an accelerant.

DOC.HEAD: Congress Clears Way for Higher Oil-Spill Liability Limits
DOC.NOTE: EDs: ADDs one graf Alaska governor comment
DOC.TEXT: WASHINGTON (AP) = Sixteen months after the Exxon Valdez disaster, House and Senate negotiators approved legislation Thursday raising liability limits for oil shippers and creating a $1 billion federal fund to clean up spills immediately. The legislation now goes to the two chambers for final approval. Supporters said they hoped it would be ready for President Bush's signature before Congress' August recess. The bill also requires the phasing out of most single-hulled oil tankers over the next 20 years and the creation of regional Coast Guard strike teams to improve responses to serious tanker accidents. The tougher requirements were the direct result of the nation's worst oil spill on March 24, 1989, when the Exxon Valdez ran aground in Alaska's Prince William Sound. The spill tarnished hundreds of miles of shoreline shores and devastated marine life. Exxon already has spent an estimated $2 billion in cleanup efforts. The legislation agreed to Thursday by a House-Senate conference committee significantly broadens liability for shippers involved in an oil spill, raising the liability ceilings from $150 to $1,200 per gross ton. As a result the largest supertankers would face maximum liabilities under federal law of more than $240 million. If gross negligence is involved in a spill, liability would be unlimited under the legislation. The House and the Senate had approved separate versions of the bill in November. Progress stalled for months as negotiators tried to resolve differences, especially over the double-hull issue and whether to limit industry liability in line with a proposed international treaty. Over the last two months, the conferees resolved the treaty issue and settled on requiring double-hull tankers for virtually all of the tanker fleet by the year 2010. A few tankers would be given an additional five years to comply. The Coast Guard has estimated that if the Exxon Valdez had been double hulled, much of the 11 million gallons of oil that spilled into Prince William Sound might have been contained. With the most controversial issues resolved going into Thursday's final meeting of the conference committee, there remained only minor changes to be made in the bill before it was approved by a voice vote. Rep. Walter Jones, D-N.C., injected some last-minute drama into the proceedings, however, when he introduced minutes before a final vote an amendment aimed at blocking _ for a time anyway _ plans by Mobil Corp., to drill for natural gas 40 miles off the coast of Cape Hatteras, N.C. The measure was attacked by oil state congressmen, but won approval among Jones' House colleagues. It was not opposed by the Senate and was written into the bill. Jones' amendment calls for no drilling until Oct. 1, 1991 so a scientific panel could further examine the environmental impact. ``This is a pure and simple moratorium,'' declared Rep. Ron Marlenee, R-Mont. He said the provision would be challenged when the legislation goes back for final consideration in the House. Congressional sources said it's doubtful that it would derail the bill. The cornerstone of the legislation remains the $1 billion federal fund to pay for oil spill cleanups and reimburse injured parties for damages. The oil industry since last January has been paying 5 cents per barrel of oil into the fund. While the higher liability requirements and the federal fund vastly increases the money that would be available after a spill, the amounts still are far below what the Exxon Valdez spill is expected to cost _ $2 billion for the company alone, with the job still unfinished. Other provisions: _Creation of a national oil spill response unit under the Coast Guard where computers will hold lists of personnel and equipment that can be called upon worldwide in response to a spill. _Expanded research into developing new technology for oil pollution control, with $2.25 million allocated for three pilot research programs in California, New York and along the Gulf Coast. _A requirement that the federal government check driving records for alcohol-related offenses before allowing anyone to operate a tanker. The captain of the Exxon Valdez had a history of alcohol-related driving offenses and was accused of drinking before the Alaska spill. At the request of Alaska's congressional delegation, the bill would bar any tanker involved in an oil spill of more than 1 million gallons from ever entering Prince William Sound. Alaska Gov. Steve Cowper praised the agreement, saying, ``Congress is on the eve of charting a new course of environmental protection for the country. ... Congress should pass it as soon as possible to head off another disaster like the Exxon Valdez.''

DOC.HEAD: Ireland Protests British Boarding of Premier's Yacht
DOC.TEXT: The Irish government protested Thursday to Britain over British marines' boarding and searching of Prime Minister Charles Haughey's private yacht this week. The marines were based in Northern Ireland. Haughey was not on the 40-foot yacht Celtic Mist when the boarding occurred Sunday, but his three sons were. The incident took place in Carlingford Lough waterway separating County Down in the British province of Northern Ireland and County Louth in the Republic of Ireland. The boundary between Northern Ireland and the Irish Republic, which lays formal constitutional claim to Northern Ireland and its territorial waters, runs down the middle of the waterway but Belfast and Dublin dispute its exact location. News reports quoted the skipper, businessman Brian Stafford, and a Haughey son as saying the yacht was in Irish Republic waters on the south side of the waterway at the time. British army headquarters in Northern Ireland said in a statement Thursday the yacht was in Northern Ireland waters. Irish news reports said Haughey was ``not exactly pleased'' over the incident. The Irish coastal patrol vessel Orla, carrying a 76mm gun and machine guns, arrived in Carlingford Lough on Tuesday, ostensibly on fishery protection duties. British news reports claimed Dublin sent the vessel to show the flag. The Irish Department of Foreign Affairs formally protested Thursday to the British government's Northern Ireland Office in Belfast over the incident. Reports conflicted as to what happened when the Royal Marine patrol boarded the yacht. Some Irish news reports said the marines abused Stafford and others aboard even when told who the owner was, and there was an exchange of insults. The British army statement said Stafford made no objection to the marines' request to board and signed customary boarding forms. It said the search was part of routine operations to deter Irish Republican Army guerrillas from smuggling weapons by sea into Northern Ireland and that the yacht was not brought to a halt during the search. It said the marines insulted no one, and that they thanked and saluted Stafford before leaving on their own vessel. The mainly Roman Catholic IRA is fighting British rule in Northern Ireland. It wants to unite the Protestant-dominated province with the 95 percent Catholic Republic of Ireland under socialist rule. Haughey was back aboard the yacht on Thursday. The vessel is cruising off County Donegal in the northwest of the Republic of Ireland, on the other side of the island of Ireland from Carlingford Lough.

DOC.HEAD: Magazine Model Sentenced To Prison for Tax Evasion
DOC.TEXT: A former Playboy model was sentenced Thursday to 10 months in prison for evading taxes on $686,000 that an aging millionaire paid her during a five-year sexual relationship with the model and her sister. Lynnette Harris, 35, was convicted of tax evasion in May by a federal jury that did not accept her claims the money represented tax-free gifts. Ms. Harris and her identical blond sister, Leigh Ann Conley, received a total of $1.1 million through June 1987 from David Kritzik of suburban Shorewood, who died last summer at age 89. Ms. Conley was convicted in June of four misdemeanor counts of failing to file tax returns on her share of Kritzik's generosity. She was to be sentenced Aug. 29. Judge Thomas Curran sentenced Ms. Harris to 10 months in prison, plus two months in a halfway house, and fined her $12,500. Harris said afterward she intends to appeal. ``I got involved in this relationship and it has turned out to be a nightmare, to say the least,'' she said. U.S. Attorney Mel Johnson argued Ms. Harris did not accept responsibility for the crimes during the trial. ``This is not a situation where Ms. Harris had a momentary lapse of judgement. It is something she did over a period of four tax years,'' Johnson said. Curran accepted a recommendation from defense attorney Dennis Coffey and allowed her a sentence reduction usually reserved for defendants who plead guilty. Ms. Harris had faced up to 12 years in prison. ``I am convinced that unlike most tax cases, the defendant did not start out with tax evasion in mind,'' Curran said. ``She didn't devise some sophisticated scheme to evade taxes.'' Ms. Harris and Ms. Conley appeared nude in Playboy magazine and in two films, ``I the Jury'' and ``Sorceress'' before becoming two of the five young women the government said befriended Kritzik. Kritzik founded General Merchandise Co. in the 1930s. The company became one of the largest mail order companies in the world. Kritzik also founded the Treasure Island Discount Store chain as a division of General Merchandise. He sold the firm to J.C. Penney Co. in 1962 for $11 million.

A light, twin-engine plane broke up right after takeoff and burst into flames late Thursday, killing five people and badly burning a sixth, police said. All the victims, except the pilot, were Australian businessmen. The sole survivor was pulled from the wreckage by Raymond Francis, a passenger who got off the plane moments earlier during a stop at Wondai, about 185 miles northwest of Brisbane, police reported. A police spokesman said investigators were sifting through the wreckage of the Beech Kingair, spread over a wide area in heavy forest about a half-mile from the end of the airstrip. Police said Francis was watching the plane take off when disaster struck. ``When we arrived there, he had pulled this survivor from the wreckage and was dousing the flame from his body. It all happened so quickly, but it's a heroic act, I must say,'' said the spokesman, who spoke on condition of not being identified.

DOC.HEAD: Gunmen Kills Veteran Colombian Congressman
DOC.TEXT: An attacker with an automatic pistol shot to death a veteran congressman Thursday outside his party headquarters in central Colombia, police said. The congressman, Jaime Salazar, was shot several times in the head during the evening attack in the town of Pereira, a police spokesman told The Associated Press. The young assassin, who rode a motorcyle, fled afterward. He was not identified. As with many political murders in Colombia, no one claimed responsibility for the attack. However, many such assassinations have been blamed on drug traffickers, leftist guerrillas or right-wing paramilitary death squads. The 66-year-old Salazar belonged to the Social Conservative Party, Colombia's second largest political movement. He had served in congress for about 30 years. So far this year, 10,956 people have been murdered in Colombia, according to a judicial police report published Thursday in the Bogota daily newspaper El Espectador. In all of 1989, there were 22,768 homicides, the report said.

An apologetic Rep. Barney Frank, reprimanded by the House, says his worst ethics offense was unintentional and stemmed from his desire to ``conceal my homosexuality'' during his relationship with a male prostitute. The House voted 408-18 to reprimand Frank on Thursday, rejecting conservative Republican efforts to censure or expel him. But the ethics committee report mentions no link between Frank's then-unknown homosexuality and a misleading memo he wrote in 1986 to help prostitute Stephen L. Gobie, who then was on probation for sex and drug convictions. And Rep. Julian Dixon, D-Calif., chairman of the ethics committee, said that Frank's concern over revealing his sexual preference ``does not, however, justify his making misleading statements.''

The Justice Department is recommending that the Northrop Corp. _ which has pleaded guilty to fraud charges _ be barred by the Air Force from building weapons for the nation's military, agency documents say. In a series of memorandums from March to June of this year, the department sharply criticized the maker of the B-2 bomber and parts for the MX nuclear missile for failing to conduct critical tests on nuclear weapons systems. ``If any case cries out for debarment, this is the case,'' said a March 13 memo from the U.S. attorney's office in Los Angeles to O. Kevin Vincent in the Air Force's general counsel office at the Pentagon. ``If ever the American people deserve to be protected from the type of reckless and potentially life-threatening conduct, this is it,'' the memo said.

The American Dental Association charged that a government report of a patient apparently contracting AIDS from her dentist was premature and could cause undue public alarm. The Centers for Disease Control reported Thursday that a young woman who went to have two molars pulled came away infected with the virus, the first time this is known to have happened in dental surgery. The CDC said that while the possibility of another source of infection could not be ruled out, all evidence was consistent with the patient being infected by her dentist. ``We think it is not a totally conclusive case of transmission,'' countered Dr. Enid Neidle, director of scientific affairs for the Chicago-based ADA. ``We are not happy at any report that could raise fears on the part of the public that the dental office is a place of danger and infection.''

The Drug Enforcement Administration's five-year crusade to avenge the murder of agent Enrique Camarena in Mexico attained its first U.S. conviction of a major drug figure in the case. Juan Ramon Matta Ballesteros, a prominent Honduran businessman and convicted drug trafficker, was found guilty Thursday of conspiring to kidnap, torture and murder Camarena in support of a racketeering enterprise. The federal jury also convicted Matta of actually kidnapping Camarena and holding him for interrogation. But he was acquitted of the agent's murder. Matta, 45, shook his head slightly when the verdict was read. Tears streamed down the faces of family members in court.

Tobacco stock prices tumbled after the state Supreme Court ruled health warnings on cigarette packs don't shield tobacco companies from liability lawsuits by smokers. Industry attorneys blasted Thursday's decision, which departed from a series of federal appeals court rulings that gave tobacco companies immunity from smoker-death lawsuits filed after Congress ordered the warnings in 1966. The ruling lets Claire Dewey of Wyckoff continue with a lawsuit she filed in 1982, a year after her husband, Wilfred, died of lung cancer. He had smoked for more than 40 years. Dewey had smoked Camels, Tareytons and Viceroys, and his wife sued the makers of those cigarettes: R.J. Reynolds Tobacco Co., American Brands and Brown & Williamson Tobacco Corp.

President Fidel Castro says the United States is stepping up efforts to bring down his communist government as part of a ``sick obsession'' President Bush has about the island nation. ``When Bush goes to eat breakfast, he finds Cuba in his coffee, in his water, in his bread,'' Castro said Thursday night in a speech on the 37th anniversary of the beginning of his revolutionary movement that came to power in 1959. Hundreds of thousands of Cubans massed on Revolutionary Plaza to hear Castro, whose government faces serious economic problems and growing isolation following the fall of communism in Eastern Europe. Cuba's foreign relations have become even more tense in recent weeks because of dozens of asylum-seekers who have sought refuge in foreign embassies in Havana.

DOC.NOTE: $Adv30
For release Mon PMs, July 30, and thereafter
DOC.HEAD: Roger Welsch Makes Dannebrog Famous
DOC.TEXT: Roger Welsch loves stories. He writes them on bar napkins. He tells them with great skill. He remembers them even if he forgets almost everything else. ``I can't remember your name,'' he said recently with some embarrassment. ``But if you told me a story right now, I would remember the story.'' Welsch's stories, which deal with the humor and wisdom found in small-town America, are featured on ``Sunday Morning,'' the CBS program hosted by Charles Kuralt. His two-year contract was recently renewed and viewers are assured of at least eight of Welsch's ``Postcards from Nebraska'' each year. Before CBS, he taught folklore and literature; not your typical buttoned-down academician, he sported a long ponytail with a feather tied in it. Eventually, he left his tenured position at the University of Nebraska-Lincoln for life in this village of 380 people. That decision came slowly and with some fear, Welsch said. He'd worked for tenure all his life, he was married and had a daughter. But he had purchased 60 acres and he wanted his child, Antonia, to grow up in the country. He also needed the open spaces and quieter lifestyle. ``I loved the people and the river and the land,'' said Welsch, 53. ``It was time to move.'' Welsch moved to Dannebrog from Lincoln in 1987, when he took a leave of absence. He resigned his teaching position the next year. He hoped to earn a living speaking at banquets, writing for magazines and a weekly column for 13 Nebraska newspapers. But the ends weren't meeting. ``I told my wife (Linda) `I've got bad news and I've got worse news,''' Welsch recalled. ```The bad news is we're not making it. The worse news is I'm not going back.'' About two months later, fortune and Charles Kuralt stepped in. Welsch had done several pieces over the years for Kuralt's show. The avuncular newsman was sitting in the audience one night as Welsch spoke at a West Point Chamber of Commerce banquet. ``He came very quietly in the back of the room'' and asked if Welsch would like to join the show. The program gave Welsch the financial security he needed. It also made him a TV star and made this central Nebraska town on the edge of the semi-arid Sandhills famous around the country. Many in this town with one main street, one bar, a restaurant, a drive-in and two gas stations enjoy the new-found fame. Others don't. ``He's just a big blowhard,'' said Charles Fox, 75, whose wife, Lucile, runs an antique store in town. Fox said some people who travel to Dannebrog are disappointed there isn't more to see. Fox also said he was described in one of Welsch's articles as ``the surliest and cheapest guy in Howard County.'' Welsch, for the record, denies he had Fox in mind when he wrote the piece. Several in town said Welsch's penchant for overalls and folksy humor might make Dannebrog appear like a town of rubes. ```On Roger's program you guys look like hicks,'' Carol Schroeder's sister told her. ``Well _ we are,'' Ms. Schroeder said. ``It's made us able to laugh at ourselves,'' she said. Welsch said he feels nothing but respect for his neighbors. He plans to air small-town opinions on major political issues, such as protecting the American flag from desecration with a constitutional amendment. A friend, Eric, ``said that if you tried to burn a flag on the main street of Dannebrog the first thing they'd do is call the fire department. What they see is not the symbol _ they see a fire,'' Welsch said. Many in town are thankful for Welsch's influence. He helped the Dannebrog Area Booster Club make contacts that led to state financial aid as the town worked to establish itself as the ``Danish Capital of Nebraska,'' said Shirley Johnson, a member of the club. On a nationwide tour for his new book, ``It's Not The End Of The Earth But You Can See It From Here,'' Welsch talked about the town at every stop and passed out brochures, Mrs. Johnson said. ``The other day three ladies were traveling from Washington State to Washington, D.C., and they planned their trip by way of Dannebrog because they'd seen him on TV,'' said Mayor Gene Hartman, who runs the Dan Dee Drive-in and Restaurant. Hartman doesn't think Welsch's tales hurt Nebraska's image. ``If you take this as Roger has meant it to be, a fun thing, then it's a fun thing to do,'' Hartman said. __ Elsewhere in television... YOU BITE UP MY LIFE: At last, TV with bite _ but not until Sept. 24. That's when the syndicated ``Dracula: The Series'' will premiere in 115 cities. In addition to being the usual pain in the neck, this new Dracula is a European billionaire seeking global domination. His dark secret is discovered by two teen-aged American lads. Geordie Johnson plays Dracula. It is not known if he'll tell the boys, ``Drink your soup before it congeals.''

DOC.SECOND: BC-Crime and Outrage, 1st Ld-Writethru b0528, Adv 29,0953
DOC.NOTE: $Adv29
For Release Sunday, July 29, and Thereafter
DOC.HEAD: Rampant Crime and a Man Who Snapped
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 1 graf after 7th `He was' to include judge's ruling on Santos
DOC.TEXT: Crime has tripled, muggers walk free, anger grows in tandem with fear, and Horacio Santos, who chased down and killed two thieves because he couldn't take any more, has become the symbol of it all. The Santos case jarred many of the 10 million people in Buenos Aires, who felt safe in their city until the last few years. Historians, sociologists, judges, police, government officials, newspaper vendors and nearly everyone else express opinions about the case at cocktail parties, in letters to editors, on street corners and radio talk shows. One Saturday morning in June, Santos, a 42-year-old engineer, heard glass breaking outside and recognized the sound of his car alarm. He rushed to a window and saw two men, laughing, walk off to their own car with his tape deck. Santos' home had been burglarized twice and thieves had broken into his car 14 times. Overwhelmed by anger, he gave chase. When Santos caught up to the thieves on the road, he shot one in the head and the other in the throat. Two bullets, two men dead. He was arrested on homicide charges and confined in a hospital for psychiatric tests. His wife, Norma, said: ``I can't believe what happened. Horacio can't either. This is a nightmare.'' On Thursday, Judge Luis Cevasco ruled that Santos was ``non-indictable'' because he acted while in a state of emotional distress. The men Santos killed were not career criminals. One was a 31-year-old bus driver and the other, 29, worked in a butcher shop. Both had wives and children. As Argentina's economic recession has shrunk real wages and increased unemployment, more people have turned to crime. Did Horacio Santos do the right thing? ``I would have done the same, may God forgive me,'' said Bernardo Neustadt, Argentina's most popular news commentator. Mariano Grondona, host of the television program ``Key Hour,'' said: ``About 99 percent of the calls to my program were in favor of Santos' reaction.'' Jorge Luis Passero, chief of the federal police, said Santos ``can't be taken as an example'' for others because ``that would be going back to the law of the jungle.'' Robbery and assault have become commonplace in Buenos Aires. Crimes like rape and murder are relatively rare, but some highly publicized cases of violence make people feel vulnerable. On June 14, two days before the Santos shooting, a businessman who had identified a mugger in a police lineup was shot and killed after the alleged assailant was released. Two months ago, men brandishing a machine gun tried to force investment broker Esteban Reynal off the main highway north of the city as he drove to his weekend home. He accelerated and outran them. Earlier this year, a judge's home was bombed and gunmen shot up the car of another. The second magistrate, Luis Cevasco, blamed ``parapolice groups'' that were trying to influence cases. ``The worst thing is that it's not just criminals, but also the forces of security'' who commit crimes, said Reynal, who recognized one of his assailants in the police station where he reported the shooting. The provincial policeman was arrested. This month, three policemen who offered to free a jailed person in exchange for a computer were sentenced to jail. A judge has been accused of trying to extort $500,000 from a medical clinic in return for dropping charges the clinic claims he fabricated. Corruption is a serious problem among police officers, who are paid the equivalent of only $100 a month and usually have second jobs. According to official statistics, the number of crimes in Buenos Aires province was 122,000 last year, compared with 47,000 in 1985. Argentines are increasingly careful about what they wear, where they go and how they get there. Months ago, Santos and his neighbors organized teams to watch homes and cars. Private security guards patrol wealthy communities. Residents in the zone of weekend homes and country clubs along the River Plate are buying guard dogs, electric gates and handguns, and chipping in to provide the police with better cars and equipment. Buenos Aires province has announced plans to transfer more officers to street duty and hire 2,000 new ones. Police acknowledge crime is increasing, but claim it isn't out of control. Most of the offenses are muggings and thefts from cars and homes. Street gangs and drug peddling, like major violent crimes, are uncommon. Chief Passero said in an interview that the conviction rate is low because of reforms in the penal code made in 1984, when civilian democracy returned after nearly eight years of military dictatorship. Each 100 arrests result in only 2.6 convictions and half of those get off without jail terms, he said. Passero said police should be allowed to hold more suspects until trial and judges should give harsher sentences. The Santos case brought fears into the open like Bernard Goetz did in New York City in December 1984, when he shot four youths he thought were going to rob him on a subway train. The weekly news magazine Somos ran a cover story called ``The Santos Case: Fear and Rage.'' Gente published a photo of a Santos, bearded and smiling, over the words, ``Assassin or Vigilante?'' Noticias featured a bullet and the headline, ``Justice Under Fire.''
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Sunday, July 29

DOC.TEXT: OPEC oil ministers said they agreed to raise the cartel's ceiling price for crude oil, and OPEC President Sadek Boussena criticized members who drove down the price by exceeding production quotas. His comments Thursday were apparently directed in part at Kuwait and the United Arab Emirates, who are blamed for keeping oil prices low by cheating on their quotas. OPEC's decision to raise the ceiling price came after it received assurances that overproduction by Kuwait and the U.A.E. would end and that overall world production of oil would decrease.

Economic problems in Brazil and higher incentive costs pushed General Motors Corp.'s second-quarter profits down 40 percent and Ford Motor Co.'s earnings down 45 percent from last year's levels. GM, the nation's largest automaker, said Thursday that it earned $900 million, or $1.32 a share, in the second quarter, compared with $1.5 billion, or $2.23 a share, in the same period last year. Ford said it earned $771 million, or $1.67 a share, during the April-June period this year, compared with $1.4 billion, or $3 a share, last year.

A House committee voted to grant junk bond financier Michael Milken and convicted stock speculator Ivan Boesky immunity from additional prosecution in order to get them to testify before Congress. The decision Thursday by the full Energy and Commerce Committee virtually guarantees the two most famous figures in the Wall Street scandals of the 1980s that nothing they tell Congress could be used against them in court. No date was set for their appearance before the panel's investigations subcommittee, but the committee agreed to delay Milken's testimony until after he is sentenced for securities fraud, now scheduled for Oct. 1.

Allied Stores Corp. won federal bankruptcy court approval of a unique borrowing arrangement to help the Cincinnati-based retailer continue operations through its Chapter 11 reorganization. Lawyers for Allied said Thursday the arrangement could save Allied $10 million a year in interest. It allows the company to obtain loan funds by selling commercial paper on the market, incurring lower interest rates than by the conventional method of borrowing from banks at the heftier prime rate.

Donald Trump and his teetering real estate empire received another reprieve as banks prepared to extend an emergency bridge loan the was part of a package that saved the developer from bankruptcy. Sources close to the transaction said a $20 million, 30-day loan that was to expire Thursday was in the process of being extended by the banks involved, including Citibank, Chase Manhattan, Bankers Trust and Manufacturers Hanover, among others. The loan was approved to tide Trump over until details on a longer-term, $65 million rescue package could be finalized.

The Senate voted to keep the federal crop-insurance program going, even if an alternative source of money must be found to finance it. An amendment to the 1990 farm bill offered by Sen. Thomas Daschle, D-S.D., would pay for the program through the Commodity Credit Corp. if funds earmarked specifically for crop insurance are phased out as directed by a vote of the House. The Senate voted Thursday.

Northrop Corp. pressured the Navy and Air Force to change contract specifications in a way that seriously damaged a fraud investigation of the company, according to Justice Department testimony prepared for Congress. In testimony to be delivered Friday before a House subcommittee, the deputy assistant attorney general in charge of the criminal division detailed the department's inquiry of Northrop that led to the company's guilty plea in February to 34 fraud charges and agreement to pay $17 million in fines.

Reebok's board of directors let the air out of chairman Paul Fireman's huge pay package, cutting it by more than $11 million under a new five-year deal that begins Jan. 1. Fireman, a key to the company's growth into a footwear giant that sells ``The Pump'' athletic shoe for $170, would receive no more than $2 million in annual salary and bonuses under the new agreement, the company said Thursday.

President Mikhail S. Gorbachev said his country needs Western aid to rebuild its consumer industries in the next two critical years of reform. Gorbachev spoke to reporters Thursday following a meeting with Italian Premier Guilio Andreotti, who as president of the European Community for the last half of 1990 has been Europe's point man on the issue of providing assistance to the Soviet Union.

Persistent worries about corporate profits helped push stock prices lower Thursday as activity continued to slow from its recent active pace. The Dow Jones industrial average dropped 10.15 to 2,920.79. The dollar rose against the Japanese yen but finished mixed against most other major currencies. Bond prices were virtually unchanged. Soybean futures prices surged; grain futures ended mostly higher; gasoline futures rose sharply; copper extended recent gains; precious metals were mixed; and livestock and meat futures were mixed.

DOC.HEAD: Capital Gains and tdhe Elderly
Es: Also moved in advance.
DOC.TEXT: Opponents of a capital gains tax cut generally defend their position by contending that the biggest beneficiaries would be the well-to-do who can well afford to pay. While that might or might not be true _ statistical wizardry can be used to support or deny the contention _ it has been a rather safe and popular position to take. Most people do not think of themselves as well-off. Now, however, the debate could move into an area where sensitivities are much more alive. The elderly, says the National Center for Policy Analysis, are hit hardest by capital gains taxes. Suddenly, the number of direct participants in the debate has grown, to say nothing of the level of their feelings. Many people aspire to being well-off, but almost everyone on earth aspires to staying on it as long as possible. The longer your stay, the center points out, the longer any capital investment you might have, such as in stocks, will be diluted by inflation. Yes, the law treats inflationary gains as if they are real ones, taxable ones. It means that if, in your old age, you finally sell your stock investment, you'll be accorded no special treatment because value was lost to inflation. No, you will be taxed on that inflation! When you can least afford it! This is just one of the points made by the center, a Dallas-based research institute, which describes itself as non-profit and non-partisan, though some of its recent papers suggest that older folks are deserving of more respect. ``The tax code discriminates against the elderly,'' declares John Goodman, president. He says that tax reform, a la 1986, was great for most young people, but that ``it contained hidden surprises for the elderly.'' In that year, the tax on long-term capital gains was raised to the same level as that of ordinary income, thus eliminating what had been a capital gains tax advantage. Goodman points out that most income earned by the young is from wages and salaries. But much of the income earned by the elderly is from capital investments. It means, he says, that the elderly got a sudden tax increase. It couldn't have come at a more unfortunate time for them, he says. Often retired, they could not raise their incomes to offset the bigger tax load. Nor could they obtain cost-of-living increases, as did many working people. Some Social Security recipients, says Goodman, are taxed at an effective rate of 42 percent, compared with 28 percent for younger people. He arrives at that number in this manner: For every dollar of income earned beyond a certain point, many elderly lose 50 cents of every $1 of Social Security. It means taxpayers who receive an additional $1 of income may pay taxes not just on that $1 but on $1.50 instead. The center's paper states that one in three taxpayers over the age of 65 years has a capital gain each year, compared with only 9 percent of the younger taxpayers, so many Social Security recipients exceed the limitations. It isn't just the elderly who are being hurt, says Goodman. Much of the incentive to save among younger people is gone, he says. Who, he asks, wants to invest for years and years, only to have it taxed away when they are older and least able to afford it?

DOC.HEAD: Government Views Securities Markets as Key Hope for Ailing Economy
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: Almost two years after the government sharply reined in economic reforms to curb inflation, it again is touting the advantages of a capitalist mainstay _ shareholding. Recent reports indicate economic planners view stock ownership of companies as a way to relieve the growing government burden of keeping ailing state enterprises afloat. China's industrial companies will ``eventually shift toward the shareholding system in which the state will serve as the major shareholder,'' Zheng Hongqing, a top economist in the State Commission for Restructuring the Economy, told Wednesday's China Daily. Rather than meddling in management, the government should be made a shareholder in state industrial firms, Zheng told the official newspaper. Zheng's comments echoed those of several liberal economists who recently reappeared in the Chinese press after months of absence following a government crackdown on dissent last June. The crackdown also criticized market-oriented reforms of China's socialist economy. Following the suppression of pro-democracy protests, in which hundreds of civilians died, talk of establishing securities markets faded. An economic austerity program that was reinforced following the crackdown succeeded in reducing inflation to its lowest level in five years. But it also left many businesses short of cash and unable to buy raw materials _ forcing many into bankruptcy. The government has found itself in a double bind as it seeks to keep growing numbers of debt-ridden state enterprises afloat while relying on shrinking tax revenues. ``The central government's treasury has had a hard time to support an ever-expanding budget and help to keep some industrial firms from going bankrupt,'' the China Daily report said. A prominent liberal economist, Li Yining, said in a recent Economic Daily report that the only way for China to extract itself from its financial morass would be through establishing securities markets. ``Only through a securities market, where ailing enterprises are sold to successful ones, could enterprise groups be established in a real sense,'' said Li, a Beijing University professor. Li said stock markets could provide a ready source of investment funds through the sale of stocks and bonds, while absorbing and putting to productive use the growing reservoir of personal savings. In turn, securities markets would generate profits both to the state and other shareholders, he wrote in the Economic Daily. ``We believe that the development of securities markets is not only a financial remedy but also a way to stabilize the economy from a long-term viewpoint,'' Wang Poming, vice president of the Beijing-based Stock Exchange Executive Council, recently told the China Daily. The reports have energized China's fledgling stock markets, especially in Shanghai, where stock prices jumped 7 percent Tuesday and Wednesday as investors flooded the market. So far, there has been little specific mention of what sort of trading would be allowed under a widescale stock ownership system. China's financial markets now are highly restrictive _ speculative dealing is not allowed _ and limited mostly to state bonds used to raise money for the national budget. Few companies are allowed to issue shares except to employees. The largest bourse is in Shanghai, which had one of Asia's biggest stock markets before the 1949 Communist takeover. Official sources say 1.2 million residents have invested in stocks and bonds worth $530.78 million in its market, which mainly deals in government bonds. Total trade volume for all China's stock exchanges is expected to reach $1.48 billion this year, up from $488.32 million last year, according to official reports.

DOC.HEAD: Reebok Chairman Agrees to $11 Million Pay Cut
DOC.TEXT: The man who amassed great wealth by overseeing Reebok's rapid growth from a small shoe company into a trend-setting athletic apparel giant will take a pay cut of more than $11 million next year. But Paul Fireman still will be able to afford expensive footwear like Reebok's $170 sneaker, ``The Pump.'' His new deal with the company could pay him $2 million a year in salary and bonuses. The company announced Thursday that a new five-year deal would pay Fireman, its 46-year-old chairman and chief executive officer, $1 million a year in salary and the potential for another $1 million in annual bonuses based on the company's profits. His current agreement, which expires Dec. 31, brought Fireman an average of about $13.6 million annually for the past four years. More than 95 percent of that was in bonuses based on the company's pre-tax earnings, the rest in salary, said Ken Lightcap, Reebok's vice president for corporate communications. His reduced compensation ``is really not a surprise,'' said Heidi R. Steinberg, an analyst with Salomon Brothers. ``It was pretty well known that he would be taking this pay cut.'' Steinberg said Reebok's earnings growth was probably not foreseen when the original pay package was negotiated. Reebok's sales jumped from $300 million in 1985 to $1.822 billion last year, and its net income rose from $38.9 million to $174.9 million during the same period, Lightcap said. The new deal also gives Fireman the option of buying 2.5 million shares of Reebok common stock at an average price of about 18 percent above the current price. He can exercise the option for 10 years from the starting date of the agreement. Fireman attended Tuesday's board of directors meeting at which the new deal was approved but was on vacation Thursday and not available to comment, Lightcap said.

DOC.HEAD: GE Fined $10 Million; Employees Get Prison
A version also moving on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: General Electric Co. still faces a possible ban on defense contracts after paying $30 million in fines and civil settlements for overcharging the Army for a battlefield computer system and other claims. GE, the nation's second-largest defense contractor with $6 billion in government business, was fined $10 million on Monday in the case. U.S. District Judge Lowell Reed Jr. also sentenced two employees of a GE subsidiary to prison for their roles in the scheme. GE also announced it would pay $8.3 million to settle a civil suit stemming from the case, and another $11.7 million in unrelated civil charges involving defense contracts. The penalties may not be over, however, as the government mulls a ban on defense contracts. ``Before we can make that determination, we would have to review the sentencing, the settlement agreement, plus matters that General Electric would present for consideration,'' said Army spokesman Maj. Pete Keating. In a statement issued by GE, the company said it was pleased the government recognized the steps it had taken to thwart recurrence of fraud. ``It's time to close the book on this old case,'' the company said. Assistant U.S. Attorney Nicholas Harbist said GE had developed self-policing and disclosure safeguards to prevent similar fraud in the future and declared ``their decade of deceit as government contractors has ended.'' In 1985 the company pleaded guilty to illegally claiming cost overruns on Minuteman missiles and paid a $1.04 million fine. It was banned then for three three weeks overall, and six months at the division where the violations occurred. The $10 million fine was the second-largest criminal fine in a defense contracting case, the government said. Northrop Corp. agreed to pay a $17 million fine in February for falsifying records on parts for the Cruise missile and Harrier jet. ``This is a sad commentary on the corporate character of General Electric'' at the time of the fraud, 1982-84, said U.S. District Judge Lowell Reed Jr. The case arose from a $246 million contract with the GE subsidiary, Management & Technical Services Co., to make a computer system to monitor supplies in the field. The company was convicted of not telling the Defense Department when it found subcontractors who would make parts at significant savings. One employee, Gerald A. Leo, 52, of King of Prussia, was sentenced to 10 months in prison and fined $15,000. Leo, the former materials manager at the subsidiary, was convicted of four counts of mail fraud and one count of trying to deceive investigators. James Badolato, 43, of Springfield, was convicted of one count of obstructing justice and one count of trying to deceive investigators. He was sentenced to five months in prison and fined $10,000. ``This was not a one-shot deal,'' Harbist told the judge. ``This was a protracted and calculated effort to steal from the Department of Defense.'' He said the men were in a ``corporate cocoon,'' feeling ``insulated and not responsible.'' The judge said both men ``have not accepted responsibility'' for their actions. He said Badolato had a ``corporate mentality'' that he felt ``shields him somehow from responsiblity.'' ``They cannot make the claim that they are merely acting on behalf of the company,'' the judge said. Leo's wife, Mary, sobbed as her husband was sentenced, then called out, ``He never did anything!'' She left the courtroom at the judge's suggestion. Badolato was convicted of misleading investigators and submitting false documents in a cover-up. Estimates from both sides of how much money the government lost ranged from $2.5 million to $8 million. The government and GE submitted a joint memorandum to the judge recommending the $10 million fine. The judge said he ``independently concluded'' that a $10 million fine was ``adequate, fair, and in the best interest of the public.'' The $8.3 million civil settlement ``certainly repays the government for what was lost, plus the costs of the investigation,'' said First Assistant U.S. Attorney Michael J. Rotko. That settlement, plus the $11.7 to settle unrelated civil actions, was ``an important factor favoring the recommended sentence,'' the joint memo said. As part of the agreement, GE waived its right to appeal the conviction. The two men work at other GE divisions but have been barred from government contract work. Leo's attorney, Seymour Toll, called his client ``a decent respected man'' who saw his ``25-year career in government contracting work obliterated.'' He maintained Leo was not aware of requirements to tell the government when savings were made in subcontracting. Badolato's attorney, Gregory Miller, argued that his client ``did not participate in or further the scheme'' and altered documents ``out of loyalty.'' The judge told Badolato ``your conduct was important to the scheme to defraud.''

DOC.HEAD: Joint Venture Latest Change In Once Placid Industry
DOC.TEXT: After decades of business as usual, the joint venture between chemical giant DuPont and industry leader Merck is the latest shakeup in an industry undergoing rapid change worldwide. Drug companies largely sat out the merger-mad 1980's. The industry's first major deal was in 1988, between two small Danish firms, Novo and Norodisk. SmithKline-Beechman Corp. and Marion Merrell Dow Inc. merged a short time later. Acquisitions became popular of late also. A.H. Robins was acquired by American Home Products Corp., Hoffmann-La Roche acquired 60 percent of Genentech, and Sterling Drug Co. was bought by the film giant Eastman Kodak Co. ``There are other ways to work together without getting married,'' said Stuart Levine of Gruntal & Co., who pointed to co-promotion and co-development of products. That's how Merck and DuPont got acquainted in October, when Merck obtained the rights to share in the development of a drug to reduce high blood pressure that DuPont had originally patented. ``That got the working relationship going,'' said Fred Siemer, an analyst who follows DuPont for the Chemical Research Inc. The joint venture was planned with the long-term in mind, according to P. Roy Vagelos, chief executive officer of Merck. The new company's research and development efforts are not expected to produce significant commercial results until the late 1990's. Like the Merck-DuPont deal, many of the recent mergers and acquisitions in the drug business have been driven at least partly by a desire to keep down research and development costs while gaining access to more markets. Wall Street greeted the joint venture that was announced after the market closed Wednesday. DuPont stock closed Thursday at 40~, up 1{, and Merck closed at 89~, up ~. The DuPont Merck Pharmaceuticals Co. will have a research and development staff of 1,500, a sales staff of 600 and will spend $230 million on research and development in its first year of existence. DuPont chipped in its entire pharmaceutical division, while Merck provides its research and development expertise, marketing rights to several of its prescription medicines, and cash and development funds. Analysts point to skyrocketing research and development costs when explaining all the activity in a field that had seen slow corporate change in the previous 30 years. ``It takes a long time to invent your way into this business, and it's expensive,'' Siemer said. ``The average cost of development of a drug, from the time we set up a project to the time it comes out on the market, is $230 million,'' Vagelos said. And Levine pointed out that it once took from four to six years to develop a drug. ``You're now looking at 12 or more years before bringing a drug to market,'' he said. It was DuPont's brisk R&D performance that attracted Merck, after DuPont beat out Merck and other firms in developing a new drug for high blood pressure, company officials say. And after spending all that time and money, competition from generic drugs cut into sales once patents expire. While pending, patents provide a monopoly and a lock on profits. ``Generic competition comes on very rapidly'' once a patent expires, said Vagelos. Generics are often promoted by governments seeking to cut costs in health care programs. Medicare, for example, reimburses hospitals for the price of generic drugs, unless a brand name drug is specifically prescribed. ``After years of clinical studies and the FDA process, you might have only five years left on a 17-year patent,'' Levine said. Long approval periods also pushed American firms to think globally, since drugs are often approved overseas before they get approval in the United States, according to Jane Belcher of Duff & Phelps in Chicago. An international sales force becomes critical, which is why Delaware-based DuPont pointed to Merck's vast international sales staff as one reason for hooking up with its New Jersey neighbor. ``You need to need to introduce (the new drug) into all the major markets of the world simultaneously,'' Vagelos said. The time of exclusivity is limited by patent and competition.'' Analysts expect more competitors to become allies or partners in this highly fragmented field. No one player has more than 4 percent market share in this $100 billion industry. But a bullish Vagelos predicted that Merck will grasp a double-digit world market share by the decade's end.

DOC.HEAD: London Shares Lower at Midday
DOC.TEXT: Share prices were lower at midday Friday on the London Stock Exchange in light and featureless trading. At midday, the Financial Times-Stock Exchange 100-share index was down 4.3 points, or 0.2 percent, at 2,339.9, its session high. Volume came to 199.3 million shares at midday, compared with 290.1 million shares at the same time Thursday.

DOC.HEAD: Allied Gets Court Approval for Borrowing Facility
DOC.TEXT: Allied Stores Corp. has received federal bankruptcy court approval of a unique borrowing arrangement to help the retailer continue operations through its Chapter 11 reorganization. Lawyers for Allied said Thursday the arrangement is a first in Chapter 11 cases because it allows the company to obtain loan funds by selling short-term corporate bonds on the market, probably incurring lower interest rates than by borrowing from banks. Allied estimates the arrangement could save the company $10 million a year in interest, company lawyer David S. Kurtz told U.S. Bankruptcy Judge J. Vincent Aug Jr. The arrangement permits the company to borrow up to $630 million, which could be increased to $700 million if needed. It is backed by the value of merchandise Allied purchases with the borrowed funds and by a $105 million letter of credit from the French bank Societe Generale, Kurtz said. ``We view this transaction as a major step forward in the reorganization and as a major achievement,'' Kurtz said. Kurtz said the arrangement, also backed by Chemical Banking Corp., will last through May 1993 or _ if it occurs earlier _ the confirmation date of Allied's financial reorganization plan, which is yet to be filed. The borrowing would permit Allied to buy merchandise for its 126 stores in 17 states operated by its four merchandising divisions: The Bon Inc., Jordan Marsh Stores Corp., Stern's Inc. and Maas Inc. The borrowing line replaces a $700 million credit line Allied had obtained through Citibank, which was to expire July 31. Kurtz said arrangements for the new credit would be concluded at a closing today in New York. On Monday, Allied will draw $386 million from the new borrowing line to pay off Citibank, Kurtz said. No creditors objected to the arrangement. Aug also approved a request by Allied and its sister corporation, Federated Department Stores Inc., to allow Federated to continue providing credit collection and related services to Allied Stores Credit Corp., Allied's credit arm. Federated and Allied Stores Corp., both owned by Toronto's Campeau Corp., filed Chapter 11 reorganization petitions Jan. 15. They listed more than $7 billion in debt, much of it acquired in Campeau's leveraged deals to buy the two companies. Federated operates 129 stores in 19 states. Federated and Allied together have about 100,000 employees.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Sets March 5 Retrial Date For Futures Traders
DOC.TEXT: Three commodities traders facing charges of fraud and racketeering that left a jury deadlocked in the original trial will be retried March 5, a federal judge says. U.S. District Judge Ann C. Williams ordered the retrial on Thursday. Assistant U.S. Attorney Mark Pollack said the government would ``retool'' the indictments against floor broker Robert Mosky and independent traders Danny Scheck and David Zatz, all of whom traded Swiss franc futures on the floor of the Chicago Mercantile Exchange. Defense lawyers said they would seek to have the charges dismissed. Mosky and Scheck were convicted July 9 of relatively minor charges of trading violations in the first trial stemming from an unprecedented undercover FBI probe of corruption at the Merc and the Chicago Board of Trade, the world's two biggest futures exchanges. The jury acquitted Zatz on two fraud charges but was unable to reach verdicts on scores of other counts, including a racketeering conspiracy charge against Mosky. The outcome of the two-month trial was widely perceived as a victory for the defense. The government claims the three conspired to cheat customers while executing their orders in the Merc's Swiss franc futures trading pit. Williams said she would withhold sentencing of the three until after the retrial. Trials are scheduled in September for two other groups of commodities traders charged in connection with the same investigation.

DOC.HEAD: Microsoft To Invest Heavily, Add 2,400 Employees
DOC.TEXT: Microsoft Corp., riding a ``red hot'' hit with its Windows 3.0 software, plans to invest millions of dollars on new products and services and add more than 2,300 employees in the next year, its executives say. Corporate officials also told financial analysts gathered at Microsoft's headquarters Thursday that because of the spending, it would be difficult to maintain the hectic pace of sales growth the company has enjoyed. Microsoft founder and chairman Bill Gates said the new version of Windows ``is the center of the universe for us now.'' The program, which provides an easy-to-use framework for running spreadsheets, word processors and other programs, will be further improved this year and have more programs adapted to it, he said. Gates also said Microsoft was beginning a major move into office computer networks and hoped to capture a share of that market now dominated by Novell Inc. of Orem, Utah. Microsoft, the world's largest publisher of personal computer software, reported Wednesday its profits for the fiscal year ended June 30 grew 64 percent over the year before, while revenues rose 47 percent. ``We're extremely bullish on the markets we participate in from a long-term standpoint,'' said Microsoft president Mike Hallman, but added that projects would require ``some heavy investments this year.'' Asked whether Microsoft could sustain the 47 percent sales growth, senior vice president and chief financial officer Frank Gaudette replied, ``I think that would be on the very high end.'' Microsoft's stock, which closed up $2 at $71.50 a share Wednesday in over-the-counter trading, fell $2.75 a share to $68.75 Thursday. Neither Hallman nor Gates would say how much investment would be required. But Steve Ballmer, senior vice president for systems software, said his segment alone would spend $18 million and hire 500 more people to work on its new ``Network Specialist Program.'' Microsoft spent $180 million on research and development and $317 million on sales and marketing in fiscal 1990. Microsoft plans to grow from its present 5,635 employees to about 8,000 over the next year. Hallman said the new workers would include 750 in research and development and 1,250 in sales and marketing. Microsoft, founded by the multibillionaire Gates and prep school friend Paul Allen 15 years ago, had just 1,800 employees in 1987. It reported fiscal 1990 profits of $279.2 million or $2.34 a share on revenues of $1.18 billion, both records. Net earnings for fiscal 1989 were $170.5 million or $41.52 a share on revenues of $803.5 million. Sales and profits were boosted by Windows 3.0, a runaway success with 800,000 copies shipped since its introduction in late May, Ballmer said. The software replaces the technical word commands needed to manage programs and information in IBM personal computers with on-screen graphics. ``It is absolutely red hot,'' Ballmer said. Microsoft shipped just 200,000 copies of its advanced computer operating system OS-2 in all of fiscal 1990, Ballmer said. At one time, OS-2 was seen as the replacement for MS-DOS, Microsoft's operating system that is the industry standard for IBM-compatible computers. But with the huge success of Windows, Microsoft now sees itself as having a ``family'' of operating systems, with OS-2 an ``advanced form of Windows,'' Gates said. ``DOS is not likely to be replaced in the foreseeable future,'' Ballmer said. In the 1990s, Microsoft will evangelize for office and corporate networks linking large computers and desktop computer users to permit instant access to vast amounts of information, Ballmer said. To do that, Microsoft will introduce a new version of its Local Area Network Manager software in August, is setting up a specially trained group of resellers, and is boosting its sales and support force, he said. It plans a major ad campaign and a series of seminars this fall and winter to launch the Network Specialist Program, he added. The target is Novell, which has 65 percent or better of the existing office network market. Novell, founded in 1983 and the maker of the NetWare operating system, had sales of $225.9 million in the six months ended April 28. Capturing market share from Novell won't happen soon, Ballmer said. ``We cannot overwhelm them. We have to show cleverness,'' he said. Gates said he didn't see the move as dramatic or dangerous, but necessary, since he believes networks will eventually dominate office computing. A Novell official, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said the move by Microsoft had been expected for some time. By educating more potential customers, Microsoft's heavy promotion of office networks should benefit the industry as a whole, Novell included, the official said.

DOC.HEAD: Revised Figures Released in Amoco Judgment
DOC.TEXT: Attorneys in the Amoco Cadiz oil spill damages case have released revised estimates of the judgment approved by U.S. District Court Judge Charles Norgle. Amoco on Tuesday was ordered to pay more than $166 million to parties affected by the 1978 spill. Amoco plans to appeal the order. If it stands, the oil company would pay the French national government, local governments and businesses more than 694.53 million francs, according to figures released by the office of Frank Cicero Jr., an attorney representing Amoco. That judgment is roughly equal to $127.77 million, based on the exchange rate late Thursday in New York. Amoco also has been ordered to pay 21.22 million pounds to Shell Oil Co., owner of the spilled oil. That amount would be roughly equal to $38.49 million at Thursday's exchange rate. The Amoco Cadiz ran aground March 16, 1978, two miles off the Brittany coast. It spilled 68 million gallons of light fuel oil, leaving an oil slick 18 miles wide and 80 miles long and polluting 100 miles of the coast.

The stock market headed lower today, confronted with new evidence of sluggish business conditions. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials dropped 14.36 to 2,906.43 in the first half hour of trading. Losers held a slight edge on gainers in the early tally of New York Stock Exchange-listed issues, with 411 up, 471 down and 504 unchanged. Volume on the Big Board came to 22.40 million shares as of 10 a.m. on Wall Street. The figure came in below most advance estimates. In addition, analysts noted that a significant amount of the increase stemmed from inventory expansion, a negative portent for production. Open-market interest rates declined in response to the news. For stock traders, however, the data seemed primarily to emphasize recent worries about the outlook for corporate profits.
