DOC.HEAD: Hong Kong Businessman Buying Stake in U.S. Junk Bond Portfolio
DOC.TEXT: Hong Kong businessman Li Ka-shing plans to spend $150 million for a half-interest in an investment group that has agreed to buy $3 billion in junk bonds from the troubled California thrift, Columbia Savings & Loan, it was announced Friday. Cheung Kong Ltd. and Hutchison Whampoa Ltd., two leading Hong Kong companies controlled by Li, along with a third company he controls privately, said they will buy half of a partnership assembled by Gordon Investment Corp., a merchant bank based in New York and Toronto. Gordon America L.P. said earlier this week it agreed to pay $300 million down for the portfolio of Columbia junk bonds and preferred stock along with a note for the remaining $2.7 billion at a 10.5 percent interest rate. Columbia, based in Beverly Hills, Calif., was forced as part of last year's thrift bailout legislation to write down the value of its junk bonds by $1 billion. It was $215 million in the red as of March 31, and needs hundreds of millions of dollars beyond that to avoid being seized by regulators. Richard Li, managing director of Hutchison's corporate fund management committee and son of the tycoon, said the purchase is part of the group's efforts to diversify its investments beyond Hong Kong's shores. ``We look at this investment as a window into corporate America and into further investment opportunities,'' he said. Local securities analysts expressed surprise at the investment. Li Ka-shing's extraordinarily successful investment career has been built largely on real estate, not stocks and bonds. But the move fits with a strategy he disclosed in a newspaper interview last November in which he expressed his desire to reduce his exposure in the colony, where 90 percent of his assets were parked. Many in Hong Kong are increasingly afraid that Communist China will break its promise to maintain Hong Kong's freewheeling economic and political system for 50 years after it takes control in 1997. ``This really comes as a surprise,'' said Peter Lui, an analyst at County NatWest Securities Asia Ltd. ``But if you believe U.S. interest rates will fall, it's probably a very good investment.'' Numerous Hong Kong-based companies are moving assets abroad in an attempt to reduce their risk in the colony. The huge trading house, Jardine Matheson, has moved its base to Bermuda, while other firms have purchased property in the United States, Canada and Australia. In 1987, Li's business empire purchased a 43 percent stake in Husky Oil Ltd., Canada's largest oil and gas company. In the current deal, Cheung Kong, a real-estate giant, and Hutchison, one of the colony's major trading houses, will each own 20 percent of Gordon America L.P. A company owned by Li's family will hold 10 percent, with the remainder held by Gordon Investment. Under the terms of the Gordon Investment transaction, Gordon America agreed to pay $3 billion for the junk bonds, but with 90 percent financing on a non-recourse basis. That means the partnership can drop the portfolio if its losses exceed 10 percent and the savings and loan would have to accept it back. U.S. regulators and legislators could possibly oppose the sale of the bonds to Gordon, however, because the government could wind up holding Columbia's bonds if the market deteriorates again.

For release Monday July 30
DOC.HEAD: Make Way For The New Raider: Bondmailers
DOC.TEXT: The slump in junk bond prices may have signaled an end to the corporate raiding of the 1980s, but has given birth to a new breed of raider for the 1990s: the bondmailer. These investors seek out companies that have trouble making junk-bond payments, which depresses the value of the bonds. The investors buy up a large chunk of the company's debt, usually at a steep discount from face value. Then they offer management a choice: Either buy back the securities or face an involuntary bankruptcy petition. A successful bondmailer chooses companies with bonds so undervalued in the market they'll return a profit even in a Chapter 11 bankruptcy reorganization. Once in bankruptcy court, the bondmailer's securities can bring cash or, more likely, equity in the company. ``We'll see more and more of this in the `90s,'' said C. Richard Lehmann, president of Bond Investors Association Inc., a non-profit Miami-based firm that tracks bond defaults. ``Many companies will change hands through bond defaults and the substitution of credit instruments with stock.'' The collapse of the junk bond market has left many companies struggling to make interest payments. Many of these high-risk securities feature what's known as a reset, to make bondholders feel safer about their investment. Under a reset clause, the bond issuer promises to raise the interest rate on the bond to increase its market value to par, or face value. With bond prices so depressed, heavily indebted companies are faced with placing huge, sometimes debilitating, interest rates on their bonds. Some have to default on the issues. In the first six months of the year, the Bond Investors Association recorded 40 bond defaults worth more than $11 billion. That makes good hunting for a bondmailer. Earlier this year, SCI Television Inc. avoided an involuntary bankruptcy petition filed by bond investor S.N. Phelps & Co. of Greenwich, Conn. The agreement gave 39 percent of the company to Phelps and the other bondholders. Bank lenders got a 5 percent stake. George Gillett, who had been controlling investor, saw his stake drop from 55 percent to 41 percent. Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Co., which created SCI through a debt-financed takeover of Storer Communications in 1985, saw its interest drop from 45 percent to 15 percent. With the likelihood that bondholders will see their securities turn into stock through negotiations with management, Lehmann said Chapter 11 filings could set off bidding wars. The strategy is in some ways analogous to the greenmailers of the 1980s who bought large stakes of a company's stock then made nuisances of themselves by forcing restructurings or theatening takeovers until management gave them a profit for their stock. Not surprisingly, the bondmailer label for the new form of raider is appearing to stick. Some have suggested the term ``vulture capitalist.'' Despite their pejorative nicknames these investors aren't so bad in Lehmann's eyes. ``The trend we're seeing is companies are squeezing bondholders by buying back bonds at a discount,'' he said. ``This keeps them honest.'' Besides, even if a company capitulates to a bondmailer's demands for a hefty profit on the debt, the company is still retiring the bonds usually well below par. By forcing a retirement of debt at a better price for bondholders, the bondmailers are ``pre-empting what management itself should be doing,'' Lehmann said. Stanford Phelps, owner of Phelps & Co. has won widespread recognition in the popular press as a bondmailer by virtue of the current cover story in Forbes magazine. Others, however are hard at work also. New York-based Japonica Partners, for example, is pressuring Pittsbugh-based appliance maker Allegheny International. If bond defaults and an undervalued junk bond market continue, expect to see more of the bondmailers in the coming years.

DOC.HEAD: Siemens Signs Pact with Robotron Unit
DOC.TEXT: Siemens AG said Friday it has signed an agreement with East Germany's Computer Elektronik Dresden GmbH for the development and production of computer hardware. CED is a unit of the East German electronics group VEB Kombinat Robotron Elektronik of Dresden. Siemens, a West German electrical and electronics concern, said the production of Siemens computers in the Dresden plant will begin on Oct. 1. The Dresden factory will produce personal and larger computers mainly destined for markets in East Germany, the Soviet Union and other East European countries. Siemens, which plans to invest more than 1 billion marks or $600 million in East Germany in the next two to three years, is currently planning more than 30 projects and joint ventures there.

The stock market gave ground today, confronted with new evidence of sluggish business conditions. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials dropped 9.16 to 2,911.63 by 11 a.m. on Wall Street. Losers outnumbered gainers by about 3 to 2 in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed issues, with 450 up, 713 down and 547 unchanged. The Commerce Department reported that the gross national product grew at a 1.2 percent annual rate, after adjustment for inflation, in the second quarter of the year. The figure came in below most advance estimates. In addition, analysts noted that a significant amount of the increase stemmed from inventory expansion, a negative portent for production. Open-market interest rates declined in response to the news. For stock traders, however, the data seemed primarily to emphasize recent worries about the outlook for corporate profits. Many big-name stocks have run into selling of late on earnings reports that didn't live up to expectations. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index was down .66 at 355.67. Volume on the Big Board came to 47.37 million shares at midmorning.

DOC.HEAD: EC, Japan, Canada, Australia, USA To Discuss Agriculture Trade Next Week
DOC.TEXT: Senior agriculture officials from the European Community, Japan, Canada, Australia and the United States meet next week to discuss disputes over agriculture that are hampering international talks to liberalize world trade, the EC Commission said Friday. But EC sources stressed the meeting in Dublin was not designed to end a deadlock in the global trade talks over government assistance to producers and exporters of farm goods. ``This cannot substitute'' for the talks within the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, said one official. ``The meeting is an occasion for certain major (GATT) players to exchange views. That is extremely useful.'' The three-day meeting, which starts Monday, has been called by EC Agriculture Commissioner Ray MacSharry. ``Our agenda will deal with agricultural policies, international agricultural trade, rural development and Eastern Europe,'' he said in a statement here. In addition to MacSharry, others expected at the meeting are U.S. Agriculture Secretary Clayton Yeutter, Japanese Agriculture Minister Tomio Yamamoto, Australian Agriculture Minister John Kerins and Canadian Agriculture Minister Donald Mazankowski. Through THE GATT, 105 nations are negotiating for more liberalized global trade. The talks began in 1986 and are to end in December although it remains questionable if an overall accord can be reached by then. The key disputes in the talks that cover 15 areas of trade touch notably on agriculture. The United States and others want the EC to end its system of export credits and slash direct subsidies for farmers. On Thursday, GATT Director-General Arthur Dunkel expressed his concern that the global trade talks are not progressing rapidly enough.

DOC.HEAD: Soybean Futures Slip On Profit-Taking; Grains Up Slightly
DOC.TEXT: Soybean futures prices fell slightly in early trading today on the Chicago Board of Trade as traders took profits after a strong rally in the previous session. Grain futures were mostly higher. Soybeans surged as much as 12{ cents a bushel Thursday on speculation the Soviet Union is resolving its credit problems and will soon be in the market for soybean meal. Analysts said the rally left the market vulnerable to profit-taking and chart-inspired selling. Beneficial showers overnight in Iowa also prompted selling of soybean futures this morning but strong cash markets limited the decline and provided support for the corn and wheat markets. In early trading, wheat futures were \ cent to 1 cent higher with September at $3.02} a bushel; corn was \ cent to 1{ cents higher with September at $2.63{ a bushel; oats were \ cent to 1{ cents higher with September at $1.34{ a bushel; soybeans were \ cent to 1{ cents lower with August at $5.92\ a bushel. Livestock and meat futures were mixed in early trading on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange. DOC.HEAD: Second Quarter GNP Up Only 1.2 Percent
With PM-GNP Revisions, PM-Yearly GNP
DOC.NOTE: EDs: SUBS 15th graf pvs, bgng, The revision... to CORRECT recession year to 1982 sted of 1985. Also moving on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: The U.S. economy, continuing to skirt along the edges of a recession, posted weak growth at an annual rate of just 1.2 percent from April through June, the government reported today. The Commerce Department said that the gross national product, the country's total output of goods and services, was propped up entirely in the second quarter by a big buildup in business inventories. Other major components of the economy, from consumer spending to business investment and housing construction, suffered declines during the quarter. The 1.2 percent GNP increase in the second quarter followed a revised 1.7 percent increase in the first quarter and a barely discernible 0.3 percent advance in the October-December period last year. This string of weak quarterly growth rates is raising concerns over whether the current economic expansion, which has lasted a peacetime record of almost eight years, is in danger of toppling into a recession. Today's report offered little comfort on that score, given the fact that the only strength came in the restocking of store shelves and backlots. In the face offalling consumer demand, those higher inventories could force production cutbacks and job layoffs in the second half of the year, one of the classic ways a recession begins. In one encouraging sign, inflation slowed markedly in the second quarter, with a GNP price measure dropping to an annual rate of increase of 3.9 percent, down from a 6.6 percent rate in the first three months of the year. One-half of the improvement came from a slowing in food prices. The Bush administration is counting on the Federal Reserve to come to the economy's rescue by switching its attention from fighting inflation to worrying more about keeping the recovery alive by lowering interest rates. Commenting on today's report, Commerce Undersecretary Michael Darby said that the significant easing of inflationary pressures ``bodes well for continued economic expansion.'' He said the administration was still looking for a significant upturn in activity in the second half of the year, led by a rebound in growt in both export sales and business investment. However, private economists were far less optimistic about the future, contending that they saw little evidence of strength anywhere in the economy. ``What the GNP is telling us is that we have an economy that has run out of steam,'' said Robert Dederick, chief economist of the Northern Trust Co. in Chicago. ``There is no dynanism left in the expansion. The consumer is tired, business is tired and government spending is being reduced as well.' In addition to reporting on weak economic growth in the just completed second quarter, the government sharply revised down its estimates of past growth. It reduced the growth estimate for every quarter in 1989 and trimmed growth for the entire year to an annual rate of 2.5 percent, down from an earlier forecast of 3 percent. The revision meant that the U.S. economy in 1989 grew at its slowest pace since an actual decline of 2.5 percent in the recession year of 1982. The government blamed the big downward revisions on mistakes that overestimated wages and salaries in 1989 by $57.9 billion. Faced with the weaker growth in downward revisions in past growth estimates, the Bush administration was forced to lower its own economic projections for this year and dramatically boost its estimate of the federal budget deficit for 1991. The need to trim the deficit to $64 billion from a projected $169 billion was a major factor forcing President Bush's recent reversal on tax increases. The administration is now projecting the economy will grow at an annual rate of 2 percent this year, but to meet even this lowered expectation will require growth in the second half to average 2.9 percent, a pace far higher than most private economists believe is possible. ``This is not a lively economy. This is a very dull, slow-growing economy,'' said Allen Sinai, chief economist of the Boston Co. Sinai is forecasting that growth in the second half of the year could dip to as low as 0.5 percent to 1 percent, a sluggish pace that would increase the chances that some unexpected event could tip the country into its first recession since 1981-82. For the second quarter, there were few signs of strength. The total GNP, after adjusting for inflation, was growing at an annual rate of $4.16 trillion, a gain of $12.6 billion over the first quarter. More than accounting for that increase was a $35.5 billion rise in business inventories. Almost half of that gain came from a rise in auto inventories as auto manufacturers boosted production in anticipation of a possible strike this fall. With auto sales still sluggish and overall consumer spending actually dropping, economists are concerned that the big buildup in inventories in the second quarter will serve as a drag on growth in coming months, forcing production cutbacks. Consumer spending, which accounts for two-thirds of overall economic activity, actually fell by 0.3 percent in the second quarter while business investment declined 6.1 percent. Housing construction, which has been hurt by rising mortgage rates, dropped by 13.5 percent. Even merchandise trade, which had been the one bright light of the economy, turned negative in the second quarter, as exports of goods and services fell by 3.7 percent while imports continued climbing by 3.2 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Newspaper Loss Reported at $35 Million a Year
DOC.NOTE: EDs: Recasts attribution more directly to Pak interview. Also moving on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: The Washington Times has been losing $35 million a year and the deficit is being covered by the Unification Church and its subsidiaries, according to an interview with a church leader published today. The Washington Post quoted Bo Hi Pak, a deputy to the church's founder, the Rev. Sun Myung Moon, from an interview in Seoul, South Korea. Pak said the church and its subsidiaries are ``very glad to subsidize'' the Times because it contributes to world peace. The newspaper will not be sold or closed, he said. The Post said Pak estimated total losses at $250 million since the newspaper started publishing eight years ago. The Times and the Post are the only two daily newspapers in Washington. The Times, which publishes Monday through Friday, reported circulation of 106,852 in September. The Post, which publishes seven days a week, reported Monday through Saturday circulation of 731,407 and Sunday circulation of 1,126,123. Arnaud de Borchgrave, editor-in-chief of the Times, said the newspaper is not subsidized directly by the Unification Church. ``We are subsidized by various businesses run by members of the church,'' de Borchgrave said. ``I run a secular newspaper. It has no connection with the church. We have never received an editorial instruction from the church or from Dr. Pak since I took over in March 1985.'' Pak is president of the parent company of the newspaper. In the interview, Pak said the church hopes to expand its video operations into a nationwide cable system, and to establish businesses in China and the Soviet Union. Businesses operated by church members include a machine tool company in Germany, a fishing fleet in Alaska, a computer lab in Japan, a video production company near Washington and a controlling interest in a nationwide cable channel. Pak told the Post that church headquarters in Seoul receives revenue of $100 million a year in business profits and church dues from members. He did not provide a breakdown.

DOC.HEAD: Passengers, Agents: Travel Brisk Despite Indictments
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs 12th graf, `There is ...' with 4 grafs to UPDATE with full-page ads in today's papers, quotes from Shugrue. Picks up 13th graf pvs: `Most agents. ... Also moving on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: Bargain hunters are filling Eastern Airlines' cheap seats despite the carrier's indictment on charges of falsifying maintenance records, passengers and ticket-sellers say. ``I just checked for the least expensive flights, and this happened to be one of them,'' said Ana Carter of Atlanta, who hadn't heard the news before boarding the plane Thursday. ``Maybe that's why.'' The Miami-based airline and nine of its high-level managers face a 60-count indictment _ unprecedented in the airline industry _ for allegedly failing to do required maintenance and falsifying records to indicate the work was done. The indictment, unsealed Wednesday, followed a 10-month investigation and covers the period from July 1985 through October 1989. Neglected were such critical items as radar, landing gear, automatic pilot instruments and fuel systems, said Andrew J. Maloney, a U.S. attorney in New York, where the indictment was returned. He said none of the alleged violations caused accidents or injuries. ``I read it in the paper this morning, after I had boarded the plane,'' said longtime Eastern passenger Charlene Ellis of Suitland, Md. ``It made me slightly uncomfortable,'' but she said she would continue to fly Eastern. ``People still like Eastern because of the cheap fares,'' said Drew Ray, manager of the vacation department at Englewood Travel, Englewood, N.J. ``Most of them don't even pay attention to that (news like the indictment) anyway,'' said Marsha Nabors, of Advance Travel in the Atlanta suburb of Lilburn. ``As long as they can get these cheap fares with no penalties, they'll ride.'' But not everybody seemed to feel that way. ``I can promise you this _ until the problem is fixed I will make no more reservations on Eastern Airlines,'' Patricia Middleton of Washington said after arriving in Miami. Eastern insists there's nothing to worry about. ``There is no carrier out there who has received nearly the scrutiny we have in the past couple of years,'' said spokeswoman Karen Ceremsak in Miami. ``That's why a passenger can feel reasonably comfortable about flying with us. There's been no stone left unturned.'' She said Eastern took out full-page advertisements in several major papers today to reassure customers. The ad _ which ran in The Washington Post, The Wall Street Journal and USA Today, among other papers _ said: ``Today about 60,000 people will fly Eastern. They have a right to know they are flying a safe airline.'' Signed by Eastern bankruptcy trustee Martin R. Shugrue Jr., the ad says: ``Two years ago, some Eastern employees in New York falsified maintenance records to reflect work that had not been done. ... Today if Eastern weren't meeting the highest government standards of safety we would not be flying.'' Most agents said they had noticed no change in demand for Eastern seats. ``Not one soul has said they won't fly Eastern,'' said Gerard Gonzalez, owner of Let's Go Travel Inc. in New York. ``Seats are so scarce, the cheap seats to Florida, that they'll take anything,'' said Mark Kazlauskas of Travel Network in Brooklyn. ``We do have one or two people say they won't fly Eastern, but that's because they're union workers, and they won't fly it.'' Eastern is struggling with a 16-month-old strike by its Machinists union that helped push the carrier into bankruptcy reorganization proceedings. It is attempting to regain the full-fare business customers that airlines depend on.

DOC.HEAD: Philip Morris Rules Out Changes in Suchard Tender Offer
DOC.TEXT: Philip Morris Cos. on Friday ruled out any changes of its $3.8 billion tender offer for the parent company of Jacobs Suchard AG, the huge chocolate and coffee group. In a brief statement, the New York-based tobacco, food and brewing company responded to an analysis by a Swiss bank, Bank Vontobel of Zurich, which suggested that public shareholders should refuse the offer as being too low. Under a June agreement with Suchard Chief Executive Klaus J. Jacobs, Philip Morris obtained control of Jacobs's private company, Colima Holding AG, which held 62 percent of the voting rights, but only 28 percent of the capital, of Suchard. To enable Philip Morris to acquire full ownership of the Swiss company, other shareholders have until Sept. 3 to accept the tender offer. The offer is 8,500 Swiss francs, or $6.071, for each bearer share, 1,660 francs, or $1,185, for each registered share and 758 francs, or $541, per participation certificate. Philip Morris said Bank Vontobel's analysis was inaccurate and misleading and that it ``has no plans to alter either the price or the timing or any other elements of its tender offer for shares of Jacobs Suchard.''. ``Particularly misleading in the Bank Vontobel research report is the implication that Philip Morris might increase the tender price in order to obtain possible U.S. tax benefits,'' it added. The bank had suggested that Philip Morris could lose large U.S. tax benefits if it did not acquire 80 percent of Suchard's capital. Philip Morris responded that ``regardless of any possible U.S. tax benefits, and whether or not it obtains 80 percent of the Jacobs Suchard shares, Philip Morris has no intention of making any changes in the terms and conditions of the tender offer.''

DOC.HEAD: Teamsters Union Gets Contract Vote Extension
DOC.TEXT: The Teamsters union and United Parcel Services of America Inc. have agreed to extend until Aug. 10 a deadline for voting on a new contract, delaying the threat of a nationwide strike. The union initially told the company it would strike if a new three-year contract wasn't approved by next Tuesday, when the old pact expires, UPS spokesman Ken Sternad said Thursday. But he said the union needed more time to get all its members to vote on the proposal. The new deadline for ratifying a contract was set at Aug. 10. UPS has about 150,000 part-time and full-time employees who are Teamsters members. The company employs 230,000 workers and is the world's largest package delivery service. It made 2.8 billion deliveries last year and had $12.4 billion in revenue. The union told UPS it had problems getting ballots to many of its members and needed extra time to get them back, Sternad said. The company said its contract proposal calls for higher wages, improved benefits and better working conditions. The proposed contract would raise wages for the average UPS full-time driver to $18 an hour within two years, Sternad said. UPS drivers now make an average of $16.10 per hour. Part-time workers, mostly package handlers and truck loaders, currently start at $8 or $9 an hour. Under the proposed contract, their wages would increase $1.50 an hour, Sternad said. Company contributions for health benefits and employees' pensions, currently at $8,300 a year for full-time workers, would increase to $10,500 by the end of the three years, he said. For part-time workers, the rate would increase by $1.05 an hour. The proposal also offers a one-time bonus of $1,000 to full-timers and $500 to part-timers, to be paid within the first month after ratification, he said. The company has agreed to make the contract retroactive to Aug. 1 if it is ratified, Sternad said.

DOC.HEAD: OPEC Ministers Agree to Raise Target Price, Limit Production
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 11 grafs to UPDATE with accord signed, ADDS effect on North Sea Brent. Pickup 11th pvs, `Kuwait and... Also moving on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: OPEC oil ministers agreed today to raise the cartel's prices and restrain production in hope of forcing up crude prices by several dollars in the next few months. All 13 ministers of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries signed the accord raising the target price to $21 a barrel from $18. Because of an oil glut, the actual price recently has been about $16.25 per barrel. The agreement set a new production ceiling of 22.5 million barrels a day, a bit above the current cap but lower than the cartel's actual output. To reach the new target price, OPEC will have to rein in production by about 700,000 barrels a day. Word of the agreement sent oil prices higher in international trading. In London, North Sea Brent, a widely used benchmark, jumped 39 cents from Thursday to $19.65 a barrel for September delivery. The September contract for West Texas Intermediate, the benchmark grade of U.S. crude, rose 9 cents to $20.39 per 42-gallon barrel. Iranian Oil Minister Gholam Reza Aqazadeh said the agreement would be valid through the end of the year. Asked whether he was confident the output levels would be adhered to, he said: ``At this time I am sure 100 percent.'' The announcement capped the regular mid-year OPEC meeting, which began Thursday and was overshadowed by a bitter dispute involving OPEC members Iraq, Kuwait and the United Arab Emirates. Iraq blamed the other two countries for a drop in oil prices, saying they had exceeded their output quotas. Kuwait and the U.A.E. deny the claims. Iraqi President Saddam Hussein threatened last week to use military force against cheaters, and diplomats reported an Iraqi military buildup at the Kuwait border. In reaching agreement, the ministers persuaded Iraqi minister Issam Abdul Raheem al-Chalabi to back off his demand for a $25 a barrel target price. Others said $25 was too high. The previous target price of $18 had been in effect since December 1986. The production limit was about 22.09 million barrels a day, based on individual quotas set for each member nation. Kuwait and the U.A.E. have been accused often of exceeding their output quotas, and Saddam claims his cash-hungry nation has lost $14 billion in oil revenue because of the resulting slide in prices. Aqazadeh said the new agreement was reached at the highest levels of the OPEC governments, so he was confident the output levels it would be strictly followed. ``The minimum reference price is $21, and the ceiling is 22.491,'' he said. Aqazadeh said ministers also agreed that in future they will increase their production ceiling and target price in tandem, rather than keeping the price constant while varying quotas as they have for more than three years. Crude prices _ and gasoline prices at the pump _ would not automatically climb just because OPEC notched up its benchmark. But if the cartel reined in production, crude prices could rise. Each dollar increase per barrel raises gasoline prices at the pump by about 5 cents a gallon. Energy experts said consumers will also probably see a jump in prices of gasoline and heating oil, but they said it was not likely to occur right away. ``We have a crude oil surplus currently of 50 million barrels (in the United States) ... and it's going to take at least a year to work off that excess,'' said Brian Tagler, an energy broker with Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc. The average price of a basket of crudes monitored by OPEC surged to $20.46 a barrel in early January but skidded to $13.64 last month. It rebounded to $16.25 last week. An output cap of 22.5 million barrels a day would be 400,000 barrels more than the current ceiling. But it would be under the cartel's actual production estimated at 23 million barrels or more a day. Under the plan, the U.A.E.'s quota will rise from 1.1 million barrels a day to 1.5 million. It now is producing about 2 million barrels a day, analysts say. The arrangement also would require Kuwait to trim output by several hundred thousand barrels a day to bring it down to its quota of 1.5 million barrels. Other members' quotas would remain the same.OPEC nations are Algeria, Ecuador, Gabon, Indonesia, Iran, Iraq, Kuwait, Libya, Nigeria, Qatar, Saudi Arabia, the U.A.E. and Venezuela. The agreement does not end the dispute between Iraq and Kuwait. Iraq claims Kuwait stole oil from a field that includes land both sides claim, and it wants compensation. Representatives from the nations are to hold direct talks this weekend in an effort to resolve the dispute. The talks are to be in Saudi Arabia this weekend. In a rare show of solidarity with Iraq, Iran today echoed the Iraqi attack on states violating OPEC quotas. Iranian President Hashemi Rafsanjani did not mention names. He said his country's cooperation with its war foe, Iraq, had helped lift the price of oil.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Administration Would Boost Beer, Wine Taxes
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Subs graf 13: The administration, to show $10,000 cap would apply to any filing status. Also moving on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: House Majority Leader Richard Gephardt declined today to criticize a Bush administration budget proposal that includes higher taxes on wine and beer and a limit on federal deductions for state and local taxes. ``I prefer not to comment on these proposals,'' said Gephardt, D-Mo., emerging from the latest budget meeting between President Bush and congressional leaders. ``Everything's on the table.'' The administration has not formally presented its proposal at the 11-week-old budget talks, saying it wants to exchange plans simultaneously with Democrats. But details of the package have begun to emerge. The administration proposal would raise the 16-cent tax on six-packs of beer to 81 cents and the 3-cent levy on the standard 750 milliliter bottle of wine to 76 cents, a GOP bargainer said. The proposal would limit wealthy Americans' ability to take deductions on their federal income tax returns for the state and local income taxes they pay, and would cut Medicare and other programs, GOP bargainers say. Overall, it would save about $54 billion next year, split evenly between new taxes and program trims, said one negotiator. Gephardt said he didn't know if Democrats will piece together a proposal of their own before Congress' summer recess, which begins as early as next Friday. But with protests already emerging about elements of the administration proposal, Gephardt declined to attack the plan. ``I expect that whatever we come out with, we'll hear from a lot of our citizens who'll say, `I wish you hadn't done that,''' Gephardt told reporters. An increase in the federal beer and wine tax would be the first since 1951. Democrats have all but concluded that the two sides will be unable to forge a budget compromise for fiscal 1991 until after Congress' month-long summer recess, which starts in early August. Democrats have yet to piece together their own deficit-reduction proposal for fiscal 1991, which begins Oct. 1. ``What's taken this thing so long is the fact that there is no apparent crisis out there to drive the administration, to drive Congress to move more rapidly,'' said No. 3 House Democrat William Gray, D-Pa. The administration package would set a $10,000 limit on the amount of state and local income taxes that a couple or individual may deduct when calculating their federal income tax. The restriction would raise between $1.9 billion and $3 billion for the government next year. Sen. Bob Packwood, a GOP budget negotiator from Oregon, said 97.4 percent of the people affected by the proposed ceiling earn more than $100,000 annually, and 86 percent of them make more than $200,000. ``If that isn't a tax on the wealthy, I don't know what is,'' Packwood told reporters. But Iowa Gov. Terry Branstad, a Republican and chairman of the National Governors' Association, said, ``The governors are very apprehensive about anything that would reduce the flexibility of states to be able to deal with their own situation in terms of revenue sources that are traditionally the states'.'' New York Mayor David Dinkins, a Democrat, said he recently balanced the city's budget by raising local taxes, adding, ``One of the reasons we did so is because of the deductibility of those taxes.'' The administration proposal reduces spending on benefit programs by $16 billion, one official said. The biggest chunk of that is the $250 billion Medicare program, which would see payments to beneficiaries, doctors and hospitals trimmed by $6 billion. Other cuts would be made in spending for agriculture, veterans and federal workers. The plan trims defense spending by about $7 billion _ at least $3 billion less than Democrats prefer. And it cuts domestic and foreign aid programs by $4 billion. Some GOP congressional negotiators said privately that they opposed the administration budget proposal, which White House officials first shopped to House and Senate Republicans on Wednesday. Others emphasized that the plan was meant only as a first offer to Democrats. ``We're a highly flexible operation,'' said White House budget director Richard Darman.

The stock market declined slightly today, confronted with new evidence of sluggish business conditions. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials dropped 5.69 to 2,915.10 by noontime on Wall Street. Losers outnumbered gainers by about 9 to 5 in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed issues, with 464 up, 823 down and 524 unchanged. The Commerce Department reported that the gross national product grew at a 1.2 percent annual rate, after adjustment for inflation, in the second quarter of the year. The figure came in below most advance estimates. In addition, analysts noted that a significant amount of the increase stemmed from inventory expansion, a negative portent for production. Open-market interest rates declined in response to the news. For stock traders, however, the data seemed primarily to emphasize recent worries about the outlook for corporate profits. Many big-name stocks have run into selling of late on earnings reports that didn't live up to expectations. Walt Disney, for instance, dropped 3{ to 117{ after posting a 23.3 percent quarterly earnings gain that evidently disappointed some traders. Elsewhere, energy stocks were broadly higher on reports that the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries had agreed on a new oil production ceiling and reference price of $21 a barrel for the rest of the year. Exxon rose 1[ to 50; Atlantic Richfield 1] to 125{; Amoco } to 54[; Texaco ~ to 62|, and Chevron 1 to 78. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks fell .57 to 193.98. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index was down .68 at 355.65. Volume on the Big Board came to 67.15 million shares at noontime, against 72.84 million at the same point Thursday.

DOC.HEAD: London Stocks Finish Lower
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES with closing prices.
DOC.TEXT: London stock prices finished lower in light trading on the London Stock Exchange Friday with investors showing little interest in the market. Shares opened on a weak note and proceeded to drift for most of the morning and early afternoon. When Wall Street opened lower, London stocks were further depressed, dealers said. Even when the New York Stock Exchange recouped some of its losses, the British market were too tired to attempt a recovery, dealers said. Activity was described as thin, with scant corporate news to influence the session. ``It's desperately quiet,'' one market maker said. ``There's no interest in doing anything at all.'' At the close, the Financial Times-Stock Exchange 100-share index was down 14 points, or 0.6 percent, at 2,330.1, well below the session high of 2,339.9 and slightly better than the early morning minimum of 2,327.9. The Financial Times 30-share index was down 9.4 points at 1,842.1 at the close. The Financial Times 500-share index fell 6.27 points to close at 1,260.29. Volume came to 344.7 million shares compared with 468.8 million shares Thursday.

DOC.HEAD: The AP
Aetna Reports Second-Quarter Profits Up $34 Million
DOC.TEXT: Aetna Life & Casualty said Friday that second-quarter profits were up $34 million over last year, primarily because of significant improvements in group insurance. The insurance company reported second-quarter net income of $204 million or $1.82 per share, compared to $170 million or $1.52 per share in 1989. However, Aetna reported revenue of $4.8 billion in the quarter ending June 30, down from $5 billion in the 1989 period. The revenue includes $3.2 billion in premiums, down from $3.4 billion last year. ``We had significantly better group insurance results,'' said Aetna Chairman James T. Lynn. Group insurance earnings of $79 million in the quarter were $24 million higher than last year. ``However, our commercial insurance and reinsurance results continue to reflect a soft pricing environment, and our personal auto insurance business is still suffering from high loss costs and inadequate rates,'' Lynn said. For the first six months of 1990, net income was $384 million or $3.43 per share, compared with $343 million or $3.04 per share for the same period last year. Revenue totaled $9.59 billion with premiums of $6.4 billion, down slightly from the 1989 period, when the company had $9.6 billion in revenue and $6.5 billion in premiums.

DOC.HEAD: Company Agrees to Pay $34 Million for Wastewater Violations
DOC.NOTE: Eds: RECASTS lead, SUBS 4th graf pvs. to CORRECT contamination in Grand Calumet sted Northern Indiana river. ADDS additional comments, details thruout. ADDS byline. Also moving on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: USX Corp. has agreed to pay $34 million in costs and penalties for the cleanup of wastewater that was illegally dumped from its Gary, Ind. steel mill, federal officials said today. The agreement stems from a 1988 lawsuit filed by the federal government alleging that USX exceeded discharge limits in the Grand Calumet River. The suit also alleged the company had made other violations of the federal Clean Water Act. Under the agreement, the company will pay $1.6 million in penalties and an estimated $25 million in cleanup and waste-management measures, officials of the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency and the U.S. Attorney's Office said. The company also agreed to pay $2.5 million on a study to determine the extent of sediment contamination in the Grand Calumet, located in northern Indiana. Another $5 million will be allocated to clean up whatever contamination is found. Dale S. Bryson, water division director for EPA's region 5, said today's settlement was among the top 10 in fines for illegal wastewater dumping. But USX will pay more than any other company for actual cleanup measures, he said. In the lawsuit, the EPA contended that USX, formerly U.S. Steel, illegally bypassed its blast furnace wastewater treatment system, dumping polluted water directly into the Grand Calumet and Lake Michigan on several occasions. In September 1989, EPA recommended that the USX-Gary Works plant be suspended from doing business with the federal government because of the violations. The recommendation will be withdrawn once the decree has been entered in the U.S. District Court in Hammond, officials said.

DOC.HEAD: GNP Grows at Anemic Rate
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 13th graf pvs to CORRECT Darby's first name to Michael sted of Robert; picks up 14th graf pvs, The administration.
DOC.TEXT: The U.S. economy sputtered at an anemic annual growth rate of 1.2 percent from April through June with virtually every economic sector exhibiting weakness, the government said Friday. The Commerce Department report on the gross national product _ the country's total output of goods and services _ renewed recession fears among private economists. The Bush administration insisted that weakness in the first half of the year will be followed by a rebound in the last part of 1990. The administration said a significant slowdown in inflation would give the Federal Reserve room to lower interest rates and thus spark a rebound in consumer and business activity. Inflation was the one bright spot in the GNP report. A price index tied to the GNP rose at an annual rate of 3.9 percent in the April-June quarter, down from a 6.6 percent spurt in the first three months of the year. Half of the inflation improvement was attributed to a drop in food costs. But adding to the pessimism of private economists was a significant downward revision in previous GNP estimates which made the economy's performance for the past year look even weaker than previously believed. GNP growth in the first three months was revised down to a 1.7 percent rate, compared to 1.9 percent previously, while growth from October through December was cut to a barely perceptible 0.3 percent, far below the 1.1 percent previous estimate. The results of all the changes lowered GNP growth for 1989 from an original estimate of 3 percent down to 2.5 percent, the weakest performance since an outright decline of 2.5 percent in the recession year of 1982. ``The economy looks as close to a recession as it can get without actually being in one,'' said Allen Sinai, chief economist of the Boston Co. ``We have a crummy economy and that presents big problems for policy makers.'' President Bush has already had to reverse his stand on taxes in an effort to cope with a federal budget deficit that is being swollen by lower-than-expected economic growth and falling tax revenues. Last week, the administration slashed its forecast of economic growth to 2 percent for this year, but to reach even that scaled-down goal would require growth to accelerate to a 2.9 percent rate in the last half of 1990. Most private economists called such a speedup improbable, given the widespread weakness evident in the second quarter GNP report. They said the best that could be hoped for was a continuation of sluggish growth with the worst outcome being a drop into an actual recession. ``We have an economy that has run out of steam,'' said Robert Dederick, chief economist of the Northern Trust Co. of Chicago. ``It is being kept on a life support system by the Federal Reserve, but there is always a risk that it will just fade away.'' However, Commerce Undersecretary Michael Darby, presenting the administration's views on the GNP report, sought to paint a less bleak picture. He said part of the second quarter weakness was a result of warmer winter weather spurring construction activity and consumer spending in the first quarter which would normally have occurred in the spring. The administration for months has been pressuring the Fed to relent and ease interest rates more. Darby said that the drop in inflation pressures shown in the GNP report ``bodes well for continued economic expansion'' by providing more maneuvering room for the Fed to lower interest rates. The GNP rose by only $12.6 billion in the second quarter to an annual rate of $4.16 trillion. That gain was more than accounted for by a $35.5 billion jump in business inventories, much of that in the auto industry where production was boosted in anticipation of a possible strike during the third quarter. Richard Rahn, chief economist of the U.S. Chamber of Commerce, blamed the economic weakness on ill-founded worries at the Federal Reserve abut inflation. He called on the Fed to lower interest rates and for Congress and the administration to abandon any thoughts of imposing a $25 billion tax increase on such a weak economy. ``The economy is now one step away from a full-blown recession,'' he said. ``The Fed must reverse present tight money policies and lower interest rates. Time is running out.''

DOC.HEAD: Abbott, Ousted Chairman Reach Agreement
DOC.TEXT: Abbott Laboratories and its ousted Chairman Robert A. Schoellhorn have reached an agreement on Schoellhorn's lawsuit against the company, although officials have provided few details of the settlement. Schoellhorn, 61, sued the North Chicago-based drug manufacturer after the board voted to remove him as chief executive officer and chairman. He contended Abbott breached a contract to employ him as chairman until his retirement at age 65. In a one-paragraph statement Wednesday, Abbott said Schoellhorn's suit will be dismissed and he will retire from Abbott on Aug. 31. Schoellhorn's lawyer, John Mathias, wouldn't comment on the settlement. The settlement apparently rescinds Abbott's firing of Schoellhorn, which took place in April after a state court lifted a temporary restraining order obtained by Schoellhorn. Abbott's board had voted in December to remove him as chief executive and on March 9 to remove him as chairman. Schoellhorn filed suit the same day, claiming the dismissal was contrary to company bylaws and pursuant to fraudulent board resolutions. The company had charged in court documents that Schoellhorn misappropriated corporate assets through private use of company airplanes and falsified expense reports. The company also alleged he caused company employees to perform personal services for him and to buy personal items for him with company funds. Schoellhorn denied the charges.

DOC.HEAD: Soybeans Tumble on Profit-Taking, Erasing Previous Gains
DOC.TEXT: Soybean futures prices fell sharply Friday on the Chicago Board of Trade amid profit-taking that erased most of the previous session's gains and sparked corresponding selloffs in the grain markets. In the absence of bullish news, the soybean market could not sustain the price levels reached Thursday amid signs of strong soybean meal demand and prospective Soviet buying, analysts said. Instead, traders returned their attention to the Midwestern weather forecasts, which continue to look good for soybean and corn crop development. ``What the market is really saying is that weather conditions are ideal throughout the Midwest,'' said Gerald Zusel, director of Balfour Maclaine Corp.'s floor operations at the Board of Trade. ``Although we had good soymeal demand yesterday in Europe, there was not enough on a continuing basis to keep the market at yesterday's levels,'' he said. At the close, wheat futures were 2\ cents to 3\ cents lower with the contract for delivery in September at $2.98{ a bushel; corn was { cent to 2{ cents lower with September at $2.63 a bushel; oats were 3 cents to 3{ cents lower with September at $1.29{ a bushel; soybeans were 2 cents to 12 cents lower with August at $5.85 a bushel.

DOC.HEAD: NBC Union Rejects Contract for Second Time
DOC.TEXT: A major union at NBC has rejected the company's four-year contract offer for the second time since April, but is trying to arrange new negotiations, a union spokesman said Friday. Members of the National Association of Broadcast Employees and Technicians voted 1,290 to 516 to reject NBC's offer, said NABET spokesman John Krieger. ``We're trying to arrange further bargaining talks,'' he said. There was no immediate comment from NBC. The union says it has 2,373 members at NBC, and NBC-owned facilities here and in Burbank, Calif.; Washington; Chicago; and Cleveland; and at NBC news bureaus in the United States. The union, which represents local and network newswriters and technical employees, struck NBC in 1987 in a bitter walkout lasting 17 weeks. No strike was imminent Friday, despite the contract rejection. Krieger said no strike vote has been taken yet, and NABET members continue to work. Their previous contract expired March 30. He said the main issues in contract talks include jurisdiction, the use of people hired by the day rather than permanently, and ``four-walling'' proposals under which outside producers could rent NBC facilities to make shows without being required to use NABET crews employed by NBC.

DOC.HEAD: House and Senate Back Economic Sanctions on Iraq
With AM-OPEC, Bjt. Also moving on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: The House and Senate voted Friday to impose economic sanctions on Iraq, and government sources said the Bush administration is considering its own, milder moves against the Baghdad government. The Senate, which took the strongest action, voted 80-16 to cut off $1.2 billion in U.S. loan guarantees that Iraq now uses to buy American wheat, rice, lumber, cattle and commercial goods such as tires and machinery. Acting on an amendment by Sen. Alfonse D'Amato, R-N.Y., senators also moved to bar sales to Iraq of weapons, sensitive technology and items which can be used for military purposes. The amendment was made part of the 1990 farm bill. The move, and a watered-down sanctions package approved by the House, were signs of growing congressional concern about Iraq's human rights abuses, intimidation of its neighbors, harboring of terrorists and developing chemical and nuclear weapons programs. ``There comes a time when we have to stand up and be counted,'' said Sen. Nancy Kassebaum, R-Kan., who conceded that the sanctions could hurt Kansas wheat farmers. But she said human rights considerations, including reports of government torture of children, outweigh economics. ``I can't believe any farmer in this nation would want to send his products, under subsidized sales, to a country that has used chemical weapons and a country that has tortured and executed its children,'' she said. State Department spokesman Richard Boucher said the congressional action would not be helpful to U.S. diplomatic efforts to moderate the behavior of the government of President Saddam Hussein. But at the same time, government sources said the Bush administration was seriously considering its own options for action against Iraq which could signal U.S. displeasure without totally alienating the Iraqi president. Options included putting Iraq back on the U.S. list of terrorist nations, which would end commodity loan guarantees and Export-Import Bank credits for purchase of American industrial goods. Also possible would be a more limited move to tighten restrictions on U.S. exports. ``This is a freight train coming down the track'' from Congress, said one senior administration official, speaking on condition of anonymity. ``There is plenty of impetus. The question becomes, do we want to be active, or let (Capitol) Hill do it to us?'' The House Foreign Affairs Committee scheduled action for next week on a bill drafted by Rep. Howard Berman, D-Calif., that would impose a similar list of sanctions on Iraq. Still other sanctions were contained in an Export Administration Act pending on the Senate calendar. In Friday's voting, sanctions advocates on both sides of the Capitol _ primarily the Israel lobby _ overpowered farm-state interests who were concerned about losing a substantial market for wheat, rice and other commodities. But agriculture forces in the House, remembering the disastrous 1980 U.S. grain embargo against the Soviet Union, were able to create a substantial loophole: the sanctions can be waived if they are hurting farmers worse than the Iraqis. Inclusion by both houses of sanctions means that some form of penalty against Iraq is virtually certain to be in the final version of the farm bill that will emerge from House-Senate negotiations later this year. Arguing for his amendment on the Senate floor, D'Amato compared the Iraqi president to Adolf Hitler and called him a ``mad dog'' and ``a butcher.'' Others were more moderate, decrying Iraq's human rights record and characterizing the vote as a move to assert U.S. leadership in the world against terrorism and outlaw behavior. ``When are we going to start exercising some moral leadership in this country?'' asked Sen. William Cohen, R-Maine. ``I think the time has come right now.'' To bow to domestic financial considerations, he said, would reduce U.S. policy to one of appeasement.
Stock prices showed a broad loss today amid persistent worries about corporate profits. Shortly before the close, the Dow Jones average of 30 industrials was down 28.46 at 2,892.33.

DOC.HEAD: Wholesalers Association Hopes Candy Consumption Will Rise
DOC.TEXT: The National Candy Wholesalers Association, aiming to boost the annual candy consumption of Americans from 19.7 pounds per person to 20 pounds, has a list of ``Candy Facts'' to soothe your guilty conscience and convince you that sweet treats may even be good for you. Association President William Elfenbein of Denver admits that some of the statements _ such as ``Candy doesn't make you fat'' and ``Candy is nutritious'' _ probably would make nutritionists shudder. And he concedes that too much of anything can be bad. ``You wouldn't want to eat just candy,'' said Elfenbein, 53, who is in Atlanta for the group's convention. ``But for most people it could be the bright note in a very dull day.'' Connie Crawley, a registered dietician at the University of Georgia, agreed balance is the key. ``Sugar has no nutritional value at all except calories. We don't promote sugar, but we aren't saying it's the worst food and you should never eat it again,'' she said. For now, the 7,000 buyers and distributors attending the convention at the Georgia World Congress Center aren't counting calories as they wander through a trick-or-treater's paradise filled with mouth-watering wonders. Through Saturday, they can gorge themselves on new and old goodies in a sample room filled with every candy bar imaginable, including favorites like Zero, Almond Joy, Milky Way, Red Hots and Sweet Tarts. ``We give everybody a sack and let them go through the room. Some eat while they fill up their bags,'' said Shelley Grossman Estersohn, communications director for the Washington-based association. Estersohn said the group is hoping candy consumption will rise on its own to 20 pounds per person by the end of the year. The list of ``Candy Facts'' was contained in a handout available to buyers and reporters attending the convention. The convention, which opened Thursday, includes an exhibition hall where browsers can take a look and a sample from more than 680 booths featuring new items: Hubba Bubba Sticks in a flip-top box, solid-chocolate car telephones wrapped in plastic that says ``Why Don't You Call Me Sometime?'' and Pez with heads from the Peanuts comic strip. Among the most prominent displays is the Hershey's booth featuring a giant Hershey's Kiss wrapped in gold foil. ``After 80 years, we finally went nuts'' reads an ad promoting the company's latest product, Hershey's Kisses with Almonds. The almond Kisses will be wrapped in gold foil, rather than silver, and will be shipped to distributors beginning Aug. 13, said Terry Freisen, director of trade development for the Hershey, Pa.-based company, which began making chocolate Kisses in 1907. Freisen said the company doesn't expect competition between the two kinds of Kisses, which will sell for the same price. ``Consumers have told us they will buy both,'' he said. The new Pez tops are being introduced in conjunction with Snoopy's 40th birthday and include his friends Lucy, Charlie Brown and Woodstock, said Scott McWhinnie, president of the company in Orange, Conn. ``Kids all know what Pez is,'' McWhinnie said. ``Its recognition level among teen-agers is 98 percent. Among mothers with children, it's 89 percent.''

DOC.HEAD: Bonds of Biggest Defense Contractors Downgraded
DOC.TEXT: The bad news continued to mount for the nation's two largest defense contractors Friday as two large commercial bond rating firms downgraded the companies' bond ratings. It was the second time this year that ratings had been lowered for McDonnell Douglas Corp. and General Dynamics Corp., both headquartered in St. Louis. McDonnell Douglas, the biggest defense contractor, had its bond rating dropped two notches by Moody's Investment Service, from Baa1 to Baa3, the lowest category of investment grade bonds. It's the third time in just over a year that McDonnell Douglas' bond ratings have been reduced by Moody's. Standard & Poor's Corp. also reduced the company's subordinated debt rating, from A- to BBB+, and its unsubordinated debt, from BBB+ to BBB. It's the second time Standard & Poor's has reduced the company's rating this year. Moody's bond analyst Tassos Philippakos said last week's announcement by McDonnell Douglas to reduce its workforce by up to 11 percent and cut other costs to save $700 million this year isn't enough to solve all of the company's problems. ``We expect that to have some positive impact in the future, but it's going to take time and time is a luxury that management doesn't have right now,'' he said. The company is facing cost overruns and delays on several large defense projects along with record backlogs and inefficiencies in its commercial jet-building operation in Long Beach, Calif. McDonnell Douglas spokeswoman Barbara Anderson said the rating downgrades were disappointing. ``McDonnell Douglas does not feel its performance, financial condition or future prospects warrant these measures,'' she said. Meanwhile, Standard & Poor's reduced General Dynamics senior debt rating from A+ to A and its subordinated debt from A to A-. In January, Standard & Poor's reduced the company's rating from AA- to A+. Bond analyst David Sotnick said the company's $240 million loss in the second quarter and the dismal outlook for the defense industry prompted the recent downgrading. Moody's reduced General Dynamics' bonds last month.

DOC.HEAD: Fixed-Rate Mortgages Under 10 Percent for Second Week
DOC.TEXT: Fixed-rate mortgages averaged 9.98 percent this week, down from 9.99 percent last week, according to a national survey released Friday by the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corp. It was the second consecutive week that fixed-rate mortgages have been below 10 percent, the first time that has occurred since mid-January. On one-year adjustable-rate mortgages, lenders were asking an average initial rate of 8.41 percent, up from 8.39 percent last week. The rates do not include add-on fees known as points.

DOC.HEAD: Oil Prices End Lower Following OPEC Production Pact
DOC.TEXT: An agreement by OPEC oil ministers Friday to restrain crude production had little effect on wholesale prices, but some experts said motorists could feel pinched at the pumps by early 1991 if the cartel sticks with the pact. Prices of energy futures settled slightly lower after initially rising on news of the OPEC pact. Some traders blamed technical factors and profit-taking from a recent price runup for the fall. The accord signed Friday by all 13 ministers of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries would raise the target price of the cartel's crude to $21 a barrel from $18. The actual price has been as low as $16.25 per barrel recently because of a worldwide oil glut. To achieve its price increase the cartel set a new daily output ceiling of 22.5 million barrels, a bit above the current cap but lower than its actual production. In all, OPEC will have to rein in production by about 700,000 barrels a day. ``There's a better chance than in the past of their adhering to this agreement,'' said James R. Fiedler, a vice president at E.D.&F. Man International Futures Inc. in New York. ``For the first time we have the United Arab Emirates agreeing to a quota ... And we have an enforcer in Iraq.'' Iraq last week threatened to use military force against cartel members exceeding their output quotas. It said Kuwait and the United Arab Emirates largely were responsible for the current glut. Oil traders had been predicting OPEC would take action to curb production, and that anticipation helped sharply boost wholesale prices in recent weeks. For instance, since June 1, crude oil futures have risen about $3 a barrel; unleaded gasoline, about 14 cents; and home heating oil, around 10 cents, according to energy experts. James Steel, an energy analyst with Refco Inc. in New York, said the general rule of thumb is that every dollar rise in a barrel of crude oil means a nickel rise at the pumps. He said that if the OPEC agreement pushes crude up $3.50 to $4 a barrel, as some expect will happen by December, we could see an increase of between 15 cents and 20 cents in early 1991. Analysts said it will take that long for consumers to start seeing an increase on the retail level because of the oil glut. In the United States, supplies of unleaded gasoline are up 10 percent from a year ago to 167.2 million barrels from 156.32 million. Crude stocks are up 50 million from 1989, to 338.7 million barrels from 330.6 million. ``Western Europe and Japan face similar situations,'' Steel said. In subdued trading Friday on the New York Mercantile Exchange, the September contract for West Texas Intermediate, the benchmark grade of U.S. crude, settled down 26 cents to $20.04 a 42-gallon barrel. The contract had lost 8 cents on Thursday. Among refined petroleum products traded on the exchange, unleaded gasoline for August delivery finished down 0.38 cent to 64.88 cents a gallon, after rising more than 2 cents a gallon earlier in the session. The contract settled up 2.22 cents on Thursday. Traders said gasoline's sharp rise earlier in the session was due mostly to internal market influences. The August contract for wholesale heating oil, which gained 0.56 cent on Thursday, settled at 56.97 cents a gallon, off 0.35 cents. In natural gas trading, the September contract settled at $1.439 per 1,000 cubic feet, up from $1.435 Wednesday.

DOC.HEAD: Shell Oil's Second-Quarter Earnings Decline
DOC.TEXT: Shell Oil Co. said Friday its second-quarter earnings fell 63 percent from the same period a year ago, which the company attributed in part to a $76 million writeoff for investments in offshore oil and gas properties. Second-quarter earnings totaled $161 million, compared with $279 million a year ago. The Houston-based company does not have per share earnings because it is a wholly owned subsidiary of Royal Dutch-Shell Groups. Shell said it took a writeoff on certain offshore California oil and gas properties because of delays in securing development permits. ``The prolonged delays experienced in developing offshore California properties have been a source of deep concern to us. Recent events indicate that these problems are getting worse, in spite of our nation's increasing dependence on foreign oil supplies,'' said Shell President Frank H. Richardson. Shell also wrote off the cost of an artifical island and exploration wells associated with an oil discovery in the Beaufort Sea off Alaska that was determined to be non-commercial. The combined writeoffs amounted to $76 million, Shell said. The company said second-quarter earnings this year fell in all three major business divisions. ``Oil and gas exploration and production results declined mainly due to sharply lower crude oil prices and the asset writeoffs. Earnings in the oil products segment were adversely impacted by a heavy program of scheduled refinery maintenance and increased environmental expenditures,'' Richardson said. ``Chemical products earnings declined from last year's record levels, mainly due to lower margins,'' he said. Earnings also were down for the first six months. Net income for the first half of the year was $363 million, a 55 percent decline from $801 million for the same 1989 period. Revenues were $5.2 billion for the 1990 second quarter, compared with $5.9 billion a year ago. For the first six months, they were $10.9 billion compared with $11 billion in 1989.
