DOC.HEAD: Bailout Of Student Loan Guarantor Would Cost Less Than $100 Million
DOC.TEXT: A taxpayer bailout of a troubled student loan guarantor would not cost more than $100 million, a senior Education Department official said Friday. Ted Sanders, under secretary of education, said the department hoped to resolve the problems of the Higher Education Assistance Foundation, or HEAF, without taxpayer money. But ``$100 million would be the outside number,'' he told the Senate Banking Committee. HEAF, a private, non-profit agency based in Overland Park, Kan., is the guarantor of $8.8 billion in student loans, or more than 17 percent of the $51 billion student loans outstanding nationally. It is the largest of 47 guaranty agencies, which are either state-run agencies or private, non-profit groups. It had said earlier that a high loan default rate, particularly on loans to trade school students, threatened to push it into insolvency and sought help from the federal government. Bankers warn that commercial lenders would flee the student loan market if HEAF defaulted and lenders were forced to take losses on the guaranteed loans. However, Sanders reassured nervous students and parents that loans would be available this fall and said the Education Department intended to ``act decisively to arrange for the orderly management of the HEAF portfolio.'' ``Despite alarmist reports in the media, this situation will not affect the ability of students to obtain loans, of lenders to make those loans, or of guarantors to insure those loans,'' he said. The program last year loaned more than $12 billion to 4 million students, according to the General Accounting Office, Congress' auditing agency. Meanwhile, Sallie Mae, the government-sponsored student loan company, said Friday it is talking with the Education Department about rescuing HEAF. Sallie Mae, the Student Loan Marketing Association, is a federally chartered but shareholder-owned secondary market company. Through several mechanisms, it finances about 40 percent of all student loans, dominating the industry. In response to a report in Friday's editions of The Wall Street Journal that it had made a bid to take over HEAF, Sallie Mae confirmed ``the Department of Education has invited Sallie Mae to propose ways in which it could participate in a resolution of HEAF's financial difficulties.'' It said, ``Among the options being explored on a preliminary basis is the possibility of Sallie Mae's being designated ... as a guarantor of student loans.'' Although Sallie Mae's charter permits it to enter that end of the business, so far it has not. Bankers and the guarantor agencies are opposing the expansion. The National Council of Higher Education Loan Programs, which represents the guaranty agencies, told the committee it would be a potential conflict of interest for Sallie Mae, as a loan holder, to rule as a guarantor on its own claims for defaulted loans. Also, the expansion would make Sallie Mae so dominant in the student loan field that the government would have to meet any demands for concessions that it made, argued Jean S. Frohlicher, executive director of the council. Earlier, an administration official, speaking on condition of anonymity, said the Education Department also was considering a takeover offer from the United Student Aid Funds, the second-largest guarantor agency, headquartered in Indianapolis. Officials have scrapped the idea of turning HEAF over to a smaller agency, the Nebraska Student Loan Program Inc.

DOC.HEAD: Profit-taking Erases Soybean Gains
DOC.TEXT: Soybean futures prices fell sharply Friday on the Chicago Board of Trade amid profit-taking that erased most of the previous session's gains and sparked selloffs in the corn, oat and wheat markets. On other commodity markets, energy futures were mixed; copper futures rose; precious metals fell; and livestock and meat futures were mixed. Soybean futures settled 3{ cents to 11{ cents lower with August down 8 cents at $5.84\. The August soybean contract had risen 8} cents and other soybean contracts rose as much as 12{ cents on Thursday. There was little bullish news Friday to help the soybean market sustain the price levels it reached Thursday amid signs of strong soybean meal demand and prospective Soviet buying, analysts said. Instead, traders returned their attention to the Midwestern weather forecasts, which continue to look good for soybean and corn crop development. ``What the market is really saying is that weather conditions are ideal throughout the Midwest,'' said Gerald Zusel, director of Balfour Maclaine Corp.'s floor operations at the Board of Trade. ``Although we had good soymeal demand yesterday in Europe, there was not enough on a continuing basis to keep the market at yesteday's levels,'' he said. After Friday's close, the market received more bearish weather news. The National Weather Service issued a new six-to-10-day forecast predicting below-normal temperatures and above-normal rainfall in the Midwest Aug. 2 through Aug. 6. In grain trading, wheat futures settled 2\ cents to 3\ cents lower with September at $2.98{ a bushel; corn was { cent to 2{ cents lower with September at $2.62{ a bushel; oats were 3 cents to 3{ cents lower with September at $1.30 a bushel. Petroleum futures finished mixed, with near-term deliveries down moderately, after OPEC oil ministers meeting in Geneva agreed, as expected, on a higher target price and new output quotas for crude oil. The new target price of $21 per barrel is $3 above the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries' previous reference price. The OPEC ministers also agreed to limit production to 22.5 million barrels per day, which is 400,000 barrels above the old ceiling but below the cartel's acutal estimated output of 23 million barrels or more per day. OPEC leaders hope the higher production ceiling will prevent cheating by cartel members whose overproduction has been blamed for weak crude oil prices. West Texas Intermediate crude oil settled 26 cents lower to 15 cents higher with September at $20.04 a barrel; heating oil was .35 cent lower to .08 cent higher with August at 56.97 cents a gallon; unleaded gasoline was .55 cent lower to .03 cent higher with August at 64.88 cents a gallon. Copper futures climbed sharply on New York's Commodity Exchange, extending recent gains amid continuing concerns about supply availability and a strike that began Thursday against Peru's state-owned Mineroperu mining and refining company. Another supportive factor was a forecast from the U.S. copper producer Asarco Inc. that world copper consumption will significantly outstrip production this year, said Peter Cardillo, director of commodities research with Jesup, Josephthal & Co. in New York. Copper settled 1.3 cents to 3 cents higher with July at $1.268 a pound. Gold futures retreated for the second straight day but closed above their lows. Cardillo said the August contract's bounce off $365.80 indicated the market could rally next week. Gold settled $1.70 to $2.20 lower with August at $368 a troy ounce; silver was 1.8 cents to 2.3 cents lower with July at $4.831 a troy ounce. Livestock and meat futures ened mixed on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange ahead of the Agriculture Department's semi-annual cattle inventory report, which contained no surprises. The USDA estimated the nation's calf and cattle herd as of July 1 at 108.9 million head, which was near expectations and confirmed ideas that the herd is slowly expanding. Live cattle futures settled .22 cent lower to .30 cent higher with August at 77.95 cents a pound; feeder cattle were .10 cent lower to .50 cent higher with August at 89.12 cents a pound; live hogs were .15 cent lower to .35 cent higher with August at 60.12 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were .40 cent lower to .77 cent higher with August at 49.72 cents a pound.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Sinks, Gold Down
DOC.TEXT: The dollar fell sharply Friday as traders, disheartened by a further weakening in the economy, grew convinced that the Federal Reserve will be forced to push U.S. interest rates lower. Gold prices slipped despite the weakened dollar. The dollar was hit hard by a Commerce Department report that the gross national product grew at an annual rate of just 1.2 percent during the second quarter. The GNP, which measures the country's total output of goods and services, was supported solely by a big buildup in business inventories. Other major components of the economy, including consumer spending, business investment and housing construction, suffered declines. The poor showing followed a meager 1.7 percent increase in the first quarter and an even more paltry 0.3 percent advance in the final quarter of 1989. ``The overwhelming majority of the market believes we're in a recession _ it's heard too many things to suggest otherwise,'' said Robert Ryan, chief foreign exchange dealer with Bank of New York Co. The financial markets believe that with the economy continuing to slump, the Fed will have to let interest rates fall to help stimulate growth. But such a move would come at the expense of the dollar. Currencies are supported by higher interest rates, so a drop in U.S. yields makes the dollar less competitive. Rates are currently higher in Europe, so ``anything on the continent is doing super,'' Ryan said. That was evident Friday as the British pound surged more than 2 cents against the dollar. Sterling rose to $1.8375 in New York from late Thursday's $1.8145. In London earlier, the British pound rose to $1.8350 from $1.8133. Other dollar rates in New York, compared with late Thursday's prices, included: 1.6120 West German marks, down from 1.6230; 1.3620 Swiss francs, down from 1.3773; 5.3990 French francs, down from 5.4360; 1,180.00 Italian lire, down from 1,187.50; and 1.15195 Canadian dollars, down from 1.15265. Other late dollar rates in Europe, compared with late rates Thursday included: 1.6145 West German marks, down from 1.6220; 1.3680 Swiss francs, down from 1.3780; 5.4080 French francs, down from 5.4355; 1.8205 Dutch guilders, down from 1.8290; 1,182.00 Italian lire, down from 1,187.50, and 1.1521 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1513. The dollar fell to 149.10 Japanese yen in New York from 150.35 late Thursday. In Tokyo earlier, the dollar rose 0.64 yen to a closing 150.75 yen and it was quoted in London at 149.70 yen. Gold often benefits from a decline in the dollar, but technical factors carried the precious metal lower Friday. Gold fell $1.50 on the Commodity Exchange in New York to $367.80 a troy ounce. Republic National Bank of New York later quoted a bid of $367.30, down $1.50 from Thursday. In London earlier, gold fell to a late bid of $367.15 a troy ounce, down from $368.65 late Thursday. In Zurich, gold fell to a closing bid of $367.15 an ounce, down from $368.50 late Thursday. Gold in Hong Kong fell 98 cents to close at $368.96 an ounce. Silver prices also declined. Silver slipped 1.9 cents to $4.831 a troy ounce on the Commodity Exchange, and it fell in London to a late bid of $4.80 a troy ounce from $4.85 late Thursday.

DOC.HEAD: Cadillac Dealer Decries Local Cadillac Ads As Japanese-Bashing
DOC.TEXT: A local car dealer is blasting as racist a regional Cadillac television ad campaign that uses World War II footage to depict the downfall of Japanese auto competitors. Mark Hennessy, owner of Hennessy Cadillac-Jaguar in Atlanta, placed ads in Friday's editions of The Atlanta Journal-Constitution denouncing the ad campaign by ``The Cadillac Dealers of the South.'' His ads called the campaign obscene, racist and an admission by the company ``that Cadillac is not marketable against Japanese luxury cars on a feature for feature or value for dollar basis.'' The ads use World War II footage depicting a dogfight _ representing the competition between American and Japanese cars _ with the slogan, ``Out of the land of the rising sun comes the land of rising prices.'' It shows a Japanese Zero fighter plane crashing into the ocean as the announcer says, ``Compared to Cadillacs, our competitors are real zeros. ``It's a xenophobic fear of the Japanese culture,'' Hennessy said Friday in an interview. Hennessy _ whose dealership also sells the Japanese-made Lexus _ said he first complained about the ads during a special screening for dealers last month. He said he told both Cadillac zone managers and representatives of the ad agency, Babbit & Reiman, that the ads would offend Cadillac owners and scare away potential customers. ``The ads give the idea that we as Cadillac dealers aren't selling our cars ... on the basis of value but that we have to just rely on emotion,'' he said. ``I'm selling due to the quality of the car and the quality of my employees and loyalty of my owner case.'' He also said Cadillac owners and potential customers have been calling his company to complain since the television ads first aired. Paul Schmidt, Atlanta zone manager for Cadillac, did not return phone calls Friday. But Joey Reiman, chairman of Babbit & Reiman, said his agency's campaign is being misinterpreted. ``Our job is to sell Cadillacs for Southeastern Cadillac dealers. This TV spot does just that,'' he said. ``Our targets are veterans who can't understand why their children are not buying American cars. ``The real zeros here are people who are taking this too seriously.'' The ads are being run throughout the South on behalf of more than 193 Southern Cadillac dealers. Reiman said the campaign is not racist. He said another ad in the campaign, which has not been aired yet, targets Lincoln cars. This ad features images of Abraham Lincoln and says, ``Take it from Lincoln, buy a Cadillac.'' ``It's not just the Japanese we're after, it's all competition,'' Reiman said. Reiman also said Hennessy may be upset about the ad because his dealership also sells Japanese cars. But Hennessy said he designed his newspaper ad to ``apologize to any of our customers or prospective customers who may be offended by these ads.'' ``I'm not on a soapbox, I'm just trying to protect the business my family built over 26 years,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: USX Agrees to Pay $34 Million for Wastewater Violations
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Stands for story slugged AM-USX Settlement on Business News Digest. Also moving on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: USX Corp. will pay about $34 million in penalties and cleanup costs for dumping wastewater from its Gary, Ind., steel mill, under an agreement announced Friday by federal officials. ``We believe this consent decree is a major victory for the much-abused Grand Calumet River,'' said Ralph R. Bauer, deputy regional administrator for the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency. ``We expect this decree to provide a framework for improvement and cleanup at the USX plant.'' The out-of-court settlement resolves a 1988 lawsuit filed by the federal government alleging that the Gary mill exceeded wastewater discharge limits in the river. The lawsuit also alleged that the company violated the federal Clean Water Act in other ways between 1983 and 1988. Under the agreement announced by the EPA and the U.S. attorney's office for northern Indiana, the company will pay $1.6 million in civil penalties and an estimated $25 million to improve equipment and develop a comprehensive wastewater management plan. The company has also agreed to pay $2.5 million on a study to determine the extent of sediment contamination in the Grand Calumet in northern Indiana. An additional $5 million will be allocated to clean up whatever contamination is found. ``This is a consent decree,'' said George Kuebler, a spokesman for USX's Gary mill. ``There are no admissions to any allegations. The evidence that we are committed to the environment can be seen by agreeing to this decree which calls for spending beyond what is statutorily required.'' Dale S. Bryson of the regional EPA office said the agreement ranks among the top 10 settlements ever received by the EPA. He said the $7.5 million the company will pay in total river cleanup costs is the highest amount ever negotiated specifically for that purpose. Bryson said the EPA expects USX to complete the improvement efforts in two years. The company could face additional penalties _ ranging from $750 a day to $17,500 a day _ for any missed deadlines, Bryson said. In addition, the EPA must approve the company's cleanup and improvement plans, and USX is obligated to pay the difference if costs exceed estimates made in the agreement, he said. In the lawsuit, the EPA contended that USX, formerly U.S. Steel, illegally bypassed its blast furnace wastewater treatment system, dumping polluted water directly into the Grand Calumet and Lake Michigan on several occasions. Last September, EPA recommended that the USX-Gary Works plant be suspended from doing business with the federal government because of the violations. The agency will withdraw this recommendation once the decree has been entered in U.S. District Court in Hammond, officials said.

DOC.HEAD: Bond Prices Rise
DOC.TEXT: Bond prices climbed Friday on further signs of weak economic growth. The Treasury's benchmark 30-year bond gained 11-16 point, or $6.88 per $1,000 in face amount. Its yield, which falls when prices rise, dropped to 8.47 percent from 8.54 percent late Thursday. The spurt came after the Commerce Department said the gross national product, the country's total output of goods and services, grew at an annual rate of just 1.2 percent from April through June. Economists said the report gave further impetus to a belief the economy is sliding into a recession. Additionally, GNP second-quarter increase followed a revised 1.7 percent increase in the first quarter and a barely discernible 0.3 percent advance in the October-December period last year. Slower growth increases the likelihood that inflation will be mild, which increases the value of fixed-income investments such as Treasury bonds. Kevin Flanagan, money market economist for Dean Witter Reynolds Inc., said the rise in bond prices was restrained partly by an inflation measure in the GNP report that was higher than expected. Inflation erodes the value of bonds. Also, some economists tempered their enthusiasm for the GNP number, arguing it was weaker than it would be after government revisions in coming months. Mike Casey, an international economist with Ramirez Capital Consultants Inc., said the GNP number was not bad enough to force the Federal Reserve to lower interest rates to spur the economy, which would push bond prices higher. Trading activity was moderate. In the secondary market for Treasury bonds, prices of short-term governments gained about \ point, intermediate maturities rose 9-32 point to 7-16 point and long-term issues were up as much as 11-16 point, according to Telerate Inc., a financial information service. The movement of a point is equivalent to a change of $10 in the price of a bond with a $1,000 face value. The Shearson Lehman Hutton Daily Treasury Bond Index, which measures price movements on all outstanding Treasury issues with maturities of a year or longer, was 4.29 higher at 1,164.31. Yields on three-month Treasury bills fell to 7.77 percent as the discount was down 4 basis points to 7.53 percent. Yields on six-month bills dropped to 7.79 percent as the discount declined 5 basis points to 7.41 percent. Yields on one-year bills fell to 7.79 percent from Thursday's auction as the discount tumbled 7 basis points to 7.27 percent. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point. The yield is the annualized return on an investment in a Treasury bill. The discount is the percentage that bills are selling below the face value, which is paid at maturity. The federal funds rate, the interest banks charge each other on overnight loans, was quoted at 8 percent, unchanged from late Thursday. In the tax-exempt market, the Bond Buyer index of 40 actively traded municipal bonds was 92~, up 7-32 point. The average yield to maturity fell to 7.37 percent down from 7.39 percent late Thursday.

DOC.HEAD: Prozac Manufacturer Among Defendants In Shooting Suits
DOC.TEXT: Eli Lilly & Co., maker the anti-depressant drug Prozac, is among five defendants in lawsuits brought by the widows of three men slain in a bloody rampage last year at a printing company. Joseph Wesbecker killed himself after fatally shooting eight co-workers at Standard Gravure Corp. on Sept. 14. Twelve other shooting victims survived. Wesbecker was on long-term disability leave from his pressman's job at Standard Gravure because of psychiatric problems at the time of the shootings and was taking Prozac. The suits, filed Wednesday, claim Lilly, based in Indianapolis, was negligent in its production, promotion and distribution of the drug and seek $50 million from the company. The Federal Drug Administration says Prozac is the most widely prescribed anti-depressant on the U.S. market. Former users of the drug have said it drove them to violent tendencies, including suicidal and homicidal thoughts. Last month, a New York woman sued Lilly for $150 million, claiming she suffered severe side effects after taking the drug. Edward West, spokesman for Eli Lilly, said that of the 2 million users of Prozac, Wesbecker's was the first report of violence. He noted that Wesbecker also had a history of psychiatric problems prior to using Prozac. ``It would not appear that Prozac caused this behavior,'' he said. After the shootings, a six-member coroner's jury concluded that excessive stress in the workplace, and possibly the effects of psychiatric drugs, were factors that contributed to the shooting. Also named as defendants were Shea Communications, the owner of Standard Gravure; Hall Security Service Inc., which provided security guards to Standard Gravure; the estate of Joseph Wesbecker, and Dr. Lee Coleman, the psychiarist who was treating Wesbecker. Each suit seeks an unspecified amount of compensatory damages from each defendant. The suits seek punitive damages in the amount of $2 million from Wesbecker's estate and $5 million from Shea Communications in addition to the $50 million from Lilly. The suits were filed by Louisville attorney B. Hume Morris II of behalf of Linda Ganote, Joyce Fentress and Sarah Wible.

DOC.HEAD: With PM- and AM-Disabled Americans
DOC.TEXT: Here are key provisions of the Americans with Disabilities Act that President Bush signed Thursday:
DOC.HEAD: DEFINITION:
DOC.TEXT: Any physical or mental impairment that substantially limits a ``major life activity'' _ caring for oneself, performing manual tasks, walking, seeing, hearing, speaking, breathing, learning and working. Anyone perceived as having a disability is covered, a person with AIDS, for example. People with the history of a disability _ a former cancer patient or former illegal drug use _ are also covered.
DOC.HEAD: EXCLUSIONS:
DOC.TEXT: Current users of illegal drugs. Homosexuals, bisexuals, transsexuals, transvestites. Pedophiles, exhibitionists, voyeurs and those with other sexual behavior disorders. Compulsive gamblers, kleptomaniacs, pyromaniacs. Anyone with a mental disorder resulting from current illegal use of drugs.
DOC.HEAD: EMPLOYMENT:
DOC.TEXT: After two years, all businesses with 25 or more workers are covered. Coverage expands after two additional years to all businesses with 15 or more workers. Employers may not reject applicants or fire current employees on the basis of disability. Businesses must modify or buy equipment or devices or provide helpers _ such as readers for blind workers _ to help the worker overcome the particular disability. Businesses are exempt if the accommodations create an undue financial hardship, determined case by case.
DOC.HEAD: PUBLIC ACCOMMODATIONS:
DOC.TEXT: Public accommodations must be made accessible to disabled patrons 18 months after the bill takes effect. Such public accommodations include hotels, restaurants, theaters, auditoriums, convention centers, doctors' offices, pharmacies, retail stores, public transportation terminals, museums, libraries, parks, zoos and recreation centers. Some businesses have a longer period to comply. All new facilities must be made accessible.
DOC.HEAD: TRANSPORTATION:
DOC.TEXT: All new buses, rapid rail vehicles or light rail vehicles used in public transit must be wheelchair accessible. Existing vehicles need not be refitted, but key stations and all new stations must be made accessible within three years. All new cars for Amtrak and commuter rail systems must be made accessible. One car per train must be made accessible within five years. Privately owned intercity bus companies have a longer period.
DOC.HEAD: TELECOMMUNICATIONS:
DOC.TEXT: All telephone companies must provide relay services for hearing-and speech-impaired customers with three years.
DOC.HEAD: FOOD HANDLERS:
DOC.TEXT: Employers could reassign employees with certain communicable or contagious diseases from food-handling duties. However, employers could only reassign workers with diseases the Department of Health and Human Services determines can be spread through contact with food. The provision was adopted after an unsuccessful attempt to make it possible for AIDS-infected workers to be reassigned. The government says AIDS is not spread through contact with food.

OPEC ministers agreed to halt overproduction in hopes of pushing up the price of crude oil. The 13 ministers of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries signed an accord Friday to notch up their target price immediately to $21 a barrel from $18. The cartel set a new production ceiling of 22.5 million barrels a day for the rest of the year. OPEC members now are producing about 23.1 million barrels of oil a day, over the ceiling of 22.1 million in effect in the first half of the year.

The OPEC agreement to reduce production had little effect on wholesale prices, but some experts said motorists could feel pinched at the pumps by early 1991 if the cartel sticks with the pact. Prices of energy futures settled slightly lower Friday after initially rising on news of the OPEC pact. Some traders blamed technical factors and profit-taking from a recent price runup for the fall.

The U.S. economy sputtered at an anemic annual growth rate of 1.2 percent from April through June with virtually every economic sector exhibiting weakness, the government said. The Commerce Department report Friday on the gross national product _ the country's total output of goods and services _ renewed recession fears among private economists. GNP growth in the first three months was revised down to a 1.7 percent rate, compared to 1.9 percent previously, while growth from October through December was cut to a barely perceptible 0.3 percent, far below the 1.1 percent previous estimate.

USX Corp. will pay about $34 million in penalties and cleanup costs for dumping wastewater from its Gary, Ind., steel mill. The out-of-court settlement Friday resolves a 1988 lawsuit filed by the federal government alleging that the Gary mill exceeded wastewater discharge limits in the river. The lawsuit also alleged that the company violated the federal Clean Water Act in other ways between 1983 and 1988. The company will pay $1.6 million in civil penalties and an estimated $25 million to improve equipment and develop a comprehensive wastewater management plan.

A taxpayer bailout of a troubled student loan guarantor would not cost more than $100 million, a senior Education Department official said. Ted Sanders, under secretary of education, said Friday the department hoped to resolve the problems of the Higher Education Assistance Foundation, or HEAF, without taxpayer money. HEAF, a private, non-profit agency based in Overland Park, Kan., is the guarantor of $8.8 billion in student loans, or more than 17 percent of the $51 billion student loans outstanding nationally.

Microsoft Corp., riding a hit with its Windows 3.0 software, plans to increase its work force by about 40 percent in the next year and make a major push into office networking software, its executives say. But corporate officials also told financial analysts gathered at Microsoft's headquarters Thursday that heavy spending in the coming year will make it difficult to maintain the hectic pace of growth the company has enjoyed.

The Pentagon's chief procurement official said he is not planning to prohibit the Northrop Corp. from building weapons for the military despite the Justice Department's belief that the company should be barred. John Betti, undersecretary of defense for acquisitions, made the comments Friday during a break in a hearing by a House Energy and Commerce panel on charges of fraud and mismanagement at Northrop. Justice Department officials described how Northrop falsified reports on the air-launched cruise missile and conducted improper tests on the Harrier AV-8B jet. Northrop pleaded guilty in February to 34 charges of fraud and was fined $17 million.

Bad news continued to mount for the nation's two largest defense contractors as two large commercial bond rating firms downgraded the companies' bond ratings. The ratings drop Friday was the second this year for McDonnell Douglas Corp. and General Dynamics Corp., both headquartered in St. Louis.

The Senate Appropriations Committee approved a $29 billion transportation spending bill that would ban radar detectors for trucks and require state courts to suspend the driver's licenses of drug offenders. The bill, approved Friday, also includes $125 million to speed passenger rail service between New York and Boston by electrifying rail lines between Boston and New Haven, Conn.

Stock prices slumped Friday as the market absorbed new evidence of sluggish business conditions. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 22.28 to 2,898.51, extending its loss for the week to 62.63 points. The dollar fell sharply. Bond prices climbed. Soybean futures prices fell sharply; energy futures were mixed; copper futures rose; precious metals fell; and livestock and meat futures were mixed.

DOC.HEAD: Italian Companies Plan Merger
DOC.TEXT: Montedison SpA and Ferruzzi Agricola Finanziaria SpA announced plans on Friday to merge into a holding company that would combine all the chemical and agro-industrial interests of Italy's Ferruzzi group. The new company, to be named Montedison SPA, will have annual aggregate sales of 35 trillion lire, or about $30 billion. State television said the operation would put the Italian group on footing with such European giants as Bayer. Raul Gardini, chairman of Ferruzzi Finanziaria SpA, the key financial holding of the Ferruzzi group, told a news conference that the merger aimed to create a ``global company designed to face the challenges of the 1990s'' and capable of ``pursuing an ever-growing integration'' between the chemicals and agro-industrial businesses. Currently, Ferruzzi Finanziaria owns 66.8 percent of Ferruzzi Agricola, which in turn holds 48.7 percent of Montedison. A large part of Montedison's chemical interests are concentrated in Enimont SpA, a 40 percent-owned joint venture with state-owned energy company Ente Nazionale Idrocarburi (ENI). Ferruzzi Agricola also owns 53 percent of Eridania SpA, which combines the group's agro-industrial interests. Shareholders of both Montedison and Ferruzzi Agricola will be asked to approve the merger plan at assemblies in early November.

DOC.HEAD: Monieson Sells Futures Business To British Firm
DOC.TEXT: A former Chicago Mercantile Exchange chairman facing possible expulsion from the futures industry said Friday the British brokerage firm E.D. & F. Man International Futures Inc. was acquiring his commodities-trading business. Brian Monieson would not disclose the financial terms of the deal, under which Man will acquire on Monday all assets, customers and accounts of Monieson's firm, GNP Commodities Inc. Monieson said he will become a trader with Man. Monieson, GNP's chairman, is appealing to the Commodities Futures Trading Commission an administrative law judge's May 25 finding that he failed to adequately supervise two employees who defrauded customers. Monieson also is appealing to the federal regulatory agency the law judge's order barring him from futures trading and requiring him to pay a $500,000 fine. The CFTC administrative law judge also found Chicago-based GNP Commodities guilty of failing to adequately supervise the two employees and ordered the firm to close all customer accounts and pay a $500,000 fine. That finding also is being appealed. Monieson said in a telephone interview that he was selling the business ``basically to eliminate some of the uncertainty for our institutional customers because of the CFTC proceedings.'' Monieson, of Northbrook, Ill., was chairman of the Merc, the world's second-largest futures exchange, from 1983 to 1985. The fraudulent trading by the GNP employees occurred from September 1984 through May 1986.

DOC.HEAD: Amoco to Expand Ethylene Production Plant
DOC.TEXT: A year after shelving plans to build a new ethylene plant at its Chocolate Bayou facility, Amoco Corp. announced it will spend $200 million to expand its existing ethylene production plant. The expansion, scheduled to be completed by nearly 1994, would boost the company's ethylene production by 600 million pounds per year. The Alvin, Texas, plant, which employs 824, already is capable of producing 2.4 billion pounds of ethylene per year and 800 million pounds of propylene. Ethylene and propylene are used in making plastics, industrial chemicals and a variety of consumer products. At Amoco, much of the ethylene produced at Chocolate Bayou is used by the company's fabrics and fibers business, which makes carpet backing, fibers and yarns. A year ago, Amoco shelved plans to build a 1.5 billion-pound-a-year ethylene plant. At the time, both the company and outside observers were predicting a glut of the chemical by 1993 and an accompanying fall in prices. Still, Amoco officials say their projections show ethylene demand will remain healthy enough to support the new capacity.
